The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.

div.head: LETTER I.
div.p:
THE tenderne≈øs of a fond father's heart admoni≈øhes me, that I ≈øhould but poorly requi ‚Ä¢ e the affectionate ≈øolicitude you have ≈øo often expre≈ø≈øed, to become acquainted with the particulars of my journey over land to India, if I any longer with-held from you an account of that ≈øingular and eventful period of my life. I confe≈øs to you, my dear boy, that often when I have endeavoured to amu≈øe you with the leading incidents and extraordinary vici≈ø≈øitudes of fortune which chequered the whole of that ≈øeries of adventures, and ob≈øerved the eager attention with which, young though you were, you li≈øtened to the recital, the tender ≈øen≈øibility you di≈øclo≈øed at ≈øome pa≈ø≈øages, and the earne≈øt de≈øire you expre≈ø≈øed that "I ≈øhould the whole relate," I have felt an almo≈øt irre≈øi≈øtible impul≈øe to indulge you with an accurate and faithful narrative, and have more than once ≈øat down at my bureau for the purpo≈øe: but ≈øober and deliberate reflection ≈øugge≈øted that it was too ≈øoon, and that, by complying with your de≈øire at ≈øuch a very early period of your life, I ≈øhould but render the great end I propo≈øed by it
abortive, fru≈øtrate the in≈øtruction which I meant to convey, and impre≈øs the mere incident on your memory, while the moral deducible from it mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily evaporate, and leave no trace, or rather excite no idea, in a mind not ≈øufficiently matured for the conception of ab≈øtract principles, or prepared by practice for the deduction of moral inferences.

I am aware that there are many people, who, contemplating only the number of your days, would con≈øider my undertaking this arduous ta≈øk, and offering it to your reflection, even now, premature: but this is a ≈øubject on which I have ≈øo long and ≈øo deliberately dwelt, which I have di≈øcu≈ø≈øed with ≈øo much care, and examined with ≈øuch impartiality, that I think I may be acquitted of vanity, though I ≈øay I am competent to form a judgment on it. The re≈øult of that judgment is, that I am determined to indulge you without further delay; and I tru≈øt that you will not, on your part, render it an empty indulgence, but, on the contrary, by turning every circum≈øtance to its be≈øt u≈øe, by converting every feeling which the≈øe pages may excite in your heart into matter of ≈øerious reflection, and by making every event (as it happens to de≈øerve) an example to promote either emulation on the one hand, or circum≈øpection and caution on the other, ju≈øtify me in that opinion of you on which I found this determination.

I remember, that when, at an early age, I entered upon that ≈øtage of cla≈ø≈øical education at which you are now, at an earlier age, arrived‚ÄîI mean the Aeneid‚ÄîI was not only captivated with the beautiful ≈øtory of the Hero, in the ≈øecond Book, but drew certain inferences from parts of it, which I ≈øhall never forget, and which afterwards ≈øerved to give a direction to the growth of my ≈øentiments on occa≈øions of a ≈øimilar nature: above all, the filial piety of Aeneas made a deep impre≈ø≈øion on my mind, and,
by imperceptibly exciting emulation in my bo≈øom, augmented con≈øiderably the natural warmth of my affection and re≈øpect for my father. It is under the recollection of this ≈øen≈øation, and a firm per≈øua≈øion that your heart is fully as ≈øu≈øceptible of every tender impre≈ø≈øion, and your under≈øtanding as fit for the reception of u≈øeful hi≈øtory, as mine was then, that I overlook your extreme youth, and write to you as though you were an adult. If there be a thing on earth of which I can boa≈øt a perfect knowledge, it is my FREDERICK'S heart: it has been the object of my uninterrupted ≈øtudy almo≈øt ≈øince it was fir≈øt capable of manife≈øting a ≈øen≈øation; and, if I am not very much mi≈øtaken in it indeed, the lively intere≈øt he feels in the occurrences of his father's life, is the re≈øult, not of idle curio≈øity, but unbounded filial affection. Such an amiable motive ≈øhall not be di≈øappointed in its end; and while I di≈øcharge the duty of a parent in gratifying it, I ≈øhall be encouraged and ≈øu≈øtained under my labours by the ≈øanguine expectation, that he will derive from my exertions the mo≈øt ≈øolid advantages in his future progre≈øs through life. As tho≈øe advantages are expected al≈øo to extend to my dear boy JOHN, who≈øe tender years di≈øqualify him from making the ≈øame immediate reflections on the various ≈øubjects as they occur, my FREDERICK will perceive that it becomes his duty, not only as a good ≈øon, but as an affectionate brother, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt and enforce them upon his mind, to explain to him the difficulties, and furni≈øh him with his rea≈øonings and inferences on them, ≈øo as that they may make, as nearly as po≈ø≈øible, equal impre≈ø≈øions on the heart and under≈øtanding of both. "Felix quem faciunt aliena pericula cautum:" And though few have the felicity to be warned by other men's misfortunes or faults, becau≈øe they ≈øeldom make deep impre≈ø≈øions on their feelings, I am
convinced that my ≈øufferings and errors, as they will intere≈øt my FREDERICK'S heart, and gratify his curio≈øity, cannot fail to enlarge his under≈øtanding, and improve his conduct.

div.head: LETTER II.
div.p: HAVING, in compliance with your reiterated ≈øolicitations, determined to give you a narrative of my journey to the Ea≈øt Indies, and the ≈øingular turns of fortune which befel me there, I think it nece≈ø≈øary, on reflection, to prepare you ≈øtill further for the reception of it, by propo≈øing certain terms to be fulfilled on your part; and as, in my la≈øt, I told you that I expected you, and, with your a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, your brother, to turn my r ‚Ä¢ tion to a more u≈øeful account than the gratification of mere idle curio≈øity, by letting the moral deducible from my errors and misfortunes ≈øtrike deep and take root in your mind‚Äî≈øo there are other things, which, though not ≈øo extremely important, are too weighty to be neglected; to which I de≈øire to direct your attention.

In order, therefore, on my part, to give every thing I do a tendency to the great object of my wi≈øhes, and induce you, on your's, to contribute your ≈øhare to it, I ≈øhall give you, as I proceed in my narrative, a topographical de≈øcription of the various Countries through which I ≈øhall have occa≈øion to conduct you, and, as conci≈øely as may be, an account of their manners, policy, and municipal in≈øtitutions, ≈øo far as I have been able to collect them; which I hope will ≈øerve to awaken in you a thir≈øt for tho≈øe indi≈øpen≈øible parts of polite education, Geography and Hi≈øtory. I expect that you will carefully attend to tho≈øe ≈øciences, and that you will not ≈øuffer your≈øelf, as you read my Letters, to be carried ‚Ä¢ ay by the rapid ≈øtream of idle curio≈øity from incident to incident, without time or di≈øpo≈øition for reflection: you mu≈øt take excur≈øions, as you go along, from my Letters to your Geographical Grammar and your Maps‚Äîand, when nece≈ø≈øary, call in the aid of your Tutor, in order to compare my ob≈øervations with tho≈øe of others on the ≈øame places, and by tho≈øe means to acquire as determinate an idea as po≈ø≈øible of their local ≈øituation, laws, and comparative advantages, whether of Nature or Art. Here I mu≈øt ob≈øerve to you, that as geography is a ≈øcience to which rational conver≈øation, as ≈øupported

The ingenious GEORGE ALEXANDER STEEVENS has, in his celebrated Lecture upon Heads, given a mo≈øt ludicrous in≈øtance of this ≈øpecies of ignorance, in the character of a citizen, who, cen≈øuring the incapacity of mini≈øters, propo≈øes to carry on the war on a new plan of his own. But a ≈øtory which I heard from a per≈øon of ≈øtrict veracity, will ≈øerve more ≈øtrongly to ≈øhew you the ≈øhame attendant on ignorance of tho≈øe things which, from „Äà‚óä„Äâ rank, we are ≈øuppo≈øed to know; and as the fear of ≈øhame never fails to operate powerfully on a generous mind, I am ≈øure it will ≈øerve to alarm you into indu≈øtry, and application to your ≈øtudies.

During the late American war, about that period when the KING of FRANCE was, ≈øo fatally for him≈øelf, though perhaps in the end it may prove fortunate for the intere≈øts of mankind, manife≈øting an intention to interfere and join the Americans, a worthy alderman in Dublin, reading the new≈øpaper, ob≈øerved a paragraph, intimating, that in con≈øequence of Briti≈øh crui≈øers having ≈øtopped ≈øome French ve≈ø≈øels at ≈øea, and ≈øearched them, France had taken umbrage! The ≈øagacious alderman, more
patriotic than learned, took the alarm, and proceeded, wi ‚Ä¢ h the paper in his hand, directly to a brother of the board, and, with unfeigned ≈øorrow, deplored the lo≈øs his country had ≈øu≈øtained, in having a place of ≈øuch con≈øequence as UMBRAGE ravi≈øhed from it!‚Äîde≈øiring, of all things, to be informed in what part of the wo ‚Ä¢ d Umbrage lay. With this the wi≈øe mag ‚Ä¢ ≈øtrates returned home, partly ≈øatisfied: but what words can expre≈øs their chagrin when they found their error‚Äîthat the unlucky book≈øeller had ≈øpread the ≈øtory over the city‚Äîthat the new≈øpapers were filled with ≈øatirical ≈øquibs upon it‚Äînay, that a caracature print of them≈øelves leading the city-watch to the retaking of Umbrage, was ≈øtuck up in every ≈øhop‚Äîand finally, that they could ≈øcarcely (albeit aldermen) walk the ≈øtreets, without

Thus, my child, will every one be more or le≈øs ridiculous who appears obviou≈øly ignorant of tho≈øe things which, from the rank he holds in life, he ≈øhould be expected to know, or to the knowledge of which vanity or petulence may tempt him to pretend.

I am ≈øure I need not ≈øay more to you on this ≈øubject; for I think you love me too well to di≈øappoint me in the fir≈øt wi≈øh of my heart, and I believe you have too much manly pride to ≈øuffer ≈øo degrading a defect as indolence to expo≈øe you hereafter to animadver≈øion or contempt. Quid munus reipublicae majus aut melius a ‚Ä¢ ferre po≈ø≈øumus quam ≈øi juventutem bene erudiamus.‚Äî Thus ≈øaith the matchle≈øs TULLY. If, then, the education of youth intere≈øts ≈øo very deeply a ≈øtate, can it le≈øs powerfully intere≈øt him who ≈øtands in the twofold connection of a citizen and parent? div.head: LETTER III.
div.p: A VARIETY of unpropicious circum≈øtances gave ri≈øe to my journey to the Ea≈øt Indies, while dome≈øtic calamity marked my departure, and, at the very out≈øet, gave me a foreta≈øte of tho≈øe mi≈øeries which fate had re≈øerved to let fall upon me in the ≈øequel. The channels from which I drew the means of ≈øupporting my family in that ≈øtyle which their rank and connections obliged them to maintain, were clogged by a coincidence of events as unlucky as unexpected: the war in India had interrupted the regular remittance of my property from thence: a ≈øevere ≈øhock which unbounded genero≈øity and beneficence had given to the affairs of my father, rendered him incapable of maintaining his u≈øual punctuality in the payment of the income he had a≈ø≈øigned me; and, to crown the whole, I had been deprived, by death, of two lovely children (your brother and ≈øi≈øter), whom I loved not le≈øs than I have ≈øince loved you and your brother.

It was under the pre≈ø≈øure of tho≈øe accumulated affl ‚Ä¢ ctions, aggravated by the goading thought of leaving my family for ≈øuch a length of time as mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily elap≈øe before I could again ≈øee them, that I ≈øet out for India in the month of May, in the year 1781, with a heart overwhelmed with woe, and too ≈øurely predictive of misfortunes.

From the gloomy cave of depre≈ø≈øion in which my mind was ≈øunk, I looked forward, to ≈øeek, in the future, a gleam of comfort‚Äîbut in vain: not a ray
appeared‚ÄîMelancholy had thrown her ≈øombre ≈øhadow on the whole. Even pre≈øent affl ‚Ä¢ ction yielded up a ≈øhare of my heart to an unaccountable di≈ømal pre≈øentiment of future ill; and the di≈øa≈øters and di≈øappointments I had pa≈ø≈øed, were lo≈øt and forgotten in ominous forebodings and in≈øtinctive pre≈øages of tho≈øe that were to come.

Of all the weakne≈ø≈øes to which the human mind is ≈øubject, ≈øuper≈øtition is that again≈øt which I would have you guard with the utmo≈øt vigilance. It is the mo≈øt incurable canker of the mind. Under its unrelenting dominion, happine≈øs withers, the under≈øtanding becomes ob≈øcured, and every principle of joy is bla≈øted. For this rea≈øon I wi≈øh to account for tho≈øe pre≈øages, by referring them to their true phy≈øical cau≈øes, in order thereby to prevent your young mind from receiving, from what I have written, any injurious impre≈ø≈øion, or ≈øuper≈øtitious idea of pre≈øentiment, as it is fa≈øhionably denominated.

If the mind of man be examined, it will be found naturally prone to the contemplation of the future‚Äî its flights from hope to hope, or fear to fear, leading it in≈øen≈øibly from objects pre≈øent and in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, to tho≈øe remote and in expectation‚Äîfrom po≈øitive good to ≈øuppo≈øitious better, or from actual melancholy to imaginary misfortune. In the≈øe ca≈øes, the mind never fails to ≈øee the pro≈øpect in colours derived from the medium through which it is viewed and exaggerated by the magnifying power of fancy. Thus my mind, labouring under all the unea≈øine≈øs I have de≈øcribed, ≈øaw every thing through the gloomy medium of melancholy, and, looking forward, foreboded nothing but misfortune: accident afterwards fulfilled tho≈øe forebodings; but accident, nay, the mo≈øt trifling change of circum≈øtances, might po≈ø≈øibly have ≈øo totally changed the face of my ≈øub≈øequent progre≈øs, that good fortune, in≈øtead of mi≈øadventure, might have been my lot,
and ≈øo all my forebodings been as illu≈øory and fallible as all ≈øuch phantoms of the imagination really are. Thus I argue now‚Äîand I am ≈øure I argue truly; but if rea≈øon be not timely called in, and made, as it were, an habitual inmate, it avails but little again≈øt the overbearing force of ≈øuper≈øtition, who, when ≈øhe once gets po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the mind, holds her ≈øeat with unrelenting tenacity, and, calling in a whole ho≈øt of horrors, with de≈øpair at their head, to her aid, entrenches her≈øelf behind their formidable powers, and bids defiance to the a≈ø≈øaults of rea≈øon.

Thus it fared with me‚ÄîUnder the dominion of a gloomy pre≈øentiment, I left London; and my journey down to Margate, where I was to take ≈øhipping, was, as SHAKSPEARE emphatically ≈øays, a phanta≈øm, or a hideous dream‚Äîand my little ≈øtate of man ≈øuffered, as it were, the nature of an in≈øurrection:‚Äîthe chaos within me forbade even the approach of di≈øcriminate reflection; and I found my≈øelf on board the packet, bound to O≈øtend, without having a ≈øingle trace left upon my mind, of the intermediate ≈øtages and incidents that happened ≈øince I had left London.

It has been ob≈øerved‚Äîand I wi≈øh you always to carry it in memory, as one of the be≈øt con≈øolations under affl ‚Ä¢ ction‚Äîthat human ≈øufferings, like all other things, find their vital principle exhau≈øted, and then extiction accelerated, by overgrowth; and that, at the moment when man thinks him≈øelf mo≈øt mi≈øerable, a benignant Providence is preparing relief, in ≈øome form or other, for him. So if, in ≈øome ≈øort, happened with me; for I was fortunate enough to find in the packet a fellow-pa≈ø≈øenger, who≈øe valuable conver≈øation and agreeable manners beguiled me in≈øen≈øibly of the gloomy contemplation in which I was ab≈øorbed, and afforded my tortured mind a temporary ≈øu≈øpen≈øion of pain. This gentleman
was General LOCKHART: he was going to Bru≈ø≈øels, to pay his court to the Emperor JOSEPH the Second, who was then ≈øhortly expected in the Low Countries, in order to go through the ceremonies of his inauguration. As Bru≈ø≈øels lay in my way, I was flattered with the hopes of having for a companion a gentleman at once ≈øo plea≈øing in his manners and re≈øpect ‚Ä¢ ble in his character, and was much comforted when I found him as much di≈øpo≈øed as my≈øelf to an agreement to travel the whole of the way thither together. Thus, though far, very far from a ≈øtate of ea≈øe, I was, when landing at O≈øtend, at lea≈øt le≈øs mi≈øerable than at my coming on board the packet.

As this letter is already ≈øpun to a length too great to admit of any material part of the de≈øcription I am now to give you of O≈øtend, and the country to which it belongs, I think it better to po≈øtpone it to my next, which I mean to devote entirely to that ≈øubject, and thereby avoid the confu≈øion that ari≈øes from mixing two ≈øubjects in the ≈øame letter, or breaking off the thread of one in order to make way for the other.

div.head: LETTER IV.
div.p:
THAT country to which I am now to call your attention‚ÄîI mean, the Netherlands‚Äîis marked by a greater number of political changes, and hara≈ø≈øed by a more continued train of military
operations, than perhaps any country in the records of modern hi≈øtory. It may truly be called the Cockpit Royal of Europe, on which tyrants, as ambition, avarice, pride, caprice, or malignity, prompted them, pitted thou≈øands, and hundreds of thou≈øands, of their fellow-creatures, to cut each other's throats about ≈øome point, frivolous as regarding them≈øelves, unimportant to mankind, and only tending to gratify a diabolical lu≈øt for dominion; Yet, under all the≈øe di≈øadvantages, (≈øuch are the natural qualities of this country), it has, till lately, been in a tolerably flouri≈øhing ≈øtate; and would, under a good government and proper protection, equal any part of Europe for richne≈øs.

Flanders, Brabant, and the country now called the United Netherlands, were in general known by the name of Netherlands, Low Countries, or Pais-bas, from their ≈øituat ‚Ä¢ on, as it is ≈øuppo≈øed, in re≈øpect of Germany. Anciently, they formed a part of Belgic Gaul, of which you may remember to have read an account in the Commentaries of JULIUS CAESAR, who de≈øcribes the inhabitants as the mo≈øt valiant of all the G ‚Ä¢ llic Nations‚ÄîHorum omnium Belgae funt forti≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ mi. They afterwards were ≈øubject to petty princes, and made part of the German Empire; and, in the ≈øixteenth century, became ≈øubject to CHARLES the Fifth of the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria: but, being oppre≈ø≈øed beyond endurance by his ≈øon, PHILIP the Second of Spain, (that blind and furious bigot), they openly revolted ‚Äî≈ølew to arms to a≈ø≈øert their freedom; and, after a ≈øtruggle as glorious in effect as virtuous in principle‚Äîafter performing prodigies of valour, and exhibiting examples of fortitude, to which none but men fighting in the godlike cau≈øe of LIBERTY are competent‚Äîled on by the wi≈ødom and valour of the PRINCE of ORANGE, and a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the SOVEREIGN of GREAT BRITAIN‚Äîthey at length ≈øo
far ≈øucceeded, that tho≈øe now called the United Netherlands, entered into a ≈øolemn league, and forced the gloomy tyrant to acknowledge their independence. But that part to which I am now particularly to allude, continued annexed to the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria. In 1787, they revolted, and made a temporary ≈øtruggle to di≈øengage them≈øelves from the dominion of the EMPEROR; but, owing to ≈øome cabals among them≈øelves, and the temperate conduct of that prince, they again returned to their allegiance, and were rewarded with a general amne≈øty. In 1792, they were over-run by the French army under General DUMOURIER‚Äîopened their arms to tho≈øe republicans, and were rewarded for it by oppre≈ø≈øion, tyranny, and inju≈øtice. The French, however, were driven back out of the country; and, wonderful to relate, they again received their old ma≈øter, the EMPEROR, with ≈øtrong demon≈øtrations of joy, and manife≈øted their loyalty and attachment to him by every expre≈ø≈øion that abject hypocri≈øy could ≈øugge≈øt.
div.q: "O! how unlike their Belgic ≈øires of old!"
div.p: Here, could I ≈øtop with ≈øtrict ju≈øtice, I would‚Äî But, behold! the French again came; again they opened their gates to receive them; and again they were, with tenfold fury and rapacity, pillaged, oppre≈ø≈øed and in≈øulted; and at the very time I am writing this, the guillotine is doing its office‚Äîenforcing the payment of the mo≈øt exorbitant and enormous contributions, and compelling, it is ≈øaid, one hundred thou≈øand of the ill-fated inhabitants to take the field, as ≈øoldiers of the republic.

Human opinion is ≈øo chequered and uncertain, that two very hone≈øt men may in certain ca≈øes act in direct contradiction and ho≈øtility to each other, with the very be≈øt intentions‚ÄîHe, therefore, mu≈øt have but a cold heart, and a contracted under≈øtanding,
who cannot forgive the man that acts in ≈øuch ca≈øes erroneou≈øly, when he acts from the exact dictates of his opinion, and upon the principle which he has con≈øcientiou≈øly adopted: but when a whole people are ≈øeen whi≈øking about with every gu≈øt of fortune, and making a new principle for every new point of convenience, we mu≈øt di≈øpi≈øe them even when they happen to act right, and can ≈øcarcely afford them ≈øo much as pity in their calamities. The Au≈øttrian Netherlands are now in that ≈øtate; and, without pre≈øuming to ≈øay in which of their tergiver≈øations they were right, I will venture to pronounce that they de≈øerve puni≈øhment, and I believe they are in hands very likely to give them their due.

To return‚ÄîO≈øtend is a ≈øea-port of Au≈øtrian Flanders, and is ≈øituated in the Liberty of Bruges. It was, at one time, the ≈øtronge≈øt town in Flanders: but a double ditch and ramparts, which con≈øtituted its ≈øtrength, are now de≈øtroyed; and in the place where the former ≈øtood, docks, or rather ba≈øons, extremely capacious and commodious, are formed, for the reception of ≈øhipping. The ground about the town is very low and mar≈øhy, and cut into a number of fine canals‚Äîinto ≈øome of which, ≈øhips of the large≈øt ≈øize may enter‚Äîand in one of which, ve≈ø≈øels of great burthen may ride, even clo≈øe to Bruges. The harbour here is ≈øo fortunately circum≈øtanced, that it was once thought, by engineers, entirely ≈øecure from a blockade; and its pri≈øtine ≈øtrength can in no way be ≈øo well de≈øcribed, as by a relation of the defence it made in the four fir≈øt years of the ≈øeventeenth century‚Äîthough, near the clo≈øe of the ≈øixteenth, it was no better than an in≈øignificant fi≈øhing town. It held out again≈øt the Spaniards for three years, two months, and ≈øixteen days. Eighty thou≈øand men lo≈øt their lives before it, while fifty thou≈øand were killed or died within. It at la≈øt ≈øurrendered, but on good terms; and not
for want of men or provi≈øions, but for want of ground to ≈øtand on, which the enemy took from them, at an amazing lo≈øs, ≈øtep by ≈øtep, till they had not room left for men to defend it. Three hundred thou≈øand cannon-balls, of thirty pounds weight each, were fired again≈øt it; and the be≈øieged often filled up the breaches made in their ramparts with heaps of dead bodies.

Such, my dear boy, are the miracles that men, animated with the all-≈øubduing ≈øpirit of Liberty, can perform‚ÄîLiberty! that immediate jewel of the ≈øoul‚Äîthat fir≈øt moving principle of all the animal creation‚Äîwhich, with equal power, influences the bird to beat the cage with its wings, and the lion to tear the bars of his impri≈øonment‚Äîthe infant to ≈øpring from the tender confinement of its nur≈øe, and the lean and ≈øhrivelled pantaloon to crawl abroad, and fly the warmth and repo≈øe of his whole≈øome chamber‚ÄîLiberty! which, for centuries enthralled by artifice and fraud, or lulled into a ≈ølumber by the witching ≈øpirit of prie≈øtcraft, now ri≈øes l ‚Ä¢ ke a giant refre≈øhed with wine‚Äîin its great efforts for emancipation, de≈øtroys and overturns ≈øy≈øtems‚Äîbut, when finding no re≈øi≈øtance, and matured by time, will, I ≈øincerely hope, ≈øink appea≈øed into a generous calm, and become the ble≈ø≈øing, the guardian and protect ‚Ä¢ r of mankind!

It is your good fortune, my dear children, to be born at a time when Liberty ≈øeems to be well under≈øtood in your own country, and is univer≈øally the prevalent pa≈ø≈øion of men. It is almo≈øt needle≈øs, therefore, for me to exhort you to make it the groundwork of your political morality: but let me remind you to guard, above all, again≈øt the de≈øpoti≈øm of certain tyrants, to whom many of the greate≈øt advocates for liberty are ≈øtrangely apt to ≈øubmit ‚ÄîI mean, your pa≈ø≈øions. Of all other tyrants, they are the mo≈øt ≈øubtle, the mo≈øt bewitching, the
