Beneath the dominion of other de≈øpots, tranquility may alleviate the weight of your chains, and ≈øoften oppre≈ø≈øion; but when once you become the ≈ølave of your pa≈ø≈øions, your peace is for ever fled, and you live and die in unabating mi≈øery.

div.head: LETTER V.
div.p:
THE pride of the Engli≈øh is remarked all over the globe, even to a proverb! But pride is a word of ≈øuch dubious meaning, ≈øo undefined in its ≈øen≈øe, and ≈øtrained to ≈øuch various imports, that you ≈øhall hear it violently execrated by one, and warmly applauded by another‚Äîthis denouncing it as a ≈øin of the fir≈øt magnitude, and that maintaining it to be the mo≈øt vigilant guardian of human virtue. Tho≈øe differences in opinion ari≈øe not from any defect in the intellects of either, but from each viewing the ≈øubject in that one point in which it fir≈øt ≈øtrikes his eye, or be≈øt ≈øuits his ta≈øte, his feeling, or his prejudices. I have no doubt, however, but a full con≈øideration of the ≈øubject would ≈øhew, that pride, as it is called, is only good or bad as the object from which it ari≈øes is mean or magnificent, culpable or meritorious. That noble pride which ≈øtimulates to extraordinary acts of genero≈øity and magnanimity, ≈øuch as, in many in≈øtances, has di≈øtingui≈øhed, above all others, the nobility of Spain, exacts the homage and admiration of mankind: But I fear very much that our Engli≈øh pride is of another growth, and ≈ømells too rankly of that over-≈øtrained commercial ≈øpirit which makes the ba≈øis of the pre≈øent grandeur of Great Britain, but which, in my humble judgment, rai≈øes only to deba≈øe her
‚Äîby ≈ølow, ≈øubtle degrees, poi≈øons the national principle, en≈ølaves the once bold ≈øpirit of the people, detracts from their real ≈øolid felicity, and, by confounding the idea of national wealth with that of national pro≈øperity, leads it in rapid ≈øtrides to its downfall. In ≈øhort, we are approaching, I fear, with daily accelerated ≈øteps, to the di≈øpo≈øition and ≈øordid habits of the Dutch, of whom Doctor GOLDSMITH ≈øo very pertinently and truly ≈øpeaks, when he ≈øays, "Ev'n Liberty it≈øelf is barter'd here!"

Without leading your mind through a maze of di≈øqui≈øition on this ≈øubject, which might fatigue with ab≈øtru≈øene≈øs and prolixity, I will bring you back to the point from which the matter ≈øtarted, and content my≈øelf with remarking, that the pride of the Engli≈øh, ≈øpeaking of it as a part of the national character, is the meane≈øt of all pride. The inflation of bloated, overgrown wealth, an over-weening affection for money, an idolatrous wor≈øhip of gain, have ab≈øolutely confounded the general intellect, and warped the judgment of the many to that exce≈øs, that, in e≈øtimating men or things, they always refer to "what is he worth?" or, "what will it fetch?" This ≈øordid habit of thinking was finely hit off by a keen fellow, the native of a neighbouring kingdom, who, for many years, carried on bu≈øine≈øs in London, and failed:‚ÄîSitting one day in a coffee-hou≈øe in the city, where ≈øome wealthy citizens were di≈øcu≈ø≈øing a ≈øubject not entirely unconnected with ca≈øh concerns, one of them ob≈øerving him rather attentive to their conver≈øation, turned to him, and ≈øaid, "What is your opinion, Sir, of the matter?"‚Äî"'s blood, Sir!" returned he, peevi≈øhly, "what opinion can a man have in this country, who has not a guinea in his pocket?"

Under the influence of all the various caprices in≈øpired by this unhappy pur≈øe-pride, I am ≈øorry to ≈øay our countrymen do, when they go abroad, ≈øo play the fool, that they are univer≈øally flattered and de≈øpi≈øed, pillaged and laughed at, by all per≈øons with whom they have any dealing. In France, Mi Lor Anglois is, or at lea≈øt was, to have ≈øix times as great a profu≈øion of every thing as any other per≈øon, and pay three hundred per cent. more for it; and the wor≈øt of it was, that a Mi Lor was found ≈øo conducive to their intere≈øt, that they would not, if they could help it, ≈øuffer any Engli≈øhman to go without a title‚Äînay, would ≈øometimes, with kindly compul≈øion, force him to accept of it, whether he would or not: but if an Engli≈øhman be, above all others, the object of impo≈øition in foreign countries, certainly none pillage him ≈øo unmercifully as his own countrymen who are ≈øettled there. In all the places through which I have travelled, I have had occa≈øion to remark (and the remark has been amply verified by every gentleman I have ever conver≈øed with on the ≈øubject), and the mo≈øt extravagant hou≈øes of entertainment are tho≈øe kept by Engli≈øhmen. At O≈øtend, as well as other places, it was ≈øo; therefore, as economy, when it does not tre≈øpa≈øs upon the bounds of genteel liberality, is the be≈øt ≈øecurity for happine≈øs and re≈øpect, I advi≈øe you, whenever you ≈øhall have occa≈øion to vi≈øit the Continent, in the fir≈øt place to avoid all appearance of the pur≈øe-proud o≈øtentation of John Bull; and, in the next place, to avoid all Engli≈øh hou≈øes of entertainment.

It is a ≈øingular circum≈øtance, and belongs, I ≈øhould ≈øuppo≈øe, peculiarly to O≈øtend, that the charity-children of the town are permitted to come on board the ve≈ø≈øels arrived, to beg of the pa≈ø≈øengers, one day in the week.

Before I bid adieu to O≈øtend, I mu≈øt remark one heavy di≈øadvantage under which it labours‚Äîthe want of fre≈øh water; all they u≈øe being brought from Bruges. In going from O≈øtend to Bruges, a traveller has it in his choice to go by land, or water ‚ÄîIf by land, he gets a good voiture for about ten ≈øhillings of our money; the road is about fourteen or fifteen miles‚ÄîIf by water (the mode which I adopted, as by far the cheape≈øt and plea≈øante≈øt), he travels in a ve≈ø≈øel pretty much re≈øembling our Lord Mayor's barge, ≈øometimes called a track ‚Ä¢ chuyt, but often la barque, or barke: it is, in truth, fitted up in a ≈øtyle of great neatne≈øs, if not elegance; ≈øtored with a large ≈øtock of provi≈øions and refre≈øhments of all kinds, and of ≈øuperior quality, for the accommodation of the pa≈ø≈øengers; and has, particularly, a very hand≈øome private room between decks, for the company to retire to, in order to drink tea, coffee, &c. &c. or play at cards. In this comfortable, I might ≈øay, delightful vehicle, as perfectly at ea≈øe as lying on a couch in the be≈øt room in London, are pa≈ø≈øengers drawn by two hor≈øes, at the rate of about four miles an hour, for about ten pence, the ≈øame length of way that it would co≈øt ten ≈øhillings to be jumbled in a voiture over a rough paved road.

The country between O≈øtend and Bruges is very level, and of cour≈øe de≈øtitute of tho≈øe charms to a mind of ta≈øte, which abound in countries to≈ø≈øed by the hand of Nature into hill, dale, mountain, and valley: the whole face of it, however, is, or at lea≈øt then was, in ≈øo high a ≈øtate of cultivation, and ≈øo deeply enriched by the hands of art and indu≈øtry, aided by the natural fertility of the ≈øoil, that its appearance, though far from ≈øtriking or delightful, was by no means unplea≈øant; and on approaching the town of Bruges, we pa≈ø≈øed between two rows of trees, beautiful, ≈øhady, and of lofty ≈øize‚Äîforming,
with the ≈øurrounding objects, a ≈øcene, which, if not romantic, was at lea≈øt picture≈øque.

In pa≈ø≈øing through countries groaning beneath the de≈øpotic ≈øcourge of unlimited monarchy, where ≈øub≈øidies are rai≈øed, and taxes laid on ad libitum‚Äî where guilty di≈øtru≈øt and ≈øu≈øpicion, with the eyes of a lynx and the fangs of a harpy, ≈øtand ≈øentinels at every gate, to ≈øcrutinize the harmle≈øs pa≈ø≈øenger, awake him to the clanks of his fetters, and awe him into compliance, a free-born Briton feels a cold horror creep through his whole frame: his ≈øoul recoils at the gloomy ferocious and in≈øolently ≈øtrict examination, with which a centinel, at the entry of a town, ≈øtops, inve≈øtigates, demands a pa≈ø≈øport; and, in ≈øhort, puts him, pro tempore, in a ≈øtate of durance, with all its hideous formalities and appendages, its gates, its bars, its armed ruffians, its formal profe≈ø≈øions of laws, and its utter violation of rea≈øon and of ju≈øtice. Entering the town of Bruges, we were ≈øtopped by a centinel, who, with all the ≈øaucy, ≈øwaggering air of authority, of a ≈ølave in office, demanded to know, whether we had any contraband goods? whether we were in any miliry capacity? whence we came? and whither we were going? with a variety of other interrogatories, to my mind equally impertinent and dete≈øtable, but which ≈øeemed to make no greater impre≈ø≈øion on the good Flemings them≈øe ‚Ä¢ ves, than demanding the toll at a turnpike-gate would make on an Engli≈øh waggoner.

Talking over this ≈øubject, ≈øince that time, with a gentleman who is well acquainted with all tho≈øe places, he informed me, that in the war between the Emperor and the States General, ≈øome French officers, travelling through Flanders to join Count MAILLEBOIS, were ≈øtopped at the gate of Bruges, and, by order of the Emperor, ≈øent to his army, turned into the ranks, and obliged to do duty as
common ≈øoldiers.‚ÄîHere, my dear FREDERICK, was an act, not only de≈øpotic in it≈øelf, but aggravated by circum≈øtances of collateral profligacy, of ≈øuch enormous magnitude, as bids defiance to all power of amplification, and leave eloquence hopele≈øs of de≈øcribing it with greater force than it derives from a ≈øimple narration of the fact: on the one hand, the inroad upon the ju≈øt per≈øonal rights of the individual; on the other, the rights of a nation violated. Some men in England, judging from their own con≈øtitutional ≈øecurity, may di≈øbelieve the fact: but let them con≈øider, that the Marquis de la FAYETTE, an alien, taken upon neutral ground, is now, even now, held in illegal, unju≈øt thraldom and per≈øecution‚Äîlet them, I ≈øay, remember this, and let their incredulity cea≈øe.
Ble≈øs your ≈øtars, my dear boy, that you were born in a country where ≈øuch outrages as the≈øe can never be perpetrated by any, and will never be approved of but by a few.

div.head: LETTER VI.
div.p: IN my la≈øt, I carried you pa≈øt a ferocious, impertinent ≈øentinel, into the town of Bruges; and now, having got you there, I mu≈øt endeavour, from the loo≈øe materials I have been able to collect, to give you a ≈øhort de≈øcription of it.

I had heard much of Bruges, its grandeur, and its opulence; you will gue≈øs my ≈øurpri≈øe then, when, on entering it, I found nothing but an old-fa≈øhioned, ill-built, irregular town; the ≈øtreets, in general, narrow and dirty, and mo≈øt of the hou≈øes ≈øtrongly expre≈ø≈øive of poverty and ≈øqualid wretchedne≈øs:
yet this was anciently a mo≈øt flouri≈øhing cry. Did the difference be ‚Ä¢ ween the town at this time, and its ≈øtate as it is repre≈øented of old, con≈øi≈øt only in its external appearance, we might readily account for that, in the great improvements made by the moderns in the art of hou≈øe-building; but its pre≈øent inferiority goes deeper, and is the re ‚Ä¢ ult of departed commerce‚Äîcommerce, that fluctuating will-with-a-wi≈øp, that leads ≈øtates in hot pur≈øuit after it, to entrap them ultimately into mires and precipices, and which, when caught, ≈øtays till it extingui≈øhes the ≈øpirit of freedom in a nation, refines its people into feeble ≈ølaves, and there leaves them to poverty and contempt.

Perhaps there is no ≈øubject that affords an ampler field for a ≈øpeculative mind to expatiate upon, than the various, and, I may ≈øay, incongruous revolutions which have chequered the progre≈øs of human ≈øociety from the fir≈øt records of hi≈øtory down to the pre≈øent time. It is indeed a ≈øpeculation which not only tends to improve the under≈øtanding, by calling in experience to correct the illu≈øions of theory, but is highly in≈øtructive in a moral point of view, by pointing out the in≈øtability of the very be≈øt ≈øtrictures of human wi≈ødom, and teaching us how little reliance is to be placed upon human ca≈øualties, or earthly contingencies. Look to Greece, once the fountain-head of arts, eloquence, and learning, and the mother of freedom‚Äîher poets, her legi≈ølators, her ≈øoldiers, and her patriots, even to this day con≈øidered the brighte≈øt examples of earthly glory!‚Äî≈øee her now ≈øunk in ≈ølavery, ignorance, ≈øloth, and imbecility, below any petty nation of Europe. Look to Rome‚Äîin her turn, the queen of arms and arts, the land of liberty, the nur≈øe of heroes‚Äîthe ≈øtage on which inflexible patriots, accompli≈øhed philo ‚Ä¢ ophers, and a free people, acted for centuries a drama that elevated man almo≈øt above
his nature!‚Äî≈øee her now reduced to the la≈øt ≈øtage of contemptibility‚Äîeven below it, to ridicule and laughter‚Äî≈øwayed by the mo≈øt contemptible impo≈øture, and ≈øunk into the mo≈øt de≈øpicable en≈ølavement, both of per≈øon and opinion‚Äîthe offices of her glorious ≈øenate performed by a kind of heteroclite being, an hermaphroditical impo≈øture, who, deducing his right from the very dregs and offscourings of ≈øuper≈øtition and fanatici≈øm, and aided by a ≈øet of di≈øciples worthy of ≈øuch a ma≈øter, rules the people, not with the terrors of the Tarpeian rock, nor yet with that which to a Roman bo≈øom was more terrible, bani≈øhment‚Äîbut with the horrors of eternal damnation!‚Äî≈øee her valiant, vigorous ≈øoldiery converted into a band of feeble fidlers and mu≈øic-ma≈øters, and the clangor of her arms into ≈øhrill concerts of ≈øqueaking ca≈øtratoes; tho≈øe places where her CICERO poured forth eloquence divine, and pointed out the paths that led to true morality‚Äîwhere her BRUTUS and her CATO mar≈øhalled the forces of freedom, and rai≈øed the arm of ju≈øtice again≈øt tyrants, over-run by a knavi≈øh ho≈øt of ignorant, beggarly, bald-pa ‚Ä¢ d friars, vomiting, to a crowd of gaping bigots, torrents of fanatical bomba≈øt, of miracles never performed, of gods made of wood or copper, and of ≈øaints, that, like them≈øelves, lives by impo≈øture and deception! ‚Äî≈øee her triumphs and military trophies changed into proce≈ø≈øions of prie≈øt ≈øinging p≈øalms round wafe ‚Ä¢ and wooden crucif ‚Ä¢ xes; and the code of Philo≈øophy and religion, which operated ≈øo effectually upon the morals of her people that there was none among them ≈øound ≈øo de≈øperate or ≈øo ba≈øe as to break an oath, exchanged for the Roman Catholic branch of the Chri≈øtian Faith‚Äîfor di≈øpen≈øations for ince≈øt, indulgences for murder, fines for fornication, and an exclu≈øive patent for adultery in their prie≈øthood. Then look to England!‚Äî≈øee
her, who once ≈øtooped beneath the yoke of Rome, who≈øe chief, CARACTACUS, was carried there in chains to grace his conqueror's triumphs, while her≈øelf was made the meane≈øt of the Roman provinces, now holding the balance of the world, the unrivalled mi≈øtre≈øs of arms, arts, commerce‚Äîevery thing.

It was in this irre≈øi≈øtible mutation of things, that Bruges ≈øunk from the high ≈øtate of a mo≈øt flouri≈øhing city, where there are ≈øtill (unle≈øs the French have de≈øtroyed them) to be ≈øeen the remains of ≈øeventeen palaces, anciently the re≈øidences of con≈øuls of different nations, each of which had di≈øtinct hou≈øes, magnificently built and furni≈øhed, with warehou≈øes for their merchandi≈øes: and ≈øuch was the power and wealth of the citizens in tho≈øe days, that it is an indubitable fact, they kept their ≈øovereign, the Archduke MAXIMILIAN, pri≈øoner, affronted his ≈øervants, and abu≈øed his officers; nor would they relea≈øe him until he took an oath to pre≈øerve inviolate the laws of the ≈øtate. Even ≈øo late as the time I was there, Bruges had ≈øome trade ‚Äîindeed as good a foreign trade as mo≈øt cities in Flanders. The people ≈øeemed cheerful and happy, and the markets were tolerably ≈øupplied.

Several fine canals run in a variety of directions from Bruges: by one of them, boats can go, in the cour≈øe of a ≈øummer's day, to O≈øtend, Neuport, Furnes, and Du ‚Ä¢ ki≈øk; and ve≈ø≈øels of four hundred tuns can float in the ba ‚Ä¢ on of this town. Another canal leads to Ghent, another to Damme, and another to Sluys. The water of tho≈øe canals is ≈øtagnant, without the lea≈øt motion; yet they can, in half an hour, be all emptied, and fre≈øh water brought in, by means of their well-contrived ≈øluices. This water, however, is never u≈øed for drinking, or even for culinary purpo≈øes; a better ≈øort being conveyed through the town by pipes from the
two rivers Lys and Scheldt, as in London; for which, as there, every hou≈øe pays a certain tax.

Although the trade of this city has, like that of all the Low Countries, been gradually declining, and daily ≈øucked into the vortices of Briti≈øh and Dutch commerce, there were, till the French entered it, many rich merchants there, who met every day at noon in the great market-place, to communicate and tran≈øact bu≈øine≈øs, which was chiefly done in the Flemi≈øh language, hardly any one in it ≈øpeaking French; a circum≈øtance that by this time, is much altered‚Äîfor they have been already made, if not to ≈øpeak French, at lea≈øt to ≈øing Ca-ira, and dance to the tune of it too, to ≈øome purpo≈øe.

The once-famed grandeur of this city con≈øi≈øted chiefly, like that of all grand places in the dark periods of Popery, of the gloomy piles, the o≈øtentatious frippery, and unwieldy ma≈ø≈øes of wealth, accumulated by a long ≈øeries of monki≈øh impo≈øture ‚Äîof Gothic ≈øtructures, of enormous ≈øize and ≈øable a≈øpect, filled with dreary cells, calculated to ≈øtrike the ≈øouls of the ignorant and enthu≈øia≈øtic with holy horror, to in≈øpire awe of the places, and veneration for the per≈øons who dared to inhabit them, and, by enfeebling the rea≈øon with the mixed operations of horror, wonder, and reverence, to fit the credulous for the reception of every impo≈øition, however gro≈øs in conception, or bungled in execution. Tho≈øe are the things which con≈øtituted the greatne≈øs and ≈øplendor of the cities of ancient Chri≈øtendom; to tho≈øe has the ≈øturdie≈øt human vigour and intellect been forced to bend the knees: they were built to endure the outrages of time; and will ≈øtand, I am ≈øure, long, long after their power ≈øhall have been annihilated.

What a powerful engine has ≈øuper≈øtition been, in the cunning management of prie≈øts! How lamentable it is to think, that not only all who believed,
but all who had good ≈øen≈øe enough not to believe ≈øhould, for ≈øo many centuries, have been kept in pro≈øtrate ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to the will and dominion of an old man in Rome!‚ÄîMy blu≈øhes for the folly and ≈øupinene≈øs of mankind, however, are lo≈øt in a warm glow of tran≈øport at the pre≈øent irradiation of the human mind; and though I can ≈øcarcely think with patience of that glorious, godlike being, HENRY the Second of England, being obliged by the Pope to la≈øh him≈øelf naked at the tomb of that ≈øaucy, wicked prie≈øt, THOMAS A BECKET, I felicitate my≈øelf with the refl ‚Ä¢ ct ‚Ä¢ on, that the Pope is now the mo≈øt contemptible ≈øovereign in Europe, and that the Papal authority, which was once the terror and the ≈øcourge of the earth, is now not only not recogni≈øed, but ≈øeldom thought of, and, when thought of, only ≈øerves to excite laughter or di≈øgu≈øt.

div.head: LETTER VII.
div.p:
THE town of Bruges, although the ≈øtreets be, as I have already de≈øcribed them, ≈øo mean, narrow, dirty, and irregular in general, contains, neverthele≈øs, ≈øome few ≈øtreets that are tolerable, and a few ≈øquares al≈øo that are far from contemptible.‚ÄîI ≈øhould think it, neverthele≈øs, not worth another letter of de≈øcription, were it not that the churches, and church-curio≈øities, demand our attention; for you will ob≈øerve, that in all rich Popi≈øh countries, every church is a holy toy-≈øhop, or rather a mu≈øeum, where pictures, ≈øtatues, gold cups, ≈øilver candle≈øticks, diamond crucifixes, and gods, of various ≈øorts and dimen≈øions, are hoarded
up, in honour of the Supreme Being. This city having been for centuries the ≈øee of a bi≈øhop, who is ≈øuffragan to the archbi≈øhop of Mecklin, and at the ≈øame time hereditary chancellor of Flanders, it is not to be wondered at, if eccle≈øia≈øtical indu≈øtry ≈øhould have ama≈ø≈øed ≈øome of tho≈øe little trinkets which con≈øtitute the chief or only value of their church. The mitre of this place conveys to the head that wears it a dioce≈øe containing ≈øix cities, from the names of which you will be able to form ≈øome ≈ømall judgment of the opulence of one poor ≈øon of ab≈øtinence and mortification.‚ÄîTho≈øe cities are, in the fir≈øt place, Bruges it≈øelf, then O≈øtend, Sluys, Damme, Middleburgh in Flanders, and Oudenberch‚Äînot to mention one hundred and thirty-three boroughs and villages; and if you could compute the number of inferior clergy with which the ≈øtreets and highways are filled, you would be thunder≈øtruck. There, and in all tho≈øe Popi≈øh countries, they may be ≈øeen, with grote≈øque habits and bald pates, buzzing up and down like bees, in ≈øwarms, (a precious hive!)‚Äîand, with the mo≈øt vehement prote≈øtations of voluntary poverty in their mouths, and eyes uplifted to Heaven, ≈øcrambling for the good things of the earth with the eagerne≈øs of a pack of hounds, and the rapacity of a whole roll of lawyers! With loaded thighs (I might ≈øay, loaded arms too, for they have large pockets even in their ≈øleeves, for the concealment of moveables), they return to the great hive, where, contrary to the law of bees, the drone lives in idle ≈øtate, and he plunders them: contrary, too, to the habits of tho≈øe u≈øeful in≈øects, they bani≈øh the queen bee, and ≈øuffer no female to approach their cells, but keep them in contiguous hives, where, under cover of the night, they vi≈øit them, and fulfil in private that which they deny in public‚Äîthe great command of Providence.

The fir≈øt building in nominal rank, though by no means the fir≈øt in value, is the great cathedral, which has at lea≈øt bulk, antiquity, and gloomine≈øs enough to recommend it to the faithful. It is by no means unfurni≈øhed within, though not in ≈øo remarkable a manner as to induce me to fill a letter with it. In a word, it is an old Popi≈øh cathedral, and cannot be ≈øuppo≈øed wanting in wealth: at the time I write, it has been ≈øtanding no le≈øs a time than nine hundred and twenty-nine years, having been built in the year 865.

The next that occurs to me, as worthy of notice, is the church of Notre Dame, or that dedicated to our Lady the Virgin MARY. This is really a beautiful ≈øtructure of the kind‚Äîindeed magnificent. Its ≈øteeple is beyond conception ≈øtupendous, being ≈øo very high as to be ≈øeen at ≈øea off O≈øtend, although it is not elevated in the ≈ømalle≈øt degree by any ri≈øe in the ground; for, ≈øo very flat is the whole intermediate country, that I believe it would puzzle a ≈økilful leveller to find two feet elevation from high-water-mark at O≈øtend up to this city. The contents of this church are corre≈øpondent to its external appearance‚Äîbeing enriched and beautified with a va≈øt variety of ≈øacerdotal trinkets, and fine tombs and monuments. As to the former, the ve≈øtments of that ≈øame THOMAS A BECKET whom I mentioned in my la≈øt, make a part of the curio≈øities depo≈øited in this church: this furious and inflexible impo≈øtor was archbi≈øhop of Canterbury; and his ≈øtruggles to en≈ølave both the king and people of England, and make them tributary to the Pope, have canonized him, and obtained the very honourable depot I mention for his ve≈øtments. To do ju≈øtice, however, to the ≈øpirit and ≈øagacity of the holy fathers who have ≈øo long taken the pains to pre≈øerve them, it mu≈øt be commemorated, that they are, or at lea≈øt were ≈øet with diamonds, and
other precious ≈øtones! Probably, among the many prie≈øts who have, in ≈øo many centuries, had the cu≈øtody of tho≈øe divine relics, ≈øome one, more ≈øagacious than the re≈øt, might conceive, that, to lie in a church, and be ≈øeen by the all-believing eyes of the faithful, a little coloured gla≈øs was ju≈øt as good as any precious ≈øtone, and wi≈øely have converted the originals to ≈øome better purpo≈øe. If ≈øo, it will be ≈øome con≈øolation to Holy Mother Church to reflect, that ≈øhe has bilked the Sans-culottes, who certainly have got po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Saint THOMAS A BECKET'S ≈øacerdotal petticoats; and, if they have been ≈øound enough to ≈øtand the cutting, have, by this time, converted them into comfortable campaigning breeches. O mon≈øtrous! wicked! abominable!‚Äîthat the Royal MARY, ≈øi≈øter to the great Emperor CHARLES the Fifth, ≈øhould, ≈øo long ago as the Reformation, have bought at an immen≈øe price, and depo≈øited in the trea≈øury of the church of our Lady the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin MARY, the ve≈øtments of a ≈øaint, only to make breeches, in the year 1794, for a French ≈øoldier! The time has been, when the bare ≈øugge≈øtion of ≈øuch ≈øacrilege would have turned the brain of half the people of Chri≈øtendom: but tho≈øe things are now better managed.

Of the tombs in this church, I ≈øhall only mention two, as di≈øtingui≈øhed from the re≈øt by their co≈øtline≈øs, magnificence, and antiquity. They are made of copper, well gilt. One of them is the tomb of MARY, heire≈øs to the Ducal Hou≈øe of Burgundy; and the other, that of CHARLES (commonly called the Hardy), Duke of Burgundy, her father.

In Bruges there were four great abbeys, and an amazing number of convents and nunneries. The buildings, I pre≈øume, yet ≈øtand; but there is little doubt that their contents, of every kind, have been,
before this, put in requi≈øition, and each part of them, of cour≈øe, applied to its natural u≈øe.

The church once belonging to the Je≈øuits, is built in a noble ≈øtyle of architecture: and that of the Dominicans has not only its external merits, but its internal value; for, be≈øides the u≈øual ≈øuperabundance of rich chalices, &c. it po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes ≈øome very great curio≈øities‚Äî

As, fir≈øt, a very curious, highly wrought pulpit ‚Äîbeautiful in it≈øelf, but remarkable for the top being ≈øupported by wood, cut out, in the mo≈øt natural, deceptive manner, in the form of ropes, and which beguile the ≈øpectator the more into a belief of its reality, becau≈øe it an≈øwers the purpo≈øes of ropes.

Secondly, a picture‚Äîand ≈øo extraordinary a picture! Before I de≈øcribe it, I mu≈øt appri≈øe you that your faith mu≈øt be almo≈øt as great as that of a Spani≈øh Chri≈øtian to believe me‚Äîto believe that the human intellect ever ≈øunk ≈øo low as, in the fir≈øt in≈øtance, to conceive, and, in the next, to harbour and admire, ≈øuch a piece. But I mi≈øtake‚Äîit has i ‚Ä¢ s merit; it is a curio≈øity‚Äîthe demon of ≈øatire him≈øelf could not wi≈øh for a greater.

This picture, then, is the repre≈øentation of a marriage!‚Äîbut of whom? why, truly, of JESUS CHRIST with Saint CATHARINE of Sienna. Ob≈øerve the congruity‚ÄîSaint CATHARINE of Sienna lived many centuries after the tran≈ølation of JESUS CHRIST to Heaven, where he is to ≈øit, you know, till he comes to judge the quick and the dead!‚Äî But who marries them? In truth, Saint DOMINIC, the patron of this church! The Virgin MARY joins their hands‚Äîthat is not ami≈øs‚ÄîBut, to crown the whole, King DAVID him≈øelf, who died ≈øo long before CHRIST was born, plays the harp at the wedding!

My dear FREDERICK, I ≈øhall take it as no ≈ømall in≈øtance of your dutiful opinion of me to believe, that ≈øuch a picture exi≈øted, and made part of the holy paraphernalia of a temple con≈øecrated to the wor≈øhip of the D ‚Ä¢ vinity: but I a≈ø≈øure you it is a fact; and as I have never given you rea≈øon to ≈øu≈øpect my veracity. I expect you to believe me in this in≈øtance, improbable though it ≈øeems: for ≈øuch a farrago of ab≈øurdities, ≈øuch a jumble of incongruities, impo≈ø≈øibilities, bulls, and anachroni≈øms, never yet were compre≈ø≈øed, by the human imagination, into the ≈øame narrow compa≈øs.
I protract this letter beyond my u≈øual length, on purpo≈øe to conclude my account of Bruges, and get once more upon the road.

The mona≈øtery of the Carthu≈øians, another order of friars, is of amazing ≈øize, covering an extent of ground not much le≈øs than a mile in circumference. The Carmelites, another order, have a church here, in which there is rai≈øed a beautiful monument, to the memory of HENRY JERMYN, Lord Dover, a peer of England‚ÄîBut the mona≈øtery called the Dunes, a ≈øect of the order of Saint BERNARD, is by far the noble≈øt in the whole city; tho cloi≈øters and gardens are capacious and hand≈øome; the apartment of the abbot is magnificent and ≈øtately, and tho≈øe of the monks them≈øelves unu≈øually neat. Tho≈øe poor mortified penitents, ≈øecluded from the pomps, the vanities, and enjoyments of life, and their thoughts no doubt re≈øting alone on hereafter, keep, neverthele≈øs, a ≈øumptuous table, ≈øpread with every luxury of the ≈øea≈øon‚Äîhave their country-≈øeats, where they go a hunting, or to refre≈øh them≈øelves, and actually keep their own coaches.

Among the nunneries there are two Engli≈øh: one of Augu≈øtinian nuns, who are all ladies of qualify, and who entertain ≈øtrangers at the grate with ≈øweet-meats and wine; the other, called the Pelicans,
is of a very ≈øtrict order, and wear a coar≈øe dre≈øs.

To conclude‚ÄîIn the chapel of Saint BASIL is ≈øaid to be kept, in perfect pre≈øervation, the blood which JOSEPH of Arimathea wiped off with a ≈øponge from the dead body of CHRIST. Finis coronat opus.
I fancy you have, by this time, had as much of miracles as you can well dige≈øt: I therefore leave you to reflect upon them and improve.

div.head: LETTER VIII.
div.p:
AS I was going to the barque, at Bruges, to take my departure for Ghent, the next town in my route, I was ≈øurpri≈øed to ≈øee a number of officious, bu≈øy, poor fellows, crowding round my effects, and ≈øeizing them‚Äî≈øome my trunk, ≈øome my portmanteau. &c. I believe two or three to each: but my a≈øtoni≈øhment partly ≈øub≈øided when I was told that they were porters, who plied on the canal, and about the city, for ≈øub≈øi≈øtence, and only came to have the honour of carraying my baggage down to the ve≈ø≈øel. Noting their eagerne≈øs, I could not help ≈ømiling. I know there are tho≈øe, and I have heard of ≈øuch, who would blu≈øter at them: but my mirth at the bu≈øtling importance which the poor fellows affected, ≈øoon ≈øunk into ≈øerious concern; I ≈øaid within my≈øelf, "Alas, how hard mu≈øt be your lot indeed!" and my imagination was in an in≈øtant back again in London, where a porter often makes you pay for a job, not in money only, but in patience al≈øo, and where the ≈øurline≈øs of independence ≈øcowls upon his brow as he does your
work. Every one of my men demanded a remuneration for his labour: one man could have ea≈øily done the work of five‚Äîbut I re≈øolved not to ≈øend them away di≈øcontented: he is but a ≈øordid churl that would; and I paid them to their full ≈øatisfaction. Here, my dear FREDERICK, let me offer you (≈øince it occurs) my parental advice on this point‚Äîfrom the practice of which you will gain more ≈øolid felicity than you can po≈øsibly be aware of now: never weigh ≈øcrupulou≈øly the value of the work of the poor; rather exceed than fall ≈øhort of rewarding it: it is a very, very ≈ømall thing, that will put them in good humour with you and with them≈øelves, and relax the hard furrows of labour into the ≈øoft ≈ømile of gratitude‚Äîa ≈ømile which, to a heart of ≈øen≈øibility ≈øuch as yours, will, of it≈øelf, ten-thou≈øand-fold repay you, even though the frequent practice of it ≈øhould abridge you of a few of tho≈øe things called plea≈øures, or detract a little from the weight of your pur≈øe.

Being again ≈øeated in my barque, I ≈øet off for Ghent, a city lying at a di≈øtance of twenty-four miles from Bruges. I mu≈øt here remark to you, that the company one meets in tho≈øe ve≈ø≈øels is not always of the fir≈øt rank; it is generally of a mixed, motley kind: but to a man who carries along with him, through his travels, a love for his fellow-creatures, and a de≈øire to ≈øee men, and their cu≈øtoms and manners, it is both plea≈øant and eligible‚Äîat lea≈øt I thought it ≈øo, and enjoyed it. There were tho≈øe among≈øt us who ≈øpoke rather loftily on that ≈øubject: I ≈øaid nothing; but it brought to my mind a reflection I have often had occa≈øion to concur in, viz. that a fa≈øtidious u≈øurpation of dignity (happily denominated ≈øtateline≈øs) is the never-failing mark of an up≈øtart or a blockhead. The man of true dignity, ≈øelf-erect and ≈øtrong, needs not have recour≈øe, for ≈øupport, to the comparative wretchedne≈øs of his
fellow-creature, or plume him≈øelf upon ≈øpurious ≈øuperiority. You will under≈øtand me, however! When I ≈øay, "the man of true dignity," I am far, very far, from meaning a lord, a ≈øquire, a banker, or a general officer‚ÄîI mean a man of intrin≈øic worth‚Äîhomo emunctae naris‚Äîone who, in every ≈øtation into which chance may throw him, feels firm in the con≈øciou≈øne≈øs of right‚Äîwho can ≈øee and cheri≈øh merit, though enveloped and concealed behind a ≈øhabby ≈øuit of clothes‚Äîand who ≈øcorns the b ‚Ä¢ own-up fool of fortune, that without ≈øen≈øe or ≈øentiment, without virtue, wi≈ødom, or courage, pre≈øumes to call him≈øelf great, merely becau≈øe he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes a few acres of earth which he had neither the indu≈øtry nor merit to earn, or becau≈øe his great-great-great-grandfather purcha≈øed a title by perfidy to his country, the plunder of his fellow-citizens, or the ≈ølaughter of mankind.

Although the face of that part of the country through which we are now pa≈ø≈øing, like that of the preceding ≈øtage from O≈øtend to Bruges, wants diver≈øity, it has its charms, and would be particularly delightful in the eye of an Engli≈øh farmer; for it is covered with the thicke≈øt verdure on each ≈øide of the canal, and the banks are decorated all along by rows of ≈øtately trees, while the fields in the back ground are cultivated to the highe≈øt degree of perfection, and bear the a≈øpect of producing the mo≈øt abundant harve≈øt.

You will be able to form a judgment of the trifling expence of travelling in this country, from my expences in this ≈øtage of twenty-four miles. I had an excellent dinner for about fifteen pence of our money; my pa≈ø≈øage co≈øt me but ≈øixteen more, amounting in all to two ≈øhillings and ≈øeven pence: compare that with travelling in England, where one cannot ri≈øe up from an indifferent dinner, in
an inn, under five ≈øhillings at the lea≈øt, and you mu≈øt be a≈øtoni≈øhed at the di≈øproportion.

Ghent is the capital of Flanders, and is to be reckoned among the large≈øt cities of Europe, as it covers a ≈øpace of ground of not le≈øs than ≈øeven miles in circumference; but there is not above one half of that occupied with buildings, the greater part being thrown into fields, gardens, orchards, and plea≈øure-grounds. Situated on four navigable rivers, and inter≈øected into no fewer than twenty-≈øix i≈ølands by a number of canals, which afford an ea≈øy, cheap, and expeditious carriage for weighty merchandize, it may be con≈øidered, in point of local advantages for commerce, ≈øuperior to mo≈øt cities in Europe; while tho≈øe i≈ølands are again united by about a hundred bridges, ≈øome great and ≈øome ≈ømall, which contrbute much to the beauty of the city.

To a man accu≈øtomed to mould his thoughts by what he ≈øees in Great Britain, the ≈øtrong fort ‚Ä¢ fications that ≈øurround almo≈øt all towns on the Continent convey the mo≈øt di≈øagreeable ≈øen≈øations‚Äî ‚Ä¢ eminding him of the fir≈øt mi≈øery of mankind, War! ‚Äî denoting, alas! too truly, the di≈øpo≈øition of man to violate the rights of his fellow-creatures, and manife≈øting the tyrannous abu≈øe of power. On me, though trained and accu≈øtomed to military habits, this "dreadful note of preparation" had an unplea≈øing effect; for, though born, bred, and habituated to the life of a ≈øoldier, I find the feelings of the citizen and the man claim a paramount right to my heart.

Ghent was once extremely well fortified, and calculated, by nature as well as by art, to repel encroachment. It had a very ≈øtrong ca≈øtle, walls, and ditches; and now, though not otherwi≈øe ≈øtrong, the country may, by ≈øhutting up the ≈øluices, be, for above a mile round, laid in a very
≈øhort time under water. It was formerly ≈øo populous and powerful, that it declared war more than once again≈øt its ≈øovereign, and rai≈øed amazing armies. In the year 1587, it ≈øuffered dreadfully from all the ravages of famine, under which a number not le≈øs than three thou≈øand of its inhabitants peri≈øhed in one week.

This town is di≈øtingui≈øhed by the nativity of two celebrated characters: one was the famous JOHN of Gaunt, ≈øon of King EDWARD the third of E ‚Ä¢ gland; the other, the Emperor CHARLES the Fifth, who was born there in the year 1500.

It was in this city that the Confederation of the States, well known under the title of the Pacification of Ghent, which united the Provinces in the mo≈øt la≈øting union of intere≈øt and laws, was held: this union was chiefly owing to the vigorous, unremitted efforts of WILLIAM the Fir≈øt, Prince of Orange, to who≈øe valour and virtue may be attributed the independence of the United States.

In this city there were computed to be fifty companies of trade≈ømen, among whom were manufactured a variety of very curious and rich cloths, ≈øtuffs, and ≈øilks: it is certain, that the woollen manufacture flouri≈øhed here before it had made the ≈ømalle≈øt progre≈øs in England, who≈øe wool they then bought. There was al≈øo a good branch of linen manufacture here, and a pretty bri≈øk corn trade, for which it was locally well calculated. You will ob≈øerve, once for all, that in ≈øpeaking of this country, I generally u≈øe the pa≈øt ten≈øe; for, at pre≈øent, they are utterly undone.

Ghent was the ≈øee of a bi≈øhop, who, like the bi≈øhop of Bruges, was ≈øuffragan to the archbi≈øhop of Mechlin. Thus, in mo≈øt Chri≈øtian countries, are the intellects, the con≈øciences, and the ca≈øh too, of the people, ≈øhut up and hid from the light, by prie≈øt within dean, and dean within bi≈øhop‚Äîlike
a ring in the hand of a conjurer, box within box ‚Äîtill at la≈øt they are enveloped in the great receptacle of all deception, the capacious pocket of the archbi≈øhop. Let not ≈øceptered tyrants, their legions, their ≈øcaffolds, and their ≈øwords, bear all the infamy of the ≈ølavery of mankind! Opinion, opinion, under the management of fraud and impo≈øture, is the engine that forges their fetters!!‚Äî JANSENIUS, from whom the Jan≈øeni≈øts took their name, was the fir≈øt bi≈øhop of this place; and the late bi≈øhop, I think, may be reckoned the la≈øt.

The municipal government of this city is correct, and well calculated to ≈øecure internal peace and order. The chief magi≈øtrate is the high bailiff; ≈øubordinate to whom are burgoma≈øters, echivins, and coun≈øellors.

Ghent is not deficient in ≈øtately edifices; and, true to their ≈øy≈øtem, the holy fathers of the church have their ≈øhare, which, in old Popi≈øh countries, is at lea≈øt nineteen twentieths. In the middle of the town is a high tower, called Belfort tower: from whence there is a delightful pro≈øpect over the whole city and its environs. Mona≈øteries and churches, there, are without number; be≈øides ho≈øpitals and market-places: that called Friday's market, is the large≈øt of all, and is adorned with a ≈øtatue of CHARLES the Fifth, in his imperial robes. The ≈øtad-hou≈øe is a magnificent ≈øtructure‚ÄîSo is the cathedral, under which the reverend fathers have built a ≈øubterraneous church. What deeds are tho≈øe which ≈øhun the light! Why tho≈øe holy patriarchs have ≈øuch a de≈øire for burying them≈øelves, and working like moles under ground, they them≈øelves be≈øt know, and I think it is not difficult for others to conjecture.

This cathedral, however, is well worth attention, on account of ≈øome capital pictures it contains. The marble of the church is remarkably fine, and
the altar-piece ≈øplendid beyond all po≈ø≈øible de≈øcription; and, indeed, in all the others, there are paintings, eminent for their own excellence, and for the celebrity of the ma≈øters who painted them.

In the mona≈øtery of St. PIERRE, there is a grand library, filled with books in all languages; but it is chiefly remarkable for the ≈øuperlative beauty of its ceiling, one half of which was painted by RUBENS.

Thus you may perceive, my dear FREDERICK, the charity of the clergy!‚Äîhow, in pure pity for the ≈øins of mankind, and in paternal care of their ≈øouls, they exact from the laity ≈øome atonement for their crimes, and con≈øtrain them at lea≈øt to repent ‚Äîand, with unparalleled magnanimity, take upon them≈øelves the vices, the gluttony, the avarice, and the ≈øen≈øuality, of which they are ≈øo careful to purge their fellow-creatures.

div.head: LETTER IX.
div.p: HAVING given you a general outline of the city of Ghent, I ≈øhall now proceed to give you an account of one of the mo≈øt excellent, and certainly the mo≈øt intere≈øting, of all the curio≈øities in that place. It is indeed of a ≈øort ≈øo immediately corre≈øpondent to the mo≈øt exalted ≈øen≈øations of humanity, and ≈øo perfectly in uni≈øon with the mo≈øt exqui≈øitely ≈øen≈øible chords of the feeling heart, that I re≈øolved to re≈øcue it from the common lumber of the place, and give it to you in a fre≈øh letter, when the ideas excited by my former might have faded away, and left your mind more clear for the reception of ≈øuch refined impre≈ø≈øions.
On one of the many bridges in Ghent ≈øtand two huge brazen images of a father and ≈øon, who obtained this di≈øtingui≈øhed mark of the admiration of their fellow-citizens by the following incidents:

Both the father and the ≈øon were, for ≈øome offence again≈øt the ≈øtate, condemned to die. Some favourable circum≈øtances appearing on the ≈øide of the ≈øon, he was granted a remi≈ø≈øion of his ≈øhare of the ≈øentence, upon certain provi≈øions‚Äîin ≈øhort, he was offered a pardon, on the mo≈øt cruel and barbarous condition that ever entered into the mind of even monki≈øh barbarity, namely, that he would become the executioner of his father! He at fir≈øt re≈øolutely refu≈øed to pre≈øerve his life by means ≈øo fatal and dete≈øtable: This is not to be wondered at; for I hope, for the honour of our nature, that there are but few, very few ≈øorts, who would not have ≈øpurned, with abhorrence, life ≈øu≈øtained on conditions ≈øo horrid, ≈øo unnatural. The ≈øon, though long inflexible, was at length overcome by the tears and entreaties of a fond father, who repre≈øented to him, at all events, his (the father's) life was forfeited, and that it would be the greate≈øt po≈ø≈øible con≈øolation to him, at his la≈øt moments, to think, that in his death he was the in≈øtrument of his ≈øon's pre≈øervation. The youth con≈øented to adopt the horrible means of recovering his life and liberty: he lifted the axe; but, as it was about to fall, his arm ≈øunk nervele≈øs, and the axe dropped from his hand! Had he as many lives as hairs, he would have yielded them all, one after the other, rather than again even conceive, much le≈øs perpetrate, ≈øuch an act. Life, liberty, every thing, vani≈øhed before the dearer intere≈øts of filial affection: he fell upon his father's neck, and, embracing him, triumphantly exclaimed, "My father, my father! we will die together!" and then called for another executioner to fulfil the ≈øentence of the law.

Hard mu≈øt be their hearts indeed, bereft of every ≈øentiment of virtue, every ≈øen≈øation of humanity, who could ≈øtand in≈øen≈øible ≈øpectators of ≈øuch a ≈øcene‚ÄîA ≈øudden peal of involuntary applau≈øes, mixed with groans and ≈øighs, rent the air. The execution was ≈øu≈øpended; and on a ≈øimple repre≈øentation of the tran≈øaction, both were pardoned: high rewards and honours were conferred on the ≈øon; and finally, tho≈øe two admirable brazen images were rai≈øed, to commemorate a tran≈øaction ≈øo honourable to human nature, and tran≈ømit it for the in≈øtruction and emulation of po≈øterity. The ≈øtatue repre≈øents the ≈øon in the very act of letting fall the axe.

Lay this to your mind, my dear FREDERICK: talk over it to your brother; indulge all the charming ≈øympathetic ≈øen≈øations it communicates; never let a mi≈øtaken ≈øhame, or a fal≈øe idea (which ≈øome endeavour to impre≈øs) that it is unmanly to melt at the tale of woe, and ≈øympathize with our fellow-creatures, ≈øtop the current of your ≈øen≈øibility‚Äîno! Be a≈ø≈øured, that, on the contrary, it is the true criterion of manhood and valour to feel; and that the more ≈øympathetic and ≈øen≈øible the heart is, the more nearly it is allied to the Divinity.

I AM now on the point of conducting you out of Au≈øtrian Flanders‚ÄîOne town only, and that comparatively a ≈ømall one, lying between Us and Brabant: the name of this town is Alo≈øt, or, as the Flemings ≈øpell it, Ael≈øt.

From Ghent to Bru≈ø≈øels (the next great ≈øtage in my way), I found, to my regret, that there was no conveyance by water: I therefore was obliged to go in a voiture, and ≈øtopt at Alo≈øt, as an intermediate ≈øtage; and mathematically intermediate it is‚Äî for it lies at equal di≈øtance from Ghent and Bru≈ø≈øels, being exactly fifteen miles from each.

This is a ≈ømall, but exceeding neat town, ≈øituated on the river Dender; and being a remarkably great thoroughfare accommodations of every kind are tolerably good in it. It would be idle to ≈øuppo≈øe, that Catholic zeal had left ≈øo many ≈øouls unprotected and undi≈øciplined, where there were ≈øo many bodies capable of drudgery to pay for it. In truth, there has been as ample provi≈øion made for the town of Alo≈øt in the way of ≈øacerdotal bu≈øine≈øs, as for any other town in the Netherlands‚Äîregard being had to its bulk; for there were ≈øeveral convents of friars, and of cour≈øe ≈øeveral of nuns: be≈øides, there was a Je≈øuit's college of ≈øome note. How they all fare by this time, it is difficult for me to determine.
The church of Saint MARTIN could boa≈øt of ≈øome excellent pictures, particularly a mo≈øt capital piece, "La Pe≈øte," by RUBENS.

In a convent inhabited by a ≈øet of monks, denomined Gulielmite, I ≈øaw the tomb of THIERRY MARTIN, who fir≈øt brought the art of printing from Germany to that place. His name and fame are tran≈ømitted to us by an epitaph upon his tomb, written by his friend, the ingenious Era≈ømus.

This tomb of THIERRY MARTIN ≈øtands a monument, not only of his merit, but of the ≈øhort-≈øigh ‚Ä¢ edne≈øs and folly even of monks. Alas, ≈øilly men! they little knew, that when they granted THIERRY MARTIN the honours of the convent, they were harbouring, in their hallowed ground, one of their greate≈øt enemies, and commemorating the man who was contributing to the overthrow of their ≈øacred order: for the art of printing, whereever it reached, illuminated the human mind, and fir≈øt kindled up that light, before which prie≈øtcraft, and all its pious impo≈øtures, like evil ≈øpectres, have vani≈øhed. To the art of printing is human ≈øociety indebted for many of the advantages which it po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes
beyond the brute or ≈øavage tribes‚Äîfor the perfection of arts, the exten≈øion of ≈øcience, the general enlargement of the mind, and, above all, for the emancipation of per≈øon and property from the ≈øhackles of de≈øpoti≈øm, and of the human intellect from the fetters of blindne≈øs and ignorance with which ≈øacerdotal fraud had chained it for centuries to the earth.

The territory of this city is of pretty large extent, and is called a county, having, in ancient times, had counts of its own; and the whole of it is extremely fruitful in pa≈øture, corn, hops, flax, and mo≈øt other productions of tho≈øe climes.

I made but a very ≈øhort ≈øtay at Alo≈øt, when I proceeded on to Bru≈ø≈øels; and, having thus brought you through that part of the Netherlands called Au≈øtrian Flanders, I think I ought to give you a general account of the country at large, as I have hitherto confined my≈øelf merely to the cities and towns of it; but as this letter is already of a length that will not allow of any great addition, I ≈øhall po≈øtpone my intended de≈øcription to my next.

div.head: LETTER X.
div.p:
WERE mankind to be guided by moderation, rea≈øon, and ju≈øtice‚Äîwere there no lu≈øt for territory in particular ≈øtates‚Äîno ambition or de≈øire in kings for an undue enlargement of their power‚Äîno unju≈øtifiable infractions attempted by one ≈øtate or potentate upon the peace and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of another‚Äîno armes to carry de≈øolation and plunder through the world, nor churchmen more mild, but not more moderate, to drain them with
their ≈øubtle deceptions‚Äîwere the hu≈øbandman, the fi≈øherman, the manufacturer, and the labourer, permitted to make, by their indu≈øtry, the be≈øt u≈øe of the ≈øoil on which chance or nature had planted them, and to lift the fruits of their labour to their own lips‚Äîno people were more happy than the inhabitants of Au≈øtrian Flanders.

This country is bounded, to the north, by the Scheldt; to the north-we≈øt, by the Northern Sea: to the ≈øouth, and ≈øouth-we≈øt, by Artois, one of the fine≈øt Provinces of France; and to the ea≈øt, by Brabant. Its greate≈øt length is ≈øeventy-five miles; and its greate≈øt breadth, fifty-five. The air is good; but it is ≈øaid to be better in proportion as it recedes from the ≈øea. The winters are ≈øometimes long and ≈øevere, and the ≈øummers ≈øometimes wet and ≈øultry; yet, in general, the climate is agreeable. The ≈øoil is in mo≈øt parts fertile, and in ≈øome to a degree equal to that of any part of Europe. It is chiefly famous for its pa≈øturage; in con≈øequence of which, great numbers of black cattle, hor≈øes and ≈øheep, are bred in it, and immen≈øe quantities of butter and chee≈øe made. It is, be≈øides, abundantly productive of all ≈øorts of culinary vegetables‚Äîfruit in great quantities‚Äîcorn and flax, which la≈øt is not only rai≈øed in great plenty, but is celebrated for the finene≈øs and ≈øtrength of its ≈øtaple. It is true, that in ≈øome parts they have not corn ≈øufficient for the inhabitants; but this is well recompen≈øed by other productions, with the redundance of which they purcha≈øe the ≈øuperfluous grain of their neighbours‚Äîfor, where the inhabitants do follow tillage, the produce is unequalled, and the ≈øuperfluity mu≈øt of cour≈øe be great.

The ≈øuperior fecundity of the ≈øheep of this country is very remarkable, and difficult, perhaps, to be accounted for‚Äîa ewe here bringing forth con≈øtantly three lambs at a birth, ≈øometimes four,
≈øometimes five, and ≈øome have been known to produce as many as ≈øix and ≈øeven‚Äîno ≈ømall in≈øtance of the prodigality of nature in providing for this ≈øpot.

At ≈øome di≈øtance from the ≈øea-coa≈øt, the face of the country is decorated with a profu≈øion of wood, fitted either for timber or for fuel; and towards the coa≈øt, where nature has been rather niggard of that ble≈ø≈øing, the inhabitants ≈øub≈øtitute, in its ≈øtead, for fuel, a kind of turf, which they find at the depth of four or five feet from the ≈øurface of the earth, and which makes a fire, not only cheerful, plea≈øant, and hot, but remarkably whole≈øome, being free from the de≈øtructive ≈øulphurious and bituminous vapour attendant upon coal.

Perhaps no part of the world is better ≈øupplied than this province with all ≈øorts of fi≈øh, as well tho≈øe of ≈øea as fre≈øh water: fowl and veni≈øon were extremely plenty and rea≈øonable; and a great deal of excellent beer was brewed in it. It is wa≈øhed by ≈øeveral rivers, four of which are noble ≈øtreams, namely, the Scheldt, the Lys, the Scarpe, and the Dender; and there are ≈øeveral canals, the chief of which is that between Bruges and Ghent.

Thus in whatever way it be con≈øidered, nature ≈øeems to have made ample provi≈øion for the happine≈øs of the people: how far they are ≈øo, you ≈øhall hear when I come to give a general view of the Netherlands‚Äîthat which is applicable to Au≈øtrian Flanders being equally ≈øo to all the other parts of the Netherlands, excepting tho≈øe under the dominion of the Republic of the United States.

The States of this country, according to the con≈øtitution it once po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, con≈øi≈øted of clergy, the nobility, and the commoners. The clergy were the bi≈øhops and abbots: the nobility was compo≈øed of certain families holding hereditary offices or ‚Ä¢ aronies, to which that privilege was annexed; and
the commoners were made up of the burgoma≈øters, pen≈øioners and deputies of the cities and di≈øtricts. But the only religion profe≈ø≈øed or tolerated in this country, was the Roman Catholic.

Of the people of Au≈øtrian Flanders a celebrated Author gives the following account, which I tran≈øcribe for your u≈øe, the rather as my ≈øtay there was too ≈øhort to enable me to make any material ob≈øervations on them, or their manners.‚Äî

"With re≈øpect to the per≈øons and characters of the inhabitants," ≈øays he, "they are, generally ≈øpeaking, lu≈øty, fat, and clum≈øy‚Äîvery indu≈øtrious, both in cultivating their lands, and in their trades and manufactures‚Äîlovers of liberty, and enemies to ≈ølavery‚Äîand not defective in good ≈øen≈øe or judgment, though they have not ≈øo lively an imagination as ≈øome other nations. Their women are fair, hand≈øome enough, and hone≈øt by their natural con≈øtitution, as well as from a principle of virtue: as they cannot pretend to wit and repartee, they do not make them≈øelves ridiculous by the nau≈øeous affectation of them. Both ≈øexes are great lovers of public diver≈øions; and every city, town, and village, have their kermi≈ø≈øes, or fairs, in which all ≈øorts of ≈øhews are exhibited."

Many arts which now enrich other nations, and the importance of which has excited conte≈øts and ≈øtruggles of the mo≈øt ≈øerious kind in the political world, were invented or improved in that country. Weaving, in general, though not invented, was greatly improved; and the art of forming figures of all ≈øorts in linen was fir≈øt invented there. To the Flemings we are al≈øo indebted for the arts of curing herrings, dyeing cloths and ≈øtuffs, and oil-colours. But tho≈øe arts, and the manufactures, have gradually ≈ølid away from them, and left but a ≈ømall ≈øhare behind, when compared with their former flouri≈øhing ≈øtate; they have flown to a land of
liberty and ≈øecurity, where ho≈øtile feet never tread, where ≈ølavery corrupteth not, where war devoureth not, no ‚Ä¢ Prie≈øts no ‚Ä¢ De≈øpots break in and ≈øteal. Neverthele≈øs, ≈øilk, cotton and woollen ≈øtuffs, brocades, camblets, tape≈øtry, linen, and lace, are ≈øtill manufactured here to ≈øome ≈ømall extent.

This province had counts of its own, from the ninth century up to the year 1369, when it was made over, by marriage, (l ‚Ä¢ ke a farm of cattle) to the dukes of Burgundy; and afterwards, again, was by them made over, in like way of marriage, to the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria. In 1667 France ≈øeized the ≈øouthern part; and the States General obtained the northern, partly by the treaty of Mun≈øter, and partly by the Barrier treaty of 1715.

To reckon upon the natural endowments of this country, one would ≈øuppo≈øe that it ≈øhould be a terre≈øtrial paradi≈øe: yet ≈øuch is the wickedne≈øs of man, and the outrageous ≈øpirit of power, that it is almo≈øt the la≈øt country in Europe in which I would have property, and fix a permanent re≈øidence. Ju≈øt now, while I am writing, I have before me an account, that the French, to whom they have opened their gates, have plundered them to the la≈øt atom of their moveable po≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øions; and that the property of the unfortunate people is now in waggons, on its way to Paris.
Once more, my boy, I ≈øay, ble≈øs your GOD, that planted you in a country cheered by the voice of freedom, defended by Briti≈øh valour, and, what is of more con≈øequence, ≈øurrounded by the Ocean.

div.head: LETTER XI.
div.p: HAVING conducted you through that part of the Netherlands called Au≈øtrian Flanders, w ‚Ä¢ are now to direct our attention to that called Au≈øtrian Brabant, of which part, as well as of the Netherlands in general, Bru≈ø≈øels, where I arrived the ≈øame day I left Ghent, is the capital, giving its name to a quarter or territory that ≈øurrounds it.

In all parts of the Netherlands through which I travelled, I could not help admiring the uniform decorations of the roads, rivers, and canals, with rows of lofty trees, which form a mo≈øt agreeable ≈øhade from the ≈øummer's burning ≈øun, and yet do not ob≈øtruct any great extent of pro≈øpect, the country is ≈øo extremely flat. And one thing I remarked, and which certainty ≈øeems at fir≈øt view, extraordinary, is, that in the great extent of country through which we have hitherto pa≈ø≈øed, from O≈øtend to Bru≈ø≈øels, being ≈øixty-eight miles, I ≈øcarce ≈øaw one nobleman or gentleman's ≈øeat‚Äînothing above the hou≈øe of a hu≈øbandman, a curate, or ≈øome per≈øon of ≈ømall fortune: and yet the country is extremely rich; and I ≈øaw many ≈øpots, as I went along, charming beyond de≈øcription, and ≈øuch as would tempt, I ≈øhould think, a man of ta≈øte and opulence to ≈øettle in them. This mu≈øt appear unaccountable to tho≈øe who do not recollect, that in a country ≈øubject like this to the ravaging incur≈øions of contending armies, fortified ‚Ä¢ owns are con≈øidered as the mo≈øt plea≈øing, becau≈øe the mo≈øt ≈øecure retreats of opulence.

As I approached the city of Bru≈ø≈øels, I was ≈øtruck with a mixed ≈øen≈øation of ≈øurpri≈øe and delight at the appearance it made‚Äînone that I had ever ≈øeen being comparable to it, and not one in Europe, by the account of travellers, being in that re≈øpect ≈øuperior to it, Naples and Genoa only excepted: like them, however, it, when entered, falls far ≈øhort of the expectation rai≈øed by its external appearance, being all compo≈øed of hills and hollows, which not only fatigue, but render the appearance of the ≈øtreets, though well built, contemptible and mean.

Bru≈ø≈øels ≈øtands on the beautiful little river Senne, on the brow of a hill. The city is about ≈øeven miles in circumference, has ≈øeven gates, with exten≈øive ≈øuburbs, and is encompa≈ø≈øed with a double wall made of brick, and ditches; but its ≈øize is too great for ≈øtrength, as a face of defence of ≈øuch extent could not po≈ø≈øibly hold out a long ≈øiege‚Äîa great and in≈øuperable defect in ≈øuch a country as I have de≈øcribed.

Great as is the extent of ground on which this city ≈øtands, it is neverthele≈øs very well built, and extremely populous. It is ornamented with no fewer than ≈øeven ≈øquares, all of them remarkably fine, particularly the great ≈øquare or market place, which is reckoned to be perhaps the fine≈øt in Europe. Around it are the halls of the different trades, the fronts of which are adorned, in a ≈øuperb manner, with emblematical ≈øculpture, with gilding, and a variety of Latin in≈øcriptions. One quarter of this ≈øquare is entirely occupied by the town-hou≈øes, a noble pile of building, in which there were apartments where the States of B ‚Ä¢ aba ‚Ä¢ t me ‚Ä¢ , ‚Ä¢ inely adorned with tape≈øtry in gift frames, and ≈øome admirable original paintings. At the time I was there, the whole city was in motion, preparing for the Inauguration of the EMPEROR, who was then impatiently expected, and who≈øe approach
made ≈øuch a bu≈øtle, and promi≈øed ≈øuch a ≈øpectacle, as made me regret the nece≈ø≈øity I lay under of proceeding on my journey. The town-hou≈øe was put into the highe≈øt order, and ≈øub≈øequently fell a ≈øacrifice to the great and important event for which it was prepared.

The ≈øteeple of this building is of a mo≈øt ≈øtupendous height‚Äîthree hundred and ≈øixty-four feet; and on the top of it is erected a ≈øtatue of Saint MICHAEL killing the Dragon, of the enormous height of ≈øeventeen feet: this colo≈ø≈øal ≈øtatue is ≈øo con≈øtructed as to ≈øerve for a weather-cock; and being made of copper, well gilt, is at once con≈øpicuous, magnificent, and ornamental.

The public buildings of Bru≈ø≈øels, particularly the palaces and courts of the ≈øeveral princes, counts, and other per≈øons of di≈øtinction, (and, you may be ≈øure, the churches and cloi≈øters too), are ≈øpacious, expen≈øive, and magnificent. Behind the imperial palace, which ≈øtood in the highe≈øt part of the city, but was burnt down many years ago, is a park, well ≈øtocked with deer, and planted with trees, like St. James's-park at London, for the inhabitants to walk in. At the farther end of it is a fine plea≈øure-hou≈øe, built by the Emperor CHARLES the fifth, after his abdication.

The palace is a magnificent ≈øtructure: the rooms of it are fini≈øhed in a ≈øtyle far ≈øuperior to tho≈øe of any palace in England, and enriched with many fine paintings: that of the family of HECTOR, in the council chamber, lays claim to the fir≈øt rank of eminence. Of the other buildings (the grandeur of which entitle them to the names of palaces), tho≈øe of the Prince de la Tour and Taxis, and the Briti≈øh Earl of Ayle≈øbury, are di≈øtingu≈øhed by great beauty and magnificence. Indeed, in all the palaces, there are collections of original paintings, by the mo≈øt eminent ma≈øters, both Italian and Flemi≈øh.

The royal library of Bru≈ø≈øels claims particular attention, for the magnitude and liberality of its e≈øtabli≈øhment, containing a grand collection of the mo≈øt excellent books in all languages, and being open all the year on Tue≈ødays, Thur≈ødays, and Saturdays, to public acce≈øs.

The ar ‚Ä¢ enal of Bru≈ø≈øels is extremely well worth going to ≈øee, on account of the very curious antique arms it contains‚Äîof which it is, at this di≈øtance of time, impo≈ø≈øible for me to give you any account worth attention. The armour of the Emperor CHARLES the Fifth, together with the furniture of his hor≈øe, and ≈øtate ≈øword, are ≈øhewn: I could ≈øee nothing either novel or intere≈øting in them‚Äîa ≈øtrong mark I pre≈øume, of my want of ta≈øte; but I confe≈øs my organs are not ≈øo refined as to feel any extraordinary emotions at the ≈øight of a heap of i ‚Ä¢ ert matter, mearly becau≈øe it once enveloped the carca≈øe of a tyrant: neither were they ≈øo very coar≈øe or dull as not to undergo very pointed ≈øen≈øations at the ≈øight of the armour of MONTEZUMA, the injured Emperor of Mexico, the victim of avarice and rapine, under their u≈øual ma≈øk, religion. Why MONTEZUMA'S armour ≈øhould make a part of the trophies of a Popi≈øh ≈øtate, and be triumphantly exhibited, is hard to account for in human folly: why that ≈øhould be exhibited which is a ≈øtain of the deepe≈øt-damned black, in their black code of faith, is a≈øtoni≈øhing, unle≈øs we allow the truth of the old ≈øaying, "Quos DEUS vult perdere, prius dementat;" and that, after having violated every principle of virtue, morality, and human feeling‚Äî after having ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed in cruelty all that we know of the wor≈øt mon≈øters of the earth, or of the deep, the fell hyena, or the ravening ≈øhark‚Äîafter having ≈øucce≈øsfully emulated the wor≈øt efforts of the mo≈øt malignant ≈øpirits that are ≈øaid to hold coun≈øel for the ruin of mankind in hell‚Äîthey were de≈øirous to tran≈ømit the ≈øpoils of their ravages to po≈øterity,
to tell them what glorious things have been atchieved in days of yore, for the love of CHRIST ‚Äîto demon≈øtrate what benefits are to be derived from a religion which has, for ≈øo many hundred years, given ≈øanction to every enormity that ≈øtrikes the ≈øoul of man with horror, and thereby to make converts to their principles. Mon≈øters! fools! Away with your idle cants, ye hypocrites, who would brand the cruelties of the pre≈øent days, the ma≈ø≈øacres of the Jacobins, with the crime of infidelity, and attribute tho≈øe much lamented defections from humanity to a falling off from the Chri≈øtian faith. Look to Mexico!‚Äî≈øee a mon≈øter, a high prie≈øt of your religion, collecting, by fair promi≈øes and ≈øweet pur≈øua≈øion, a people round him; and, when a plain was filled, commanding his blood-hounds, armed with ≈øword and crucifix, to fall upon and murder them‚Äîbecau≈øe one poor creature, who knew not what a book meant, had accidentally dropped a bible from his hands!‚Äî≈øee him not ≈øparing age or ≈øex, but butchering all, for the love of CHRIST!‚ÄîWhen have the deluded and enfrenzied mob of France perpetrated, in the full torrent of popular frenzy, ≈øuch atrocities as this cruel prie≈øt committed in cold blood? when have they hunted down their follow creatures, ma≈ø≈øacred children, and given their yet panting members to their dogs for food, as pious Chri≈øtians, headed by a pious prie≈øt, have done in Mexico? Never! never! ‚ÄîLearn wi≈ødom, then, ye hypocrites! and if you cannot convince your enemies by rea≈øon, or conquer them by force, and if their predatory and wicked progre≈øs is not to be ≈øtopped, do not ≈øanctify their enormities, or palliate their crimes, in the eye of rea≈øon, by a compari≈øon with tho≈øe of a deeper dye: remember, that "not to be the wor≈øt ≈øtands in ≈øome rank of prai≈øe," and that the Jacobin cruelties of Paris, horrible though they were, were pity and tender mercy, compared with the
Chri≈øtian butchery in Mexico, in Europe, in A≈øia, in every place where Popery ever ≈øet its bloody hoof.

You are not, from what I ≈øay, to infer that I entertain any illiberal animo≈øity to Popery, as many men, and more women, do, merely becau≈øe its articles of faith differ from tho≈øe in which I was bred; I tru≈øt my heart and under≈øtanding are above ≈øuch very degrading prejudices: but I abhor every thing that militates again≈øt human happine≈øs‚Äîevery thing that cru≈øhes the operations of intellect‚Äîevery thing that ≈øtops the current of opinion, and prevents its cour≈øe from enlarging and meliorating our condition: I abhor the impertinent and hypocritical intru≈øion of all churchmen upon national or dome≈øtic concerns; the more, when that intru≈øion is mi≈øchievous; and more ≈øtill, when it a≈ø≈øumes the ma≈øk of piety‚Äîfor that is at once a fraud upon man and an abu≈øe of GOD. All tho≈øe cau≈øes of abhorrence attach, more or le≈øs, to all ≈øects of the Chri≈øtian religion, the Quakers only excepted‚Äîbut to Popery rather more than to any of the others; for it is ob≈øerved, that while the very fir≈øt principles of Chri≈øtianity, as originally laid down in theory, are peace and good-will towards men, warfare, per≈øecution, and blood≈øhed, have practically marked its foot≈øteps wherever it has trod, and its very e≈ø≈øence been perverted by its own mini≈øters, who, entru≈øted with the key of the temple, ≈øteal the ve≈øtments from the alter, to cover the deformed, crookrd back of vice. But the rays of dawning rea≈øon now break with fuller light upon mankind; and it ha≈øtens to meridian re≈øplendence, before which tho≈øe phantoms rai≈øed by pious jugglers will vani≈øh, and, "like the ba≈øele≈øs fabric of a vi≈øion, leave not a wreck behind."

div.head: LETTER XII.
div.p: IN the ar≈øenal of Bru≈ø≈øels was another curio≈øity, which I overlooked in my la≈øt‚Äîa model of a cannon, con≈øtructed ≈øo as to throw ≈øeven balls at once. It is ≈øome con≈øolation to philanthropy to reflect, that of all the abominable engines and in≈øtruments which the inventive faculties of man have di≈øcovered to increa≈øe the cruelty and carnage of war, not one has been of late times adopted. This model lies here, therefore, only as a memorial of the diabolical genius of the inventor.

The opera-hou≈øe of Bru≈ø≈øels, accounted the noble≈øt and large≈øt in Europe, is built after the Italian manner, with rows of lodges or clo≈øets, in mo≈øt of which are chimneys. One of tho≈øe, which belonged to a prince, who≈øe title I now forget, was hung with looking-gla≈ø≈øes, in which, while he ≈øat by the fire, took refre≈øhments, or reclined on his couch, he could ≈øee the whole repre≈øentation, without being expo≈øed to the view of either the actors or the audience.

The markets of Bru≈ø≈øels are very remarkable. The dukes of St. Pierre paid no le≈øs than forty thou≈øand florins, or upwards of three thou≈øand pounds Sterling, for four pictures of them, painted by RUBENS and SYNDER‚ÄîLEWIS the Fourteenth of France offered an immen≈øe ≈øum of money for them; but they found their way at la≈øt into the collection of the Briti≈øh Earl of Orford. The value of them is ≈øaid, by connoi≈ø≈øeurs, to be beyond computation.

Bru≈ø≈øels is extremely well ≈øupplied with water: for, be≈øides the river, it has twenty public fountains,
adorned with ≈øtatues, at the corners of the mo≈øt public ≈øtreets; and the lower part of the city is cut into canals, which communicate with the great one, extending from Bru≈ø≈øels to the Scheldt, fifteen miles: by means of this canal, which was fini≈øhed in 1561, and co≈øt the city eight hundred thou≈øand florins, a per≈øon may ≈øail from Bru≈ø≈øels to the North Sea; and barques do actually go twice a-day to Antwerp, and back again.

This city is full of churches, of which the mo≈øt remarkable is that of Saint MICHAEL and Saint GUDULA, commonly called the cathedral. It is a ≈øuperb, old Gothic ≈øtructure, and, from its celebrated ≈øituation, a mo≈øt beautiful ornament to the city. It is not only grand in its external appearance, but finely adorned within. The pillars which ≈øupport the roof are lofty and elegant: and again≈øt each is a ≈øtatue of ten feet in height. There are no le≈øs than ≈øixteen chapels in it; and each chapel is enriched with abundance of ≈øplendid ornaments, altar finery, candle-≈øticks, crucifixes, &c. and with ≈øome excellent pictures too: a picture of JESUS CHRIST pre≈øenting the keys of Paradi≈øe to Saint PETER, which is reckoned among the chef-d'oeuvres of RUBENS, hangs in one of tho≈øe chapels. There are ≈øome monuments, al≈øo, of very great merit, in the choir of this church. But that which I think by far the greate≈øt and mo≈øt admirable curio≈øity (I mean of human workman≈øhip) in the church, is a pulpit‚Äîone of the riche≈øt and mo≈øt exqui≈øitely wrought pieces I have ever ≈øeen: at the bottom are ≈øeen ADAM and EVE as large as life, repre≈øented as at the moment when the angel drove them out of Paradi≈øe: in both of their faces are deeply and expre≈ø≈øively marked the traits of a mind agoni≈øed with angui≈øh and remor≈øe: behind EVE is a figure of Death, which follows them; and on the top of the pulpit are ≈øeen the figures of JESUS CHRIST and the Virgin MARY cru≈øhing the head of the
Serpent. The ≈øtrong expre≈ø≈øions in the faces of all tho≈øe figures, and the exqui≈øite turn of the workman≈øhip. is the more remarkable, as it is all cut out of oak wood.

Of ≈øupernatural curio≈øities, one of the chapels in this cathedral contains ≈øome, that, for miracle, yield to none in the long catalogue of monki≈øh devices. Three ho≈øts or wafers are daily wor≈øhipped by the people; which ho≈øts or wafers, the prie≈øts firmly a≈ø≈øert, and the people as firmly believe, were, ≈øo long ago as the year 1369, ≈øtabbed by a Jew, and bled profu≈øely. div.p:

In the year 1781, the Emperor JOSEPH the Second came to Bru≈ø≈øels, in order to indulge his paternal feelings as a monarch with the contemplation and view of his ≈øubjects, and al≈øo to be inaugurated; and perhaps upon no occa≈øion that has ever occurred in the mo≈øt volatile nation, was there greater joy more univer≈øally expre≈ø≈øed. Of the number I have heard, I will mention one anecdote only, and one remarkably expre≈ø≈øion of JOSEPH'S, which will ≈øerve to ≈øhew in its true light what his di≈øpo≈øition was; and when you con≈øider them as the act and ≈øentiment of a young man

The affability of monarchs has often been magnified by the fooli≈øh, and often blamed by the wi≈øe: But, if all the in≈øtances of eonde≈øcen≈øion practi≈øed by kings were like that I have recited of JOSEPH; if they aro≈øe from a ≈øound, unque≈øtionable ≈øpirit of philanthropy, not from gaping curio≈øity, broad folly, or a peurile inqui≈øitive habit; and if, in≈øtead of conceiving tho≈øe they vi≈øit paid for their intru≈øion with the honour of having conver≈øed with maje≈øty, and leaving them churli≈øhly, they would generou≈øly pay them with hard ca≈øh, as the good Emperor JOSEPH did; then, indeed, their affability

On the 13th of July, the ceremony of inauguration took place at Bru≈ø≈øels. Nothing could equal the ≈øplendour of the place but the general joy of the people: the crowds were beyond all conception immen≈øe, and every thing was carried on with regularity till evening, when, in playing off ≈øome fire-works, that noble building the town-hou≈øe took fire, and was burnt: ≈øix unfortunate per≈øons lo≈øt their lives, and twenty were dangerou≈øly hurted: tho≈øe who peri≈øhed were ab≈øolutely roa≈øted, and their cries were beyond de≈øcription piercing. To ≈øuch a temper as JOSEPH'S, you will readily conclude that this mu≈øt be a mo≈øt afflicting circum≈øtance ‚Äîit was ≈øo; and he left Bru≈ø≈øels under the pre ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ re of very different feelings from tho≈øe with which he entered it, and was followed by the prayers and ble≈ø≈øings of all the people.

How a people, once formed for manly pith and love of freedom, could bend ≈øo low, is unaccountable. The fir≈øt of the≈øe, however, you will ob≈øerve, is not the oppre≈ø≈øion of the Emperor: it is a tyranny of that wor≈øt of all con≈øtituent parts of a ≈øtate, an ari≈øtocracy‚Äîa vile ari≈øtocracy!‚Äîthat univer≈øal, that every-day de≈øpoti≈øm, under which all places groan, more or le≈øs‚Äîwhich is exerci≈øed in all the various gradations of life that chequer ≈øociety, from the great man who, under the name of mini≈øter, domineers
over the peer, to the country fox-hunting ≈øavage, who puts a poor wretch in jail to pine for years, (his family, the while, ≈øupported by the pari≈øh charity). only for doing that which makes the enjoyment of his own life, killing a partridge or a hare!‚Äîthat ari≈øtocratic tyranny which is ≈øeen ≈øcowling on the brows of a ≈øwaggering fellow in power, adopted by his ≈øecretary with increa≈øe, by him handed down to an up≈øtart ≈øet of fellows in office, dependent on his ≈ømile, and by them di≈øplayed in all the nau≈øeous, de≈øpicable forms which awkwardne≈øs and ignorance lifted above their ≈øtations, never fail to a≈ø≈øume‚Äîthe cold re≈øerve, the affected ≈øtare, the liftle≈øs nod, the feigned deafne≈øs, blindne≈øs, ab≈øence, and other fa≈øhionable perfections, which ≈øerve as vents for up≈øtart arrogance, and indemnify the ≈øycophant for the vile homage and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion which he has before paid ≈øome wretch, mean and arrogant as him≈øelf!‚ÄîI tell you, my dear FREDERICK, it is this ari≈øtocratic u≈øurpation of power, where power exi≈øts not, nor is nece≈ø≈øary‚Äî this in≈øulting a≈ø≈øumption of ≈øuperiority, this hidden petty oppre≈ø≈øion which rears its head in every manor, nay, almo≈øt every town and village in the kingdom, that put the nations out of tune, mars the harmony of ≈øocial arrangement, and renders power in the aggregate obnoxious. more u≈øeful plants‚ÄîThus it goes round in ≈øhameful traffic; and, as the poet ≈øays,

I am per≈øuaded, that if the grievances of the mo≈øt de≈øpotic ≈øtates were fairily e≈øtimated, and a≈ø≈øigned to their real authors, the princes of ≈øuch ≈øtates would be found re≈øpon≈øible for a very ≈ømall ≈øhare indeed, when compared with the ari≈øtocracy: and by ari≈øtocracy, I mean not merely lords, but all men who convert the wealth which Providence has be≈øtowed upon them to the purpo≈øes of tyranny, exactions, impo≈øition and oppre≈ø≈øion‚Äîunder which four heads we will again find, not only impri≈øonment for begging alms, impri≈øonment for ≈øhooting a partridge, but often ≈øeduction, adultery, and per≈øecution for re≈øi≈øting or re≈øorting to law for puni≈øhment of that ≈øeduction or adultery. div.p:
