Having ≈øeen as much of Bru≈ø≈øels as my time and occa≈øions would at all allow, and, in truth, having rather tre≈øpa≈ø≈øed on my plan, for the rea≈øons ju≈øt mentioned, I determined to pu≈øh forward as fa≈øt as it was po≈ø≈øible, and took po≈øt for Liege, where I arrived, after pa≈ø≈øing through a beautiful, fertile, well-cultivated country, to the charms of which the renewed agony of my feelings redered me almo≈øt in≈øen≈øible.

As we have now almo≈øt the whole length of Germany before us to travel through, it will be proper, before I proceed further, to give you a general idea of the con≈øtitution of this ve≈øt empire‚Äî over all which, while one great monarch nominally pre≈øides, there are ≈øpread a number of petty potentates, who really rule after as di≈øtinct forms of government as almo≈øt any two governments, however remote in Europe.

Con≈øidering the nature of government ab≈øtractedly, one would ≈øuppo≈øe that it aro≈øe from the general will of the ≈øociety governed, and was formed for their u≈øe and benefit alone: but if we view the different ≈øy≈øtems ≈øcattered over the civilized part of the earth, we ≈øhall find that they originated from force and fraud; and that, in their fir≈øt formation, when bodily prowe≈øs, not intellectual power, bore ≈øway‚Äîwhen he that could carry the ≈øtronge≈øt armour, and ≈øtrike the heavie≈øt blows, was ≈øure to govern‚Äîwhen mere animal ≈øtrength and ferocity di≈øinherited rea≈øon of her rights, and robbed her of that a≈øcendency to which the invention of gunpowder, aided by the art of printing, has ≈øince in ≈øome ≈øort re≈øtored her‚Äîthe ba≈øis upon which
governments were rai≈øed was, one man, not the whole ≈øociety; the point then was, how this or that ≈øtrong ruffian could collect mo≈øt ≈ølaves about him, not how this or that ≈øociety ≈øhould choo≈øe the be≈øt head: if he has ≈øtrength to carry havoc through the ranks of their enemies, and then to overawe them≈øelves, he was ≈øure of dominion over the people, and left it to his ≈øon; but if it ≈øo happened that he did not al≈øo bequeath to him bodily prowe≈øs to pre≈øerve it, the next ≈øtrong ruffian ≈øeized the reins, flung him from his ≈øeat and kept it till he, or ≈øome one of his heirs, was again ≈øerved ≈øo in his turn by ≈øome other u≈øurper. Hence aro≈øe the cabals and intrigues of courts, the ≈øpirit of party, and inte≈øtine commotion; till at length the people, for their own ≈øecurity, and to avoid the horrors of civil war, made choice (from di≈ømal nece≈ø≈øity) of ≈øome one family to rule them. As ≈øociety advanced, and opulence held forth temptation, ≈øome greater ruffian, followed by a horde of needy, fami≈øhed barbarians, made incur≈øions on tho≈øe rulers; and being irre≈øi≈øtible, as well from numbers firmly connected, as from the powerful impul≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity, under who≈øe banners they generally robbed and ravaged, was ≈øubmitted to on terms, and became Lord Paramount of a number of petty ≈øovereigns, who did homage to him, and fleeced the mi≈øerable ≈øubjects, to keep him in humour; and thus, in a ≈øeries of time, the power of both took root, and remained immoveable, unle≈øs when torn up by ≈øome violent tempe≈øt that convu≈øed the ≈øtate, and ≈øhook it to its foundations.

Reading this account, you will very naturally exclaim, "Good GOD! how ab≈øurd! how irrational!" Yet ≈øo it is; and from this ≈øource, muddy though it be, is modern honour, and modern greatne≈øs, and modern high blood, derived: from this foul and turbid fountain have mo≈øt of the governments of the world i≈ø≈øued; from tho≈øe ≈øtrong men of yore have mo≈øt of our modern governors de≈øcended: and as it
generally happens (≈øo equally has Providence di≈øtributed the gifts of nature) that the ≈øtrength of the intellectual part is in the inver≈øe ratio of the animal, perhaps that is the rea≈øon why monarchs are formed, in general, of greater bodily vigour than mental endowments, and better fitted for the field than the cabinet‚Äîand for this rea≈øon are obliged to take from the pui≈øne ranks of their ≈øubjects ≈øome a≈ø≈øi≈øtant, ≈øo far removed from the great ≈øtandard of antique dignity, as to po≈ø≈øe≈øs under≈øtanding enough to govern.

Upon a retro≈øpective view of the Hi≈øtory of Europe, it will be found, that for a long time after the birth of CHRIST, Germany was divided among ≈øuch petty rulers as I have de≈øcribed, who each held his little ≈øtate in ≈øovereignty, and was called Princeps in Latin, or, in plain Engli≈øh, Prince. After the downfal of the We≈øtern Empire, a nation called Franks, from that part called Franconia, over-ran a great part of Gaul and Germany, and in the fifth century took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of that part of Gaul which lay north of the river Loire. In the year 800, CHARLEMAGNE, the ≈øon of PEPIN, their king, formed an immen≈øe empire in the we≈øt, comprehending a great part of Germany, France, Italy, and a part of Spain. About eighty years afterwards, the petty princes of Germany ≈øhook off the French Carlovinian race, and elected an emperor of their own from the Hou≈øe of Bavaria.

At la≈øt HENRY the Fourth, having di≈øplea≈øed that grand arbiter the Pope, was put under the ban, and in con≈øequence depo≈øed by the ≈øtates; on which occa≈øion his Holine≈øs had the addre≈øs to make that great dignity elective, he having uncontroled power over the electors; ≈øince which it has continued ≈øo, with ≈øome modifications, and under certain regulations, formed by CHARLES the Fourth, at the diet of Nuremberg. The election, however, has been always ≈øo managed, that it has never departed
from the regular line of ≈øucce≈ø≈øion but when there was an actual want of heirs.

In a country over which the Pope had ≈øuch influence, it might rea≈øonably be ≈øuppo≈øed that intolerance is carried to a great length; but it is not ≈øo, as a review of each particular ≈øtate ≈øhews. The e≈øtali≈øhed religion, in general, is Popery. JOSEPH the Second, that good and wi≈øe monarh, di≈øplayed a greater ≈øpirit of toleration than any other Catholic prince ≈øince HENRY the Fourth of France. He was not murdered by a friar for it, it is true‚Äîtho≈øe days of pious barbarity are pa≈øt; but he was vi≈øited on the occa≈øion by his Holine≈øs, who, after a variety of remon≈øtrances again≈øt the relaxation he gave to religious ≈øeverity in his own dominions, finding him unmoved by papers, re≈øolved to attack him in per≈øon; but, whether it was that the pontifical amulet lo≈øt its charm when out of the air of Rome, or that his Holine≈øs was not properly anointed before (like Hecate in Macbeth) he took his flight, or that he forgot ≈øome of tho≈øe reliques which were expected to operate on JOSEPH'S mind, ≈øo it was, that the good emperor continued inflexibly attached to his former re≈øolve; and, after ki≈ø≈øing his Holine≈øs' toe, and a thou≈øand other pretty politene≈ø≈øes, ≈øent him back to Rome again with his finger in his mouth; and a ≈øtory to relate. that would, at one time, have ≈øet all Europe in a flame, and ≈øent the good monarch, like HENRY the Second of England, to la≈øh him≈øelf naked over the rotten remains of ≈øome vagabond fraudulent prie≈øt.

In the election of emperor, the laws of the empire have laid down no qualification but that which ought to be the fine qua non of all princes, namely, that he be ju≈øtus, bonus, et utilis‚ÄîNeither have they made any limitation in regard to religion, nation, ≈øtate, or age; neverthele≈øs, the majority of electors being Papi≈øts, a Roman Catholic prince is always cho≈øen.

The rank of the emperor is very great: he is looked upon by all crowned heads as the fir≈øt European potentate; and‚ñ™ as ≈øuch, precedence is always given him and his amba≈ø≈øadors: he is the ≈øupreme head of the German empire; but his powe ‚Ä¢ in the admini≈øtration thereof is very limited indeed. In ancient times. the emperor had con≈øiderable domains and incomes; but warfare and prodigality have di≈ø≈øipated the greate≈øt part of them, and they have been ≈øucce≈ø≈øively alienated or mortgaged, ≈øo that his revenues were very incon≈øiderable lately, and now, ≈øince the French war, are almo≈øt as nothing.

The pre≈øent emperor FRANCIS found the empire, when he was elected, incumbent with difficulties of the mo≈øt enormous magnitude‚Äîa war on which the exi≈øtence of every monarchy in Europe ≈øeemed to depend, an exhau≈øted trea≈øury, and a di≈øpo≈øition to revolt in a part of his dominions, the Netherlands. At this pre≈øent time, his ≈øituation is, beyond that of every other prince, lamentable:‚Äîalmo≈øt all his re≈øources gone, and an in≈øolent, formidable, triumphant enemy, proceeding and carrying conque≈øt by rapid ≈øtrides through his country. He called upon his people to ≈øupport him. The ≈øtates of the Netherlands, in≈øtead of a≈ø≈øi≈øting him to ≈øtop the progre≈øs of the enemy, invited and opened their gates to them, put them in their bo≈øom, and were ≈øtung. Of the other ≈øtates, ≈øome refu≈øe their aid, while ≈øome have recour≈øe to feeble expedients; and, to evade the weight, tempori≈øe, procra≈øtinate, and ≈øhuffle, till at length will come the French army, and force them to do for their enemy ten times more than (if done timely, and with a good grace) might ≈øave the empire and them≈øelves. The KING of PRUSSIA, one of tho≈øe ≈øtates, on being called upon, ≈øays he is bu≈øily employed in ≈øecuring the plunder of Poland, and cannot come‚Äîwhile the tyger is glutting in the blood of the harmle≈øs flocks, the
hunt≈ømen are coming upon him, to cut him off. As an Engli≈øhman, zealous for the welfare of my country, I wi≈øh the KING of PRUSSIA may not, by his attention to Poland, ≈øacrifice all Germany to the French. As an hone≈øt man, I cannot help entertaining a wi≈øh, that the ≈øcandalous and outrageous wrongs done to Poland, and this treachery to the allies whom he him≈øelf brought into the pre≈øent difficulties, may be expiated by any calamity, however great, that does not extend to the intere≈øt or wellbeing of Europe.

It is a maxim in courts of equity, that a man coming to demand redre≈øs, ≈øhould come with clean hands, and, ≈øeeking equity, ≈øhould do equity. This maxim has unfortunately never yet extended to deci≈øions between ≈øtates: power is their right, and force decides‚ÄîYet, in a conte≈øt like the pre≈øent, the very foundation of which is ho≈øtility to kings, and which is carried on in the twofold way of arms, in the open field, and private negociation for in≈øurrection; when, for the intere≈øt of the cau≈øe they e≈øpou≈øe, as well as their own per≈øonal ≈øafety, kings ≈øhould a≈ø≈øume at once their be≈øt form to appreciate them≈øelves, and di≈øcredit their enemies in the eyes of mankind‚Äîin ≈øuch a ≈øtate of things, I ≈øay, for the KING of PRUSSIA and the EMPRESS of RUSSIA to take the part they have done with regard to Poland, is ≈øo extravagant, that we can only account for it in the will of the ALMIGHTY predi≈øpo≈øing them for ≈øome extraordinary cri ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s. No one would expect them to depart from their accu≈øtomed crooked path of policy, if ≈øafety did not loudly call upon them to proceed in the direct road. It is mon≈øtrous to ≈øee beings endowed with common ≈øen≈øe, expending them≈øelves in an unju≈øt ≈øtruggle for aggrandizement, while the ≈øword of extinction is ≈øu≈øpended by a hair over their heads.

But to return‚Äîin this ≈øtate is the young emperor at this moment, de≈øerted by his people in the Low Countries, unaided by his Continental ally, and ≈øupported only by Great Britain. What the i≈ø≈øue may be, GOD alone can tell: but every one po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing a heart of feeling, or a ≈øingle ≈øentiment of honour or ju≈øtice, mu≈øt wi≈øh that young prince a fortunate delivery from the difficulties which the impolicy and wickedne≈øs of others have led him into, and which the treachery of ≈øome of them make more formidable, if not utterly in≈øuperable.

div.head: LETTER XV.
div.p:
THE various di≈øtricts or territories into which Germany is divided, go under a variety of de≈øignations, not known among us as independent titles to power‚Äîprincipalities, ≈øeigniories, counties, electorates, margravates, and bi≈øhoprics lay and ≈øpiritual. Of the lay bi≈øhoprics, O≈ønaburg, the prince bi≈øhop of which is our DUKE of YORK, makes one: and Liege, where we are now arrived is the territory of a bi≈øhop lay and ≈øpiritual, or ≈øpiritual and temporal, one of the faire≈øt kind of that cla≈øs ‚Äîfor he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes temporalities, and enjoys them; whereas their lord≈øhips merely ≈øpiritual, enjoy and have the ingratitude and impudence to renounce them: but no matter for that; the bi≈øhop of Liege po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes a bi≈øhopric, fruitful in corn, wine, wood, and pa≈øture, with air extremely plea≈øant and temperate; and while the latter gives his terre≈øtrial clay health and appetite, the former afford him the means of pre≈øerving the one, and indulging the other, with true ≈øpiritual comfort, and high eccle≈øia≈øtical voluptuou≈øne≈øs. In ca≈øes of repletion, too,
the mineral waters of the bi≈øhopric, particularly the well-known one of Spa, offer their aid; and ≈øome of the be≈øt beer in the world, which is brewed in the≈øe territories diver≈øifies his ≈øpiritual Lord≈øhip's cup, and, with its pungent bitter, ≈øends back his palate to his wine with renovated reli≈øh.

It is a≈øtoni≈øhing how incon≈øi≈øtent with them≈øelves, and how di≈øcordant in their con≈øtituent principles, ≈øome very wi≈øe in≈øtitutions are. Thus epi≈øcopacy, and all other branches, po≈øts or ranks, high or low, commi≈ø≈øioned or non-commi≈ø≈øioned, of the church, publicly and ≈øy≈øtematically profe≈øs poverty, ab≈øtinence, and an utter indifference to temporal concerns, while their livings are enormous, and, them≈øelves overfed. Nay, ≈øo cautiou≈øly has eccle≈øia≈øtical law provided for that, even in our liberal e≈øtabli≈øhments, that a bi≈øhop, at his in≈øtalment, po≈øitively declares, in the face of GOD, at the holy altar, that he is aver≈øe to being a bi≈øhop‚Äînolo epi≈øcopari ‚ÄîUnder ≈øuch conditions, what mu≈øt not the charity, the conde≈øcen≈øion, the mortifying ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion of a divine be, to ≈øtoop to a bi≈øhopric, and ≈øuffer ≈øuch a heavy load to be heaped upon his back‚Äîagain≈øt his will! A≈ø≈øuredly, the impo≈øing a bi≈øhopric upon him mu≈øt be a great act of violence on his inclinations: for I cannot think it po≈ø≈øible that a Chri≈øtian divine would, in the fir≈øt place, commit the crime of ≈øimony by ≈øeeking preferment, and gaining it by pro≈øtitution; much le≈øs can I believe that he would be guilty, at the holy altar, of a ≈øolemn act of perjury, by ≈øwearing nolo epi≈øcopari, if he was not actually, and bon√¢ fid√™, aver≈øe to a bi≈øhopric.

The bi≈øhop of Liege, however, may be fairly acquitted on the ≈øcore of his temporal half, for the ≈øhare of tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions committed by his ≈øpiritual half. And unque≈øtionably, as a Chri≈øtian divine, he mu≈øt groan in ≈øpiritual humiliation, when he reflects that his title is emblazoned with the gorgeous
vanities of prince of Liege, duke of Bouillon, marquis of Franchemont, count of Looz, &c. Such a ≈øet of proud worldly titles are of them≈øelves ≈øufficient (putting the wine and beer, and repletion, out of the que≈øtion) to annihilate the ≈øpiritual merits of the bi≈øhop, and expunge the grace of GOD from his name here, if not from him≈øelf hereafter.

Of all kinds of ≈ølavery, that nation groans beneath the wor≈øt, which has the name, without the e≈ø≈øence, of a free con≈øtitution; and Germany abounds with ≈øuch. By the con≈øtitution of this bi≈øhopric, the government con≈øi≈øts of three ≈øtates, the fir≈øt is the chapter of Liege; the ≈øecond, the nobility; and the third, the deputies of the towns and capital. The≈øe, however, are very ≈øeldom called together, except to rai≈øe taxes, or on ≈øome ≈øuch extraordinary emergency: but there is a committee of the ≈øtates who meet three times a-week, and in time of war daily; they are always about the prince bi≈øhop, to make remon≈øtrances, and demand the redre≈øs of grievances‚Äîfrom whence we may rea≈øonably infer, that the people are well protected, or at lea≈øt well governed; the continual intercour≈øe between the committee and bi≈øhops, no doubt, tending to promote a very happy influence in favour of the people!

In forming this con≈øtitution, ≈øpecial care has been taken to give the fir≈øt ≈øtate a great preponderance. The chapter is to con≈øi≈øt of ≈øixty per≈øons, who mu≈øt either prove their nobility for four generations, both by father and mother, or have been doctors or licentiates of divinity for ≈øeven years, or of law for five years, in ≈øome famous univer≈øity, before they can be admitted.

How is it that the profe≈ø≈øion of the law ≈øhould bear ≈øuch potent ≈øway in almo≈øt all countries‚Äîthat even in Liege, a Catholic country and eccle≈øia≈øtical government, five years ≈øtudy of the law ≈øhould be deemed an equal qualification of ≈øeven of divinity?
In England, and its dependencies, the a≈øcendancy of the law is ≈øtill greater; and even in America, that profe≈ø≈øion is the fir≈øt ≈øtep to ≈øtate honours. The truth is, that the ≈øcience of the law, which, however de≈øpicable in practice, is the noble≈øt of human ≈øciences, quickens and invigorates the under≈øtanding more than all the other kinds of learning put together; while the ≈øtudy of divinity (I do not mean real divinity or morality, but that whim≈øical jumble of miracles and incongruities, of ful≈øome cant and ≈øen≈øele≈øs rhap≈øody, called ≈øo by churchmen) contracts the under≈øtanding, and bends it into a kind of crooked cunning. Formerly, the clergy were the di≈øpen≈øers of the laws, and they alone ≈øtudied it‚ÄîHappy times! happy people! When the united powers of both lawyers and prie≈øts were lodged in the ≈øame per≈øon, it is no wonder that they were able to en≈ølave the per≈øons, when they had got po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the under≈øtanding, of the people‚Äîthat we at this day ≈øee ≈øo many ≈øtupendous monuments remaining of their pride and power, and that the bloated load of epi≈øcopacy ≈øtill has its votaries and ≈øupporters.

The bi≈øhopric of Liege is very populous and exten≈øive, containing many large towns, many baronies and ≈øeigniories, ≈øeventeen abbeys for men, who mu≈øt be all gentlemen, and eleven for ladies, exclu≈øive of ≈øwarms of inferior note. In this di≈øtribution of the abbeys, male and female, I do not think that ≈øufficient regard has been had to equality of numbers: I really think the fathers have been ill u≈øed. The ladies, though, I dare ≈øay, are well enough contented with the arrangement.

Although, as I have already apprized you, I do not mean to enter into a minute de≈øcription of towns, ≈øo very ea≈øily found in many volumes of geography and hi≈øtory, there occa≈øionally occur certain curio≈øities in ≈øome of tho≈øe towns, which it would be unpardonable in me to pa≈øs over, as they
may not perhaps be found in ≈øuch books of tho≈øe ≈øciences as fall in your way.

Liege, the capital of the bi≈øhopric, is unque≈øtionably a beautiful city, of immen≈øe ≈øize: its opulence, its plea≈øantne≈øs, its plenty, and ≈øalubrity, may be calculated from the name it has long been expre≈øsly called by way of eminence‚Äîthe Paradi≈øe of Prie≈øts.‚ÄîIndeed, it mu≈øt needs be a holy and happy city; for it is chiefly occupied with convents, churches, and other religious foundations.

The Paradi≈øe of Prie≈øts!‚ÄîExcellent! Why, if the genius of ≈øen≈øuality him≈øelf were to torture his invention for centuries, to ≈øtrike out an appellation for the grand emporium of luxury, voluptuou≈øne≈øs, and ≈øen≈øual enjoyment, he could not have hit on one ≈øo ≈øingularly appropriate as the Paradi≈øe of Prie≈øts.

In a grand cathedral here, are five great ≈øilver che≈øts full of reliques, be≈øides ≈øeveral ≈øilver ≈øtatues of ≈øaints; and a Saint GEORGE on hor≈øeback, of ma≈ø≈øy gold; and in Saint WILLIAM'S Convent, without the city, is the tomb of the famous Engli≈øh traveller, Sir JOHN MANDEVILLE, from whom all lying travellers have been ≈øince proverbially called Mandevilles‚Äîan appellation which, I promi≈øe you, I will hazard the imputation of dulne≈øs rather than incur. I ≈øuppo≈øe it was for his truly prie≈øtlike powers in the marvellous that he was honoured with a birth among their reverences. They have thought it nece≈ø≈øary, however, to entreat, by an in≈øcription in bad French, all per≈øons who ≈øee it, to pray for his ≈øoul. In truth, poor Sir JOHN'S marvellous ≈øtories were as harmle≈øs as ever were invented, and entertaining to boot. If ≈øo much could be ≈øaid for their reverences, they might venture to re≈øt their future ≈øafety on their own innocence and GOD'S mercy: but I fear their miracles cut deeper, and will be found to go to a much more important and ≈øerious account.

In the bi≈øhopric of Liege, twenty miles from the capital, ≈øtands the famous town of Spa. ≈øo renowned for its excellent waters, that it has become a vulgar name for almo≈øt all mineral waters what≈øoever. Tho≈øe are ≈øaid to open ob≈øtructions, concoct crudities, dry up exce≈ø≈øive moi≈øture, and ≈øtrengthen the nerves and bowels; and ≈øuch is their reputation, that prodigious quantities of them are carried into foreign countries.
Fortunate coincidence, to have ≈øuch a choice and ea≈øy panacea for intemperance attached to the Paradi≈øe of Prie≈øts!

div.head: LETTER XVI.
div.p: AIX-LA-CHAPELLE‚ÄîThe imperial city of Aix-la-Chapelle, by the Germans called Achen, lies at the di≈øtance of twenty-≈øix miles, nearly ea≈øt, of Liege. As it was a moderate ≈øtage, the weather fine, and the face of the country around beautiful, I found my journey extremely plea≈øant, and entered that famous city in as good a di≈øpo≈øition to be plea≈øed with it, as circum≈øtances and reflections ≈øo melancholy as mine (which, in ≈øpite of every effort, would intrude them≈øelves) may be ≈øuppo≈øed to allow. It is certainly a very fine city, and well de≈øerves the reputation it has in all parts of the world.

Perhaps no city in Germany has a fairer claim to antiquity than Aix-la-Chapelle; for it was famous, even, in the time of the ancient Romans‚ñ™ for its waters, and was by them called Aqua≈øgranum, or Urbs Aqu ‚Ä¢ n≈øus. It was de≈øtroyed by the H ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, who, like the French now, de≈øtroyed and tr ‚Ä¢ mpled under foot every ve≈øtige of refinement, wherever
they carried their conque≈øts; and it lay in ruins till it was rebuilt by CHARLEMAGNE, who made it the ≈øeat of his empire on this ≈øide of the Alps. By him it was ordained, the kings of the Romans ≈øhould be crowned there: and it has been famous, ≈øince that time, for councils and treaties, particularly that famous one between France and Spain in 1663, and another lately between France and Great Britain.

Although there are many Prote≈øtants, both Lutherans and Calvini≈øts, in this city, they are obliliged to go to church two miles off, at a place called Vaels, in the dutchy of Limburg; ≈øo that Popery prevails with ≈øome portion of its intolerance. Here, as in all other places ≈øubject to its power, it has rai≈øed the Gothic gloomy pile, accumulated enormous ma≈ø≈øes of wealth, and hoarded up trea≈øures, under the gulling pretexts of religious paraphernalia: a golden ca≈øket, ≈øet with precious ≈øtones of ine≈øtimable value, is hoarded up, not for the actual value of the moveable, but as the only fit receptacle for a relique it contains‚Äîa curious one, too, even of its kind‚Äîa bit of earth!‚ÄîA bit of earth? yes! a bit of earth, common earth!‚Äîonly with this fortunate circum≈øtance in addition, that a drop of the blood of Saint STEPHEN fell, or is ≈øaid to have fallen, upon it, as he was ≈øtoned to death! think of that, ma≈øter FREDERICK! But, to carry the matter farther, when we recollect that ≈øome of the wi≈øe≈øt and brighte≈øt of mankind, ≈øome of the brave≈øt warriors, ≈øterne≈øt philo≈øophers, and able≈øt ≈øtate≈ømen, that ever exi≈øted, have been the dupes of tho≈øe ≈øhallow artificers, and actually have knelt in devout homage

We have already had, and are likely yet to have ≈øuch a clum≈øy load of cathedrals to attend to, that I ≈øhould not mention that of Aix-la-Chapelle (a large, gloomy, dreary, old-fa≈øhioned, Gothic pile), were i ‚Ä¢ not that it carries along with it ≈øome matters worthy of notice. But where, I hear you a≈øk‚Äîwhere, in the name of GOD, collect the bi≈øhops? a pope and emperor are ea≈øily had! My dear FREDERICK, three hundred and ≈øixty-five bi≈øhops might ea≈øily be picked up in Chri≈øtendom, and leave more behind, too, than would ≈øerve any u≈øeful purpo≈øe to the world.‚ÄîYes, the Emperor CHARLEMAGNE, and three hundred and ≈øixty-five bi≈øhops, were pre≈øent at the con≈øecration of this cathedral by Pope LEO the Third. That emperor lies now in great ≈øtate under the altar of the choir: Pope LEO rots in Rome; and for the bi≈øhops, they are gone, perhaps, as Hamlet ≈øays, "to ≈øtop a beer barrel."‚Äî

Might ≈øtop a hole, to keep the wind away‚ñ™"

div.p:
From ≈øuch a ≈øplendid and opulent attendance at the con≈øecration, one would naturally expect that this cathedral would have been, at the very outlet, enriched with co≈øtly and valuable trappings: but no‚Äîone image of that of Liege would purcha≈øe the whole. It ≈øhould be recollected, however, that they were all, excepting the emperor, Churchmen ‚Äîa cla≈øs, who≈øe charity, generally ≈øpeaking, has, like a ring, neither end nor beginning; or at lea≈øt
ends and begins in it≈øelf, where nobody can ≈øee it; or, according to the old proverb, begins at home.

To compen≈øate, however, for tho≈øe worldly, worthle≈øs vanities, gold, ≈øilver, and jewels, his Holine≈øs, and their three hundred and ≈øixty-five Graces, pre≈øented the cathedral with ≈øome exqui≈øite pieces of relique, of more ine≈øtimable value, by their account, than the mines of Poto≈øi or Golconda: the fir≈øt, an old covering‚Äîit would be folly for me to ≈øay, whether gown, petticoat, or ≈øhift‚Äî but they, that is to ≈øay, the prie≈øts, ≈øay, and the faithful believe them, that it was the ≈øhift worn by the Virgin MARY at the birth of CHRIST‚Äîhow their Holine≈ø≈øes came by it, is hard to conjecture: ‚Äîin the next place, a piece of coar≈øe cloth, which, they al≈øo ≈øay, and are believed when they ≈øay, was girt about CHRIST on the cro≈øs: thirdly, a piece of cord, with which they ≈øay he was bound:‚Äî fourthly, ≈øome of the blood of Saint STEPHEN, now eighteen hundred years old;‚Äîand, fifthly, a picture of the Virgin and Child, embo≈ø≈øed on a j ‚Ä¢ ≈øper, by Saint LUKE. With all due deference to their Reverences' knowledge, I ≈øhould think a dozen ≈øtatues in gold of the apo≈øtles would be rather a more valuable gift, and more ornamental, than the≈øe rags and cords, which I dare ≈øay did not co≈øt altogether ≈øix pence. We talk here of our blue ribbons, our red ribbons, and our ≈øtars as great donations; but I think the pre≈øents of the Pope and three hundred and ≈øixty-five bi≈øhops to the cathedral of Aix-la-Chapelle, beat them out of the field, whether we con≈øider the magnificence of the gift, or the genero≈øity of the givers.

But that which, above all things, renders Aix-la-Chapelle worthy of notice, is the ≈øalubrity of its waters, which bring from England, and all other European nations, a va≈øt concour≈øe of valetudinarians, who contribute at once to the gaiety and opulence of the city and adjacent country. Some
of tho≈øe waters are u≈øed for drinking, and others for bathing, re≈øembling very much, in their quality, the virtues of tho≈øe of Bath in Somer≈øet≈øhire, but that ≈øome of them are ≈øtill hotter and ≈øtronger: they are unplea≈øant to the ta≈øte till u≈øe reconciles the palate to them, and mo≈øt of them have a very offen≈øive ≈ømell; but they are often powerful in effect, and give relief in a great variety of maladies; and they are rendered ≈øtill more palatable by the commodious neatne≈øs of the baths, the excellence of the accommodations, and the great plenty of provi≈øions, which are at once good and rea≈øonable in this city.

I ≈øtaid to ≈øhort a time at Aix-la-Chapelle, that I could not, without the aid of ≈øome of the miracles wrought by the ≈øaints of the Romi≈øh church, or Sir JOHN MANDEVILLE, acquire a ≈øufficient knowledge of the people, to attempt a de≈øcription of them, or their manners‚Äîbut it and Spa are ≈øo well known, that you cannot have much trouble in finding a de≈øcription of them already written.

div.head: LETTER XVII.
div.p: BIDDING adieu to the famous city of Aix-la-Chapelle, which, very untraveller-like, I pa≈ø≈øed without drinking of its waters. I pu≈øhed on, and ≈øoon arrived at the city of Juliers, the capital of a dutchy of that name, ≈øixteen miles from Aix. The country it≈øelf is wonderfully fruitful, teeming with abundance of all ≈øorts of corn, wood, pa≈øture, woad, coal, and cattle; above all, a mo≈øt excellent breed of hor≈øes, of which great numbers are exported.

As to the city, though a capital, there was nothing in it that I thought worth attention‚Äîthat of neatne≈øs is its greate≈øt prai≈øe. It is not, like Liege, overloaded with enormous church edifices; but, what is much better, the people are opulent, the poor well ≈øupplied, and all happy. In all likelihood, this is owing to the inhabitants being a mixture of Prote≈øtant and Roman Catholic; for, by a treaty between the Elector Palatine and the Emperor of Brandenburg, re≈øpecting the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of the territories of the Duke of Cleves, both the Lutherans and Calvini≈øts of this dutchy, and of Berg, are to enjoy the public exerci≈øe of their religion, and all other religious rites.

If experience would allow us to wonder at any thing in the management of the rulers of nations, it mu≈øt ≈øurely be matter of a≈øtoni≈øhment, that in an article of ≈øuch con≈øequence as eternity, and which mu≈øt be directed by private ≈øentiments alone, ≈øuch violence ≈øhould ≈øy≈øtematically be offered to opinion, and that mankind ≈øhould be dragooned, as they have been for ≈øo many weary centuries, into
the profe≈ø≈øion of particular modes of faith. Combating opinion by force is ≈øo ab≈øurd, that I am ≈øure tho≈øe who attempted it, never could flatter them≈øelves with the ≈øl ‚Ä¢ ghte≈øt hopes of ≈øucce≈øs. It is therefore clear, that it was in motives very different from real wi≈øhes for the eternal welfare of man's ≈øoul, that religious per≈øecution originated. Political fine≈ø≈øe and ≈øtate ≈øtratagem are the parents of per≈øecution: and until every con≈øtitution is clean purged of religious prejudices, it mu≈øt continue to be clogged with ob≈øtructions, and involved in confu≈øion. If it be objected that certain religious ≈øects are ho≈øtile to certain ≈øtates, it may be an≈øwered, that they are ≈øo becau≈øe the ≈øtate is ho≈øtile to them. Cea≈øe to per≈øecute, and they will cea≈øe to be ho≈øtile ‚ÄîSublata cau≈øa tollitur effectus. It is folly, broad folly, to ≈øuppo≈øe that there are in any particular religion, ≈øeeds of ho≈øtility to government, any more than in any particular name, complexion, ≈øtature, or colour of the hair. Put, for experiment, all the men in the kingdom, of above five feet ten inches high, under te≈øts and di≈øqualifications, (and it would be full as rational as any other te≈øts)‚Äîand, my life for it, they would become ho≈øtile‚ñ™ and very ju≈øtly, too; for there is no principle, human or divine, that enforces our attachment to that government which refu≈øes us protection, much le≈øs to that which brands us with di≈øqualifications, and ≈øtigmati≈øes us with unmerited marks of inferiority.

The ≈øtates of this dutchy, and that of Berg, con≈øi≈øt of the nobility and the deputies of the four chief towns of each; and they lay claim to great privileges in their diets‚Äîbut they are ≈øubject to the Elector Palatine, to whom they annually grant a certain ≈øum for the ordinary charges of the government, be≈øides another which bears the name of a free gift.

"Some authors ≈øay that this town was founded by JULIUS; others deny it; the di≈øpute has run high, and is impo≈ø≈øible to be determined: fortunately, however, for mankind, it does not ≈øignify a ≈øtraw who built it; nor could the deci≈øion of the que≈øtion an≈øwer any one end that I know, of in≈øtruction, profit, or entertainment. Parva leves capiunt animos. Tho≈øe who rack their brains, or rather their heads, for brains they can have none, with ≈øuch finical impertinent inquiries, ≈øhould be puni≈øhed with mortification and di≈øappointment, for the mi≈øu≈øe of their time. But what el≈øe can they do? You ≈øay, Why, yes; they might ≈øit idle, and refrain from wa≈øting paper with ≈øuch execrable ≈øtuff; and that would be better. By the bye, if there were two good friends in every library in Europe, licen≈øed to purge it, like the Barber and Curate in Don Quixotte, of all its u≈øele≈øs and mi≈øchievous ≈øtuff, many, many ≈øhelves that now groan under heavy weights would ≈øtand empty.

Travelling over a very even road, and a country extremely flat, (for from Aix-la-Chapelle I met with but one hill), I arrived at Cologne, the capital, not only of the archbi≈øhopric of that name, but of the Circle of the Lower Rhine. My ≈øpirits, which were not in the very be≈øt tone, were not at all rai≈øed on entering the city, by the ringing of church-bells, of all tones and ≈øizes, in every quarter. Being a ≈øtranger, I thought it had been a rejoicing day; but, on inquiry, found that it was the con≈øtant practice. Never, in my life, had I heard ≈øuch an infernal clatter: never before had I ≈øeen any thing ≈øo gloomy and melancholy‚Äîthe ≈øtreets black‚Äîdi≈ømal bells tolling‚Äîbald-pated friars, in myriads, trailing their long black forms through the ≈øtreets, moulding their faces into every ≈øhape that art had enabled them to a≈ø≈øume, in order to excite commi≈øeration, and begging alms with a melancholy ≈øong calculated for the purpo≈øe, ≈øomewhat like that
of our blind beggars in London, and productive of the ≈øame di≈øagreeable effect upon the ≈øpirits. In ≈øhort, I was not an hour in Cologne, when tho≈øe circum≈øtances, con≈øpiring with the in≈øuperable melancholy of my mind, made me wi≈øh my≈øelf out of it.

Neverthele≈øs, Cologne is a fine city; and if it be any ≈øatisfaction to you to ≈øpin tho≈øe fine imaginary ligaments that, in the brain of the book-worm, connect the ancient and modern world, I will inform you, that it was anciently called Colonia Agrippina, becau≈øe AGRIPPINA, the mother of NERO, was born there, and honored it with a Roman colony, becau≈øe it was her birth-place. The mind, forced back to that period, and contemplating the mi≈øchiefs of that mon≈øter NERO, cannot help wi≈øhing that Cologne had been burnt the nigth of her birth, and Mi≈øs AGRIPPINA buried in the ruins, ere ≈øhe had lived to give birth to that ≈øcourge of the world.

Although the e≈øtabli≈øhed religion here be the Roman Catholic, extraordinary as it may appear, they are very jealous of power; and though the elector, by his officers, admini≈øters ju≈øtice in all criminal cau≈øes, they will not permit him, in per≈øon, to re≈øide above three days at a time in the city, nor to bring a great train with him when he vi≈øits it; for this rea≈øon he commonly re≈øides at Bonne.
Cologne has a very con≈øiderable trade, particularly in Rheni≈øh wine; and its gin is reckoned the be≈øt in the world, and bears a higher price than any other in all the nations of Europe.

Like all great Roman Catholic cities, it has a profu≈øion of churches, cro≈ø≈øes, miracles, ≈øaints, and church trinkets; and I really think it has more ≈øteeples and bells than any two cities in Germany. As Liege was called the Paradi≈øe of Prie≈øts, this ought to be called the Golgotha of Skulls and Skull-caps. In the church of Saint URSULA, they ≈øhew, or pretend at lea≈øt to ≈øhew, the bones of
eleven thou≈øand virgin martyrs. The ≈økulls of ≈øome of tho≈øe imaginary virgins are in ≈øilver ca≈øes, and others in ≈økull-caps, of cloth, of gold, and velvet. And in the church of Saint GERION, are no le≈øs than nine hundred heads of Moori≈øh cavaliers, of the army of the Emperor CONSTANTINE, (previous to that ≈øaint's conver≈øion to Chri≈øtianity), who they ≈øay was beheaded for refu≈øing to ≈øacrifice to idols: by the bye, the Popi≈øh divines burn, in≈øtead of beheading, for not ≈øacrificing to idols‚ÄîEvery one of tho≈øe heads, however, has a cap of ≈øcarlet, adorned with pearls. The whole forms a ≈øpectacle no doubt equally agreeable and edifying. It ≈øtruck me, however, as an extremely ludicious ≈øight, malg ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the ≈øolemnity of ≈øo many death's he ‚Ä¢ ds: and when their ≈øtory was recounted, I could not help internally chuckling, and ≈øaying (rather punningly, to be „Äà‚óä„Äâ ). "Ah! what blockheads ye mu≈øt have been, to ≈øuffer your≈øelves to be ≈øeparated from your ≈ønug warm bodies, rather than drop down and wor≈øhip an idol, in which ≈øo many good Chri≈øtian divines have ≈øhewn you an example!" This, you will conclude, I ≈øaid to my≈øelf: an avowal of my ≈øentiments in that place might have given my head a title to a ≈øcarlet cap and pearls; and as I had ≈øome further u≈øe for it, I did not think it expedient to leave it behind me in the church of Saint GERION ‚Äî≈øo, very prudently, kept my mind to my≈øelf.

Coming out of the church, a multitude of beggars, all in canonicals, or ≈øtudent's habits, ≈øurrounded, be≈øeeching me for alms‚Äîone, pour l'amour de DIEU; another, pour l'amour de la Sainte Vierge; a third, pour le ≈øalut de no ‚Ä¢ e Redempteur; a fourth, pour l'amour de Saint GERION; and ≈øo on!

When I had gone as far as I wi≈øhed in donations, another attacked me: though I told him my charity-bank was exhau≈øted, he per≈øevered, and was uncommonly ≈øolicitous‚Äîtill at length, having exhau≈øted
the whole catalogue of ≈øaints that are to be found in the calendar, he rai≈øed his voice from the mi≈øerable whine of petition, and exclaimed with great energy, "Par les neuf cent tetes des Cavaliers Maures qui ≈øont ≈øantifies au Ciel, je vous conjure de me faire l'aumone!" This was too formidable an appeal to be ≈ølighted; and ≈øo, in homage to the ≈økulls and red caps, I put my hand in my pocket, and ≈øtopped his clamours.

Tho≈øe mi≈øerable modes of peculation are the mo≈øt pardonable of any produced by the church: we have no right to regret a trifle ≈øacrificed at the ≈øhrine of compa≈ø≈øion, even when that compa≈ø≈øion is mi≈øtaken; but our rea≈øon revolts at impo≈øition, when it calls coercion to its aid, and a≈ø≈øumes the name of right.

Without any national predilection, which you know I am above, I think our church affairs in Scotland are arranged upon a better ≈øy≈øtem than any other that I know of: hence their clergy are in general examples worthy of imitation, for learning, piety, and moral conduct.

div.head: LETTER XVIII.
div.p:
LABOURED inve≈øtigations to e≈øtabli≈øh connections between the hi≈øtory of the ancient and bu≈øine≈øs of the modern world, and virulent di≈øputes about trifles of antiquity, ≈øuch as in what year this place was built, or that great man was born, when and where JULIUS CAESAR landed in England, whether he pa≈ø≈øed this road or that, what route HANNIBAL took over the Alps. and ≈øuch like, are ≈øo e≈ø≈øentially unintere≈øting, u≈øele≈øs, and unimportant, ≈øo unprofitable, and, one would think, ≈øo
painful too‚ñ™ that it is wonderful how ≈øo many men of great learning have been unwi≈øe enough to employ their lives in the re≈øearch.

It does not follow, however, that when information that tends to recall to our minds the great men of antiquity is pre≈øented to us, we ≈øhould reject it. A man of cla≈ø≈øical ta≈øte and education feels a delight in tho≈øe little memorials of what gave him plea≈øure in his youth. I know a gentleman, who, being at Seville; in Spain, travelled to Cordova, for no other purpo≈øe but to ≈øee the town where LUCAN and SENECA were born: and I dare ≈øay, that if you were at Cologne, you would be much plea≈øed to ≈øee the town-hou≈øe, a great Gothic building, which, contains a variety of ancient in≈øcriptions; the fir≈øt to commemorate the kindne≈øs of JULIUS CAESAR to the Ubii, who inhabited this place, and of whom you have found mention made by him in his Commentaries, and al≈øo his building two wooden bridges over the Rhine: a ≈øecond commemorates AUGUSTUS ≈øending a colony here. There is al≈øo a cro≈øs-bow of whalebone, twelve feet long, eight broad, and four inches thick, which they who ≈øpeak of it conjecture to have belonged to the Emperor MAXIMIN. There are al≈øo ≈øome Roman in≈øcriptions in the ar≈øenal, the import of which I now forget.

It is very extraordinary, but certainly a fact, that there are, about Cologne, families yet exi≈øting, who indulge the ≈øen≈øele≈øs ambition of pretending to be de≈øcended from the ancient Romans, and who actually produce their genealogies, carried down from the fir≈øt time this city was made a colony of the Roman empire. Of all kinds of vanity, this is perhaps the mo≈øt extravagant; for, if antiquity merely be the object, all are equally high, ≈øince all mu≈øt have originated from the ≈øame ≈øtock; and if it be the pride of belonging to a particular family who were di≈øtingui≈øhed for valour or virtue, a claim which often only ≈øerves to prove the degeneracy of
the claimant, it could not apply in the ca≈øe of a whole people: but this is among the frailties of humanity; and we are often ≈øo dazzled with the ≈øplendour of terre≈øtrial glory, that we endeavour to be allied to it even by the mo≈øt remote and ridiculous connections. I heard of a man, who≈øe pride and boa≈øt, when drunk, was, that Dean SWIFT had once thrown his mother's oy≈øters (≈øhe was an oy≈øter-wench) about the ≈øtreet, and then gave her half a crown as an atonement for the injury. On the ≈øtrength of this affinity did he call the Dean nothing but Cou≈øin Jonathan, though the Dean was dead before he was born!

But of all the ≈øtories I have ever heard as illu≈øtrative of this ≈øtrange ambition, that which the late Lord ANSON has left us is the mo≈øt ≈øtriking. When that great man was travelling in the Ea≈øt‚ñ™ he hired a ve≈ø≈øel to vi≈øit the i≈øland of Tenedos‚ñ™ his pilot, a modern Greek, pointing to a bay as they ≈øailed along, exclaimed in great triumph, "There, ‚Ä¢ ay, there it was that our fleet lay."‚Äî"What fleet?" interrogated ANSON‚Äî"Why, our Grecian fleet, at the ≈øiege of Troy," returned the pilot.

While tho≈øe doughty de≈øcendants of the ancient Romans indulge the cheerle≈øs idea of their great and illu≈øtrious line of ancient ance≈øtry, the prince who rules them felicitates him≈øelf with the more ≈øub≈øtantial dignities and emoluments of his modern offices. As elector and archbi≈øhop of Cologne, he has dominion over a large, fruitful, and opulent country: he is the mo≈øt powerful of the eccle≈øia≈øtical electors: he has many ≈øuffragan princes, lay and ≈øpiritual, under him: and he is archchancellor of the Holy Roman Empire. The revenues of his archbi≈øhopric amount annually to one hundred and thirty thou≈øand pounds Sterling; and as elector, he is po≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øed of ≈øeveral other great benefices. I pre≈øume, becau≈øe he is a prince, that he is a man of ≈øen≈øe; and, I will venture to ≈øay, that, as ≈øuch, he
would not barter tho≈øe good things for the power to demon≈øtrate that LUCRETIA was his aunt, BRUTUS his grandfather, and the great JULIUS CAESAR him≈øelf his cou≈øin-german.

CHRIST cho≈øe his di≈øciples out of fi≈øhermen. The Chapter of Cologne is, perhaps, on the contrary, the very mo≈øt ari≈øtocratic body exi≈øting, being compo≈øed of forty canons, who are princes or counts of the empire‚ÄîOf tho≈øe, twenty-five choo≈øe the archbi≈øhop, and many advance one of their own body to that great and wealthy dignity, if they plea≈øe.

From Cologne I proceeded to the town of Bonne, which is ≈øaid to take its name from the plea≈øantne≈øs of its ≈øituation. Here the elector re≈øides, and has a very fine palace. The country around is extremely fruitful and plea≈øant, and is ble≈ø≈øed with mo≈øt of the good things which render the rich magnificent and happy, and remind the poor of their inferiority and wretchedne≈øs‚Äîparticularly wine, which is here remarkably excellent. It contains churches, prie≈øts, convents, cloi≈øters, &c.; but I need not mention them‚Äîwhat place could exi≈øt without them?

I ≈øhould not forget to tell you, that, at this place, JULIUS CAESAR built one of his bridges acro≈øs the Rhine‚Äîworks which would have handed down to po≈øterity the name of a common man, for the magnitude of the ≈øtructure and ingenuity of the contrivance, but are lo≈øt in the crowd of a≈øtoni≈øhing talents which di≈øtingui≈øhed that brighte≈øt of morals. The greate≈øt biographer of antiquity ≈øays of him, that he was as great a general as HANNIBAL, as great an orator as CICERO, and as great a politician as AUGUSTUS; but it might be added, that he was among the fir≈øt poets of his day‚Äîthat he was of the fir≈øt mechanical genius, and the fine≈øt gentleman, in Rome.

Nature ≈øeems to have formed, in CAESAR, a compendious union of all human talents, as if to demon≈øtrate
how unavailing they were when oppo≈øed to ≈øtrict rigid hone≈øty and virtue in the character of BRUTUS.

To go from Bonne to Frankfort, there are two ways‚Äîone over the mountains of Wetterania, the other up the river Rhine. I made no he≈øitation to adopt the latter, and was rewarded for my choice with the view of as ≈øine a country, inhabited by as fine a race of people, as I had ever ≈øeen. Valleys filled with herds, plains enamelled with corn-fields, and the hills covered with vineyards, regaled the eye, and conveyed to the mind all the felicitating ideas of plenty, natural opulence, and true pro≈øperity. My anxiety, however, to get forward, and di≈øengage my≈øelf from a ≈øpecies of ≈øolitude in a country where, though travelling is cheap, accommodations of mo≈øt kinds in the public hou≈øes are bad, induced me to pu≈øh on, without taking the time nece≈ø≈øary for making accurate ob≈øervations on the country as I pa≈ø≈øed; ≈øo that, gliding, as it were, imperceptibly, through a number of towns, of which I recollect nothing di≈øtinctly but the names of Coblentz and Mentz, I arrived at the great, free, and imperial city of Frankfort on the Maine.

Here I ≈øhall ≈øtop, for a ≈øhort time, my relation, in order to give you time for ju≈øt reflection and examination of what I have already written: and as, in the latter part of it, I have ≈økimmed very lightly over the country, I de≈øire that you will ≈øupply the deficiency of my information by clo≈øe re≈øearch in books; inform your≈øelf of the great outlines of the Germanic Con≈øtitution; look back to its origin, its progre≈øs, and its e≈øtabli≈øhment; thence proceed to the di≈øtrict parts, or inferior ≈øtates, of which it is compo≈øed; ponder them all well; and from tho≈øe draw your own inferences, and let me hear what they are with freedom: ≈øhould they be wrong, I will endeavour to ≈øet them right; but ≈øhould they be right, they will afford me the mo≈øt lively ≈øatisfaction;
for they will ≈øerve to correct one of the greate≈øt errors under which youth labours‚Äîan over-weening, ≈øanguine imagination, that things in this life are, or at lea≈øt can be modelled into perfection; whereas experience, and a ju≈øt ob≈øervation of the hi≈øtory of mankind, will ≈øhew, that on this ball things will never be as they ought, but mu≈øt remain as they are‚Äîimperfect.

div.head: LETTER XIX.
div.p: THE country about Frankfort is delightful, rich and fruitful, and watered by the beautiful river Maine, which divides the city into two parts, that on the north being called Frankfort, and that on the ≈øouth, Saxenhau≈øen, from the Saxons, who are ≈øuppo≈øed to have been the founders of it. The city it≈øelf is large, populous, and rich, and di≈øtingui≈øhed for being the place where the emperor and king of the Romans is elected‚Äîthough, by the appointment of CHARLEMAGNE, Cologne has a ≈øuperior claim to that honor. The magi≈øtrates, and great part of the inhabitants, are Lutherans or Calvini≈øts; notwith≈øtanding which, mo≈øt of the churches are in the hands of the Roman Catholics‚Äîa laudable in≈øtance of the true tolerant ≈øpirit of a wi≈øe and virtuous in≈øtitution, and a heavy reflection upon, as well as a noble example to the Popi≈øh Powers of Europe.

The territory belonging to Frankfort is of very con≈øiderable extent; and the trade carried on through it, by means of the rivers Rhine and Maine, of very great importance, not only to the country it≈øelf, but to other commercial nations, and particularly to Great Britain, who≈øe manufactures
are ≈øent to Frankfort, and thence circulated through the Continent. in amazing quantities.

The fairs of Frankfort are talked of all over Europe ‚Äîof ≈øuch importance are they in the world of commerce. They are held, one at Ea≈øter, and another in September, and continue for three weeks, during which time the re≈øort of people there from all quarters is a≈øtoni≈øhing. Every thing is done by the government to render them as attractive to merchants as po≈ø≈øible; and taxes or duties are extremely low‚Äîa bale of the value of ten or twenty thou≈øand crowns paying duty only about ten or eleven pence of our money. All commodities from all parts of the world are ≈øold there, and circulated through the empire; but, particularly, books are ≈øold in prodigious quantities. After the fairs are over, the ≈øhops of the foreign merchants are ≈øhut up, and their names written over their doors.

To give an idea of the great importance the≈øe fairs are to commerce, I need only mention, that in the pre≈øent war, the impediments thrown by the French in the way of the tran≈øit of goods up the Rhine, and the ≈øhutting up that fair, gave a mo≈øt alarming paraly≈øis to the manufacturing e≈øtabli≈øhments of England, and a ≈øhock to public credit in con≈øequence, that would, but for the timely interference of Parliament, have, in all probability, been fatal to the national credit.

Frankfort is in many re≈øpects a plea≈øant place: the merchants are extremely convivial and ≈øociable, and form clubs, where they meet to drink tea and coffee, and play at cards. There is a playhou≈øe al≈øo, a great number of coffee-hou≈øes, and other hou≈øes of entertainment in abundance. The country around is covered with woods and vineyards, and the circumjacent villages are very plea≈øant, and well ≈øupplied with hou≈øes of entertainment, to which the inhabitants of the city re≈øort in the
Summer ≈øea≈øon: and the inns in Frankfort are excellent.

A ≈øingular cu≈øtom prevails here, which I think worth mentioning: Taverns are denoted by pinetrees planted before the doors of them; and the different prices of the wines in their cellars are marked in ciphers on the door-po≈øts.

In the town here is pre≈øented the original Golden Bull, or Pope's Authority, which contains the rules and orders to be ob≈øerved at the election of the Emperors. The Golden Bull is never ≈øhown to ≈øtrangers but in the pre≈øence of two of the council and the ‚Ä¢ ecretary‚ÄîIt is a little manu≈øcript in q ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to, con≈øi≈øting of forty-two leaves of parchment, with a gold ≈øeal of three inches diameter, of the value of twenty ducats, hung to it by a cord of yellow ≈øilk. It is ≈øaid to be written in Latin and Gothic characters, without diphthongs; and kept in a black box together with two written tran≈ølations of it into the German language.

It is ≈øaid of Frankfort, that the Roman Catholics po≈ø≈øe≈øs the churches, the Lutherans the dignities, and the Calvini≈øts the riches. It is therefore one of the few places in Chri≈øtendom where the churches and the riches do not go into the ≈øame hands.

From Frankfort to Aug≈øburgh, I pa≈ø≈øed through a number of towns, all of them ≈øo very incon≈øiderable as not to merit any particular de≈øcription. The way lies from the Palatinate though the Circle of Suabia. In the extreme end of the Palatinate, and immediately before entering the Dutchy of Wirtemberg, the country is covered with fir-trees, and money is ≈øo ≈øcarce in it, that a loaf of wheaten bread, weighing eight pounds, co≈øts but two pence.

This city of Aug≈øburgh is the capital of a bi≈øhopric of that name in the Circle of Suabia, and is worthy of the attention of the cla≈ø≈øical traveller for its antiquity. About twelve years before the birth
of CHRIST, AUGUSTUS CAESAR ≈øubdued all this country, and, on the place where Aug≈øburgh now ≈øtands, formed a colony, gave the town the name of Augu≈øta Vindelicorum, and put it under the government of DRUSUS the brother of TIBERIUS, afterwards emperor of Rome. The inhabitants of this place were the Vindelici, a branch of the Illyrians. But, ancient though it be, it has little more of antiquity to entitle it to notice than the bare name; for it has been pillaged ≈øo often, particularly by that mon≈øter ATTILA, that there are ≈øcarcely any remains of its antiquity to be found.
Aug≈øburgh, is now, however a hand≈øome city‚Äî the public buildings in general magnificent, and adorned with fountains, water engines of a curious con≈øtruction, and ≈øtatues.

The mo≈øt rich and ≈øplendid part of the town belongs to a family of the name of FUGGERS (originaly de≈øcended from a weaver), who enriched them≈øelves by commerce, and one of whom rendered not only him≈øelf, but the whole family, con≈øpicuous, by entertaining the emperor CHARLES the Fifth in a ≈øuperb manner, and ≈øupplying him with money, and then throwing his bond into the fire; in return for which, the emperor, made him a count of the empire.

This city is remarkable for gold≈ømiths' ware; and its mechanics are equal to any in the world, for works in gold, ivory, clocks, and time-pieces; and they engrave better than any people in Germany, which brings them con≈øiderable profits. But what they are, above all other people, eminent for, is the manufacturing ≈øteel-chains ≈øo prodigiou≈øly fine, that when one of them, of a ≈øpan in length, has been put about the neck of a flea, it lifts up the whole of it as it leaps; and yet tho≈øe are ≈øold for le≈øs than a ≈øhilling of our money a piece.

Controver≈øy, and difference in rel ‚Ä¢ gious opinions‚ñ™ which has almo≈øt, ever ≈øince the commencement of
Chri≈øtianity, di≈øgraced the human under≈øtanding, and defaced ≈øociety, impo≈øes upon the liberal, well-thinking traveller, the office of ≈øatiri≈øt but too often. Aug≈øburgh, however, is a ≈øplendid exception, and holds up a mo≈øt glorious ≈øpectacle of manly ≈øen≈øe, generous ≈øentiment, ju≈øtice, and I will ≈øay policy too, vanqui≈øhing that ≈øhark-jawed enemy of mankind, bigotry. The magi≈øtracy of Aug≈øburgh is compo≈øed of about an equal number of Prote≈øtants and Roman Catholics‚Äîtheir ≈øenate con≈øi≈øting of twenty-three Roman Catholics and twenty-two Lutherans, and their common Council of a hundred and fifty of each: The executive power is lodged in the ≈øenate‚Äîthe legi≈ølative authority in both bodies. But, what is hardly to be found any where, they all, as well as the people, agree together in the mo≈øt perfect harmony, notwith≈øtanding the difference of religion; and at all tables but the communion table, they a≈ø≈øociate together, dip in the ≈øame di≈øh, and drink of the ≈øame cup, as if they had never heard of the odious di≈øtinction of Papi≈øt and Prote≈øtant, but as being bound to each other by the great and irrefragable bond of humanity: fellow-creatures, affected by the ≈øame feelings, impelled by the ≈øame pa≈ø≈øions, labouring under the ≈øame nece≈ø≈øities, and heirs to the ≈øame ≈øufferings, their means of a≈ø≈øuaging the one, gratifying or re≈øi≈øting another, and ≈øupplying the third, are the ≈øame, though chequered and varied a little in the mode‚Äîthe road alone different, the ends alike. Is it not cruel, then‚Äîis it not intolerable, that the calamities in≈øeparable from humanity ≈øhould be aggravated with artificial ≈øtings, and the nakedne≈øs of human nature expo≈øed, and rendered more offen≈øive, by factitious calamities of human contrivance? Cur≈øed were tho≈øe who fir≈øt fomented tho≈øe di≈øputes, and ca≈øt tho≈øe apples of di≈øcord through the world: blind were they who fir≈øt were ≈øeduced from the paths of peace by them; and more cur≈øed, and more
blind, mu≈øt they be, who, in this time of intellect and illumination, continue on the one hand, to keep up a ≈øy≈øtem ≈øo wicked and ≈øo dete≈øtable, or, on the other, to ≈øubmit to error at once ≈øo fooli≈øh and ≈øo fatal.

div.head: LETTER XX.
div.p: FOR the rea≈øons mentioned in my la≈øt, Aug≈øburgh is a mo≈øt agreeable place to live in. Touched with the ≈øen≈øations natural to a man who loved to ≈øee his fellow-creatures happy, my heart expanded to a ≈øy≈øtem of peace and harmony, comprehending the whole globe: my mind expatiated involuntarily on the ble≈ø≈øings and advantages derived from ≈øuch a ≈øy≈øtem; and, taking flight from the bounds of practicability, to which our feeble nature is pinned on this earth, into the regions or fancy, had reared a fabric of Utopian mold, which, I verily believe, exceeded in extravagance the works of all the Utopian architects that ever con≈øtructed ca≈øtles in the air.

Hurried on by this delightful vi≈øion, my per≈øon paid an involuntary obedience to my mind; and the quickne≈øs of my pace increa≈øing with the impetuo≈øity of my thoughts, I found my≈øelf, before I was aware of it, within the chapel-door of the convent of the Carmelites. Ob≈øerving my error, I ≈øuddenly turned about, in order to depart, when a friar, a goodly per≈øon of a man, elderly, and of a benign a≈øpect, called me, and, advancing towards me, a≈øked, in terms of politene≈øs, and in the French language, why I was retreating ≈øo abruptly‚ÄîI was confu≈øed: but truth is the enemy before whom confu≈øion ever flies; and I told him the whole of my mi≈øtake, and the thoughts from which they aro≈øe.

The good father, waving further di≈øcour≈øe on the ≈øubject, but with a ≈ømile which I thought carried a mixture of benevolence for my≈øelf, and contempt for my ideas, brought me through the church, and ≈øhewed me all the curio≈øities of the place, and particularly pointed out to me, as a great curio≈øity, a ≈øun-dial made in the form of a Madonna, the head enriched with rays and ≈øtars, and in the hand a ≈øceptre which marked the hours.

Quitting the chapel, and going towards the refectory, the friar ≈øtood, and, looking at me with a ≈ømile of gaiety, ≈øaid, "I have yet ≈øomething to ≈øhew you, which, while lady Madonna marks the time, will help us to pa≈øs it; and, as it will make its way with more force and ≈øubtlety to your ≈øen≈øes than tho≈øe I have yet ≈øhewn you, will be likely to be longer retained in remembrance."

He ≈øpoke a few words in German, which of cour≈øe I did not under≈øtand, to a vi≈øion bearing the ≈øhape of a human creature, who, I under≈øtood, „Äà‚óä„Äâ lay-brother; and, turning down a long alley, brought me to his cell, where we were ≈øoon followed by the afore≈øaid lay-brother, with a large earthen jug of liquor, two gla≈ø≈øes, and a plate with ≈øome delicately white bi≈øcuit.

"You mu≈øt know," ≈øaid the friar, "that the convent of Carmelites at Aug≈øburgh has for ages been famed for beer unequalled in any part of the world; and I have brought you here to have your opinion‚Äîfor, being an Engli≈øhman, you mu≈øt be a judge, the Britons being famed for luxury, and a perfect knowledge of the ≈øcavoir vivre." He poured out, and drank to me: it looked liker the cleare≈øt Champaigne than beer‚ÄîI never ta≈øted any thing to equal it; and he ≈øeemed highly gratified by my expre≈ø≈øions of prai≈øe, which I lavi≈øhed upon it, as well from politene≈øs, as regard to truth.

After we had drank a gla≈øs each, "I have been reflecting," ≈øaid the friar, "on the ≈øingular flight
of fancy that directed your ≈øteps into this convent‚Äî Your mind was di≈øea≈øed, my ≈øon! and a propitious ≈øuperintending Power has guided your ≈øteps to a phy≈øician, if you will but have the goodne≈øs to take the medicine he offers."
I ≈øtared with vi≈øible marks of a≈øtoni≈øhment.

"You are ≈øurpri≈øed," continued he; "but you ≈øhall hear! When fir≈øt you di≈øclo≈øed to me tho≈øe ≈øickly flights of your mind, I could on the in≈øtant have an≈øwered them: but you are young‚Äîyou are an Engli≈øhman‚Äîtwo characters impatient of reproof: the dogmas of a prie≈øt, I thought therefore, would be ≈øufficiently difficult to be dige≈øted of them≈øelves, without any additional di≈øta≈øte caught from the chilling au≈øterity of a chapel!"
I looked unintentionally at the earthen jug, and ≈ømiled.

"It is very true," ≈øaid he, catching my very inmo≈øt thoughts from the expre≈ø≈øion of my countenance ‚Äî"it is very true! good doctrine may, at certain times, and with certain per≈øons, be more effectually enforced under the cheering influence of the ≈øocial board, than by the authoritative declamation and formal ≈øanctity of the pulpit; nor am I, though a Carmelite, one of tho≈øe who pretend to think, that a thing in it≈øelf good, can be made bad by decent hilarity, and the animation produced by a moderate and wi≈øe u≈øe of the goods of this earth."
I was a≈øtoni≈øhed‚Äî

"You fell into a reverie," continued he, "produced by a contemplation of the happine≈øs of a ≈øociety exi≈øting without any difference, and where no human breath ≈øhould be wa≈øted on a ≈øigh, no ear tortured with a groan, no tears to trickle, no griefs or calamities to wring the heart."
"Yes, father!" ≈øaid I, catching the idea with my former enthu≈øia≈øm; "that would be my wi≈øh‚Äî that my greate≈øt, fir≈øt de≈øire."
"Then ≈øee≈øt thou," interrupted he, "the extent of thy wi≈øh, ≈øuppo≈øe you could realize it, which, thank GOD! you cannot."
"What! thank GOD that I cannot? are the≈øe your thoughts?"
"Yes, my ≈øon; and ere Madonna marks the progre≈øs of ten minutes with her ≈øceptre, they will be your's too."
"Impo≈ø≈øible!"
"Hear me, my ≈øon!‚ÄîIs not death a horrible precipice to the view of human creatures?"
"A≈ø≈øuredly," ≈øaid I‚Äî"the mo≈øt horrible: human laws declare that, by re≈øorting to it for puni≈øhment, as the ultimatum of all terrible inflictions."

"When, then," ≈øaid he, "covered as we are with mi≈øery, to leave this world is ≈øo in≈øupportable to the human reflection, what mu≈øt it be if we had nothing but joy and felicity to ta≈øte of in this life? Mark me, child!" ≈øaid he, with an animated zeal that gave an expre≈ø≈øion to his countenance beyond any thing I had ever ≈øeen: "the mi≈øeries, the calamities, the heart-rendings, and the tears, which are ≈øo intimately interwoven by the great arti≈øt in our natures as not to be ≈øeparated in a ≈øingle in≈øtance, are in the fir≈øt place our ≈øecurity of a future ≈øtate, and in the next place ≈øerve to ≈ølope the way before us, and, by gradual operation, fit our minds for viewing, with ≈øome ≈øort of fortitude, that hideous cha≈øm that lies between us and that ≈øtate‚Äî death. View tho≈øe mi≈øeries, then, as ≈øpecial acts of mercy and commi≈øeration of a beneficent Creator, who, with every calamity, melts away a link of that earthly chain that fetters our wi≈øhes to this di≈ømal world. Accept his ble≈ø≈øings and his goods, when he ≈øends them, with gratitude and enjoyment: receive his afflictions, too, with as joyous acceptance, and as hearty gratitude. Thus, and not otherwi≈øe, you will realize all your Utopian flights of de≈øire, by turning every thing to matter of comfort,
and living contented with di≈øpen≈øations which you cannot alter, and, if you could, would mo≈øt certainly alter for the wor≈øe."
I ≈øat ab≈øorbed in reflection‚ÄîThe friar, after ≈øome pau≈øe proceeded‚Äî

"Errors ari≈øing from virtuous di≈øpo≈øitions and the love of our fellow creatures, take their complexion from their parent motives, and are virtuous. Your wi≈øhes, therefore, my ≈øon! though erroneous, merit reward, and, I tru≈øt will receive it from that Being who ≈øees the rece≈ø≈øes of the heart; and if the truths I have told you have not failed to make their way to your under≈øtanding, let your adventure of to-day impre≈øs this undeniable maxim on your mind‚Äî≈øo limited is man, ≈øo imperfect in his nature, that the extent of his virtue borders on vice, and the extent of his wi≈ødom on error."
I thought he was in≈øpired; and, ju≈øt as he got to the la≈øt period, every organ of mine was opened to take in his words.

"'Tis well, my ≈øon!" ≈øaid he‚Äî"I perceive you like my doctrine: then" changing his manner of ≈øpeaking, his expre≈ø≈øive countenance the whole time almo≈øt anticipating his whole words, "take ≈øome more of it," ≈øaid he gaily, pouring out a fre≈øh gla≈øs. I pleaded the fear of inebriety‚Äî"Fear not," ≈øaid he; "the beer of this convent never hurts the intellect."

Our conver≈øation continued till near dinner-time; for I was ≈øo delighted, I ≈øcarcely knew how to ≈ønatch my≈øelf away: ≈øuch a happy melange of piety and plea≈øantry, grave wi≈ødom and humour, I had never met. At length, the convent-bell tolling. I ro≈øe: he took me by the hand, and, in a tone of the mo≈øt complacent admonition, ≈øaid, "Remember, my child! as long as you live, remember the convent of the Carmelites; and in the innumerable evils that certainly await you if you are to live long, the words you have heard from old Friar AUGUSTINE will afford you comfort."

"Father!" returned I, "be a≈ø≈øured I carry away from you a token that will never ≈øuffer me to forget the ho≈øpitality‚ñ™ the advice, or the politene≈øs of the good father AUGUSTINE. Poor as I am in natural means, I can make no other return than my good wi≈øhes, nor leave any impre≈ø≈øion behind me: but as my e≈øteem for you, and perhaps my vanity‚ñ™ make me wi≈øh not to be forgotten, accept this, (a ‚Ä¢ eal ‚Ä¢ ing, with a device in hair, which I happened to have on my finger); and whenever you look at it, let it remind you of one of tho≈øe, I dare ≈øay innumerable, in≈øtances, in which you have contributed to the happine≈øs and improvement of your fellow-creatures."

The good old man was affected, took the ring, and attended me to the convent gate, pronouncing many ble≈ø≈øings, and charging me to make Aug≈øburgh my way back again to England if po≈ø≈øible, and take one gla≈øs more of the convent ale.

div.head: LETTER XXI.
div.p: LEAVING Aug≈øburgh, I travelled thro' Bavaria a long way before I reached the Tyrol Country, of the natural beauty of which I had heard much. and which I therefore entered with great expectations of that ≈øublime gratification the beauties of nature never fail to afford me. I was not di≈øappointed; indeed, my warme≈øt expectations were exceeded.

The fir≈øt thing that ≈øtrikes a traveller from Bavaria, on entering it, is the fort of Cherink, built between two inacce≈ø≈øible rocks which ≈øeparate Tyrol from the bi≈øhopric of Frei≈øingen. So amply has nature provided for the ≈øecurity of this country
again≈øt the incur≈øion of an enemy, that there is not a pa≈øs which leads to it that is not through ≈øome narrow defile between mountains almo≈øt inacce≈ø≈øible; and on the rocks and brows of tho≈øe pa≈ø≈øes, the emperor has con≈øtructed forts and citadels, ≈øo advantageou≈øly placed, that they command all the valleys and avenues beneath.

After a variety of windings and turnings through mountains of ≈øtupendous height and awful a≈øpect, I began to de≈øcend, and entered the mo≈øt delightful valley I had ever beheld‚Äîdeep, long, and above a mile in breadth‚Äî≈øurrounded with enormous piles of mountains, and diver≈øified with the alternate beauties of nature and cultivation, ≈øo as to form an union rarely to be met with, and delight at once the eye of the farmer, and the fancy of him that has a true ta≈øte for rural wildne≈øs. From the heights in de≈øcending, the whole appeared in all its glory; the beautiful river Inn gliding along through it longitudinally, its banks ≈øtudded with the mo≈øt romantic little villages, while a number of inferior ≈øtreams were ≈øeen winding in different cour≈øes, and ha≈øtening to pour their tribute into its bo≈øom.

Here I felt my heart overwhelmed with ≈øen≈øations of tran≈øport, which all the works of art could never in≈øpire: here nature ru≈øhed irre≈øi≈øtibly upon my ≈øen≈øes, and, making them captive, exacted their acknowledgement of her ≈øupremacy: here vanity, ambition, lu≈øt of fame and power, and all the tin≈øelled, gaudy frippery to which habit and worldly cu≈øtom en≈ølave the mind, retired, to make way for ≈øentiments of harmony, purity, ≈øimplicity, and truth: here Providence ≈øeemed to ≈øpeak in language mo≈øt per≈øua≈øive, "Come ≈øilly man, leave the wild tumult, the endle≈øs ≈øtruggle, the glittering follies, the fal≈øe and ≈øpurious plea≈øures which artifice creates, to ≈øeduce you from the true‚Äîdwell here, and in the lap of natute ≈øtudy me:" Here, oh! here, exclaimed I, in a tran≈øport which bereft me, for the time, of
every other con≈øideration, here will I dwell for ever. The charm was too finely ≈øpun, to with≈øtand the hard tugs of fact; and all its precious delu≈øions vani≈øhed before a ho≈øt of gloomy truths‚Äîderanged affairs‚Äîfamily far off, with the di≈øtance daily increa≈øing ‚Äîthe hazards and the hard≈øhips of a long untried journey‚Äîand the Ea≈øt Indies, with all its horrors, in the rear. I hung my head in ≈øorrow; and, offering up a prayer to protect my family, ≈øtrengthen my≈øelf, and bring us once more together in ≈øome ≈øpot heavenly as that I pa≈ø≈øed through, was proceeding on in a ≈øtate of dejection proportionate to my previous tran≈øports, when I was rouled by my po≈øtillion, who, pointing to a very high, ≈øteep rock, de≈øired me to take notice of it. The Emperor MAXIMILIAN, that glory of the world, (he is now in the lap of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin in Paradi≈øe), once on a time, before he was emperor, that is to ≈øay, when he was archduke, was always laughing at the country people's fears of

div.head: LETTER XXII.
div.p:
IN all nations under Heaven, and at all times ≈øince the creation there have been men formed to make a noi≈øe in the world‚Äîto increa≈øe or impede, to direct or di≈øturb, the calm, ≈øober progre≈øs of ≈øocial life‚Äîand, in the eagerne≈øs and violence of their efforts to reach the goal of ≈øuperiority, overturn or thru≈øt out of their ordinary path the re≈øt of mankind, till either they provoke again≈øt them a general con≈øpiracy of their fellow-creatures, or, till reaching the point of their pur≈øuit, they become elevated objects of homage and admiration. Such men are generally compo≈øed of great materials for mi≈øchief:‚Äîhaving ≈øtrong natural talents and violent ungovernable ≈øpirits; according to the direction the≈øe get, they are harmle≈øs or mi ‚Ä¢ chievous ‚Äîbut, like morbid matter in the animal ≈øy≈øtem, if not let loo≈øe by ≈øome channel or other, they never fail to di≈øturb the whole economy of the body they belong to, and produce fatal con≈øequences to it and to them≈øelves: Colonial po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions have therefore, in ≈øome views, been of u≈øe (as America formerly to
England) to draw off tho≈øe dangerous ≈øpirits, who, though they are in times of peace better at a di≈øtance, in times of war are found to be the toughe≈øt ≈øinews of a nation.

The country of Tyrol, ≈øuch as I have de≈øcribed it, formed bv nature for the re≈øidence of the Sylvan deities, rich in the products of the earth, the people contented and happy, and the whole the region of peace; manufactures, the fir≈øt root of low vices, and commerce, the great in≈øtigator of war, have ≈øcarcely been able to ≈øet their feet there: hence it happens, that there is no channel through which tho≈øe exuberant ≈øpirits I have alluded to can take their cour≈øe, or expand their force. Home, therefore, is no place for tho≈øe of the Tyrole≈øe, who are cur≈øed or ble≈ø≈øed (call it which you plea≈øe) with tho≈øe very combu≈øtible qualities; and they are obliged to roam abroad in ≈øearch of opportunities of di≈øtingui≈øhing them≈øelves, giving vent to their ≈øpirits, and manife≈øting their talents. They are found, therefore, ≈øcattered all over the Continent: and as it rarely happens that opportunities occur in life of ≈øignali≈øing ≈øuch talents in a dignified line, rather than be idle they do what they can, and apply to chicanery as a wide and appropriate field for their genius and vigour to work on‚Äîthe emigrant Tyrole≈øe are, therefore, by mo≈øt nations of the continent, reckoned among the mo≈øt expert and accompli≈øhed ≈øharpers in the world‚Äîthe people, however, who remain at home, are of a different character‚Äîthey are, generally ≈øpeaking, tall, robu≈øt, and vigorous; the women ≈øtrong, and very fair; and both ≈øexes exhibit a very plea≈øing mixture of German phlegm and Italian ≈øprightline≈øs; or, to ≈øpeak more properly, they are a mean between tho≈øe two extremes.

Inn≈øpruck, though a ≈ømall city, is hand≈øome and agreeable, ≈øtanding in a very beautiful valley, ≈øurrounded with mountains, which, while their lower
parts are well cultivated, are capped on the tops with perennial ≈ønow. The ca≈øtle formerly the re≈øidence of the Au≈øtrian princes is ≈øtately and magnificent, adorned within with fine paintings, and decorated without by natural and artificial fountains, ≈øtatues, plea≈øant gardens, groves, walks, and covered galleries, leading to five different churches.

A-propas‚ÄîLet me not forget the churches! In a chapel of the Franci≈øcan church, there is an image of the Virgin MARY as big as the life, of ≈øolid ≈øilver, with many, other images of faints of the ≈øame metal. If ≈øome of tho≈øe ≈øilver deities were transferred to Paris, I fear their divinity would not ≈øave them from the hands of the ≈øacrilegious Convention. One thing, however, is well worth the attention of travellers, particularly tho≈øe who wi≈øh to wipe away the ≈øins of a decea≈øed friend, and get them a direct pa≈ø≈øport to happine≈øs‚ÄîThis Franci≈øcan church is held to be one of the mo≈øt ≈øacred and venerable in the world, on account of the indulgences granted to it by ≈øeveral popes; ≈øo that one ≈øingle ma≈øs ≈øaid in it, is declared to be ≈øufficient to deliver a ≈øoul from the pains of purgatory. When we con≈øider the great and important extent of their power in that re≈øpect, we cannot wonder if they had all the ≈øaints in the calendar, and the Virgin MARY to boot, in ≈øolid ≈øilver, even of the ≈øize of the Colo≈ø≈øus at Rhodes.

Hall, the ≈øecond city in Tyrol, lies one league from Inn≈øpruck: it is famous for its ≈øalt-works, and for a mint and ≈øilver mines, in which ≈øeven thou≈øand men, women, and children are con≈øtantly employed.

At a royal palace and ca≈øtle called Ombras, lying at equal di≈øtance from Inn≈øpruck and Hall, there is an ar≈øenal, famous for a prodigious collection of curio≈øities, ≈øuch as medals, precious ≈øtones, ≈øuits of armour, and ≈øtatues of ≈øeveral princes on hor≈øeback, in their old rich fighting accoutrements; be≈øides
great variety of military ≈øpoils and trophies taken by the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria; in particular, a ≈øtatue of FRANCIS the Fir≈øt and his hor≈øe, ju≈øt as they were taken at the battle of Pavia, and two others of Turki≈øh ba≈øhaws, with the co≈øtly habits and appointments with which they were taken, embelli≈øhed with gold, ≈øilver, and precious ≈øtones. But, above all their curio≈øities, the mo≈øt extraordinary is an oak inclo≈øing the body of a deer: this la≈øt, however unaccountable, is fact; and equals, I think, any of the wonders in the metamorpho≈øes of OVID.

Leaving Inn≈øpruck, I proceeded on my journey, and ≈øoon entered into the mountains, which are there of a terrible height‚ÄîI was the be≈øt part of a day a≈øcending them: as I got near the top, I was ≈øhewn, by my driver, the ≈øpot where FERDINAND, king of Hungary, and the Emperor CHARLES the F ‚Ä¢ fth, met, when he returned from Africa, in the year 1520.
