Although this mountain, called Bremenberg (or Burning-hill), is covered with ≈ønow for nine months in the year, it is inhabited to the very top, and produces corn and hay in abundance; at the highe≈øt part there is a po≈øt-hou≈øe, a tavern, and a chapel, where the traveller is accommodated with fre≈øh hor≈øes, provi≈øions, and, if he choo≈øes, a mouthful of prayers‚ÄîI availed my≈øelf of the two fir≈øt; but the latter being not altogether in my way, I declined it, for which I could perceive that I was, by every mouth and eye in the place, con≈øigned to perdition as a heretic.

Ju≈øt at this ≈øpot there is a ≈øpring of water which falls upon a rock, and divides into two currents, which, at a very ≈ømall di≈øtance, a≈ø≈øume the appearance, and, in fact, the magnitude too, of very large rivers. The mountain is ≈øometimes difficult to pa≈øs,
≈øometimes ab≈øolutely impracticable‚ÄîI was fortunate, however, in this re≈øpect; for I got over it without any very extraordinary delay, and on my way was regaled with the mo≈øt delicious veni≈øon that I have ever ta≈øted in my life; it was ≈øaid to be the fle≈øh of a kind of goat.

Although it is but thirty-five miles from Inn≈øpruck to Bri≈øen, it was late when I reached the latter; and as it contained nothing worth either the trouble or delay attending the ≈øearch of it, I ≈øet out the next morning, and, travelling with high mountains on one ≈øide, and a river all along upon the other, arrived at a town called Bol≈øano, in the bi≈øhopric of Trent. The country all along was thickly inhabited, and the mountains perfectly cultivated and manured even to their highe≈øt tops. On entering the valley of Bol≈øano, I found the air becoming obviou≈øly ≈øweet, delightful, and temperate; the vineyards, and all the trees and ≈øhrubs, olives, mulberries, willows, and ro≈øes, &c. of all the mo≈øt lively green, and every thing marking the mo≈øt luxuriant vegetation.

Bol≈øano is a ≈ømall, but extremely neat and plea≈øant town‚Äîbut nothing I ≈øaw about it plea≈øed me ≈øo much as their vineyards, which are planted in long terraces along the ≈øides of the hills, and are formed into the mo≈øt beautiful arbours, one ‚Ä¢ ow above another.

From Bol≈øano to Trent, is fifty-one miles, a good day's journey: almo≈øt the whole of it lies through the valley of Bol≈øano, a mo≈øt fruitful and plea≈øant ‚Äîindeed, delightful road, which made the day's journey appear to me much ≈øhorter than it really was.

Perhaps no part of the habitable globe is, within the ≈øame comparatively ≈ømall compa≈øs of earth, ≈øo wonderfully diver≈øified by the hand of nature in all her extremes, as that through which I have ju≈øt carried you. There, under almo≈øt the ≈øame glance
of the eye, were to be ≈øeen the ≈øtupendous, the rugged, the ≈øavage, and the inacce≈ø≈øible‚Äîthe mild, the fruitful, and the cultivated. Here, the mountain capped with perpetual ≈ønow, gradually falling in blended gradations of ≈øhade, far beyond the reach of the arti≈øt's pencil, into the green luxuriant valley; and there, the vineyard, the olivary, and the rich corn-field, bur≈øting at once from rugged rocks and inacce≈ø≈øible fa≈øtne≈ø≈øes: the chu ‚Ä¢ li≈øh a≈øpect of the tyrant winter for ever prowling on the mountain's head above‚Äîperpetual ≈øpring ≈ømiling with all her fa≈øcinating charms in the plains below. Such ≈øcenes as the≈øe would baffle all efforts of the poet's pen or painter's pencil: to be conceived, they mu≈øt be ≈øeen. I ≈øhall therefore clo≈øe my account of them with a ≈øtrong recommendation to you, that whenever you travel for improvement, you go through the Country of Tyrol, and there learn the great and marvellous working of nature.

div.head: LETTER XXIII.
div.p:
PERHAPS the learned unwi≈øe men of the world, who ≈øpend their lives poring after impo≈ø≈øibilities, have never met with a more copious ≈øubject of puzzle-pated enjoyment than the derivation of the names of places. In all di≈øputed ca≈øes on this ≈øubject, the utmo≈øt within human reach is conjecture; but the joke of it is, that, fortunately for mankind, the certainty of it would not be of a ≈øingle button advantage to them, even if it could be acquired by their ≈øearch. Doctor GOLDSMITH, in his Citizen of the World, has thrown this matter into high ridicule; and I recommend it to your peru≈øal, le≈øt this ≈øhadow of literature ≈øhould one
day wheedle you from more re≈øpectable pur≈øuits. Trent has afforded va≈øt exerci≈øe to book-worm conjectures in this way; for, while ≈øome pronounce it to be derived from Tridentum, and for this purpo≈øe will have it that NEPTUNE was wor≈øhipped there, though ≈øo far from the ≈øea-others claim the di≈øcovery of its derivation from Tribus Torrentibus, or three ≈øtreams which run there. Its name is Trent; and if it had been Putney, or John o' Groat's hou≈øe, the town would be neither the better nor the wor≈øe, nor the trea≈øures of literature ≈øuffer any defalcation from the difference.

The bi≈øhopric of Trent is about ≈øixty miles long, and forty broad‚Äîfertile, and abundant in wine, oil, fruit, and pa≈øture‚Äîand plea≈øant, the beautiful river Adige meandering through the whole of it from north to ≈øouth. As I receded from Germany, and advanced towards Italy, I found the air, the per≈øons, and the manners of the people, to di≈øplay a very great difference, and to re≈øemble tho≈øe of the Italians more than tho≈øe of the Germans. Perhaps contra≈øt was never more perfectly exemplified than in a compari≈øon between the Germans and Italians; and that contra≈øt ≈øtrikes more forcibly and ≈øuddenly in pa≈ø≈øing from one country in the other, than it would in ≈øo ≈øhort a ≈øpace between any two people exi≈øting. The Germans, on the contrary, open, good-natured, free from malice and ≈øubtlety, laborious, ≈øincere, hone≈øt, and ho≈øpitable‚Äîand, with tho≈øe valuable qualities, properly complai≈øant. So happy is the character of this people, that to be German hearted has long been a phra≈øe ≈øignifying an hone≈øt man who hated di≈ø≈øimulation: and their ho≈øpitality was even in the days of JULIUS CAESAR, remarkable; for we learn from him, that their hou≈øes were open to all men‚Äîthat they thought it inju≈øtice to affront a traveller, and made it an article of their religion to protect tho≈øe who came under their roof. The city of Trent, though not very large in circumference, is populous. Trent once boa≈øted a curio≈øity‚Äîwhich indeed ≈øtill remains, though out of u≈øe‚Äîthat, I think, would be found ≈øerviceable in mo≈øt towns in Chri≈øtendom, and el≈øewhere too, and particularly at Bath, and ≈øuch places. The people of Trent ≈øpeak promi≈øcou≈øly, and indifferently, both the German and Italian languages; but whether well or not, I was not adept enough to di≈øcover.

My next ≈øtage was Ba≈ø≈øano, a town in the territory of Vincenza in Italy, ≈øituated at the end of a very long n ‚Ä¢ rrow valley. It is watered by the river Bren ‚Ä¢ a, which wa≈øhes that very rich, fertile, ≈øerene, healthy, and plentiful di≈øtrict of Italy, ≈øo celebrated for its admirable wines, as well as for its fine pa≈øture-grounds, rich corn-fields, and prodigious abundance of game, cattle, and mulberry-trees; from all which it is called the Garden and Shambles of Venice.

The next day I arrived at an early hour at Venice, the de≈øcription of which I ≈øhall not injure by commencing it with the mutilated fragment of a letter, and ≈øhall therefore po≈øtpone it to my next.

THUS, my dear FREDERICK, have I, in order to pre≈øerve the unity and order of my progre≈øs, brought you through Germany with a preci≈øe regularity, that, if I was not wi≈øhing for your improvement, might be di≈øpen≈øed with‚Äîyet have left much, very much indeed, untouched, in the confidence that you will your≈øelf have the indu≈øtry to find it out.

div.p: AS I approached Venice, I was much delighted with its appearance. The place where Venice now ≈øtands, is ≈øuppo≈øed to have been formerly a mar≈øhy ground, on which the Adriatic Sea had gradually encroached, leaving the more elevated parts of it above water, and thereby forming a va≈øt number of little i≈ølands, hence called Lagunes: on tho≈øe the fi≈øhermen of the neighbouring ≈øhores built their huts; and when Italy was invaded by the Goths under AIARIC, and afterwards by that barbarous race the Huns, under ATTILA, both of whom ≈øpread ruin and de≈øolation wherever they came, va≈øt numbers of people from the circumjacent ≈øhores of the Adriatic, particularly from Padua and Aquileia, ≈øled hither, and brought along with them immen≈øe wealth. Here
they laid the fir≈øt foundations on ≈øeventy-two di≈øtinct little i≈ølands, and certainly with huts, of a city which afterwards ≈øtood almo≈øt foremo≈øt in the naval and commercial world: as tho≈øe i≈ølands were built upon, and became over-people, they gradually pu≈øhed forward their piles, and built upon them aga ‚Ä¢ n, till the whole became one va≈øt city, extending to many more of tho≈øe i≈ølands beyond the original ≈øeventy-two.

As it was indebted in a great mea≈øure, for its ri≈øe and importance to the commerce of the Ea≈øt, which then was carried on by way of the Red Sea and Alexandria, when the pa≈ø≈øage by the Cape of Good Hope was di≈øcovered, that trade declined and Venice declined gradually along with it.

It is amazing, what an extent of territory and accumulation of power the Venetians once po≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øed. Be≈øides their pre≈øent po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, which comprehend the territories of Padua and Verona, the Vincentine, the Bre≈øcians, the Bergamales, the C ‚Ä¢ ema ‚Ä¢ co, the Polefin of Rovig ‚Ä¢ , Marca Trevig ‚Ä¢ ana, the Patria del Friuli, and I≈øt ‚Ä¢ ia, they had under their dominion the i≈ølands of Rhodes, Scio, Samos, My ‚Ä¢ lene, Andros, Candia, the Morea, and the cities of Gallipo ‚Ä¢ i and The≈ø≈øalonica: be≈øides which, they, in conjunction with France, took Con≈øtantinople, and remained for ≈øometime ma≈øters of that part of the Empire; and di≈øputed the dominion of Sclavonia, Croatia, Morlachia and Dalmatia, with the Kings of Hungary, and contended with the Genocie „Äà‚óä„Äâ the empire of the ≈øea: but of a great part of the≈øe, I and their other conque≈øts, they have ≈øince been ≈øtripped, almo≈øt entirely, by the Turks.

As to the government of Venice, I ≈øhall not enter into any particulars of its hi≈øtory‚Äî It is called a republic, and was once a democracy. The name remains, while that which gave it is gone. It is, certainly, now a downright ari≈øtocracy‚Äîthe

Hence it is ≈øaid, that the doge of Venice is a king in his robes, a ≈øenator in council, a pri≈øoner in the city, and a private man out of it; and what is more extraordinary, is, that though he may be depo≈øed, he cannot re≈øign‚Äînor even decline the office, if he be once cho≈øen, without expo≈øing him≈øelf to bani≈øhment, and his effects to confi≈øcation.

The e≈øtabli≈øhed religion of this ≈øtate is the Roman Catholic; but the Venetians are not b ‚Ä¢ gots, and reject the ≈øupremacy of the Pope. Jews, Armenians, Greeks, and Prote≈øtants, are allowed the exerci≈øe of their religion there; and, provided they do not intermeddle with ≈øtate affairs, of which they are extremely jealous, even their prie≈øts, monks, and nuns, may take almo≈øt any liberties they plea≈øe ‚Äîa privilege that you may be a≈ø≈øured is not neglected by any of them.

As few places have excited greater admiration and attention than Venice, ≈øo none have been more copiou≈øly de≈øcribed by travellers, every one of whom may, when he returns to his native country, give a very accurate account of the public buildings, curio≈øities, paintings. &c. by only tran≈ølating the book given to him by his va ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ de place, or cicerone, on his arrival the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ‚ÄîIt is certain, Venice abounds with all tho≈øe, particularly paintings; but I had not the time minutely to inve≈øtigate; nor ≈øhould I have the inclination, if I did, to de≈øcribe ≈øuch things: they are open to you in many well written volumes, which I recommend to your peru ‚Ä¢ ual. Such things, however, as ≈øtrike me for their novelty, or difference from tho≈øe in other
places, I will, as well as I can recollect them, give you an idea of.

To their local ≈øituation they own their ≈øecurity‚Äî ≈øeparate I from terra firma by a body of water of five miles in breadth, too deep to be forded, and too ≈øhallow for ve≈ø≈øels of force to pa ‚Ä¢ s: and on the other ≈øides, by ≈øcattered ≈øhallows, the channels between which are marked out by ≈øt ‚Ä¢ kes, which, on the appearance of an enemy, they can take away; they bid defiance to ho≈øtile army or navy, and have not been reduced to the nece≈ø≈øity to erecting walls or fortifications for their defence.

The fir≈øt peculiarity that ≈øtrikes me, as ari≈øing immediately from their living, I may ≈øay, in the ≈øea, is the total exclu≈øion of all ≈øort of carriages; for tho≈øe ≈øtreets that are on firm ground are extremely narrow and crooked; and on mo≈øt of the canals, ≈øo far from having a quay on either ≈øide to walk on, the water comes up to the doors of the hou≈øes; ≈øo that walking is but little known, for they get into a boat off their thre≈øhold, and their fir≈øt ≈øtep out of it again is, ten to one, on the thre≈øhold of another. This circum≈øtance, though in ≈øome re≈øpects it has its u≈øes, is, in others, extremely di≈øagreeable, as well as injurious; for, though tho≈øe who have occa≈øion to labour have a ≈øufficiency of exerci≈øe, tho≈øe who≈øe condition exempts them from labour, and who, therefore, in all other countries, re≈øort to artificial labour (exerci≈øe) for the promotion of health, are here entirely cut off from all ≈øuch means of it as we practi≈øe, having neither hunting, ≈øhooting, riding, bowling, &c. &c. nor can they have them, unle≈øs they go to the Continent for them. The chief amu≈øements of the Venetians are re≈øerved for the carnival time, which commences about a week after Chri≈øtmas, and which, therefore, I could not ≈øee; but, from the concurrent te≈øtimony of all travellers and the people them≈øelves, as well as from the evidence of
my own ob≈øervation on the manners of the people, I am well warranted in ≈øaying, are fe≈øtivals of debauchery, not, and licentiou≈øne≈øs. This is a ≈øubject on which I am, neverthele≈øs, di≈øpo≈øed to believe, that more has been ≈øaid than truth will bear ou ‚Ä¢ ‚Äîyet, a bare ≈øtatement of the truth, would, I fear, ‚Ä¢ ear hard enough upon the moral character, or at lea≈øt the piety, of the Venetians.

That ma≈øquerades are the very wor≈øt ≈øchools of vice, the private anecdotes of the beau monde even in England might ≈øuffice to demon≈øtrate‚ÄîThat courtez ‚Ä¢ ns are found lo≈øt to all ≈øen≈øe of mode≈øty and common decency, the ≈øtreets of London afford nightly proof:‚ÄîTherefore, that ma≈øquerading (which is the amu≈øement of the Venetians) ≈øhould cloak many crimes, and that their courtezans ≈øhould be ≈øhamele≈øs and their women lewd, is no ≈øuch wonder, ≈øeeing, as we do, tho≈øe things in this Northern clime; but we may, without any illiberality, ≈øuppo≈øe, that, from phy≈øical cau≈øes of the mo≈øt obvious kind, they are carried to a greater extent there than here: though one of the mo≈øt enlightened and amiable of all travellers ≈øays it would be hard to be proved, yet, with deference to him, I think it may be rationally ≈øuppo≈øed.

There is an active principle in the mind of man which will not ‚Ä¢ ofter it to re≈øt; it mu≈øt have ≈øome materials to work upon. Men, enlightened by ≈øcience, have within them≈øelves a fund, and can never want food for contemplation; but the many, in tho≈øe hours when a ≈øu≈øpen≈øion of labour or worldly bu≈øine≈øs drives them to expedients for the employment of their time are but too prone to leave the mind to the guidance of the ≈øen≈øes, and to cogitate on vice till they w ‚Ä¢ ≈øh to practice it. In England we have a variety of expedients which the Venetians want, who≈øe minds being be≈øides naturally more vivid, are more prompt
to give a loo≈øe to the warm illu≈øions of ≈øen≈øual fancy. Thus prepared, they meet the carnival, when every thing con≈øpires to give circulation to indulgence; and when tho≈øe operations of the mind which with us have ≈øo many channels to di≈øcharge them≈øelves, with them, like a va≈øt ≈øtream ≈øuddenly confined to one narrow channel, bur≈øt forth with an irre≈øi≈øtable torrent, and carry away before them every bond that religion or morality has laid down as re≈øtraints on the exhuberance of human pa≈ø≈øion. The cu≈øtoms and habits of the place and time contribute to it; for, while the ≈øevere re≈øtrictions of the female ≈øex for the re≈øt of the year ≈øharpen both inclination and invention on the one hand‚Äîon the other, the unbounded licen≈øe, the univer≈øal change of habits, cu≈øtoms and laws‚Äîthe total ≈øu≈øpen≈øion of all di≈øtinction, care, or bu≈øine≈øs which take place at that time, aided by perpetual ma≈øquerade‚Äîand tho≈øe mo≈øt convenient of all receptacles, the gondolas, with tho≈øe mo≈øt expert and forward of all pandars, the gondoliers‚Äîafford ample ≈øcope to their wi≈øhes, and form altogether a ma≈øs of circum≈øtances in favour of vicious indulgence, not to be found in any other part of Chri≈øtendom; to re≈øi≈øt which, they mu≈øt be more virtuous than any other people ‚Äîa point never yet laid to their charge by the be≈øt-natured and mo≈øt extenuating of all tho≈øe who have written upon that ≈øubject.

div.head: LETTER XXV.
div.p:
PROFLIGATE though the people of London are, I will not allow that it is ≈øo vicious a city as Venice. That there are in it, and indeed in all capitals, individuals who have reached the

The Venetian men are well-featured and well-≈øhaped‚Äîthe women, well-≈øhaped, beautiful, and, it is ≈øaid, witty: but I had that within which robbed every object of its charms; and I might ≈øay with HAMLET, that "man delighted not me, nor woman either."‚ÄîIn ≈øhort, not all the beauties and novelty of the place, not all the plea≈øures that ≈øta ‚Ä¢ e the traveller in the face, and ≈øolicit his enjoyment, not all the exqui≈øite looks of the ladies, could rou≈øe my mind from its melancholy, or fix my attention‚Äî I grew weary of Venice before I had been many hours in it, and determined to gra≈øp at the very fir≈øt opportunity that offered for my departure.

I had arranged, in my own mind, a plan to proceed to Latichea, a con≈øiderable ≈øea-port town in Syria, and thence to Aleppo, whence, as it was a great Ea≈øtern mart, I entertained hopes that I ≈øhould find a ≈øpeedy, or at lea≈øt a certain conveyance, by a caravan, acro≈øs the de≈øerts, to Ba≈ø≈øo ‚Ä¢ ah, and little doubted but that I ≈øhould find a ve≈ø≈øel at ≈øome of the Venetian ports, either bound, or belonging to a ≈øea-port of ≈øuch commercial con≈øequence, upon which I could procure a pa≈ø≈øage‚Äî But in this I was di≈øappointed; for, on the fulle≈øt

I accordingly ≈øet out for Trie≈øte, with all the impatience of a ≈øanguine mind, anxious to change place, eager to pu≈øh forward, and full of the new route I had laid down‚Äîthe charms of which, particularly of ≈øeeing Grand Cairo, the Land of Egypt, and the Pyramids, were painted by my imagination in all the glowing exaggerated colours of romance. Soon after our arrival at Trie≈øte, I had the mortification to find, that the ve≈ø≈øel was by no means
likely to keep pace with the ardour of my mind, and that, owing to ≈øome unfore≈øeen event, her departure was to be delayed; ≈øo, after a few of tho≈øe effu≈øions which may be ≈øuppo≈øed on ≈øuch an occa≈øion to e≈øcape a man of no very cool temper hanging on the tenter-hooks of expectation, I found it nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øit down, and patiently wait the revolution of time and event, which nothing could either impede or accelerate.

It has often been remarked, and is held as a point of faith by Prede≈øtinarians, that ≈øome men are doomed by fate to di≈øappointment‚Äîand that, when they are ≈øo, no wi≈ødom can obviate, no vigilance provide again≈øt, nor no re≈øolution re≈øi≈øt, her decrees; but, that, in ≈øpite of all the efforts of rea≈øon and indu≈øtry, a ≈øeries of ≈øini≈øter events ≈øhall pur≈øue them through life, and meet them at every turn they attempt to take. The≈øe reflections aro≈øe from the following incident:

I had procured a ≈øervant to attend me on my journey, who, from my ≈øhort ob≈øervation of him, promi≈øed to contribute very con≈øiderably to my comfort, my convenience, and, indeed, to my ≈øecurity, as he was apparently hone≈øt, ≈øincere, active, and clever in his duty, and ma≈øter of ≈øeveral languages, and particularly of the lingua Franca, a mixture of languages, peculiarly u≈øeful in travelling through the Ea≈øt. But gue≈øs what mu≈øt have been my feelings when I found, almo≈øt immediately after his departure, that the ve≈ø≈øel was preparing to ≈øail, and that I mu≈øt either lo≈øe my pa≈ø≈øage or my ≈øervant: anx ‚Ä¢ ous though I was to get forward, and grievous though my former delay had been to me, I he≈øitated which to do; but prudence, for once, prevailed over inclination; and I determined, at all events, to depart, under all the embarra≈ø≈øment attending the want of a ≈øervant and lingui≈øt, and all the poignant feelings of having been acce≈ø≈øary to the di≈øappointment, and perhaps the injury of a poor fellow, whom I really conceived to be a per≈øon of merit. In our pa≈ø≈øage to Alexandria we touched at Zante, an i≈øland on the coa≈øt of Greece, belonging to Venice; it was anciently called Zacy ‚Ä¢ s‚Äîis about fifty miles in circumference, and contains fifty thou≈øand inhabitants. Never before had I ta≈øted any thing equal to the delicious flavour of the fruits of this „Äà‚óä„Äâ ‚Äîthe grapes exqui≈øite, and the me ‚Ä¢ n and pe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ hes of prodigious bigne≈øs and unequ ‚Ä¢ d „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ i≈øland is abundantly fruitful in wine, currants, o ‚Ä¢ , figs, and corn, but
is very ≈øubject to earthquakes. Near the ≈øea-port which we entered is as great a curio≈øity in nature as is any where, I believe, to be found. In the fir≈øt ≈øtages of melancholy, con≈øolation is rejected by the mind as premature. Hence the truly ≈økilful in the human heart con≈øider premature con≈øolation as an aggravation of woe, and comfort only with condolence, well knowing that the tide of grief mu≈øt take its cour≈øe, and that, until it be fir≈øt full, no hopes can be had of its retiring. The full force of this I began now to feel. div.head: LETTER XXVI.
div.p: AT the time I ≈øet out upon my journey over land to India, I was (though married, and the father of children) very young, naturally of a ≈øanguine con≈øtitution: my attachment to the fair ‚Ä¢ ex was ‚Ä¢ o ways dimini≈øhed by a military education: and a warmth of temper, an ardent ≈øen≈øibility of mind, and a frank un≈øu≈øpicious di≈øpo≈øition, left me but too often to regret the facility with which I yielded to the charms of women. But‚Äîoh! ≈øhort-≈øighted man! bubble of every delu≈øive ≈øhadow! On my arrival at Alexandria, I found, to my fre≈øh mortification, that the plague was raging all over Egypt‚Äîand as, if this was not of it≈øelf ≈øufficient to block up my intended route, an irruption of the Arabs, who in formidable bodies infe≈øted all the roads, put a period to all my hopes of ≈øeeing Grand Cairo, and viewing the curio≈øities of that country, which all who, like us, have the Bible put early into their hands, are taught to venerate as ≈øoon as they are taught to read. Alexandria was built by ALEXANDER the Great, ≈øoon after the overthrow of Tyre, about 333 years before CHRIST, and is ≈øituated on the Mediterranean, twelve miles we≈øt of that mouth of the Nile, anciently called Canopicum. By the de≈øcription of STRABO and other ancients, it appears that this city was built upon a plan well worthy the va≈øt mind of its founder; and the fragments of its ornaments afterwards made part of the grande≈øt embelli≈øhments of Rome and Con≈øtantinople. In the mu≈øeum of the royal palace, which occupied a fourth part of the city, the body of ALEXANDER was depo≈øited in a golden coffin‚Äî but the dete≈øtable SELDUCUS CIBYOFACTES violated the monument, took away the golden coffin, and ≈øub≈øtituted a gla≈øs one in its place.

‚ñ™ there are 4000 p ‚Ä¢ ce, 4000 baths," &c. &c.

The great advantages of the Ea≈øt India trade, which was then carried on by the Red Sea, pre≈øerved Alexandria through ≈øeveral re≈øolutions; but having fallen under the dominion of the Turks, and the pa≈ø≈øage round the Cape of Good Hope being di≈øcovered, a fatal blow was given to its commerce, and it has ≈øince fallen to decay. ‚Ä¢ ained,
in its face, fragments of architecture of the mo≈øt exqui≈øite workman≈øhip, ≈øuch as broken columns, friezes, &c.; tho≈øe were the antique ruins of ≈øome fallen pieces of antiquity, at the time that this ant ‚Ä¢ que wall was built: what then mu≈øt be the length of time ≈øince they had fir≈øt undergone the hands of the workman? At Alexandria I remained about twelve days, till, wearied of the confined ≈øtate I lived in on account of the plague, I re≈øolved to devi≈øe ≈øome m ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ s, if po≈ø≈øible, to get away, and at length hired a b ‚Ä¢ at to carry me to the i≈øland of Cyprus, from whence I concluded, that I ≈øhould find no ≈øort of difficulty in procuring a conveyance to Latichea, and ≈øo proceed by my fir≈øt intended route. Although the etymologies of the names of places are of very little importance, and mo≈øt frequently uncertain, I think it probable that the learned are r ‚Ä¢ ght, who a≈ø≈øert the name of this is derived from Cyprus, or Cypre≈øs‚Äîwith which ≈øhurbs the i≈øland

This i≈øland holds a very high rank in cla≈ø≈øic lore ‚ÄîIt gave birth to ≈øome great philo≈øophers and con≈øiderable poets‚ÄîThe Apo≈øtle BARNABAS was a native of it, and, a≈ø≈øi≈øted by ST. As the branches of an empire mo≈øt remote from the great ≈øeat of government are always more de≈øpotically governed than tho≈øe near the ≈øource of redre≈øs, Cyprus has been continually ruled with a rod of iron ≈øince it came into the hands of the Turks. There is one dreadful mi≈øchief to which this i≈øland is ≈øubject. In the hot ≈øea≈øon, locu≈øts come from the Continent, in ≈øwarms ≈øo va≈øt and ≈øo thick as to darken the ≈øky like clouds. The whole i≈øland, as well as particular towns, was entirely con≈øecrated to the godde≈øs VENUS, who thence was called VENUS CYPRIA, or DEA CYPRIA, and is repre≈øented by the poets as taking a preculiar plea≈øure in vi≈øiting it; and this unque≈øtionably aro≈øe from the loo≈øe habits and la≈øcivious temperament of the women there, who certainly are, at this time, not remarkable for cha≈øtity.

I mu≈øt confe≈øs, however, that I felt great plea≈øure in entering Cyprus; it was, as I have already ≈øtated, cla≈ø≈øic ground, and dedicated to the Queen of Love. But a traveller who vi≈øits it with ≈øhapes of amu≈øement, will be much di≈øappointed; for in no one particular did it ≈øeem to me to re≈øemble that Cyprus famed in the Heathen Story and Mythology. Of the Cyprian queen's favours the ladies ≈øeemed to boa≈øt no one ma≈øk, ≈øave the mo≈øt nau≈øeous, di≈øgu≈øting lewdne≈øs; and the natural fertility of the ≈øoil is half lo≈øt beneath the oppre≈ø≈øive yoke of the ≈øervants of the Turki≈øh government. Thus, in the extraordinary revolutions that human affairs are ince≈ø≈øantly undergoing, that i≈øland which for its ≈øuperior beauties was ≈øuppo≈øed to be the re≈øidence of love, which gave birth to the philo≈øophers ZENO, APPOLLONIUS, anD XENOPHON, is now a mi≈øerable, half-cultivated ≈øpot, peopled with a mixture of wretched Turks, Jews, Greeks, and Chri≈øtians
‚Äîgroaning under the tyranny of a barbarous de≈øpotic abu≈øe of delegated power‚Äîinfe≈øted with locu≈øts which devour the fruits of the earth‚Äîand di≈øgraced by a race of ignominious women, who e≈øteem it to be an act of religion to pro≈øtitute them≈øelves to all ≈øtrangers.

Our RICHARD the Fir≈øt made a conque≈øt of this i≈øland on his way to the Holy Land, and conferred the royalty of it on GUY LUSIGNAN, king of Jeru≈øalem. The Venetians po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of it in the year 1480‚Äîbut, in the ≈øixteenth century, the Turks di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them, and have ever ≈øince kept it under the yoke‚ÄîI ≈øhould have remarked that then wine is excellent.

Continuing my route, I hired another boat, after only forty-eight hours ≈øtay at Cyprus, and proceeded for Latichea, which, as I have ≈øomewhere before mentioned, is a con≈øiderable ≈øea-port town of Syria, built on a promontory of land, which, running into the ≈øea, occa≈øions its being continually refre≈øhed with breezes. Fortune, who had hitherto been not very liberal in her di≈øpen≈øations, now favoured me; for, ju≈øt as I arrived at Latichea, a caravan was preparing. The con≈øul of the Turki≈øh Company at Cyprus received me with great politene≈øs and ho≈øpitality‚Äîgave me a letter to the re≈øident at Latichea; and by his in≈øtruction and a≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øtance, after a very ≈øhort ≈øtay, I ≈øet out on my way to Aleppo with the caravan.

As I ≈øhall hereafter have occa≈øion more particularly to de≈øcribe the nature or tho≈øe caravans, I ≈øhall, for the pre≈øent, tell you, that this was compo≈øed of no other bea≈øts of burden than mules and a≈ø≈øes, of which there were not le≈øs than three or four hundred in number.

Mounted on a mule, I travelled along, well plea≈øed with the fertile appearance of the country, and delighted with the ≈øerenity of the air‚ÄîWe were, as well as I can now recollect, near ten days on the road; during which time we travelled only
in the morning early, and in the heat of the day repo≈øed under the ≈øhade of trees.

I was informed, that if, in≈øtead of going to Latichea, I had gone to Scandaroon (otherwi≈øe Alexandretta), I ≈øhould, in the road from thence to Aleppo, have travelled through a country, in which the mo≈øt ≈øingular and extravagant cu≈øtoms prevail that exi≈øt in any country emerged from barbari≈øm‚ÄîSeveral of tho≈øe I heard; but one in particular was, that the men pro≈øtituted their wives and daughters to all comers‚Äîand that this originated from a principle of religion, though there was every rea≈øon to believe, that, like many of their religious in≈øtitutions, it was made at la≈øt ≈øub≈øervient to the gratification of avarice.

On my way to Aleppo, I was met by a Mr. ‚Äî, an Engli≈øh gentleman, who had heard of my coming, and who, in the mo≈øt kind and ho≈øpitable manner, in≈øi≈øted upon my living at his hou≈øe in≈øtead of the Briti≈øh con≈øul's, where I ≈øhould otherwi≈øe have re≈øided during my ≈øtay there; and his manner of a≈øking me was ≈øo engaging, intere≈øting, and impre≈ø≈øive, that I found it impo≈ø≈øible to refu≈øe him.

As the great public caravan had departed from Aleppo before my arrival, and the expence of fo ‚Ä¢ ming a private one on my account was too great, as I was travelling on my own account, and had no di≈øpatches to authori≈øe or enforce my departure, or bear me out in the expence; I was con≈øtrained to remain at Aleppo till ≈øome eligible mode of travelling occurred, or another public caravan was formed. This delay gave me an opportunity of ≈øeeing and informing my≈øelf of the city and ≈øurrounding country; the re≈øult of which, I ≈øhall, in as ≈øhort a manner as po≈ø≈øible, relate to you in a future letter. It al≈øo gave occa≈øion to one of tho≈øe unhappy incidents wihch I have often had occa≈øion to lament, no ‚Ä¢ from any con≈øciou≈øne≈øs of direct criminality, but for the ≈øcope it gave to mi≈ørepre≈øentation, and the injury which that mi≈ørepre≈øentation did me in the opinion of ≈øome of my friends.

div.head: A JOURNEY TO INDIA, &c. PART II.
LETTER XXVII.
div.p: SO long as the route of my journey lay through European regions, little pre≈øented it≈øelf re≈øpecting human nature of ≈øuch very great novelty as to excite admiration or awaken curio≈øity. In all the various nations through which we have pa≈ø≈øed, a certain parity of ≈øentiment, ari≈øing from the ore great ≈øub≈øtratum, Chri≈øtianity, gave the ≈øame general colouring to all the ≈øcenes, however they might differ from each other in their various ≈øhadings. Whatever di≈ø≈øimilitude the influence of accident, climate, or local circum≈øtance, may, in the revolutions of ages, have introduced into their manners, cu≈øtoms municipal laws, and exterior forms of wor≈øhip‚Äîthe great code of religion and moral ≈øentiment remains nearly the ≈øame with all: and right and wrong, good and evil, being defined by the ≈øame principles of rea≈øon, and a≈øcertained by the ≈øame boundaries, bring the r ‚Ä¢ le of conduct of each to ≈øo clo≈øe an approx ‚Ä¢ mation with that of the orders, that, when compared with tho≈øe we are now to attend to, they may really be con≈øidered as one and the ≈øame people.

In the empire now before us, were we to leave our judgment to the guidance of general opinion of Chri≈øtian nations, we ≈øhould have, on the contrary, to contemplate man under a variety of forms and modifications, ≈øo entirely different from tho≈øe to which habit has familiari≈øed our minds, as at fir≈øt to impre≈øs us with an idea of a total di≈øruption from our nature, and induce us, as it has already the generality of our people, to divorce them from a participation of all tho≈øe ≈øympathetic feelings which ≈øerve to enforce the di≈øcharge of mutual good offices among men. Deducing all their principles, not only of moral conduct, but municipal government, from a religion radically different from, and e≈ø≈øentially adver≈øe to, ours; deluded by that ≈øy≈øtem into a variety of opinions which liberality it≈øelf mu≈øt think ab≈øurd; unaided by that enlightened philo≈øophy which learning, and learned men, acting under the influence of comparative freedom, and a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the art of printing, have diffu≈øed through the ma≈øs of Europeans; and living under a climate the mo≈øt unfavourable to intellectual or bodily exertion, they exhibit a ≈øpectacle which the philo≈øophic and liberal mind mu≈øt view with di≈øapprobation, regret, and pity‚Äîthe illiberal fierce Chri≈øtian with unequalified dete≈øtation and di≈øgu≈øt: while, on their part, bigoted to their own principles and opinions, they look on us with abhorrence, and indulge as con≈øcientious a contempt of, and antipathy to Chri≈øtians, which I apprehend no lap≈øe of time, without a great change of circum≈øtance, will be able to eradicate. Should Mahomedani≈øm and Chri≈øtianity ever happen to merge in Dei≈øm (but not otherwi≈øe), the inhabitants of Syria and Europe will agree to con≈øider each other even as fellow creatures. In Spain and Portugal, Jew, Turk, and indeed Prote≈øtant, are without di≈øtinction called hogs. In Turkey, Jews and Chri≈øtians are di≈øcriminately called dogs; each thinking the other completely
excluded from the pale of humanity, and well worthy the dagger of any TRUE BELIEVER who would have the piety to apply it.

You will allow, my dear FREDERICK, that it mu≈øt have been rather an important contemplation to your father, to have perhaps two thou≈øands miles to travel through the immen≈øe and almo≈øt trackle≈øs wilds of a country inhabited by ≈øuch people, without the con≈øolation of any others to accompany him in his journey; for, unle≈øs a public di≈øpatch was to overtake me, there was little probability of my having a ≈øingle European partner of my fatigue and perils.

However, as the period was not yet arrived at which I was to go forward, or even determine my mode of travelling, I endeavoured to ≈øoothe my mind as much as I could into content, and to take advantage of my ≈øtay at Aleppo, to acquire all the knowledge po≈ø≈øible of the place, that is to ≈øay, of that city in particular, and of the Turki≈øh government and manners in general.

A di≈øtant view of Aleppo fills the mind with expectations of great ≈øplendour and magnificence. The mo≈øques, the towers, the large ranges of hou≈øes with flat roofs, ri≈øing above each other, according to the ≈øloping hills on which they ≈øtand, the whole variegated with beautiful rows of trees, form altogether a ≈øcene magnificent, gay, and delightful: but, on entering the town, all tho≈øe expected beauties vani≈øh, and leave nothing in the ≈øtreets to meet the eye, but a di≈ømal ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of high ≈øtone walls, gloomy as the rece≈ø≈øes of a convent or ≈øtate pri≈øon, and unenlivened by windows, embelli≈øhed, as with us, by the human face divine. The ≈øtreets them≈øelves, not wider than ≈øome of the meane≈øt alleys in London, overca≈øt by the height of the pri≈øon-hou≈øes on either ≈øide, are rendered ≈øtill more formidably gloomy by the ≈øolitude and ≈øilence that pervade them; while here and there a lattice towards the top, barely vi≈øible, ≈øtrikes the
≈øoul with the gloomy idea of thraldom, coercion, and impri≈øonment.

This dete≈øtable mode of building, which owes its origin to jealou≈øy, and the ≈øcandalous re≈øtraints every man is empowered by the laws and religion of the place to impo≈øe upon the women con≈øigned either by ≈øale or birth to his tyranny, extends not to the in≈øide of the hou≈øes, many of which are magnificent and hand≈øome, and all admirably ≈øuited to the exigencies of the climate, and the dome≈øtic cu≈øtoms and manner of living of the inhabitants.

The city is adorned, it is true, here and there, with mo≈øques and appendant towers, called Minarets, from which cryers call the faithful to prayers; and in ≈øome of the ≈øtreets there are arches built at certain di≈øtances from each other, ≈øo as to carry the eye directly through them, and form a vi≈øta of con≈øiderable grandeur: but all the≈øe are far from ≈øufficient to counterbalance the general a≈øpect or gloomine≈øs and ≈øolitude which reigns over the whole, and renders it ≈øo peculiarly di≈øgu≈øting, particularly at fir≈øt ≈øight, to an Engli≈øhman who has enjoyed the gaiety and contemplated the freedom of a city in Great Britain.

The mo≈øques (Mahomedan temples) are extremely numerous in this city; indeed almo≈øt as much ≈øo as churches and convents in the Popi≈øh countries of Chri≈øtendom. There is nothing in their external appearance to attract the notice of the traveller, or indulge the eye of the architect; they are almo≈øt all of one form‚Äîan oblong quadrangle: and as to the in≈øide, I never had an opportunity of ≈øeeing one; none but Mu≈ø≈øulmen being permitted to enter them, at lea≈øt at Aleppo.

The next buildings of a public kind to the mo≈øques that de≈øerve to be particularly mentioned, are the caravan≈øeras‚Äîbuildings which, whether we con≈øider the ≈øpirit of beneficence and charity that fir≈øt ≈øugge≈øted them, their national importance, or
their exten≈øive utility, may rank, though not in ≈øplendour of appearance, at lea≈øt in true value, with any to be found in the world.

Caravan≈øeras were originally intended for, and are now pretty generally applied to, the accommodation of ≈øtrangers and travellers, though, like every other good in≈øtitution, ≈øometimes perverted to the purpo≈øes of private emolument or public job: they are built at proper di≈øtances through the roads of the Turki≈øh dominions, and afford the indigent or weary traveller an a≈øylum from the inclemency of the weather; are in general very large, and built of the mo≈øt ≈øolid and durable materials; have commonly one ≈øtory above the ground floor, the lower of which is arched, and ≈øerves for warehou≈øes to ≈øtow goods, for lodgings and for ≈øtables, while the upper is u≈øed merely for lodgings; be≈øides which, they are always accommodated with a fountain, and have cooks ≈øhops and other conveniencies to ≈øupply the wants of the lodgers. In Aleppo the C ‚Ä¢ avan≈øeras are almo≈øt exclu≈øively occupied by merchants, to whom they are, like other hou≈øes, rented.

The ≈øuburbs of Aleppo, and the ≈øurrounding country, are very hand≈øome, plea≈øant, and, to a per≈øon coming out of the gloomy city, in ≈øome re≈øpects intere≈øting. Some to≈ø≈øed about into hill and valley lie under the hands of the hu≈øbandman; others are covered with hand≈øome villas; and others again ≈øaid out in gardens, whither the people of Aleppo occa≈øionally re≈øort for amu≈øement.

The roofs of all the hou≈øes are flat, and formed of a compo≈øition which re≈øi≈øts the weather effectually. On tho≈øe mo≈øt of the people ≈øleep in the very hot weather: they are ≈øeparated from each other by walls; but the Franks, who live contiguous to one another, and who, from their di≈øagreeable circum≈øtances with regard to the Turks, are under the nece≈ø≈øity of keeping up a friendly and
harmonious intercour≈øe together, have doors of communication, which are attended with the≈øe fortunate and plea≈øing advantages, that they can make a large circuit without de≈øcending into the ≈øtreets, and can vi≈øit each other during the plaque, without running the ri≈øk of catching the infection by going among the natives below.

There is a ca≈øtle in the city which I had nearly forgotten to mention‚ÄîThe natives conceive it to be a place of great ≈øtrength. It could not, however, with≈øtand the ≈øhock of a few pieces of ordnance for a day. It is e≈øteemed a favour to be permitted to ≈øee it; and there is nothing to recompen≈øe one for the trouble of obtaining permi≈ø≈øion, unle≈øs it be the pro≈øpect of the ≈øurrounding country, which from the battlements is exten≈øive and beautiful.

Near this ca≈øtle ≈øtands the ≈øeraglio, a large old building, where the ba≈øhaw of Aleppo re≈øides: the whole of it ≈øeemed to me to be kept in very bad repair, con≈øidering the importance of the place. It is ≈øurrounded by a ≈øtrong wall of great height: be≈øides which, its contiguity to the ca≈øtle is very convenient; as, in ca≈øe of popular tumults, or inte≈øtine commotions, the ba≈øhaw finds an a≈øylum in the latter, which commands and overawes the city, and is never without a numerous garri≈øon under the command of an Aga.

Such is the ≈øummary account I have been able to collect of Aleppo, the capital of Syria; which, mean though it is when compared with the capitals of European countries, is certainly the third city for ≈øplendour, magnificence, and importance, in the va≈øt extent of the Ottoman Empire‚ÄîCon≈øtantinople and Grand Cairo only excelling it in tho≈øe points, and no other bearing any ≈øort of competition with it.

div.head: LETTER XXVIII.
div.p: HOWEVER faction may agitate or abu≈øe irritate the minds of men again≈øt the executive branch of their government, the people of every nation under Heaven are di≈øpo≈øed to think their own con≈øtitutional ≈øy≈øtem the be≈øt; and the artful intertexture of religion with governments confirms them in that opinion, and often con≈øigns the under≈øtanding to unalterable, error and illiberal prejudice. It would be wonderful, then, if the Turki≈øh con≈øtitution, founded on the Koran, was not looked upon with abhorence by the bulk of the Chri≈øtian world; and more wonderful ≈øtill, if the outrageous zealots of the Chri≈øtian church, who for ≈øo many centuries engro≈ø≈øed all the learning of Europe to them≈øelves, ≈øhould not have handed down with exaggerated mi≈ørepre≈øentation every circum≈øtance belonging to the great enemies of their faith. But that, at this day of intellectual illumination, mankind ≈øhould be enveloped in ≈øuch error and darkne≈øs, with regard to the government of ≈øo large a portion of the globe as Turkey, is extraordinary; and only to be accounted for by a reference, in the fir≈øt place, to tho≈øe religious prejudices which we ≈øuck in from our nur≈øe, and which habit, ince≈ø≈øant document, and every part of our education, tend to confirm in our mind; and in the next, to that indi≈øpo≈øition the human mind feels to part with its old prejudices, and the general indolence and incapacity of men to acquire knowledge by the arduous and fatiguing paths of ≈øtudy.

The Turki≈øh government is gro≈ø ‚Ä¢ ly mi≈ørepre≈øented. Were our opinions to be directed by the general
belief of Europeans, we ≈øhould ≈øuppo≈øe that the life and property of every being in that va≈øt empire were irremediably at the mercy of the Grand Seignior‚Äîand that, without laws to protect, or any intermediate power whatever to ≈øhield them, they were entirely ≈øubject to the capricious will of an inexorable tyrant, who, ≈øtimulated by cruelty, ≈øharpened by avarice, and unre≈øtrained by any law human or divine, did every thing to oppre≈øs his ≈øubjects, and carry de≈øtruction among mankind. I firmly believe, that, from the combination of ideas ari≈øing from tho≈øe prejudices, there are few Chri≈øtians who think or hear of the grand Turk, that do not, by an involuntary act of the mind, in≈øtantly think of blood and murder, ≈øtrangling with bow-≈øtrings, and ≈ølicing off heads with cimeters.

As there is no part of your education more near my heart than the eradicating illiberal prejudices from your mind, and fortifying you again≈øt their a≈ø≈øaults; I find it impo≈ø≈øible to refrain from giving you my opinion of the Turki≈øh government, which I have been at ≈øome pains to collect, as well from oral information as from the be≈øt authors; and which, though very far from what a generous and univer≈øally philanthropic di≈øpo≈øition would wi≈øh them to have, is very different from that which is generally attributed to them, and unque≈øtionably far more limited in its powers than the governments of ≈øeveral Chri≈øtian countries I could mention.

The con≈øtitution of that country is laid down expre≈øsly in the Koran. The emperor of Turkey (commonly called the Grand Seignior) is a de≈øcendant of Mahomet, who pretended he had the Koran from Heaven: and he is as much bound by the in≈øt ‚Ä¢ tutes of that book as any ≈øubject in his realm‚Äîas liable to depo≈øition as they to puni≈øhment for breach of them, and indeed has been more than once depo≈øed, and the next in ≈øucce≈ø≈øion rai≈øed to the throne. Thus far, it is obvious, his power is
limited and under control. But that is not all‚ÄîIt is equally certain that the Turki≈øh government is partly republican; for, though the people at large have no ≈øhare in the legi≈ølation, and are excluded by the Koran from it (which Koran has e≈øtabli≈øhed and preci≈øely a≈øcertained their rights, privileges, and per≈øonal ≈øecurity), yet there is an intermediate power which, when rou≈øed to exertion, is ≈øtronger than the Emperor's, and ≈øtands as a bulwark between the extremes of de≈øpoti≈øm and them. This body is the ULAMA, compo≈øed of all the members of the Church and the law, ≈øuperior to any nobility, jealous of their rights and privileges, and partly taken from the people, not by election, but by profe≈ø≈øion and talents.‚ÄîIn this body are compri≈øed the Moulahs, the hereditary and perpetual guardians of the religion and laws of the empire: they derive their authority as much as the Emperor from the Koran, and, when nece≈ø≈øary, act with all the firmne≈øs re≈øulting from a conviction of that authority; which they often demon≈øtrate by oppo≈øing his mea≈øures, not only with impunity, but ≈øucce≈øs. Their per≈øons are ≈øacred; and they can, by means of the unbounded re≈øpect in which they are held, rou≈øe the people to arms, and proceed to depo≈øe. But, what is much more, the Emperor cannot be depo≈øed without their concurrence.

If, by this provi≈øion of the con≈øtitution, the power of the monarch is limited, and the per≈øonal ≈øecurity of the ≈øubject a≈øcertained, on the one hand; the energy of the empire in its external operations is, on the other, very frequently and fatally pal≈øied by it. Declarations of war have been procra≈øtinated, till an injurious and irrecoverable act of ho≈øtility has been ≈øu≈øtained; and peace often protracted, when peace would have been advantageous. The Ulama being a numerous body, it has been found always difficult, often impo≈ø≈øible, to unite ≈øo many different opinions; and nothing being to
be done without their concurrence, the executive power finds it often impo≈ø≈øible to take a deci≈øive ≈øtep in a cri≈øis of advantageous opportunity. But as this code of laws and government is received as a divine revelation, binding both prince and people, and ≈øuppo≈øed to be ≈øealed in Heaven, the breach of it would be ≈øufficient to confign even the monarch to depo≈øition and death.

As to the military force, which in the hands of all De≈øpots has been made the in≈øtrument of the people's ≈ølavery, that of the Turk could avail him nothing; and, whenever it does interfere, acts only to his overthrow. The very reverence they have for his per≈øon ari≈øing from obedience to their religion, they are, √† fortiori, governed by it, not him. He holds no communication with them; and the ≈øtanding force of the Jani≈ø≈øaries is, compared with the ma≈øs of the people, only a handful. Some wild accounts, indeed, have ≈øtated it at 300,000; but the be≈øt informed fix it below 60,000 of which a great part con≈øi≈øts of fal≈øe mu≈øters and abu≈øes‚Äîgreat multitudes being enrolled to obtain certain privileges annexed to the office of Jani≈ø≈øary. The fact is, that the chief force of the empire is a militia compo≈øed of the people; who, with re≈øpect to obedience and ≈øubordination, are ≈øo loo≈øe that they leave their duty whenever they plea≈øe, without receiving any puni≈øhment. How far the people of Turkey are protected from the encroachments of power, will appear from the recital of a fact related by one of the be≈øt and mo≈øt liberal of our hi≈øtorians on that ≈øubject, and which is of too great notoriety to be doubted.

In the year 1755, the Porte, as it is called, or Palace of the Grand Vizir at Con≈øtantinople, was burnt down: in laying the plan for rebuilding it on the former ≈øite, the leading con≈øideration was, how to contrive matters ≈øo as to render it ≈øecure from accidents of a like nature in future; and it
was determined that the only certain means to do ≈øo was, to leave a ≈øpace of clear ground all round it, for which purpo≈øe the contiguous hou≈øes ≈øhould be purcha≈øed from the proprietors, and demoli≈øhed. All the owners of the hou≈øes agreed to the ≈øale, except one old woman, who pertinaciou≈øly refu≈øed: ≈øhe ≈øaid ≈øhe was born, and had lived all her life, in that ≈øpot, and would not quit it for any one. Now, in England, for the convenience of a private canal, the Parliament would force her to ≈øell. But what did they ≈øay in Turkey? When all the people cried out, "Why does not the Sultan u≈øe his authority, and take the hou≈øe, and pay her the value?" No! an≈øwered the magi≈øtrates and the Ulama, it is impo≈ø≈øible! it cannot be done! it is her property. While the power of the monarch is thus limited, and the rights of the people thus a≈øcertained by the Koran, and in things manife≈øt and open to view rigidly adhered to, ju≈øtice between man and man is rarely admini≈øtered; for, though the laws them≈øelves are good, the corrupt admini≈øtration of them di≈øarms their effect, and di≈øtorts them from their purpo≈øe. The venality of the judges is beyond conception flagitious and barefaced; and their connivances at fal≈øe witne≈ø≈øes ≈øo ≈øcandalou≈øly habitual, that te≈øtimony is become an article of commerce, and can be procured with a facility and at a price that at once ≈øtamps an approbrium on the country, and furni≈øhes matter of wonder to the con≈øiderate mind, how, if judges are flagitious and ≈øhamele≈øs enough to be guilty of it, the people can bear ≈øuch a pern ‚Ä¢ cious ≈øy≈øtem ≈øo long. Hence flow all the cen≈øures on the laws and government of that country‚Äîhence mo≈øt of the impediments under which its commerce and agriculture langui≈øh; while the actual written laws of the realm are, if duly admini≈øtered, ≈øufficiently adequate to the ≈øecurity of property, the regulation of commerce, the repre≈ø≈øion of vice, and the puni≈øhment and preven≈øion of crimes.

In endeavouring to guard your mind again≈øt an illiberal, vulgar prejudice, I have ≈øtated to you what the Turki≈øh con≈øtitution is, and what the laws; but you mu≈øt not carry what I have ≈øaid to an over≈øtrained or forced interpretation. I would not have you infer that the people are well governed; I only ≈øay, that their con≈øtitution contains within it the means of better government than is ≈øuppo≈øed. I would not have you infer that property is always ≈øecure; I barely ≈øay there are laws written to ≈øecure it. This too I wi≈øh to impre≈øs on you, that the common people are more free, and that property and life are better ≈øecured, in Turkey, than in ≈øome European countries. I will mention Spain for one. Like the country we are now contemplating, fear keeps them, as di≈øunited individuals, under pa≈ø≈øive obedience in ordinary ca≈øes; but, unlike the Spaniards, when notoriou≈øly aggrieved: when their property or religious code is forcibly violated: when the prince would riot in blood, and per≈øi≈øt in an un≈øucce≈øsful war: the Turks appeal to the law; they find a chief; the ≈øoldiery join their ≈øtandard, and depo≈øe or de≈øtroy him, not on the furious pretext of popular hatred, but upon the legitimate ground of the Koran, as an infidel, and a violator of the laws of GOD and Mahomet‚ÄîThey always, however, place his regular ≈øucce≈ø≈øor on the throne. Yet, notwith≈øtanding the general venality which pollutes the fountains of ju≈øtice, and notwith≈øtanding the great abu≈øe of power to which I have alluded, their internal policy is, in many re≈øpects, excellent, and may be compared with advantage to that of any nation in Europe. Highway-robberry, hou≈øe-breaking, or pilfering, are little known and rarely practi≈øed among them; and at all times the roads are as ≈øecure as the hou≈øes. Ample provi≈øions too are made again≈øt tho≈øe petty ≈øecret frauds which many who carry a fair face in England, and would bring an action for damages again≈øt one
that ≈øhould call them rogues, practi≈øe every day. Bakers are the mo≈øt frequent victims of ju≈øtice, and are not unfrequently ≈øeen hanging at their own doors. They are mulcted and ba≈øtinadoed for the fir≈øt and ≈øecond offence, and on the third, a ≈øtaple is driven up into their door-ca≈øe, and they are hanged from it. Notwith≈øtanding which, men are con≈øtantly found hardy enough to pur≈øue the ≈øame cour≈øe of practi≈øe; and this is more extraordinary, as the police is ≈øo ≈øtrictly attended to, that the ba≈øhaw or vizir him≈øelf goes about in di≈øgui≈øe, in order to di≈øcover frauds and detect the connivances of the inferior officers of ju≈øtice. But what will our great ladies, who con≈øume their nights, de≈øtroy their con≈øtitution, and ≈øquander their hu≈øband's property in gambling; who afterwards, to repair their ≈øhattered finances, have recour≈øe to the infamous expedient of keeping gaming-hou≈øes, and endeavour to recover by degrading means what they have lo≈øt by fo ‚Ä¢ ly, to the di≈øgrace of them≈øelves and family, and the ≈øhame of their ≈øex and rank‚ÄîWhat will they ≈øay when I tell them, that gaming is held among the Turks to be as infamous as theft, and a game≈øter looked upon with more dete≈øtation than a highway robber? The Turki≈øh amba≈ø≈øador and his train will, on their return to their country, have to tell a curious tale of this much-famed i≈øland, in that and other re≈øpects.

div.head: LETTER XXIX.
div.p:
PREJUDICE, that canker of the human heart, has injured mankind by impeding per≈øonal intercour≈øe, and thereby clogging the channel of intellectual improvement: it forbids that interchange
of ≈øentiment‚Äîthat reciprocal communication of opinion‚Äîthat generous circulation of intellectual wealth, which, while it enriches another, advances it≈øelf‚Äîit di≈ø≈øevers the bond of ≈øocial union, and makes man ≈øit down the gloomy, ≈øelfi≈øh po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor of his own mi≈øerable mite, with too much hatred to give, and too much pride to receive, tho≈øe benefits, which Providence, by leaving our nature ≈øo unaccommodated, has pointed out as nece≈ø≈øary to pa≈øs between man and man: under its influence we ≈øpurn from us the good, if we di≈ølike the hand that offers it, and will rather plunge into the mire than be guided by the light of any one who≈øe opinion is at variance with our own.

Thus it is between the Turks and us‚Äîthe little of their affairs which the prejudice of the Mahomedans have allowed them≈øelves to communicate, or ≈øuffered others to glean among them, has been in general ≈øo mi≈øu≈øed, di≈øtorted, and mi≈ørepre≈øented by the prejudices of the Chri≈øtians, that it is not going beyond the truth to ≈øay, there exi≈øt not a people in the civilized world who≈øe real hi≈øtory and genuine ≈øtate are ≈øo little known as tho≈øe of the Turks: and the wor≈øt of it is, that not one mi≈ørepre≈øentation, not one ≈øingle mi≈øtake has fallen on the generous, charitable ≈øide; but all, all without exception tend to repre≈øent the Turk in the mo≈øt degraded and dete≈øtable point of view. As the purity of the Chri≈øtian does not allow him to be guilty of a wilful, uncharitable mi≈ørepre≈øentation, we ≈øhould attribute it to unavoidable error, were it not that, till ≈øome late authors who≈øe liberality does them honour, they all walked in the very ≈øame track, and could hardly have been ≈øo uniformly erroneous from de≈øign. We mu≈øt therefore attribute it to religious zeal and mi≈øtaken piety; in which, in this in≈øtance alone, they ≈øeem to be reputable competitors with the Turks. The moro≈øene≈øs, the animo≈øity, and the ≈øupercilious ≈øelf-po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion
of the bigot, each holds in common with the other.

One ≈øtriking feature in the con≈øtitution of Turkey is, that neither blood nor ≈øplendid birth are of them≈øelves ≈øufficient to recommend a man to great offices. Merit and abilities alone are the pinions which can lift ambition to its height. The cottager may be exalted to the highe≈øt office in the empire; at lea≈øt there is no ab≈øolute impediment in his way; and I believe it has often happened. Compare this with France under its late monarchy, where no merit could rai≈øe a man from the Canaille: this, I ≈øay, is one of the criterions of a free con≈øtitution, and Turkey is ≈øo far democratic.

The very fir≈øt principle ingrafted in the minds of the Mahomedan children, is a high contempt of all religions but their own; and from the minute babes are capable of di≈øtingui≈øhing, they are taught to call Chri≈øtians by the name of Ghiaour, or Infidel: this grows up in their manhood ≈øo ≈øtrong in them, that they will follow a Chri≈øtian through the ≈øtreets, and even ju≈øtl ‚Ä¢ again≈øt him with contempt, crying, Ghiaour! Ghiaour! or, Infidel! Infidel!‚Äî Men of dignity and rank, indeed, will treat Chri≈øtians with courte≈øy; but as ≈øoon as they are gone out of hearing, will call them dog! This is mon≈øtrous! But let us recollect how a Turk would be treated in Spain or Portugal, and we ≈øhall ≈øee that inhuman bigotry may be found in a greater degree among Chri≈øtians than even Mahomedans. In Spain or Portugal they would treat them thus:‚Äîthe common people would call them hogs; they would ju≈øtle them al≈øo in contempt; and what is more, they would ≈øtab them (it has often happened) por amor de Dios; and as to the people of rank, they would very con≈øcientiou≈øly con≈øign them to the Inqui≈øition, where the pious fathers of the church would very piou≈øly con≈øign them to the flames, and coolly go to the altar, and pray to GOD to damn them
hereafter to all eternity. So far the balance, I think, is in favour of the Turks. Need I go further?‚ÄîI will.‚Äî

The Mahomedans are divided into two ≈øects, as the Chri≈øtians are into many. Tho≈øe are the ≈øect of Ali, and the ≈øect of Omar. Now, I have never heard among them of one ≈øect burning the other deliberately: but the Roman Catholics, even now, burn Prote≈øtants by juridical ≈øentence‚Äîburn their fellow Chri≈øtians to death for differing from them in a mere ≈øpeculative point of doctrine. Which then are the better men? I am ≈øure it is unnece≈ø≈øary to ≈øay; though bad are the be≈øt.

The Turks are allowed, by tho≈øe who know them be≈øt, to have ≈øome excellent qualities; and I think, that in the prodigality of our cen≈øure, which, tho' ≈øtow acquainted with them, we are forward to belittle, it would be but fair to give them credit for many of tho≈øe good qualities, which even among our≈øelves it requires the greate≈øt intimacy and the warme≈øt mutual confidence and e≈øteem to di≈øclo≈øe or di≈øcover in each other. That they have many vices is certain. What people are they that have not? Gaming they dete≈øt; wine they u≈øe not, or at lea≈øt u≈øe only a little, and that by ≈øtealth; and as to the plurality of women, it can in them be ≈øcarcely deemed a vice, ≈øince their religion allows it. One vice, and one only, of a dark dye is laid to their charge; and that has been trumpeted forth with the grievous and horrid addition, that though contradictory to nature, it was allowed by their religion. This I have rea≈øon to believe is one of the many fabrications and artifices of Chri≈øtian zealots, to render Mahomedani≈øm more odious: for I have been informed from the mo≈øt competent and re≈øpectable authority, and am therefore per≈øuaded, that the dete≈øtable crime to which I allude, is forbidden both by the Koran and their municipal laws; that it is openly condemned by all, as with us; and
that‚ñ™ though candour mu≈øt allow there are many who practice it (by the bye there are too many in England w ‚Ä¢ o are ≈øuppo≈øed to do the ≈øame), there are none hardy or ≈øhamele≈øs enough not to endeavour to conceali ‚Ä¢ t; and, in ≈øhort, that it is apparently as much reprobated there as any where; which, at all events, re≈øcues the laws and religion of the country from that ≈øtigma.

Perhaps there is no part of the world where the flame of parental affection burns with more ardent and unextingui≈øhable ≈øtrength, or is more faithfully returned by reciprocal tenderne≈øs and filial obedience, than Turkey. Educated in the mo≈øt unaffected deference and pious ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to their parents will; trained both by precept and example to the greate≈øt veneration for the aged, and ≈øeparated almo≈øt from their infancy from the women, they acquire a mode≈øty to their ≈øuperiors, and a ba≈øhfulne≈øs and re≈øpectful deportment to the weaker ≈øex, which never cea≈øe to influence them through life. A Turk meeting a woman in the ≈øtreet, turns his head from her, as if looking at her were criminal: and there is nothing they dete≈øt ≈øo much, or will more ≈øedulou≈øly ≈øhun, than an impudent, audacious woman. To get the better of a Turk therefore, there is nothing further nece≈ø≈øary, than to let ≈ølip a virago at him, and he in≈øtantly retreats.

Since the arrival of the Turki≈øh amba≈ø≈øador in London, I have had frequent occa≈ø≈øion to ob≈øerve, that the people of his train have been already, by the good example of our Briti≈øh belles and beaux, pretty much ea≈øed of their national mode≈øty, and can look at the women with as broad and intrepid a ≈øtare, as the greate≈øt puppy in the metropolis.

Their habitual tenderne≈øs and deference for the fair ≈øex, while it ≈øpeaks much for their manly gallantry‚ñ™ mu≈øt be allowed by candour to be carried to an exce≈øs extravagant and irrational. It is the greate≈øt di≈øgrace to the character of a Turk to lift
his hand to a woman: this is, doubtle≈øs, right, with ≈øome limitations; but they carry it ≈øo far as to allow no provocation, be it what it may, ≈øufficient to ju≈øtify u≈øing force or ≈øtrokes to a woman; the utmo≈øt they can do is, to ≈øcold and walk off. The con≈øequence of this is, that the women often run into the mo≈øt violent exce≈ø≈øes. There have been in≈øtances where they have been guilty of the mo≈øt furious outrages; where they have violated the laws in a collected body, and broke open public ≈øtores of corn laid up by the government: the magi≈øtrates attended, the Jani≈ø≈øaries were called, and came running to quell the riot‚Äîbut, behold they were women who committed it: they knew no way of re≈øi≈øting them, unle≈øs by force; and force they could not u≈øe: ≈øo the ladies were permitted quietly to do their work in defiance of magi≈øtrates, law, right, and rea≈øon.

Among the variety of errors and moral ab≈øurdities fal≈øely a≈øcribed to the Mahomedan religion, the exclu≈øion of women from Paradi≈øe holds a very con≈øpicuous place, as a charge equally fal≈øe and ab≈øurd; on the contrary, the women have their fa≈øts, their ablutions, and the other religious rites deemed by Mahomedans nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øalvation. Notwith≈øtanding, it has been the practice of travellers to have recour≈øe to invention, where the cu≈øtoms of the country precluded po≈øitive information; and to give their accounts rather from the ≈øugge≈øtions of their own prejudiced imagination, than from any fair inferences or conclu≈øions drawn from the facts that came under their ob≈øervation.

div.head: LETTER XXX.
div.p: THE ≈øubject I touched upon in my la≈øt three letters, and on which this, and probably ≈øome ≈øucceeding ones, will turn, is attended with circum≈øtances of great delicacy, and may po≈ø≈øibly bear the a≈øpect of at lea≈øt a dubious import, as touching the great point of religion. I will therefore, before I proceed further, explain to you (le≈øt it ≈øhould require explanation) the whole ≈øcope of my meaning.

My object throughout the whole of what I have ≈øaid re≈øpecting the Turks, is to war with prejudice, not to draw compari≈øons:‚Äîto ≈øhew that where the Mahomedans are vicious or en≈ølaved, it is not the fault of their religion or their laws:‚Äîto convince you, the Turks are not the only people in the world, who, under all the external forms of ≈øanctity and religion, are capable of the mo≈øt dete≈øtable „Äà‚óä„Äâ , and ≈øometimes, utterly be ‚Ä¢ eft of all pretentions to charity‚Äîand that, while they have been held up as a perpetual ≈øubject of reproach and accu≈øation, they were con ‚Ä¢ ting only ju≈øt the ≈øame crimes that con ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cience might have re≈øorted on their accu≈øers. If allowance can be at all made for hi≈øtorical m ‚Ä¢ ≈ørepre≈øentation, we may perhaps be di≈øpo≈øed to „Äà‚óä„Äâ that of the ignorant Catholic mi≈ø≈øion ‚Ä¢ of the early ages, as en ‚Ä¢ t ‚Ä¢ ed to ≈øome ex ‚Ä¢ u≈øe, or „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . The intemperate z ‚Ä¢ al of ‚Ä¢ ≈øe times „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢ e the fall exerci≈øe of the rational f ‚Ä¢ es; but in this age of illumination and liberality, he that fal≈øifies from polemical malice ≈øhould meet little quarter and le≈øs belief. And it mu≈øt be grievous to all men of virtue and religion to reflect,
that churchmen, di≈øciples of the Chri≈øtan church, which ≈øhould be the fountain of purity and truth, have been foremo≈øt in the li≈øt of fal≈øifiers.

The difficulty of obtaining information of any kind in Turkey, is very great; of their religion chiefly they are extremely tenacious; and as to their women, it is allowed by the be≈øt informed men, who have lived there for many years, in departments of life that gave them the be≈øt means of obtaining information Europeans can have, that, at be≈øt, but a very imperfect knowledge can be had of them. Yet travellers who probably never migrated farther than "from the green bed to the brown," have given us di≈ø≈øu≈øe accounts of their religion; and adventurers who never were beyond the purlieus of Drury, have ≈øcaled Seraglio walls, and carried off the favorites of Sultans.

The truth is, my dear FREDERICK, the Turks, like all other people, have their ≈øhare of vices, but are by no means countenanced in them by their religion; and from what I have been able to collect, as well from my own inquiries and ob≈øervations, as from reading the be≈øt hi≈øtorians, I am per≈øuaded that they have not, in the whole ≈øcope of Mahomedani≈øm, one doctrine ≈øo ≈øubver≈øive of virtue, or ≈øo encouraging to the indulgence of vice, as many that are to be found in that curious code, Popery.

The malice of our intemperate zealots again≈øt Mahomedani≈øm has been of cour≈øe extended to its founder with more than common exaggeration and additions. They have repre≈øented Mahomet to be a man of mean origin, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing a mind unenlightened by ≈øcience or literature, and an under≈øtanding and faculties naturally gro≈øs. All tho≈øe ≈øugge≈øtions are undoubtedly fal≈øe;‚Äîhe ≈øprung from the mo≈øt noble of all the Arabian tribes‚Äîthe Cor ‚Ä¢ i≈øhites: at his time, poverty, ≈øo far from being a reproach among them, was a mark of every thing that was great and dignified, if ≈øupported with magnanimity
and fortitude; and the two fir≈øt caliphs lived as poor as Mahomet him≈øelf, although they had immen≈øe revenues, commanded va≈øt armies, and were lords of great provinces. As to his under≈øtanding I can only ≈øay, that perhaps he was the very la≈øt man in the world who≈øe intellectual powers ≈øhould be called in que≈øtion. His genius was unbounded, his ≈øpirit enterpri≈øing, his powers of addre≈øs were unequalled, he was allowed to be the greate≈øt orator of his time; and yet, with all the≈øe qualifications, his under≈øtanding was ≈ølighted. It is a logical truth, that when people prove too much, they prove nothing at all: our Chri≈øtian zealots, in this in≈øtance, have over≈øhot the mark, and thereby rendered all their other information at lea≈øt doubtful. Perhaps the con≈øummation of all policy was Mahomet's pretending to be an idiot, in order to make his great and wonderful effu≈øions appear to be the immediate in≈øpiration of Heaven‚ÄîHe called him≈øelf THE IDIOT PROPHET.Mohammed.

The whole of Mahomedani≈øm may be reduced ≈øimply to this one article of faith‚Äî"There is but one GOD, and MAHOMET is the prophet;" but upon this they have ≈øuperinduced, from time to time, ≈øuch a variety of ab≈øurdities as would require volumes to de≈øcribe: however, in ≈øtrict candour let us reflect, and a≈øk our own hearts the que≈øtion, whether ≈øprinkling with holy water, or wor≈øhipping a bit of white wafer as GOD, can be exceeded, or are le≈øs ab≈øurd than the periodical ablutions of the Turks, or their going on a pilgrimage to Mecca?

With regard to the women, I have ≈øaid before that the be≈øt information we can obtain is very imporfect; all I have been able to collect, you ≈øhall have. They are formed in a ≈øtyle of the mo≈øt exqui≈øite ≈øymmetry, par ‚Ä¢ icularly about the che≈øt and bo≈øom; they have delicate ≈økins, regular features, black hair and eyes, and are, above all other beings,
cleanly and neat in their per≈øons, bathing twice a day regularly, be≈øides on other occa≈øions, and not ≈øufferng even the ≈ømalle≈øt hair to remain upon their bodies. They are kept in the mo≈øt rigorous confinement, and only per≈øons of ill fame paint. Women of character are there cha≈øte‚Äînor is their cha≈øtity to be attributed to re≈øtraint merely, for, from their infancy they are trained to di≈øcretion and ≈øelf-≈øubjection, and the mode≈øty natural to the ≈øex is cheri≈øhed from its fir≈øt dawnings. When they grow up, they are not, like our women here, ≈øubjected to the contagion of infamous gallantry; neither are the men trained to, nor do they pride them≈øelves, like ≈øome among us, on the arts of ≈øeduction. In fact, that practice makes no part of the accompli≈øhments of their fine gentlemen; nay, it is held by them to be infamous. There are no ≈øuch characters to be found in Turkey as your box-lobby loungers‚Äînone of your up≈øtart cubs like tho≈øe who doudle the be≈øt part of the day through Pall-Mall, St. James's-≈øtreet and Bond-≈øtreet; who, without birth, wealth, education, or parts, fancy them≈øelves fine fellows, and powder their no≈øes in ladies' head-dre≈ø≈øes, whi≈øpering them in order to get the reputation of gallantry; who ≈øtrut like Bantam cocks, and a≈ø≈øume a fierce air to conceal their con≈øcious want of ≈øpirit; and dre≈ø≈øed in a ≈øuit of regimentals bought by papa, at mama's reque≈øt, to exhibit ≈øweet Ma≈øter Jacky to advantage in the Park‚Äî though never to be ≈øoiled with gunpowder, or per≈øonated with a ball in the na≈øty field of battle!!!‚Äî my dear FREDERICK, I have often told you that you ≈øhall make choice of your own profe≈ø≈øion. If you ≈øhould choo≈øe any of the learned profe≈ø≈øions, you may fail in it without di≈øhonour; for many of the able≈øt men have failed before: but, mark me! avoid the military as you would ruin, unle≈øs you have the requi≈øites; let not the glitter of a ≈øcarlet coat, or the empty name of a ≈øoldier, tempt you to
be like one of tho≈øe mi≈øerable animals I have de≈øcribed. There may be chara≈øters more wicked‚ÄîI know none ≈øo utterly contemptible.

All extremes are bad; but the exceedings of virtue even where they run into error, are ≈øtill preferable to vice. However ludricous it may appear, we cannot ab≈øolutely de≈øpi≈øe or condemn the prudery of the Turki≈øh women, though it runs into ≈øuch extravagance, that, when feeding their poultry, they keep carefully vieled if there happens to be a cock among them, ≈øo fa≈øtidiou≈øly aver≈øe are they to the odious male creature ≈øeeing their pretty faces.

When the circum≈øtances under which the Turki≈øh women ≈øtand are con≈øidered, it mu≈øt appear amazing, that cha≈øtity, from principle, is univer≈øal among them, as it is confe≈ø≈øed to be: the nature of man urges him to de≈øire, with greate≈øt ardour, that which is mo≈øt forbidden; and women who are much confined, may well be ≈øuppo≈øed to have their pa≈ø≈øions inflamed by the exaggerated workings of the imagination. Infidelity, however, to the marriage-bed, is much le≈øs frequent among the men there, than among the women here; and the tide or fa≈øhion, which in this country gives ≈øuch a rapid and irre≈øi≈øtible circulation to vice and adultery, runs there in an oppo≈øite direction; and contrary to our cu≈øtoms, no man is ≈øo unfa≈øhionable in Turkey as he that has interrupttd the dome≈øtic peace of a family by ≈øeduction.

Among the many virtues which may with ≈øtrict ju≈øtice be a≈øcribed to the Turks, ho≈øpitality holds a con≈øpicuous place. It is not confined to common civility, it extends to per≈øonal protection. Many deem it ab≈øolutely their duty to ri≈øk their lives in defence of their gue≈øts; nor will any motive, however cogent, be allowed to ju≈øtify the violation of it. Nay, to ≈øuch a ≈øy≈øtem is it carried up, that an engagement with a ≈øtranger is accepted as an excu≈øe
for not obeying the ≈øummons of a great man, when no other apology, not even that of indi≈øpo≈øition, would be admitted.

While the Turks abhor and de≈øpi≈øe all other religions but their own, their government is by no means intolerant in ≈øpiritual concerns. The exerci≈øe of all religions is free, and at Con≈øtantinople (we are told) Monks dre≈øs in their habits, and are allowed at funeral proce≈ø≈øions to elevate the cro≈øs, which is more than the Engli≈øh tyranny allowed the Roman Catholics of Ireland to do, till very lately: a Turk, however, convicted of apo≈øtacy, could not by any means e≈øcape death. Meantime it mu≈øt be ob≈øerved, that if they keep up a decent ≈øemblance of the forms of their religion, no intru≈øive inquiry is made unto their real faith: and though it is one of the injunctions of Mahomet to endeavour to convert unbelievers, and they ≈øometimes in obedience to that command ≈øolicit the conver≈øion of Chri≈øtians and others; they never ≈øail to con≈øider any renegado, or per≈øon who becomes a convert, with contempt, if not di≈ølike.

I will conclude this letter with an extract from that mo≈øt valuable and accurate work, Ru≈ø≈øel's Hi≈øtory of Aleppo, which will give you a better, becau≈øe a true, notion of Turki≈øh morals, than you are likely to receive from general opinion. "Upon the whole," ≈øays he, "whether it be a≈øcribed to the influence of their political con≈øtitution, or to the ab≈øence of various temptations, which in Europe often lead to the violation of better laws; there are perhaps few great cities where many of the private and dome≈øtic virtues are in general more prevalent than at Aleppo."

div.head: LETTER XXXI.
div.p: THE u≈øe of periodical ≈øtated times of devotion is univer≈øally admitted, and the nece≈ø≈øity of adopting them makes a part of the Chri≈øtian code. The Mahomedan religion, however, exceeds it far in the rigid attention to, and frequency of, devotion. There are no le≈øs than five ≈øtated times of prayer in every twenty-four hours, fixed as indi≈øpen≈øable, at none of which a true believer fails; and the fervency of their praying exceeds even the frequency. I have heard it a≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ rted, that if the hou≈øe was to take fire while they are at their devotion, they would not break off; and ≈øo rigidly intent do they conceive it their duty to be during the time of prayer, that if in the mid≈øt of it they were interrupted by a fit of ≈øneering or coughing, they con≈øider all already done as gone for nothing, and always begin them again. And to tell a truth of them, if the Chri≈øtian cur≈øe them, they are pretty even with them in return, never failing to pray for di≈øcord, enmity, and di≈ø≈øen≈øion among their enemies, as well as health and pro≈øperity to them≈øelves; and to the efficacy of tho≈øe prayers they fondly attribute all the wars and di≈ø≈øen≈øions which ince≈ø≈øantly hara≈øs Chri≈øtendom. A bell tolls as a public notice of prayer; and when a true Mahomedan hears it, let him be where he will, whether at home or abroad, in the highway or in the market, be the place dirty or clean, wet or dry, he immeditely falls down and wor≈øhips.

As ≈øub≈øidiary to prayer they have their ablutions, in which they are full as ≈øcrupulou≈øly punctual as in their prayers. One is preparatory to prayer, another
after cohabitation with women, a third before e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ing, and another again incidental. Tho≈øe they never neglect to perform, unle≈øs ≈øome in≈øuperable ob≈øtacle lies in the way. Charity, that mo≈øt glorious doctrine of any religion, is enjoined by the Koran under the mo≈øt heavy denunciation of heavenly vengeance, in ca≈øe of neglect; and by it they are charged to regard no bounds in liberality to the poor. Many Mu≈ø≈øulmen in their zeal to di≈øcharge this duty have given a fourth, many a third, and ≈øome one half of their property. Nay, the in≈øtances are not unfrequent of men giving away their all, and living afterwards them≈øelves upon alms. To do ≈øtrict ju≈øtice it mo≈øt be ≈øaid, that poverty is no where ≈øo re≈øpectfully attended to, honoured, or reverenced, as among the Mahomedans; who have a ≈øaying among them, "that the fear of want is a mark of the judgment of GOD."

Ab≈øtinence is con≈øidered as a virtue among them, and very ≈øtrictly enjoined as a religious duty. The great fa≈øt appointed by the Koran continues for the month of Ramedan, during which time they neither eat, drink, nor conver≈øe with their wives, from ≈øun-ri≈øe till the ≈øtars appear, or the lamps are hung out at the mo≈øques. Any man who breaks it is puni≈øhed with death; but the wor≈øt of it is, that they will not allow even travellers, the ≈øick o ‚Ä¢ the wounded, to plead a right to exemption: ≈øome of the Turks, however, and all the Chri≈øtians, have hit upon expedients to pa≈øs the month without much mortification; that is, ≈øleeping in bed all day, and ≈øitting up and carou≈øing all night, to evade the re≈øtraint.

The la≈øt and greate≈øt ordinance of their religion is the pilgrimage to Mecca, which when once accompli≈øhed is ≈øuppo≈øed to be a dire≈øt pa≈ø≈øport to Heaven; and there are few of them who do not at one time o ‚Ä¢ other of their lives take that painful and hazardous journey. As this is a very intere≈øting
journey, however, to travel in the clo≈øet, as it includes the de≈øcription of a caravan, and ≈øerves to ≈øhew to what extremeties enthu≈øia≈øm can influence men, I will give you a de≈øcription of it as handed to me by a very accurate and ingenious per≈øon, on who≈øe preci≈øe veracity I can rely; fir≈øt making ≈øome remarks upon the preceding part of this letter.
