You will ob≈øerve from what I have already ≈øaid, that, excepting the mere points of religious faith, the moral ordinances of Mahomedani≈øm comprehend mo≈øt of tho≈øe parts of the Chri≈øtian religion, on the practice of which the reputation of piety is founded; and that for ≈øtrict obedience to tho≈øe ordinances the Mahomedans are more remarkable than we are. Adultery is not frequent among them; wine is ≈øeldom or never u≈øed; theft is little known; ≈øo is murder. Then in the practical parts of devotion, there are in the fir≈øt place prayers; ≈øecondly, ab≈øtinence or fa≈øting; thirdly, charity. Tho≈øe are all Chri≈øtian doctrines, more zealou≈øly ob≈øerved by them than by us. Their ablutions are at lea≈øt no injury to the cau≈øe of morality or piety; but rather, being done as a religious exerci≈øe, ≈øerve to keep up the ≈øeries of intercour≈øe which ≈øhould ≈øub≈øi≈øt between the creature and his Creator: be≈øides, I cannot help thinking with our inimitable poet Thom≈øon, that
‚Äîfrom the body's purity, the mind
Receives a ≈øecret ≈øympathetic aid. SEASONS‚ÄîSummer.
And as to the pilgrimage to Mecca, however irrational it may appear to us, it is at lea≈øt recommended by ≈øincerity and zeal, and is doubtle≈øs in the eye of an all-≈øeeing Providence meritorious. HE, we are to ≈øuppo≈øe, will judge, not by the value of the act, but the purity of the motive; and will accept it as the offering of a frail, blind mortal, bending in obedience to that which he conceives to be the will of Heaven. Be≈øides, for the life of me I cannot ≈øee why a pilgrimage to Mecca is at all more culpable
than a pilgrimage to Jeru≈øalem; not to mention the thou≈øand other holy places to which well-meaning Chri≈øtians go, for their ≈øoul's ≈øake, at imminent hazard of their lives, and certain mortification and hard≈øhip to their bodies.

Bani≈øh then, my FREDERICK! bani≈øh from your heart all illiberal and uncharitable prejudices, if any have yet found their way to it. Revere and cling to your religion as the be≈øt and mo≈øt conducive to eternal and temporal happine≈øs; and the more good becau≈øe it enjoins us to be charitable even to the Jews as well as to the Gentiles: but never think that you advance the cau≈øe of that religion, or do ≈øervice to your GOD, by waging war again≈øt your fellow-creatures for opinions they can no more help entertaining than you can help having yours, or by denouncing again≈øt them that eternal ≈øentence which re≈øts with the Almighty alone to judge of or to pronounce.

To a benevolent mind the animo≈øities of mankind pre≈øent a mo≈øt afflicting picture‚ñ™ and the frivolous pretexts upon which tho≈øe animo≈øities are grounded render it only the more horrible. One would think that the ≈øub≈øtantial traffic of life, and the ≈øtruggle of mankind for the ≈øuperfluities of it, of them≈øelves afforded ample materials for ≈øcuffle, without re≈øorting to the ≈øhadows of ≈øpeculation for contention. Yet experience has ≈øhewn us that opinion is a much more copious ≈øource of animo≈øity and warfare; and that for one man who has been cur≈øed, murdered, or de≈øtroyed by his fellow-creatures in a conte≈øt for property, there are a thou≈øand who have fallen ≈øacrifices to the vengeance of ho≈øtile opinion.

Were it po≈ø≈øible that I could obtain from the bounty of Heaven a grant of the fir≈øt wi≈øh of my heart, that wi≈øh ≈øhould be to ≈øee all mankind in harmony and mutual good will, ranging without di≈øtinction under the one great name of man and brother. As tho≈øe who foment the di≈øunion between
them are the mo≈øt pernicious mon≈øters of ≈øociety, ≈øo he who endeavours to bring them one ≈øtep nearer to a general accommodation of ≈øentiment, who ≈øtrives to inculcate the principles of mutual toleration, and encourage the growth of reciprocal affection between men as fellow beings, may be ju≈øtly ranked among the be≈øt friends of mankind, and the mo≈øt faithful ≈øervants of Him who gave being to all.

Among the gro≈øs mi≈ørepre≈øentations of which I complain, and which for the ≈øake of mankind I lament, is that general fal≈øehood, the infidelity of the Turki≈øh women. The re≈øpectable author whom I have before taken the freedom of quoting, I mean Dr. Ru≈ø≈øel, declares that in twenty years re≈øidence at Aleppo, he did not remember a public in≈øtance of adultery; and that in the private walks of ≈øcandal tho≈øe he heard of were among the lowe≈øt cla≈øs, and did not in number exceed a dozen. "In re≈øpect to the Franks (continues he) the undertaking is attended not only with ≈øuch ri≈øk to the individual, but may in its con≈øequences ≈øo ≈øeriou≈øly involve the whole ≈øettlement, that it is either never attempted, or is concealed with a ≈øecrecy unexampled in other matters. I have rea≈øon to believe that European travellers have ≈øometimes had a Greek courte≈øan impo≈øed on them for a ≈øultana; and after having been heartily frightened, have been induced to pay ≈ømartly, in order to pre≈øerve a ≈øecret which the day after was known to half the ≈øi≈øterhood in town." He remarks, however, that at Con≈øtantinople the ≈øtate of gallantry is different.

On the ≈øubject of the Turki≈øh moral character, I have endeavoured to be as conci≈øe as ju≈øtice would allow me to be; and yet I find that I have gone to ≈øome length. I cannot however di≈ømi≈øs it without giving you a trait to which the mo≈øt ob≈øtinate polemical prejudice, and the mo≈øt inveterate hatred, mu≈øt in ≈øpite of them pay the tribute of
applau≈øe. Their treatment to their ≈ølaves is beyond all example among us humane, tender, and generous, and ≈øuch as may well bring a blu≈øh into the faces of Chri≈øtian dealers in human fle≈øh. When young ≈ølaves, male or female, are bought by a Turk, they ≈øeem to be introduced into the family rather in the condition of an adopted child; they receive the ≈øame education, perform nearly the ≈øame offices, and are bound to no greater marks of re≈øpect than their ma≈øter's own children‚Äîand in fact feel none of the galling circum≈øtances of a ≈øtate of ≈øervility; the very wor≈øt treatment they ever receive is to be put on a footing with the menial dome≈øtics, or ordered to the ≈øame duty as a valet or a page. It often happens, on the other hand, that they are married into the family, and very frequently are promoted to high offices in the ≈øtate. If they adopt the religion of their ma≈øters, it is always ≈øpontaneou≈øly; and even to ≈ølaves taken in war, no compul≈øion is u≈øed to make them change their faith.

The following is the be≈øt de≈øcription I am able to give you of an Ea≈øtern caravan. It exactly coincides with my own ob≈øervations, and with the various accounts I have had from others. I owe it, as well as the account of the proceedings of the pilgrims at Mecca, to the kind offices of a friend, who took the pains to procure them for me.

div.head: DESCRIPTION OF A CARAVAN. Inclo≈øed in the preceding Letter.
div.p:
A CARAVAN, which is ≈øo often mentioned in the hi≈øtory and de≈øcription of the Ea≈øt, and in all the tales and ≈øtories of tho≈øe countries, is an a≈ø≈øemblage of travellers, partly pilgrims, partly merchants, who collect together in order to con≈øolidate a ≈øufficient
force to protect them, in travelling through the hideous wilds and burning de≈øerts over which they are con≈øtrained to pa≈øs for commercial and other purpo≈øes; tho≈øe wilds being infe≈øted with Arabs, who make a profe≈ø≈øion of pillage, and rob in mo≈øt formidable bodies, ≈øome almo≈øt as large as ≈ømall armies. As the collection of ≈øuch a number requires time, and the embodying of them is a ≈øerious concern, it is concerted with great care and preparation, and is never attempted without the permi≈ø≈øion of the prince in who≈øe dominions it is to be formed, and of tho≈øe al≈øo through who≈øe dominions it is to pa≈øs, expre≈ø≈øed in writing. The exact number of men and carriages, mules, hor≈øes, and other bea≈øts of burthen, are ≈øpecified in the licen≈øe; and the merchants to whom the caravan belongs, regulate and direct every thing appertaining to its government and police during the journey, and appoint the various officers nece≈ø≈øary for conducting it.

Each caravan has four principal officers: the fir≈øt, the caravanbachi, or head of the caravan; the ≈øecond, the captain of the march; the third, the captain of the ≈øtop or re≈øt; and the fourth, the captain of the di≈øtribution. The fir≈øt has the uncontrolable authority and command over all the others, and gives, them his orders: the ≈øecond is ab≈øolute during the march; but his authority immediately cea≈øes on the ≈øtopping or encamping of the caravan, when the third a≈ø≈øumes his ≈øhare of the authority, and exerts it during the time of its remaining at re≈øt: and the fourth orders the di≈øpo≈øition of every part of the caravan, in ca≈øe of an attack or battle. This la≈øt officer has al≈øo during the march the in≈øpection and direction of the di≈øtribution of provi≈øions, which is conducted under his management by ≈øeveral inferior officers, who are obliged to give ≈øecurity to the ma≈øter of the caravan; each of them having the care of a certain
number of men, elephants, dromedaries, camels, &c. &c. which they undertake to conduct and furni≈øh with provi≈øions at their own ri≈øque, according to an agreement ≈øtipulated between them.

A fifth officer of the caravan is the pay-ma≈øter or trea≈øurer, who has under him a great many clerks and interpreters, appointed to keep accurate journals of all the material incidents that occur upon the journey. And it is by the≈øe journals, ≈øigned by the ≈øuperior officers, that the owners of the caravan judge whether they have been well or ill ≈øerved or conducted.

Another kind of officers are the mathematicians, without whom no caravan will pre≈øume to ≈øet out. There are commonly three of them attached to a caravan of large ≈øize; and they perform the offices both of quarter-ma≈øters and aides-de-camp, leading the troops when the caravan is attacked, and a≈ø≈øigning the quarters where the caravan is appointed to encamp.

There are no le≈øs than five di≈øtinct ≈øorts of caravans; fir≈øt, the heavy caravans, which are compo≈øed of elephants, dromedaries, camels and hor≈øes; ≈øecondly, the light caravans, which have but few elephants; thirdly, the common caravans, where there are none of tho≈øe animals; fourthly the hor≈øe caravans, where there are neither dromedaries nor camels; and la≈øtly, ≈øea caravans, con≈øi≈øting of ve≈ø≈øels; from whence you will ob≈øerve that the word caravan is not confined to the land, but extends to the water al≈øo.

The proportion ob≈øerved in the heavy caravan is as follows: When there are five hundred elephants, they add a thou≈øand dromedaries and two thou≈øand hor≈øes at the lea≈øt: and then the e≈øcort is compo≈øed of four thou≈øand men on hor≈øeback. Two men are required for leading one elephant, five for three dromedaries, and ≈øeven for eleven camels. This multitude of ≈øervants, together with the
officers and pa≈ø≈øengers, who≈øe number is uncertain, ≈øerve to ≈øupport the e≈øcort in ca≈øe of a fight, and render the caravan more formidable and ≈øecure. The pa≈ø≈øengers are not ab≈øolutely obliged to fight; but according to the laws and u≈øages of the caravans, if they refu≈øe to do ≈øo, they are not entitled to any provi≈øions whatever from the caravan, even though they ≈øhould agree to pay an extravagant price for them.

Every elephant is mounted by what they call a nick: that is to ≈øay, a young lad of nine or ten years old, brought up to the bu≈øine≈øs, who drives the elephant, and pricks it with a pointed iron to animate it in the fight: the ≈øame lad al≈øo loads the fire-arms of the two ≈øoldiers who mount the elephant, with him.
The day of the caravan ≈øetting out being once fixed, is never altered or po≈øtponed‚ñ™ ≈øo that no di≈øappointment can po≈ø≈øibly en≈øue to any one.

One would ≈øuppo≈øe that ≈øo enormous and powerful a body, ≈øo well armed, might be „Äà‚óä„Äâ of moving forward without fear of being robbed: but as mo≈øt of the Arabian princes have no other means to ≈øub≈øi≈øt but by their robberies, they keep ≈øpies in all parts, who give them notice when the caravans ≈øet out, which they way lay; and ≈øometimes attack with ≈øuperior force, overpower them, plunder them of all their trea≈øure, and make ≈ølaves of the whole convoy‚Äîforeigners excepted, to whom they generally ≈øhew more mercy. If they are repul≈øed, they generally come to ≈øome agreement; the conditions of which are pretty well ob≈øerved, e≈øpecially if the a≈ø≈øailants are native Arabians. The carrying on of robberies with ≈øuch armies may appear a≈øtoni≈øhing; but when the temptation is con≈øidered, and when it is known that one caravan only is ≈øometimes enough to enrich tho≈øe princes, much of our ≈øurpri≈øe vani≈øhes.

They are obliged to u≈øe great precautions to prevent the caravan from introducing that dreadful di≈øtemper, the plague, into the places through which they pa≈øs, or from being them≈øelves infected with it. When therefore they arrive near a town, the inhabitants of the town and the people of the caravan hold a ≈øolemn conference concerning the ≈øtate of their health, and very ≈øincerely communicate to each other the ≈øtate of the ca≈øe, candidly informing each other whether there be danger on either ≈øide.‚ÄîWhen there is rea≈øon to ≈øu≈øpect any contagious di≈øtemper, they amicably agree that no communication whatever ≈øhall take place between them; and if the caravan ≈øtands in need of provi≈øions, they are conveyed to them with the utmo≈øt caution over the walls of the town.

The fatigues, hard≈øhips, and hazards, attending tho≈øe caravans, are ≈øo great, that they certainly would never be undertaken, if the amazing profits did not in ≈øome mea≈øure counterbalance them.‚Äî The merchant who travels in them mu≈øt be content with ≈øuch provi≈øions as he can get, mu≈øt part with all his delicacies, and give up all hope of ea≈øe; he mu≈øt ≈øubmit to the frightful confu≈øion of languages and nations; the fatigues of long marches over ≈øands, and under a climate almo≈øt ≈øufficiently hot to reduce him to a cinder: he mu≈øt ≈øubmit cheerfully to exorbitant duties fraudulently levied, and audacious robberies and ≈øubtle tricks practi≈øed by the herd of vagabonds who follow the caravans ‚Äîfor preventing which, the merchants have a variety of well contrived locks, that can only be opened by tho≈øe who know the knack of them.
But in ≈øome tracks of caravans there are dangers, and horrible ones again≈øt which no human fore≈øight or power can provide, and beneath which whole caravans ≈øink, and are never after heard of.

The Egyptian caravans are particularly ≈øubject to hazards in the horrid tracks they are nece≈ø≈øarily
obliged to take through ≈øandy de≈øerts, where, for boundle≈øs extents, nature has denied one ≈øingle circum≈øtance of favour; where a blade of gra≈øs never grew, nor a drop of water ever ran; where the ≈øcorching fire of the ≈øun has bani≈øhed the kindly influence of the other elements; where, for ≈øeveral days journey, no object meets the eye to guide the pa ‚Ä¢ ched traveller in his way; and where the ca≈øual track of one caravan is clo≈øed by the moving ≈øands, before another can come to take advantage of it. In tho≈øe va≈øt plains of burning ≈øands, if the guide ≈øhould happen to lo≈øe his way, the provi≈øion of water, ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to carry them to the place where they are to find more, mu≈øt infallibly fail them; in ≈øuch a ca≈øe the mules and hor≈øes die with fatigue and thir≈øt; and even the camels, notwith≈øtanding their extraordinary power to ≈øub≈øi≈øt without water, ≈øoon peri≈øh in the ≈øame manner, together with the people of the caravan, wandering in tho≈øe frightful de≈øerts.

But more dreadful ≈øtill, and ≈øtill more inevitable, is the danger when a ≈øouth wind happens to ri≈øe in tho≈øe ≈øandy de≈øerts. The lea≈øt mi≈øchief it occa≈øions is, to dry up the leathern bags which contain the provi≈øion of water for the journey. This wind, to which the Arabs give the epithet of poi≈øoned, often ≈øtifles in a moment tho≈øe who have the misfortune to meet it; to prevent which, they are obliged to throw them≈øelves immediately on the ground, putting their faces clo≈øe to the burning ≈øands which ≈øurround them on all ≈øides, and covering their mouths with ≈øome linen cloth, le≈øt by breathing they ≈øhould ≈øwallow in≈øtantaneous death, which this wind carries with it wherever it extends. ‚ÄîBe≈øides which, whole caravans are often buried under moving hills of burning ≈øand, rai≈øed by the agitation of the winds.

All tho≈øe horrors and dangers are ≈øo exqui≈øitely de≈øcribed by our charming bard THOMSON, that I
cannot refrain tran≈øcribing the pa≈ø≈øage, as bringing them more immediately home to the under≈øtanding and the heart, than volumes of common de≈øcription could do.
‚ÄîBreathed hot
From all the boundle≈øs furnace of the ≈øky,
And the wide glittering wa≈øte of burning ≈øand,
A ≈øuffocating wind the pilgrim ≈ømites
With in≈øtant death. Patient of thir≈øt and toil,
Son of the De≈øert! even the camel feels,
Shot through his withered heart, the fiery bla≈øt.
Or from the black-red either bur≈øting broad
Sallies the ≈øudden wirlwind. Straight the ≈øands,
Commov'd around, in gathering eddies play;
Nearer and nearer ≈øtill they darkening come;
Till, with the general all-involving ≈øtorm
Swept up, the whole continuous wilds ari≈øe;
And by their noon-day fount dejected thrown,
Or ≈øunk at night in ≈øad di≈øa≈øtrous ≈øleep
Beneath de≈øcending hills, the caravan
Is buried deep. In Caro's crowded ≈øtreets
Th' impatient Merchant wondering waits in vain,
And Mecca ≈øaddens at the long delay.‚Äî
Yet, notwith≈øtanding all tho≈øe horrible circum≈øtances of terror and danger‚Äîtrade, and the de≈øire of gain, on the one hand, induce multitudes of people to run the hazard.
Impiger extremos currit Mercator ad Indos,
Per mare pauperiem fugiens, per ‚Ä¢ ax ‚Ä¢ , per ignes. HORACE.
And on the other hand, enthu≈øia≈øm and religious zeal ≈øend thou≈øands to tempt their fate, and take a pa≈ø≈øage to Heaven through tho≈øe horrid regions. Thus we ≈øee in what various ways delu≈øion operates. ‚ÄîThe merchant might find a livelihood, and the bigot his way to divine favour, ju≈øt as well by ≈øtaying within the confines of their own native home.

div.head: ACCOUNT OF THE CEREMONIES OBSERVED BY PILGRIMS ON THEIR ARRIVAL AT MECCA.
div.p: The caravans are generally ≈øo ordered, as to arrive at Mecca about forty days after the Fa≈øt of Ramedan, and immediately previous to the Corban, or Great Sacrifice. Five or ≈øix days before that fe≈øtival, the three great caravans, viz. that from Europe, that from A≈øia Minor, and that from Arabia, unite; and all, con≈øi≈øting of about two hundred thou≈øand men, and three hundred thou≈øand bea≈øts of burthen, encamp at ≈øome miles from Mecca. The pilgrims form them≈øelves into ≈ømall detachments, and enter the town to arrange the ceremonies preparatory to the Great Sacrifice. They are led through a ≈øtreet of continual a≈øcent, till they arrive at a gate on an eminence, called the Gate of Health. From thence they ≈øee the great mo≈øque which inclo≈øes the Hou≈øe of Abraham. They ≈øalute it with the mo≈øt profound re≈øpect and devotion, repeating twice, "Salam Alek Iru≈øoul Allah!" that is to ≈øay, "Peace be with the Amba≈ø≈øador of God!" Thence, at ≈øome di≈øtance, they mount five ≈øteps to a large platform faced with ≈øtone, where they offer up then prayers; they then de≈øcend on the other ≈øide of it, and advance towards two arches, of the ≈øame kind of dimen≈øions, but at ≈øome di≈øtance from each other, through which they pa≈øs with great ≈øilence and devotion. This ceremony mu≈øt be performed ≈øeven times.

From hence proceeding to the great mo≈øque which inclo≈øes the Hou≈øe of Abraham, they enter the mo≈øque, and walk ≈øeven times round the little building contained within it, ≈øaying, "This is the Hou≈øe of GOD, and of his ≈øervant Abraham." Then ki≈ø≈øing with great veneration a black ≈øtone, ≈øaid to have de≈øcended white from Heaven, they go to the famous well called Zun Zun, which the angel
≈øhewed to Hagar when ≈øhe was di≈øtre≈ø≈øed in the de≈øert, and could find no water for her ≈øo ‚Ä¢ I≈øhmael, and which the Arabs call Zem Zem. Into this well they plunge with all their clothes, repeating "Toba Alla, Toba Alla!" that is to ≈øay, "Forgivene≈øs, GOD! Forgivene≈øs, GOD!" They drink a draught of that foe ‚Ä¢ id, turbid water, and depart.
The duty of bathing and drinking they are obliged to pa≈øs through once; but tho≈øe who would gain Paradi≈øe bofore the others, mu≈øt repeat it once a day during the ≈øtay of the caravan at Mecca.

At fifteen miles from the town of Mecca there is a hill called "Ghiabal Arafata," or "the Mount of Forgivene≈øs." It is about two miles in circumference‚Äîa mo≈øt delicious ≈øpot. On it ADAM and EVE met, after the LORD had, for their tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions, ≈øeparated them forty years. Here they cohabited and lived in exce≈øs of happine≈øs, having built a hou≈øe on it, called "Beith Adam," that is to ≈øay, "the Hou≈øe of Adam." On the eve of the day of Sacrifice, the three caravans, ranged in a triangular form, ≈øurround this mountain‚Äîduring the whole night the people rejoice, clamour, and riot‚Äîfiring off cannon, mu≈økets, pi≈øtols, and fireworks, with an ince≈ø≈øant ≈øound of drums and trumpets. As ≈øoon as day breaks, a profound ≈øilence ≈øucceeds‚Äîthey ≈ølay their ≈øheep and offer up their ≈øacrifice on the mountain with every demon≈øtration of the mo≈øt profound devotion.

On a ≈øudden a ≈øcheik (or head of the temple), a kind of prelate, ru≈øhes from amid≈øt them, mounted on a camel‚Äîhe a≈øcends five ≈øteps, rendered practicable for the purpo≈øe, and in a ≈øtudied ≈øermon preaches thus to the people:

"Return prai≈øe and thanks for the infinite and immen≈øe benefits granted by GOD to Mahomedars, through the mediation of his mo≈øt beloved friend and prophet, Mahomet: for that he has delivered them from the ≈ølavery and bondage of ≈øin and idolatry,
in which they were plunged; has given them the Hou≈øe of Abraham, from whence they can be heard, and their petitions granted; al≈øo the mountain of forgivene≈øs, by which they can implore Him, and obtain a pardon and remi≈ø≈øion of all their ≈øins.

"For that the ble≈ø≈øed, pious, and merciful GOD, giver of all good gifts, commanded his ≈øecretary, Abraham, to build him≈øelf a hou≈øe at Mecca, whence his de≈øcendants might pray to the Almighty, and their de≈øires be fulfilled.

"On this command all the mountains in the world ran, as it were, each ambitious to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the ≈øecretary of the LORD, and to furni≈øh a ≈øtone towards erecting the holy hou≈øe; all, except this poor little mountain, which, through mere indigence, could not contribute a ≈øtone. It continued therefore thirty years grievou≈øly afflicted: at length the Eternal God ob≈øerved its angui≈øh, and, moved with pity at its long ≈øuffering, broke forth, ≈øaying, I can forbear no longer, my child! your bitter lamentations have reached my ears; and I now declare, that all tho≈øe who go to vi≈øit the hou≈øe of my friend Abraham ≈øhall not be ab≈øolved of their ≈øins, if they do not fir≈øt reverence you, and celebrate on you the holy Sacrifice, which I have enjoined my people through the mouth of my prophet Mahomet! Love God! Pray! Give Alms!"
After this ≈øermon the people ≈øalute the Mountain, and depart.

div.head: LETTER XXXII.
div.p:
IN my la≈øt letters I endeavoured to give you an account of the Turki≈øh government, laws,
and con≈øtitution in general, ≈øo far as I was able to collect information on the ≈øubject. I will now proceed to a de≈øcription of tho≈øe particular parts of that va≈øt empire through which I had occa≈øion to travel.

During my ≈øtay at Aleppo, I experienced much politene≈øs and ho≈øpitality from the European gentry re≈øident there, and particularly from Mr. ‚Äî, at who≈øe hou≈øe I entirely re≈øided; and as the Franks live on a very good footing with each other, the time pa≈ø≈øed ≈øo agreeably, that were it not for "that within," I ≈øhould have been happy enough ‚ÄîWe rode out occa≈øionally, ≈øometimes hunting, ≈øometimes merely for the ride ≈øake. Sometimes with an intelligent native whom I got to walk with me, or with ≈øome of the Franks, I walked about the town, in order to amu≈øe away the time and ≈øee what was going forward, notwith≈øtanding the cry of "Frangi Cucu!" or "Cuckold Frank!" which frequently followed us for the length of a ≈øtreet. Sometimes we went of evenings to ≈øome of the outlets, where preperation was made for our reception by ≈øervants, previou≈øly di≈øpatched for the purpo≈øe, and there regaled with coffee, wine, fruits, &c.

The fir≈øt day we went on a party of the la≈øt mentioned kind, Mrs. ‚Äî did us the honour to accompany us: the place appointed was in a range of beautiful rural gardens that lie along the ≈øide of a river; where the well cultivated earth teeming with a va≈øt abundance of the be≈øt e≈øculent plants, flowers, flowering ≈øhrubs and fruit-trees, afforded a mo≈øt delicious regale to the ≈øen≈øes; and the plane, the willow, the a≈øh, the pomegranate, and a variety of other trees, clu≈øtered together in almo≈øt impervious thickets, yielded a delightful ≈øhady retreat from the piercing rays of the ≈øun. It was on this occa≈øion that I got the fir≈øt ≈øpecimen of Turki≈øh illiberality, which, as I was entirely unprepared for it
confounded me, and nearly deprived me of temper and of prudence. As we walked along, I ob≈øerved ≈øeveral Turks addre≈ø≈øing them≈øelves to Mrs. ‚Äî and me, who walked arm in arm, and ≈øpeaking with a loudne≈øs of voice, contortion of countenance, and violence of ge≈øticulation, attended with a clappling of hands, which, though I did not under≈øtand their language, I could plainly perceive carried the appearance of a menace or in≈øult. I was at a lo≈øs what to think of it: Mrs. ‚Äî blu≈øhed, and ≈øeemed much hurt: Mr. ‚Äî and the other gentlemen were ≈øilent, and betrayed not the lea≈øt mark of emotion or re≈øentment. At length, when we got from them, I a≈øked what it meant? and was told, that it was all aimed at Mrs. ‚Äî, or at lea≈øt occa≈øioned by her: that, bigoted to the cu≈øtoms of their own country, and utterly ignorant of tho≈øe of any other, they were affected with great indignation at her dre≈øs, occa≈øional derangement of her veil, and, above all, at the ≈øhamele≈øs and unpardonably wicked circum≈øtance of a woman walking ≈øo openly and familiarly in the company of men.‚Äî Talking of this affair afterwards with Mr. ‚Äî, the lady's hu≈øband, he a≈ø≈øured me, that there was not an opprobrious and infamous epithet which the vulgar ingenuity of the brighte≈øt que ‚Ä¢ n in Billings-gate could think of, that they had not huddled upon us. I was beyond mea≈øure a≈øtoni≈øhed at the coolne≈øs with which he bore it, and ≈øaid, that if I had under≈øtood what they had ≈øaid, I ≈øhould mo≈øt certainly have been unable to re≈øtrain my≈øelf, and would have knocked one of them down as an example to the re≈øt. Had you done ≈øo, returned he, you would certainly have repented it: for, if you e≈øcaped being ≈øtoned, or put to death upon the ≈øpo ‚Ä¢ , the legal puni≈øhment for an infidel ≈øtriking a true believer, you could not e≈øcape; and probably we, and all the Franks in the city, would ≈øuffer for it: it would at all events cau≈øe a dreadful convul≈øion
in the place, and you would your≈øelf fall a ≈øacrifice to it.

Not long ≈øince I was conver≈øing on this ≈øubject with a gentleman of my acquaintance, and mentioned it with ≈øome a≈øperity, as ari≈øing from a ≈øpirit of bigotry peculiar to Mahomedans. "My good Sir," ≈øaid he, "let me undeceive you! the very ≈øame would be done in mo≈øt parts of Spain. I was one day," continued he, "walking in a town in Spain, in company with the wife of a gentleman who re≈øided there, who were both well known, and bore the mo≈øt unexceptionable character. Seeing me however walking with her, the populace, as we pa≈ø≈øed, held up two fingers ≈øignificantly, and cried to her, What a cuckold is your hu≈øband! and concluded with 'Todas las Ingle≈øas ≈øon putas,' or, "All Engli≈øh women are ‚Äîs." He added, "that he was even in Cadiz, where commercial intercour≈øe renders them rather more liberal than in other part of the country, frequently acco≈øted by little children them≈øelves, with 'Crees in Dios?' Do you believe in God? and ≈øometimes forming a cro≈øs with the thumb of the right hand and the forefinger, 'Crees en e≈øte? Crees en e≈øte? No! No! Ah Judio! Moro! Barbaro! Bruto! Prote≈øtante! Puerco! Voia al los Infernos!!' In Engli≈øh‚ÄîDo you believe in this? Do you believe in this? No! No! Ah Jew! Moor! Barbarian! Prote≈øtant! Hog! Go to Hell!!"
So much for human beneficience and charity, under the fo≈øtering au≈øpices of religion!

The hou≈øe of Mr. ‚Äî, where I was ≈øo ho≈øpitably lodged, was a magnificent edifice, built in all the fulne≈øs of Ea≈øtern grandeur and luxury, and furni≈øhed with all the ≈øplendour and ≈øtate of Turkey, united with the ta≈øte and opulence of Great Britain. It was indeed a hou≈øe in which voluptuou≈øne≈øt it≈øelf might ≈øit down with ≈øatisfaction‚ÄîThe mo≈øt unaffected ho≈øpitality and generous benevolence
≈øpread the board, and politene≈øs and affability pre≈øided over all. Never ≈øhall I forget it‚Äînever ≈øhall I think of it without gratitude and e≈øteem.

A gentleman of the opulence and con≈øequence of Mr. ‚Äî, with a hou≈øe ≈øuch as I have de≈øcribed, and a di≈øpo≈øition to ≈øocial enjoyment, was not, you will conclude, without a re≈øort of company and friends; in truth, he had friends even among the better ≈øort of Turks. Parties of plea≈øure had no intermi≈ø≈øion while I was there; and as the ladies of Europe or of European extraction in that country are highly accompli≈øhed, ≈øpeak many languages, are indefatigable in their efforts to plea≈øe, and receive ≈øtrangers from Europe with a joy and ≈øatisfaction not to be de≈øcribed, Aleppo would have been to me an Ely≈øium, if the plea≈øures of the place did not from the beginning ≈øuffer diminution from my own painful ≈øen≈øations, which were aggravated at la≈øt by an incident that aro≈øe from my intercour≈øe there‚Äî of which more hereafter.

While I remained at Aleppo, I walked as I before told you, frequently about the ≈øtreets; and I think I never was witne≈øs to ≈øo many broils in all my life put together, as I was in my wanderings there‚ÄîNot a time I went out that I did not ob≈øerve one, two, three, and ≈øometimes half a dozen or more. They have nothing terrible in them however, and, were it not extremely di≈øgu≈øting to ≈øee men ≈øcold, would be very entertaining; for I will venture to ≈øay that a ≈øtreet battle "√† la Turque" is one of the mo≈øt ludicrous exhibitions in the world. The parties approach to each other, and retreat mutually, as the action of the one gives hopes to the other of victory, lifting their hands, and flouri≈øhing them in the air, as if ready to ≈øtrike every moment, grinning and gna≈øhing their teeth, while their beard and whi≈økers be≈øprent with the ≈øpume of their mouths, and wagging with the quick motion of their lips and gha≈øtly contortions of their jaws, pre≈øent the
mo≈øt ridiculous ≈øpectacle imaginable. They reminded me at the time of a ver≈øe in an old Engli≈øh ballad:‚Äî
'Tis merry in the hall,
When beards wag all.

Nothing, in fact, can exceed the extravagance of their ge≈øture: the vehement loudne≈øs of their voice, or the whim≈øical di≈øtortions of their countenances, in which are di≈øplayed ≈øometimes the quicke≈øt vici≈ø≈øitudes of fear and fury, and ≈øometimes the mo≈øt laughable combination of both. All this time, however, not a ≈øingle blow is actually ≈øtruck; but they compen≈øate for the want of bodily prowe≈øs by the exerci≈øe of the tongue, denouncing vengeance again≈øt each other, threatening in≈øtant demolition, lavi≈øhing every bitter reproach, every filthy epithet, and every horrible imprecation that they can think of, and both boa≈øting occa≈øionally of their patience and forbearance, which fortunately enabled them to refrain from annihilating their adver≈øary. At la≈øt the fray gradually decays: exhau≈øted with fatigue, and half choaked with du≈øt and vociferation, they retreat gradually backwards to their own doors; where ≈øumming up all their malignity into a mo≈øt horrid execration, they part for the time, and retire to vaunt in empty threat, and growl away their rage, in the rece≈ø≈øes of their haram.

Yet tho≈øe people are found terrible in battle by the Chri≈øtian troops that have from time to time been oppo≈øed to them: here, if proof be wanting of the effects of religion on the human mind, is an incontrovertable one of its powerful operations. Under the influence of their faith, which tells them that they go to Paradi≈øe in≈øtantly if killed in battle with Infidels, they perform prodigies of valour fighting again≈øt Chri≈øtians; while, forbidden by that faith to imbrue their hands in the blood of a true believer, their pa≈ø≈øions have been gradually brought under the dominion of their religion, till
that which at fir≈øt was faith at la≈øt becomes habit, and the appropriate energy and courage of the man has ≈øunk into the degrading and ema≈øculant efforts of the woman.

The practice of fighting, or per≈øonal conflicts between individuals of the ≈øame ≈øociety, ≈øeems to have been condemned by the univer≈øal con≈øent of all religions. The Gentoos, as well as all the other ≈øects of the various parts of the Ea≈øt through which I have travelled, give vent to their pa≈ø≈øion in nearly the ≈øame manner as the Turks. The Chri≈øtians too are mo≈øt ≈øtrictly forbidden to ≈øtrike one another by the great Author of their faith: but it is their good fortune, that they not only have the be≈øt religion in the world for their guidance, but that they are the only people in the world who claim exemption from the penalties of that religion, and think them≈øelves wronged and their per≈øonal rights infringed, if they are refu≈øed the privilege of breaking through its rules whenever tho≈øe rules are at variance with their convenience.
Be it your care, my dear child, to fortify your mind with the ≈øpirit of true religion and ≈øound morality, and let your practice in life be ever guided by their precepts.

div.head: LETTER XXXIII.
div.p:
THE avidity with which human creatures ≈øearch for ≈øomething to recreate the mind and keep it in exerci≈øe, is of it≈øelf a convincing proof of the natural activity of our intellectual faculties, and ≈øhews that, like the different parts of the body, they were given by Providence to be called into effort and improved by practice. As they who
by the favours of opulence are exempted from the nece≈ø≈øity of actual bodily labour, are obliged to have recour≈øe to artificial labour called exerci≈øe; ≈øo they who have the misfortune to be precluded from the employment of the mind by bu≈øine≈øs, are obliged to ≈øeek mental exerci≈øe in a variety of expedients, ≈øome of which are criminal, ≈øome fooli≈øh, and ≈øome good for nothing or indifferent. Cards, dice, and games of chance are (according to the extent to which they are carried) of the two former‚Äîtale and novel-reading of the two latter. Tho≈øe however ≈øerve to occupy the vacant hours of all the idle and unemployed. And when letters deny their friendly aid, we find among our≈øelves the deficiency ≈øupplied from the le≈øs ample re≈øources of the memory; and ≈øtory-telling, love tales, fairy tales, and goblin and gho≈øt adventures, are recited round the villager's fire or the kitchen hearth in as great numbers, with as much ingenuity, and to as great effect, as they are to be found written in the innumerable volumes on the ≈øhelves of our circulating libraries.

In Turkey, where the art of printing has not yet been known, were the circulation of literary productions is chained down within the narrow compa≈øs of manu≈øcript, and where therefore the efforts of genius are repre≈ø≈øed by di≈øcouragement, the bu≈øine≈øs of ≈øtory-telling makes in it≈øelf a profe≈ø≈øion, which, as it is acquired by ≈øtudy and pro≈øecuted with art, is followed with con≈øiderably profit.

One day a friend (a French gentleman) who e≈øcorted me through the town called to draw me out with him for a walk; he ≈øaid he wi≈øhed to ≈øhew me ≈øome of the caravan≈øeras, ob≈øerving that he thought I ≈øhould be entertained with a view of them. I agreed to go; and he brought me to two, which after he had ≈øhewn to me and explained their principle, police, and etiquette, I could not help admiring and approving. To both the≈øe were attached
eating-hou≈øes and coffee-hou≈øes, and every appendage that could render them convenient and comfortable. As we were about leaving the la≈øt I ob≈øerved my friend ≈øtop and li≈øten attentively. "Come hither," ≈øaid he, after a minute's pau≈øe‚Äî "come into this coffee-hou≈øe, here is ≈øomething going forward that may amu≈øe you."

We accordingly entered the coffee-hou≈øe, where we ≈øaw a number of people, ≈øome ≈øeated in the Turki≈øh fa≈øhion, ≈øome on low ≈øtools, and ≈øome ≈øtanding; and in the middle a man walking to and fro, ≈øpeaking in an audible voice, ≈øometimes ≈ølowly, ≈øometimes with rapidity, varying his tones occa≈øionally with all the inflections of a corre≈øponding ≈øen≈øe. I could not under≈øtand him, but he ≈øeemed to me to ≈øpeak with "good empha≈øis and good di≈øcretion:" his action was ea≈øy to him, though expre≈ø≈øive and emphatical; and his countenance exhibited ≈øtrong marks of eloquent expre≈ø≈øion. I could not help ≈øtaring with a≈øtoni≈øhment at a ≈øcene ≈øo new to me, and felt great approbation of the tones and manner of this extraordinary orator, though I could not under≈øtand a ≈øingle word he ≈øaid. He was li≈øtened to by all with great attention, and the Turks (albeit not u≈øed to the laughing mood) frequently betrayed ≈øtrong ≈øymptoms of ri≈øibility: but in the height and torrent of his ≈øpeech he broke ≈øuddenly off, ≈øcampered out of the door and di≈øappeard. I ≈øet it down that he was a maniac or lunatic of an ingenious kind, and was for going away. "Stay," ≈øays my friend, "re≈øt where you are for a few minutes, let us hear further."

The orator had ≈øcarcely been gone three minutes when the room was filled with the buzz of conver≈øation, a word of which I could not under≈øtand, but which my guide li≈øtened to very attentively. At length the buzz began to grow loud, and ≈øoon increa≈øed into clamour; when a ≈øcene en≈øued of ≈øo very ludricious a kind as forced me to cram my
handkerchief into my mouth to ≈øuppre≈øs a laugh, or at lea≈øt ≈øo to ≈øtifle it as to avoid ob≈øervation. In ≈øhort, they were di≈øputing violently, and the beards were, as I once before mentioned to you, ALL WAGGING. I became more convul≈øed with mirth; and my friend ≈øeeing that I was likely to give offence, took me under the arm and hurried me out of the coffee-hou≈øe: we retired into a porch in the caravan≈øera, where I gave vent to my ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed laughter till my ≈øides were ≈øore and my eyes ran tears.

"In the name of God, my friend!" ≈øaid I, "tell me what is the meaning of all that extravagant ≈øcene to which we have ju≈øt now been witne≈øs: who is that madman that ≈øpoke ≈øo much? and why did they all quarrel after he went away?"
"Come, come," ≈øaid he, "let us retire to my hou≈øe, and I will there explain the whole of it to you, from begining to ending."

I accordingly accompanied him home, where we found a very gay circle a≈ø≈øembled, to whom he de≈øcribed my a≈øtoni≈øhment; recounting my immoderate laughter, till they all laughed very nearly as immoderately as my≈øelf. "You mu≈øt know," ≈øaid he, addre≈ø≈øing him≈øelf to me, "that he whom you took to be a madman, is one of the mo≈øt celebrated compo≈øers and tellers of ≈øtories in A≈øia, and only wants the aid of printing to be perhaps as eminent in reputation for making CONTES, as Marmontel or Madame D'Anois. As we pa≈ø≈øed along I heard his voice, and, knowing it, re≈øolved to let you ≈øee him, and brought you in for the purpo≈øe. He was entertaining the company with a very curious, intere≈øting, and comical ≈øtory; the ≈øubject of which was ava ‚Ä¢ ce: the hero a mi≈øer of the name of Ca≈ø≈øem. His mi≈øery and avarice are repre≈øented in it as bringing him into a variety of ≈øcrapes, which wa≈øte his wealth; and his character is drawn with ≈øuch ≈øtrength of colouring, and marked with ≈øuch
grote≈øque lines of humour‚Äîhe related it moreover with ≈øo much wit, in ≈øuch admirable language, and embelli≈øhed and enforced it with ≈øuch appropriate action, utterance, and empha≈øis‚Äîthat it rivited, as you ≈øaw, the attention of all his auditors, and extorted laughter even from Turki≈øh gravity,"
"But how came he to break off ≈øo ≈øuddenly?" ≈øaid I.

"That," returned my friend, "is a part of the art of his profe≈ø≈øion, without which he could not live; ju≈øt as he gets to a mo≈øt intere≈øting part of the ≈øtory, when he has wound the imagination of his auditors up to the highe≈øt climax of expectation, he purpo≈øely breaks off to make them eager for the re≈øt. He is ≈øure to have them all next day, with additional numbers who come on their report, and he makes his terms to fini≈øh the ≈øtory."
"Why then," interrupted I, "why did they‚ñ™ who remained behind fall di≈øputing?"

"That I will explain to you," ≈øaid he. Ju≈øt as he broke off, Ca≈ø≈øem the mi≈øer (who, as far as I heard, ≈øeems as well drawn as Moliere's AVARE) having already ≈øuffered a thou≈øand whim≈øical mi≈øfortunes and dilapidations of fortune, is brought before the cadi for digging in his garden, on the pre≈øumption that he was digging for trea≈øure. As ≈øoon as the hi≈øtorian was gone, they fir≈øt applauded him, and then began to di≈øcu≈øs his ≈øtory‚Äîwhich they one and all agreed in prai≈øing highly and when they came to talk of the probable i≈ø≈øue of the ≈øequel of it, there were almo≈øt as many opinions as there were men in company; each maintained his own, and they went to loggerheads as you law about it‚Äî when the chance is a thou≈øand to one, that not one of them was near the mark. One in particular ‚Ä¢ urmiled that Ca≈ø≈øem would be married to the cadi's daughter; which gave great offence to ≈øome, and rou ‚Ä¢ ed another of the company to declare, that he was well a≈ø≈øured in his con≈øcience that Ca≈ø≈øem
would be brought to the ba≈øtinado or the ≈øtake, or el≈øe hanged, in the ≈øequel."

"And is it po≈ø≈øible," ≈øaid I, "that a group of twenty or thirty rational beings can be ≈øo far bereft of all common ≈øen≈øe, as to di≈øpute upon the re≈øult of a contigency, which ab≈øolutely depends on the arbitrary fancy of an acknowledged fabricator of fal≈øehoods?"

"C'e≈øt vrai, Mon≈øieur? and thereby they demon≈øtrate the power of the poet (for poet we may call him); and entre nous, I doubt whether it is not more rational, as well as more fair, to di≈øpute what the denouement ought to be before than after the inventor of the piece has di≈øpo≈øed of it, as is the practice with us. When he has once fini≈øhed his fable, you will find them all content, and the voice of critici≈øm ≈øilent. Now in France or England, our critics lie perdue, in order to attack the poet, let him fini≈øh his performance how he may. But you will recollect, Mon≈øieur, that in Turkey critici≈øm is the hone≈øt ≈øpontaneous i≈ø≈øue of the heart, and with us is a trade, where ≈øometimes lucre, ≈øometimes vanity, but oftener than both, envy and malice direct the deci≈øion, and di≈øpo≈øe to cavil and cen≈øure.
"But we will go again to-morrow," continued he, "probably he will be there to conclude or proceed further with his ≈øtory;" I agreed to this and we parted.

On the next day we went, and not ≈øeeing the o ‚Ä¢ in his place, lounged about the caravan≈øera, and going to another coffee-hou≈øe found him de
‚Ä¢ g ‚Ä¢ h all his might. My friend told me that the ≈øtory h ‚Ä¢ was now on was quite different from the former: however we watched his motions ≈øo effectually that we got the conclu≈øion of the ≈øtory of Ca≈ø≈øem, which completely di≈øappointed the progno≈ø ‚Ä¢ of the two conflicting Turki≈øh critics; for Ca≈ø≈øem was neither ba ‚Ä¢ adoed, ≈øtaked,
or hanged, nor married to the cadi's daughter, but lived to ≈øee that extreme avarice was folly; and to be ≈øen≈øible that to make the proper u≈øe of the goods of this life is to enjoy them.

div.head: LETTER XXXIV.
div.p: MY la≈øt letter has ≈øhewn you, that the conceptions of genius, though they may want the aid of the pre≈øs to bring them in full and perfect di≈øclo≈øure to the world, will yet bur≈øt through their bounds, and find ≈øome means of communication with mankind; for though the art of printing be unknown in Turkey, the emanations of ≈øuperior intellect and fancy find their way to the general ear through the medium of public declamation in coffee-hou≈øes. This letter will ≈øerve to ≈øhew you that malver≈øation in office, public delinquency, and all tho≈øe crimes of the great, which with us are cognizable by no tribunal but that of the public pre≈øs, are not altogether ≈øo exempt from the la≈øt and expo≈øure of the ≈øatiri≈øt in Turkey, as the want of that great palladium of freedom would di≈øpo≈øe us to believe; and that, incredible as it may appear, the magi≈øtrates are held up to ridicule in public exhibition, ≈øatiri≈øed with all the extravagant vulgarity of coar≈øe humour and unpoli≈øhed wit, and expo≈øed with all the bitter exaggerations of envenomed genius.

The French gentleman whom I mentined to you in my la≈øt, as having procured me that plea≈øant repa≈øt at the coffee-hou≈øe, called on me a morning or two after that, and reminded me how highly I ≈øeemed to be entertained: ≈øaid, there were often to be ≈øeen, by walking about and going into public
places, a variety of things, which however worthle≈øs and unentertaining in them≈øelves, might, from the novelty of their appearance, and their unlikeline≈øs to any thing ≈øeen in Europe, ≈øerve either to divert by their oddity, or promote the conception of new ideas in the mind: he therefore recommended it to me, with all the zeal of a per≈øon who took an intere≈øt in my happine≈øs, to keep on my legs and in the ≈øtreets while I remained at Aleppo.

You will conclude that I readily complied, and we ≈øallied ou ‚Ä¢ directly in que≈øt of adventure. We proceeded, therefore, to one of the before mentioned coffee-hou≈øes, where, as my friend ob≈øerved to me, though there were no people of great rank, there was generally ≈øomething to afford contemplation or amu≈øement; and where, if nothing el≈øe occurred, the motley appearance of the company was ≈øufficient to excite a variety of whim≈øical emotions, and ≈øugge≈øt numberle≈øs ludicrous images to the imagination of an Engli≈øh or French man. As there was no orator at work declaiming, I had time to indulge my≈øelf with a more accurate view than I had before taken of the group that ≈øurrounded us: and ≈øurely never was ponderous gravity more ludicrou≈øly, or in more various forms depicted by any caricaturi≈øt in the world.‚ÄîHere it was to be ≈øeen, in all its ≈øhadings, from the ≈øelf-important nod of ≈øerious cogitation, down to the ≈øoporific a≈øpect of ≈øtolid ≈øtupidity. Not a mu≈øcle was moved in way of mirth, not a face di≈øgraced with a ≈ømile, and I could not help thinking all the time, that if every nation of the earth was to take ≈øome animal for its in≈øignia, as the Briti≈øh a≈ø≈øume the lion, and the Pru≈ø≈øian the eagle, the Turks might be divided in their choice between the appropriate claims of the owl and the a≈øs.

Soon after we entered, a band of what they called mu≈øic, ≈øtruck up a concert. And here again the notion of the owl and the a≈øs ≈øtruck me with
increa≈øed force, as peculiarly pre≈øiding over their mu≈øic: for no other combination of ≈øounds that I know on earth, but the ≈øcreeching of the one, and the braying of the other, could form any thing to re≈øemble this concert, with which the auditory ≈øeemed va≈øtly plea≈øed, though I was obliged to betake my≈øelf to ≈ølight, in order to get relief from the torture it give me. The Turks, however, as I retreated, honoured me with a few remarks, which as I did not under≈øtand, I could not preci≈øely feel‚ñ™ my friend however told me, they were to the effect that we were Frangi Dumus (Frank H ‚Ä¢ g)‚ñ™ and had no more ear than that filthy animal for mu≈øic.

Come, ≈øaid my friend, don't be di≈øcouraged!‚Äî But the mu≈øic‚Äîthe mu≈øic! interrupted I.‚ÄîWell then, ‚Ä¢ id „Äà‚óä„Äâ , the mu≈øic, or rather the ≈øounds were execrable to be ≈øure; they have at lea≈øt ≈øerved to e≈øtabli≈øh this certainty, that there is nothing, however di≈øcordant or d ‚Ä¢ ≈øtable, which habit will not reconcile us to. Doubt not, ≈øaid he, that the be≈øt piece of H ‚Ä¢ ndel or Correll ‚Ä¢ , performed by the be≈øt band in Rome, would appea ‚Ä¢ as ridiculous to them, as their concert did to us.

We vi ‚Ä¢ ted many coffee-hou≈øes in the cour≈øe of that day, in every one of which we found ≈øomething to divert or di≈øgu≈øt us; at length as we entered one, my friendly guide turning to me with ≈øatisfaction in his countenance, ≈øaid "Here is ≈øomething about to go forward that will plea≈øe you better than the concert of mu≈øic." What is it ≈øaid I? A drama, returned he; a drama, to you mo≈øt certainly of a new and extraordinary kind; and I do a≈ø≈øure you that ≈øo zealous am I to procure you entertainment, I would rather than a couple of lou ‚Ä¢ s' you could under≈øtand what is going forward: your hearty mirth and laughter, added he, are ≈øufficient to put one in ≈øpirits. He then directed my attention to a fellow who was bu≈øily employed
in erecting a ≈øtage, which he accompli≈øhed in a time incredibly ≈øhort. The light of the ≈øun was completely excluded, and a puppet ≈øhew commenced, which gave great delight to all the audience, and ignorant as I was of the language, plea≈øed me very much.

I was a≈øtoni≈øhed when informed that one man only ≈øpoke for all the per≈øonages of the drama, for ≈øo artfully did he change his tone of voice, that I could have ≈øworn there had been as many people to ≈øpeak, as there were characters in the piece. The images were not actually puppets, commonly ≈øo called, but ≈øhadows done in the manner of A≈øtley's Ombres Chinoi≈øes. They were, however, far inferior to his in execution and management, though the dialogue and incident evidently appeared even to me, to be executed with a degree of the vis comica far ≈øuperior to any I ever ≈øaw in a thing of the kind in Europe; indeed ≈øo perfect was the whole, that though I knew not a word of the language, I comprehended clearly the plan of the piece, and many of the ≈øtrokes of humour contained in the dialogues.‚ÄîThe plan was obviou≈øly taken from a ≈øtory which I have read in ≈øome of the Ea≈øtern tales, I believe the Arabian Nights Entertainments, and it is founded on the law of the country, that a man may repudiate his wife twice, and take her back again; but in the event of a third divorce, cannot retake her to his marriage-bed, unle≈øs ≈øhe be previou≈øly married and divorced by another man. To obviate which, hu≈øbands who repent having divorced their wives a third time, employ a man to marry them, and re≈øtore her back again; and he who does this office is called a Hullah.‚ÄîIn the piece before us, however, the Lady and the Hullah like each other ≈øo well, that they agree not to ≈øeparate; the hu≈øband brings them both before the cadi to enforce a ≈øeparation; and the ≈øcene before the cadi was as ludic ‚Ä¢ ous, and
as keen a ≈øatire upon tho≈øe magi≈øtrates as can well be conceived, though of the low kind.

The piece was introduced with a grand nuptial proce≈ø≈øion, in which the ma≈øter di≈øplayed the powers of his voice by uttering a variety of the mo≈øt oppo≈øite tones in the whole gamut of the human voice; ≈øometimes ≈øpeaking, ≈øometimes ≈øqueaking like a hurt child, ≈øometimes hazz ‚Ä¢ ing as a man, a woman, or a child; ≈øometimes neighing like a hor≈øe, and ≈øometimes inter≈øper≈øing it with other ≈øuch ≈øounds as commonly occur in crowds, in ≈øuch a manner as a≈øtoni≈øhed me: while the concomitant action of the images, grote≈øque beyond mea≈øure, kept up the laugh; hor≈øes kicking and throwing their riders, a≈ø≈øes biting tho≈øe near them, and kicking tho≈øe behind them, who retire limping in the mo≈øt ridiculous manner; while their great ≈øtanding character in all pieces, KARA-GHUSE (the ≈øame as our Punch), rai≈øed a general roar of ob≈øtreperous mirth even from the Turks, with his whim≈øical action, of which I mu≈øt ≈øay that, though non≈øe≈øical, though indecent, and ≈øometimes even di≈øgu≈øting, it was on the whole the mo≈øt fini≈øhed compo≈øition of low ribaldry and fun that I ever beheld.

When they come before the cadi, he is ≈øeated in his divan of ju≈øtice; but as ≈øoon as the complaint is opened and an≈øwered, he ri≈øes and comes forward between the contending parties: here he turns to one and demands in a terrific tone what he has to ≈øay, while the other puts ca≈øh in his hand behind, and in proportion as the ca≈øh is counted in, increa≈øes the terror of his voice; he then pockets the money, and again turns to the other, and demands what he has to offer, while in like manner he receives the bribes from his adver≈øary and puts it in an oppo≈øite pocket: this alternate application la≈øts till the pur≈øes of both are exhau≈øted, when, giving a great groan, he retires on one ≈øide to reckon
the money of each from a pocket he has on either ≈øide, one called plaintiff, and the other defendant; when balancing them, he finds plaintiff better by one a≈øper (or three-halfpence) than defendant, and pronounces his judgment accordingly. The defendant appeals to the ba≈øhaw; they go before him: KARA-GHUSE (Punch) however, takes the defendant a≈øide, and in a dialogue, which my friend a≈ø≈øured me was pointed, witty, and bitterly ≈øatirical, developes to him the whole ≈øy≈øtem of magi≈øtratical inju≈øtice, advi≈øes him to bribe the ba≈øhaw, and declaring his zeal for all young people fond of amorous enjoyment (which he is at ≈øome pains to enlarge upon to the exce≈øs of indelicacy), offers him the aid of his pur≈øe. The advice is followed; the bribe is accepted; the cadi's decree is rever≈øed, and him≈øelf di≈øgraced, and the mob at once hu≈øtle him and bear the Hullah home to his bride with clamours of joy. Here again the ma≈øter ≈øhewed his extraordinary powers, giving not only, as before, di≈øtinct and oppo≈øite tones of voice, but huddling a number of different ≈øounds with ≈øuch ≈økill and rapidity together, that it was ≈øcarcely po≈ø≈øible to re≈øi≈øt the per≈øua≈øion that they were the i≈ø≈øue of a large and tumultuous crowd of men and animals. With this extravagant melange the curtain dropped, and the performance ended.

Returning home we conver≈øed together on the ≈øubje≈øt of the piece, which I confe≈øs I could not get out of my head for ≈øome time. My friend explained to me, as well as he could recollect, a great part of the dialogue, and a≈ø≈øured me, that the freedom of ≈øpeech of Mon≈øieur KARA-GHUSE had from time to time created a great deal of unea≈øine≈øs, not only to private offending individuals, but to the magi≈øtracy it≈øelf‚Äîthat no offender, however intrenched behind power, or en≈øhrined in rank, could e≈øcape him‚Äîthat ba≈øhaws, cadis, nay the Ja ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øaries them≈øelves, were often made the ≈øport of his fury; that he was not
more re≈øtrained in the effu≈øions of ob≈øcenity which he utered, than in his ≈øatire; that he was always well received and applauded, even venerated (as we venerate the liberty of the pre≈øs) as a bold teller of truth, who with little mi≈øchief does a great deal of good, and often rou≈øes the lethargic public mind to a ≈øen≈øe of public dangers and injuries. He added, that in ≈øome ca≈øes the magi≈øtrate had been obliged to interfere; and the ba≈øhaw him≈øelf was ≈øeriou≈øly called upon at times to ≈øtop the licentious tongue of this champion of Freedom, KARA-GHUSE.
"Well then," ≈øaid I, "it appears upon the whole that Mon≈øieur KARA-GHUSE is a very great black-guard, but a very witty, and a very hone≈øt one."

"You have ju≈øt hit it," ≈øaid he; "and if Ma≈øter Kara-ghu≈øe was to take ≈øuch liberties in France, Spain, Portugal, or Germany, all his wit and hone≈øty would not ≈øave him from puni≈øhment. In England you do not want him; every man there is a KARA-GHUSE, and every new≈øpaper a puppet-≈øhew."
"And yet," returned I, "we complain ≈øadly of want of liberty!"
"That is natural," returned my ≈øagacious Frenchman, "perfectly natural. Liberty is like money; the more we have of it, the more covetous we grow."

"Very true, Mon≈øieur," ≈øaid I, plea≈øed with his compliment to our happy con≈øtitution, and to clinch his ob≈øervation, gave a Latin quotation, which when a child I got out of Lilly's Grammar, "Cre≈øcit amor nummi, quantum ip≈øa pecunia cre≈øcit;" and then changging nummus for libertas, "Cre≈øcit amor libertatis, quantum ip≈øa libertas cre≈øcit."

"'Tis very well, Mon≈øieur," ≈øaid he; and to carry on your allu≈øion, may we not ≈øay, that they who do not know when they have enough, are as dangerou≈øly wrong in the one ca≈øe, as tho≈øe who ≈øay we have too much, are in the other? The Engli≈øh complaining of the want of liberty, reminds me of the coffee-hou≈øe orator's ≈øtory of Ca≈ø≈øem, who,
wallowing in wealth, lo≈øt it all in the wild pur≈øuit of more.‚ÄîI hope however that they never will, like him, lo≈øe their ≈øtock in vain endeavours to increa≈øe it."

div.head: LETTER XXXV.
div.p:
WHILE I was, in the manner I have already mentioned, endeavouring to pa≈øs away the time as cheerfully as po≈ø≈øible, till a caravan was formed, or Company's di≈øpatches were coming over land, of which I might avail my≈øelf; I found my ≈øituation in the hou≈øe of Mr. ‚Äî growing extremely critical. That gentleman, of who≈øe good ≈øen≈øe, and truly excellent di≈øpo≈øition, I had too manifold proofs to call them in que≈øtion, had, though fallen into the vale of years, married his lady at a very tender age. She was then young, beautiful, full of ≈øen≈øibility, and gifted with ≈øuch natural endowments both of mind and per≈øon, accompanied with all tho≈øe accompli≈øhments which helped to dre≈øs them to advantage, that ≈øhe might well be acquitted of vanity, even though fancy ≈øugge≈øted to her ≈øhe was fit to grace and confer happine≈øs on a younger bed; while reflection on the obvious di≈øparity of the match (which the cool temper of ≈øatiety po≈ø≈øibly ≈øugge≈øted to him) might perhaps have alarmed his mind to circum≈øtances of probable danger, that, before wedlock, were all hid behind the deceptive veil of pa≈ø≈øion. Whether the≈øe were the private ≈øentiments that influenced both or either of them, I cannot pre≈øume to determine, though I think it probable: for I was not long in the hou≈øe till I plainly perceived they were on a very bad footing with each other, and
in ≈øhort that di≈øagreement was become habitual to them. At fir≈øt, that is to ≈øay, for a few days after my becoming an inmate of their hou≈øe, decency enforced concealment, and the ebullitions of peevi≈øhne≈øs were ≈øtifled by the dictates of prudence; but the animo≈øities of the connubial ≈øtate are tho≈øe which of all others are the mo≈øt impatient under control; and as time, by producing familiarity, relaxed re≈øtraint, the pent-up pa≈ø≈øions began to force their way, and open bickering took place in my pre≈øence.

It is but barely doing ju≈øtice to my≈øelf to ≈øay, that I felt the mo≈øt poignant concern at ≈øeeing a couple, each ≈øo perfectly amiable in all other re≈øpects bla≈øting the hours that ≈øhould be given to harmony and love, in jarring reproach, and recrimination; and I would have given all I was worth that I had never had occa≈øion to e≈øteem them ≈øo much, or that I could give them that peace which ≈øeemed to have ‚Ä¢ lown them for ever. Fain would I ca≈øt a veil over the whole tran≈øaction fain would I bury it even from my≈øelf, in oblivion: but it has been made by my enemies the ≈øubject of triumphant ≈ølander; and to do ju≈øtice to my≈øelf, and di≈øclaim the extent of guilt which they would impute to me, I am reluctantly obliged to avow the ≈øhare I had, and declare how the matter really ≈øtood. I mu≈øt ≈øpeak the truth, and hope you will not conceive that I de≈øignedly lean too heavily upon any one, to ea≈øe my≈øelf of my ≈øhare of the load.

Whatever dome≈øtic unea≈øine≈øs may ≈øub≈øi≈øt between a married pair, the man, if prudent, will endeavour to conceal it; and the woman, if truly virtuous, will take care to do ≈øo: ≈øhould great di≈øparity of age (as in the pre≈øent in≈øtance) be the ca≈øe, the lady is more particularly bound to conceal any unea≈øine≈øs, le≈øt it ≈øhould be attributed to that cau≈øe which people are in ≈øuch ca≈øes too prone to ≈øu≈øpect, di≈ølike to her hu≈øband; and before young men, above all, ≈øhe ≈øhould be mo≈øt exemplary, as
≈øhe mu≈øt well know that their natural vanity, combined with the leading idea of her aver≈øion and infidelity to her hu≈øband, ≈øugge≈øt ideas to them from whence their warm imaginations draw inferences of a nature too plea≈øing to be parted with, and too probable not to be put in practice, or at lea≈øt attempted. Here then a woman at once lays her≈øelf fairly open to the a≈ø≈øaults of illicit love. I think it will not be denied, that the woman who promulgates the di≈øagreements between her and her hu≈øband, particularly if ≈øhe ≈øuffers a young man to be privy to it, is either extremely ignorant, or intentionally vicious, or both.

That the lady I allude to may in ≈øome re≈øpect be acquitted of this imputation, I mu≈øt tell you, that ≈øhe was only eighteen years of age; her tender, inexperienced mind had not yet arrived to that maturity which gives ≈øound judgment; and though of good natural talents, highly cultivated (for ≈øhe ≈øpoke fluently Engli≈øh, French, Italian, Arabic, Per≈øian, and the Greek and Turki≈øh languages), ≈øhe yet was ≈øimple‚ñ™ innocent, uninformed in the ways of the world, and incapable of rea≈øoning from cau≈øes up to con≈øequences. But unfortunately that ≈øimplicity is attended with as much mi≈øchief, though not guilt, as the wilful mi≈øconduct of the more experienced; it has the ≈øame baleful effects with the hearers, in≈øpires the ≈øame confidence, emboldens with the ≈øame hopes, and leads to the ≈øame pernicious practices.

I have already mentioned, and will now remind you, that I was then young. Perhaps it was owing to a congeniality pointed out by our age, perhaps to a compa≈ø≈øionate politene≈øs amounting to tenderne≈øs, which I always di≈øclo≈øed on tho≈øe unhappy occa≈øions, joined perhaps to the ardent look of youth kindled by the imaginations to which this imprudent conduct in≈øen≈øibly gave birth, that the lady thought proper to take the very hazardous ≈øtep
of making a confidant of a young man and a ≈øoldier ‚Äîand revealing to me the whole tale of her grievances, with a pathetic eloquence, that would have made an impre≈ø≈øion upon a much le≈øs ≈øu≈øceptible heart than mine. I declare it mo≈øt ≈øolemely, that though this extraordinary mark of confidence and e≈øteem communicated to my heart ≈øtrong ≈øen≈øations of unju≈øtifiable plea≈øure: I ≈øo far got the better of my≈øelf at fir≈øt, as to receive the whole with the ≈øame appearance of tranquility, as if I had been only a confidential female friend. I pitied, it is true;‚ÄîI expre≈ø≈øed my pity:‚ÄîI advi≈øed, not treacherou≈øly but faithfully;‚ÄîI ≈øaid ≈øuch things as occured to me to be mo≈øt likely to a≈ø≈øuage and extingui≈øh the flame of di≈øcord, and lead to an amicable adju≈øtment; and I parted for that time with her to go to a ≈øelf-approving pillow, where, while my fancy was inflamed and tickled by the flattering mark of regard ≈øhewn me by ≈øo all-accompli≈øhed a per≈øon. I had the ≈øoothing delightful con≈øciou≈øne≈øs of having, as far as I was able, done my duty, and e≈øcaped the corroding reflection of having violated the rights of ho≈øpitality.

Not an opportunity however afterwards offered, that the ≈øame unhappy point was not the ≈øubject of di≈øcu≈ø≈øion, and unfortunately tho≈øe opportunities but too frequenlly occurred; till at length we began to feel that they were the ≈øweete≈øt minutes of our lives, and were ‚Ä¢ ought for with indu≈øtrious avidity by both of us. No human re≈øolution was ≈øufficient to with≈øtand ≈øuch an unlucky concurrence of circum≈øtances: from lamenting the grievances, we wi≈øhed to remove them; from wi≈øhing, we proceeded to con≈øider the means: and when we had got that length, the fl ‚Ä¢ ght was not far to the ext ‚Ä¢ s and‚Äîthe execution of it. My pa≈ø≈øions hurried me before them, my expre≈ø≈øions grew gradually more and more ung ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ our conver≈øation became more intere≈øting and warm; and though I
felt and ≈øtruggled to be guided by the ≈øtrict principles of honour, and formed a thou≈øand re≈øolutions not to tran≈øgre≈øs the laws of ho≈øpitality, by injuring the man who had treated me with ≈øuch kindne≈øs, the ≈øtruggle became too ≈øeverve for me‚Äîthe de≈øire of plea≈øing a lovely woman, who had repo≈øed ≈øuch unbounded confidence in me, and who ≈øeemed to expect and require of me to alleviate her mi≈øery, at length bore down all the oppo≈øitions ≈øugge≈øted by rea≈øon and principle, and I agreed to become the in≈øtrument of her removal from this unhappy ≈øituation. We fell‚Äîbut not intirely. There is one length to which no earthly con≈øideration‚Äîno allurement however dazzling could tempt me‚Äîit is now the mo≈øt cordial con≈øolation to my mind; I never ≈øuffered my≈øelf to think of tre≈øpa≈ø≈øing on the decorum of his hou≈øe, nor did we in any ≈øingle in≈øtance carry our intercour≈øe to a direct violation of his bed. Though the tran≈øports of youthful pa≈ø≈øion hurried us into conver≈øations and reflections on the ≈øubject of her determination to be ≈øeparated from her hu≈øband, yet that pa≈ø≈øion was of too delicate a kind to ≈øink into the brutal ≈øordid indulgence of di≈øhonourable ≈øtolen embraces. She wi≈øhed for that ≈øeparation, rather as a ≈øubterfuge from ince≈ø≈øant diurnal mi≈øery, than as a prelude to any vicious or illicit enjoyment; and we looked with plea≈øure to the event, but we looked no further.

It is thus that, in the down-hill path of vice, we are hurried on ≈øtep by ≈øtep, fondly imagining that each ≈øucce≈ø≈øive object, which bounds our ≈øight, will ≈øtop our headlong career; while alas! every ≈øtep we advance gives additional rapidity to our de≈øcent: like the centripetal force of a projectile, our pace increa≈øes with uniformly accelerated motion‚Äî till di≈ødaining all control, and breaking down every impediment that rea≈øon, morality, or honour throw in the way to re≈øcue us or retard our ruin, we precipitate
unexpectedly into the la≈øt gulph of vice and infamy.

Fortunately, however, an incident intervened in the pre≈øent ca≈øe, which arre≈øted our progre≈øs down this hideous de≈øcent, and re≈øerved us both I hope to conviction of our folly, and repentance of our error. And I have the con≈øolation to reflect, that out of ≈øuch a ho≈øt of dangers and temptations as I was be≈øet with, I have e≈øcaped without the actual perpetration of a deed, which would, had it happened, in all probability have embittered my life.

While we hugged our≈øelves in the ≈øecurity and ≈øecrecy of expre≈ø≈øing our genuine ≈øentiments, her hu≈øband di≈øcovered our wi≈øhes, and all at once took the nece≈ø≈øary mea≈øures for preventing them. So that, overwhelmed with grief and ≈øhame, I directly formed the re≈øolution to leave Aleppo, and proceed in the be≈øt manner I could on my de≈øtination.

Thus you ≈øee, my dear FREDERICK, was your father, by failing to re≈øi≈øt the fir≈øt impre≈ø≈øions of an unlawful and di≈øhonourable pa≈ø≈øion, in≈øen≈øibly led to the very brink of a precipice, the bare remembrance of which now makes him ≈øhudder with horror. The ≈øtory, by means unnece≈ø≈øary for me to mention, took wind. The folly of ≈øome, the malice of others, and the unaccountable propen≈øity to fal≈øehood of more, trumpeted it about with many exaggerations to my injury, and I was held up as the deliberate ≈øeducer of innocence: but the whole tran≈øaction is exactly as I have ≈øtated it; and the di≈øagreements previous to my arrival at Aleppo, which, in telling the ≈øtory, they purpo≈øely left out, were of ≈øuch public notoriety, that every European, even the con≈øul him≈øelf, was fully acquainted with them. This is the con≈øequence of a deviation from the ≈øtrict rule of right. Trea≈øure it up in your mind, my child, never to be forgotten; and let it operate as a caution to you, how you entangle
your≈øelf in the ≈ønares of women: recollect that my e≈øcape was ≈øingularly fortunate, and the mere effect of accident; and flatter not your≈øelf, that becau≈øe accident ≈øerved in one ca≈øe it will in another. Providence has, for the wi≈øe≈øt of purpo≈øes, implanted in our nature a fondne≈øs for the fair ≈øex; and ≈øo long as it is u≈øed prudently and virtuou≈øly, it con≈øtitutes the fir≈øt happine≈øs of life; but if on the contrary, it ≈øtimulates us to exce≈øs, impels to injure our fellow creature, or break in upon the repo≈øe of a family; it is our reproach, our ≈øhame, our cur≈øe, and very frequently our utter and irremediable ruin; add to this, that there is in the general character of women, a capriciou≈øne≈øs, a levity, and a vanity, under the influence of which they ≈øport with men, only to di≈øplay their power, and evince the force of their charms, which makes the cultivation of their good graces in any way hazardous. To adopt the idea of an old epigram‚Äî "There is no living with them, nor without them."

As your happine≈øs, my dear boy, is the fir≈øt object of my life, my efforts ≈øhall be turned to the guiding of your greener years from any premature impre≈ø≈øions; and when rea≈øon and matured age fit you for the cultivation and enjoyment of female ≈øociety, be it mine to direct your ≈øteps away from that cla≈øs, who think rank a ≈øufficient ≈øanction for vice, who fl ‚Ä¢ re in all the bronze of ari≈øtocratic a≈ø≈øurance, under a load of obloquy, beneath which the poore≈øt pea≈øant's wife would ≈øink; who think that wealth and rank confer a right to commit exce≈ø≈øes that would degrade the meane≈øt of the canaille; and felicitate them≈øelves with the reflection, that, under the protection of family or an infamous hu≈øband, they may indulge in enormities, for which the lowe≈øt of their ≈øex are beating hemp in Bridewell.

div.head: LETTER XXXVI.
div.p: THE di≈øcovery to which I alluded in my la≈øt letter, ≈øurpri≈øed and grieved me very much ‚Ä¢ and indeed it a≈øtoni≈øhed me the more, from the manner in which it was communicated.

One day I received a polite me≈ø≈øage from the Briti≈øh con≈øul, ≈øaying, he wi≈øhed to ≈øpeak to me as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible, upon a bu≈øine≈øs of great con≈øequence. I thought at fir≈øt, that it might be ≈øome plan for my proceeding on my journey‚Äîperhaps Company's di≈øpatches that had arrived to go over land; and at intervals, ≈øomething like apprehen≈øions of the true motive of his ≈øending for me flew acro≈øs my mind. I however went to him, when, after ≈øome little introductory conver≈øation, he told me, that my ho≈øt Mr. ‚Äî had been with him that morning, laying before him a complaint of a mo≈øt extraordinary and ≈øerious nature, of which, as it immediately concerned me, he thought him≈øelf bound to inform me, in order that I might either contradict ≈øo gro≈øs a calumny if it were untrue, or find means to avoid the obviou≈øly nece≈ø≈øary re≈øult if founded in fact.

He then proceeded to relate to me, that Mr. ‚Äî had informed him of a con≈øpiracy having been meditated again≈øt his peace and honour, between his wife and the Engli≈øh gentleman whom he had entertained in his hou≈øe; that their plan was nothing le≈øs than an elopement, and that he did not know how ≈øoon it might be carried into execution, if not timely prevented; and finally, that he had demanded the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the con≈øul and his intere≈øt with the Turki≈øh magi≈øtrate to prevent
it, by granting him an armed force for the protection of his hou≈øe.

I was much ≈øurpri≈øed to find that conver≈øations ≈øo very guarded as ours were di≈øcovered, and more ≈øo that the aggrieved per≈øon did not think proper to ≈øpeak to my≈øelf, and charge me in per≈øon with the offence; never reflecting the while, that all my ideas were military, and his merely commercial: I was al≈øo much at a lo≈øs to conjecture how he came to make the di≈øcovery‚Äîbut this I found afterwards he owed to a female ≈øervant, who had been improvidently intru≈øted by her mi≈øtre≈øs with the ≈øecret.

Finding, however, that by whatever means he became acquainted with the affair, it was a certain fact that he was appri≈øed of it, I directly acknowledged the whole truth with the utmo≈øt candour to the con≈øul; told him the affair ≈øtep by ≈øtep as it aro≈øe, a≈ø≈øuring him (which I really thought to be the ca≈øe) that pity for the lady's deplorable ≈øituation made me li≈øten to ≈øuch a mea≈øure; and that unlawful pa≈ø≈øion had ≈øo little to do with it, that in all our private conferences we had never tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed the limits of purity; and that her per≈øon was, at lea≈øt re≈øpecting me, and I firmly believed all mankind, ≈øpotle≈øs and inviolate. I added, that great allowances were to be made for a young creature barely eighteen years of age, con≈øigned by the wickedne≈øs of avaricious parents to the embraces of a man of ≈øixty-five; who, amiable and worthy though he was, in ≈øocial intercour≈øe with the world (which I knew him to be), was yet in the mo≈øt indi≈øpen≈øable point of connubial felicity ≈øo utterly defective, as nece≈ø≈øarily to create di≈øgu≈øt and abhorrence in a youthful mind. I remarked to him, that, in the forming of laws, it as plainly appeared on their face, who made them among≈øt the Engli≈øh, as it does on the face of the Gentoo laws, that they were made by the Bramins: for,
as by the latter the penalty of a few punsCouries, a kind of ≈ømall ≈øhells u≈øed in India, as a circulating medium in place of coin, in value much below the ≈ømalle≈øt copper coin‚Äîa Pu ‚Ä¢ s a certain number of them. of couries (not value a ≈øhilling) is annexed to the perpetration of a crime, for which tho≈øe of another cla≈øs loo≈øe their lives; ≈øo, among us, it appears that our laws are made by the aged, the decrepid, the ≈øen≈øual, and the rich. El≈øe it could never happen that there were in the ≈øame code, laws to puni≈øh marriage between the young and vigorous, and enable the brutality of a parent to take its full ≈øcope, and con≈øign, as in the pre≈øent in≈øtance, youth, beauty, health, and every per≈øonal attraction, to the arms of age, infirmity, and impotence. And I concluded by ≈øaying, that all parties aiding in ≈øuch an unnatural confederacy ≈øhould be puni≈øhed.

The con≈øul fairly acknowledged there was too much truth in what I had ≈øaid; but remarked withal, that it was rather a hazardous experiment, and he was ≈øure it would be an endle≈øs one, to correct all the abu≈øes to which the fallibility of man, and his incompetency to form any thing perfect, nece≈ø≈øarily left ≈øociety and their laws liable‚Äî that the law was written, and it was the duty of every individual to obey it‚Äîand that in ca≈øes of adultery, the offence could be ju≈øtified on no ≈øolid grounds whatever, for, independent of the feelings of the hu≈øband, which perhaps were more poignant in old age than youth, the injury to his family was not to be got over, in probably giving to him an heir no way a-kin to him. "It would be right, I think," ≈øaid he, "to ≈øtop ≈øuch di≈øproportionate matches; yet, once made, they ≈øhould be as religiou≈øly ob≈øerved inviolate as tho≈øe of love, among which we almo≈øt as frequently, as in tho≈øe of compul≈øion, ≈øee in≈øtances of infidelity. If you doubt this," ≈øaid he, "read the records of Doctors' Commons."

I agreed to the ju≈øtice of what he ≈øaid, at the ≈øame time a≈ø≈øured him, that my intentions went no farther than wi≈øhing the lady to be re≈øcued from her thraldom, which I told him was dreadful.‚Äî "I am ≈øure," ≈øaid the con≈øul, "that Mr. Campbell thinks ≈øo, becau≈øe I am convinced he would not otherwi≈øe ≈øay ≈øo. But may not," ≈øaid he, ≈ømiling, "may not Mr. C. have deceived him≈øelf? the≈øe are things in which the pa≈ø≈øions are ≈øtrangely apt to hoodwink the under≈øtanding. However," continued he, breaking off plea≈øantly, "I mu≈øt give you all the comfort that truth will allow me to do: I am ≈øure that the poor lady is condemned to great wretchedne≈øs; partly from my own ob≈øervation, partly from public report, and partly from her own mouth: for you mu≈øt know ≈øhe has ≈øeveral times complained to me of her hu≈øband's peevi≈øhne≈øs and tyranny; and even be≈øought me to u≈øe my influence and authority to relieve her from her mi≈øery. Mr. ‚Äî," continued he, "is a man whom on all other accounts I e≈øteem, and val ‚Ä¢ e highly. In this in≈øtance he has erred, and I cannot pity him, even though he ≈øuffers all the torments of jealou≈øy‚ñ™ and as there are laws for puni≈øhing with death premature intercour≈øe with the ≈øex, I cannot ≈øee, any more than you, why the ≈øacrificing youth to extreme old age ≈øhould not be equally puni≈øhed, for I am ≈øure it is equally unnatural, and ≈øtill more injurious to a ≈øtate. The≈øe are my ≈øentiments," continued he; "but let not this declaration induce you to think that I the le≈øs di≈øapprove of your intermeddling. You have allowed me the privilege of a friend, and I will not ≈øuffer it to be made an empty one. You were more culpable than many young men would be; fir≈øt, becau≈øe you are married, and ≈øhould, upon the common principle of doing as you would be done by, have refrained; and next, becau≈øe you were enjoying the ≈øweets of ho≈øpitality in his hou≈øe, and
≈øhould have da≈øhed from his lips, rather than held to them, the deepe≈øt cup of bitterne≈øs."

"But, my dear ≈øir," ≈øaid I, "I do not attempt to ju≈øtify‚ÄîI only endeavour to mitigate the matter, and you will recollect that the very circum≈øtance which in one point of view aggravates, in another alleviates the fault: the living in his hou≈øe afforded tho≈øe interviews and expo≈øed me to tho≈øe temptations under which I was near ≈øinking‚ÄîI ≈øhould never have ≈øought them: but he mu≈øt be more or le≈øs than man, that could have re≈øi≈øted them: and though I have a high ≈øen≈øe of Mr. Con≈øul's ≈øtrict honour and virtue, as well as prudence, he mu≈øt excu≈øe me, though I doubt whether he could him≈øelf have re≈øi≈øted ≈øo long and ≈øo effectually as I did. I am ≈øure there are many who will cen≈øure, that could not."

The con≈øul ≈ømiled, and, turning the di≈øcour≈øe from its direct line, ob≈øerved, that it was ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary I ≈øhould de≈øi≈øt, el≈øe he would be obliged to u≈øe his influence and power to protect Mr. ‚Äî.

In an≈øwer to this, I gave him my honour in the fir≈øt place, that I would proceed no farther in the bu≈øine≈øs; and that, on the contrary, I was determined to ≈øet out upon my journey to India directly, if means could be contrived for my conveyance; adding, that I ≈øhould con≈øider it as a great favour, in addition to tho≈øe I had already received at his hands, if he would contrive ≈øome means to ≈øet me forward in my route.
