To this he an≈øwered, that as the making up of a caravan would be extravagantly expen≈øive, he knew no means that were not attended with certain hard≈øhip and eventual danger; but finding me determined at almo≈øt any danger or hazard to ≈øet off, he propo≈øed to ≈øend for a man who knew every re≈øource in that way, and when he came would talk farther on the bu≈øine≈øs; and in the mean time, recommended great circum≈øpection to me while I
continued at Mr. ‚Äî's hou≈øe, to which I very ≈øolemnly pledged my word.

Being now con≈øtrained by every con≈øideration, as well of prudence and decency as of inclination, to leave Aleppo immediately; I determined that no common impediments ≈øhould ≈øtop me, and waited with impatience the arrival of the per≈øon on whom the con≈øul re≈øted his hopes of di≈øpatching me.

He came in the evening, and after a conference with the con≈øul he introduced him to me, and acquainted me that he was a Tartar, and one of the va≈øt number of that de≈øcription who are employed by the Turki≈øh ≈øtate in carrying di≈øpatches from court to the various viceroys and ba≈øhaws, and interchangeably between them again; that they were men on who≈øe fidelity the utmo≈øt reliance could be had; and that this man, who had an excellent character, had agreed to take me to Bagdad, provided I would ≈øubmit to the di≈øgui≈øe of a Tartar.

The agreement between us I entirely ≈øubmitted to the di≈øcretion of the con≈øul, who had the goodne≈øs to ≈øettle it thus:‚ÄîThe Tartar was to deliver me ≈øafe at Bagdad; to ≈øupply me and my ≈øervant, who acted as interpreter, with an ample ≈øufficiency of provi≈øions and hor≈øes on the road; to exchange my hor≈øe for me as often as I plea≈øed, and to go at ≈øuch a rate, whether fa≈øter or ≈ølower, as I thought proper: for this he was to receive one hundred pounds; and I further promi≈øed, as an encouragement to him, that if he acted to my ≈øatisfaction, I would, on our arrival at Bagdad, add a douceur of twenty pounds.

The next day he came, and I had a di≈øtinct view of this my new fellow traveller and ≈øuppo≈øed ma≈øter, for in ≈øeveral places, I was to pa≈øs for his ≈ølave. He was one of tho≈øe ≈øtriking character figures that a painter would like to take a ≈øketch of‚Äîand me-thought Tartar was written legibly in every lineament of his countenance and per≈øon.‚ÄîHe was
tall, mu≈øcular, and bony‚Äîhis figure be≈øpoke great hardihood, ≈øtrength, and activity‚Äînor could the trow≈øers which he wore conceal the Herculean texture of his limbs‚Äîhis ≈øhoulders were expanded to an enormous breadth‚Äîhe was unincumbered with fle≈øh, or indeed rather extremely lean‚Äîhis forehead, though partly concealed beneath his turban, was very high‚Äîhis no≈øe large, hooked, ≈øharp, and prominent‚Äîa pair of ≈ømall, fierce, black, penetrating eyes, barely ≈øeparated by the no≈øe, and a formidable pair of mu≈øtachios, which he carefully ≈øleeked with pomatum into a point re≈øembling an awlblade, and which moved like the whi≈økers of a purring cat, with every word he ≈øpoke, gave a whim≈øical ferocity to the countenance, beyond the reach of de≈øcription, and rendered him altogether as di≈øcouraging a confidental friend, as ever a Chri≈øtian tru≈øted his life to ≈øince Mahomet fir≈øt ≈øet up the trade of a prophet. He ≈øurveyed me with great attention ‚Äîopened his mouth two or three times like a ga≈øping pike, as if to ≈øpeak‚Äî≈øtroaked his whi≈økers as often‚Äîand at la≈øt pronounced that he would undertake to conduct me; adding, in allu≈øion to my black hair and dark complexion, that I looked more like a native, than any Frank he had ever ≈øeen. He ordered me to cut my hair quite ≈øhort, to provide my≈øelf with the Tartar dre≈øs and cap, in the fa≈øhion of his own; and ≈øaying he would call on me in proper time, departed.

Thus equipped, we ≈øet out, not without great pain and regret on my part; pain at leaving a mo≈øt beautiful young woman, whom I pitied and e≈øteemed, ≈øubject to the re≈øentment of a hu≈øband, at once jealous from nature, peevi≈øh from habit, and enraged from her open and unequivocal demon≈øtrations of hatred and regret at having been betrayed by ≈øituaation into ≈øuch a very ≈øerious dilemma.

After my departure from Aleppo, this affair was repre≈øented in a variety of unfavourable lights to
the different new comers from England; and as a ≈øtory is that commodity which of all others hone≈øt people do not love to ≈øteal any thing from, in its pa≈ø≈øage though their hands, it found its way in various forms (none of them however tending to ≈øo ‚Ä¢ en i ‚Ä¢ ) ‚Ä¢ o many of my friends and connections, tho≈øe from whom of all others I wi≈øhed to conceal it. Labouring under ≈øuch calumnies, it cannot be con≈øidered as a violation of decorum, or unnece≈ø≈øary infraction upon delicacy, if I ≈øtate the truth, in order, though I cannot acquit my≈øelf of cen≈øurable conduct, at lea≈øt not ≈øilently to ≈øubmit to unlimited calumny, and charges of crimes which I hope I have too much honour and integrity to commit.

I mu≈øt add, that previous to my departure the con≈øul did every thing that it was po≈ø≈øible for him to do, conducive to my ≈øafety and accomodation on the road, which as we were obliged to go to the city of Diarbeker, a great length out of our way, he ob≈øerved would be long, dreary, fatiguing, and hazardous; he procured me from others, and gave me him≈øelf, a number of letters, and at parting defited me to comfort my≈øelf with the reflection, that when I arrived at my journey's end, I ≈øhould have to boa≈øt, that I went to India by a route never travelled by an European before.

div.head: LETTER XXXVII.
div.p:
AS I became familiari≈øed to my Tartar guide I found his character di≈øclo≈øe much better traits than his fir≈øt appearance be≈øpoke, and I began in≈øen≈øibility to think him a very entertaining fellow: preceiving that I was very low ≈øpirited
and thoughtful, he exhibited manife≈øt marks of compa≈ø≈øion; and taking it into his head that I was actually removed for ever from my friends and my family, he ≈øpoke in a ≈øtyle of regret and feeling, that did great honor to his heart: and to ≈øay the truth, he did every thing in his power to alleviate my feelings, conver≈øing with me either by means of the interpreter, or in broken lingua franca; ≈øupplying all my wants cheerfully and abundantly; changing hor≈øes with me as often as I pea≈øed, and going ≈ølow or golloping forward ju≈øt as be≈øt ≈øuited my inclination or humour.

The fir≈øt object he ≈øeemed to have in view on our journey, was to impre≈øs me with a notion of his con≈øequence and authority, as a me≈ø≈øenger belonging to the Sultan. As all tho≈øe men are employed by the fir≈øt magi≈øtrates in the country, and are, as it were, the links of communication between them, they think them≈øelves of great importance in the ≈øtate; while the great men who≈øe bu≈øine≈øs they are employed in, make them feel the weight of authority, and treat them with the greate≈øt contempt: hence they become habitually ≈øervile to their ≈øuperiors, and by natural con≈øequence in≈øolent and over-bearing to their inferiors, or tho≈øe who being in their power they conceive to be ≈øo. As carriers of di≈øpaches, their power and authority wherever they go is in ≈øome points undi≈øputed; and they can compel a ≈øupply of provi≈øions, hor≈øes, and attendants, wherever it ≈øuits their occa≈øions; nor dare any man re≈øi≈øt their right to take the hor≈øe from under him to proceed on the Emperor's bu≈øine≈øs, be the owner's occa≈øion ever ≈øo pre≈ø≈øing.

My feelings, which I can tell you were altogether of the mo≈øt unplea≈øant kind, ≈øerved as a ≈øtimulus to my mind, and increa≈øed my anxiety to get forward; I therefore pu≈øhed on as fa≈øt as the hor≈øes, which were in general excellent, could carry me: and as we halted at a number of ≈øtages to get fre≈øh
hor≈øes and provi≈øions, my Tartar guide had frequent opportunities of indulging his ≈øelf-importance, and di≈øplaying his great authority and power. As ≈øoon as he ≈øtopped at a caravan≈øera, he immediately called lu≈øtily about him in the name of the Sultan, demanding with an imperious and menacing tone of voice, fre≈øh hor≈øes, victuals, &c. on the in≈øtant. The terror of this great man operated like magic; nothing could exceed the activity of the men, the bri≈økne≈øs of the women, and the terror of the children; for the caravan≈øeras are continually attended by numbers of the very lowe≈øt cla≈ø≈øes of the people; but no quickne≈øs of preparation, no effort or indu≈øtry could ≈øatisfy my gentleman; he would ≈øhew me his power in a ≈øtill more ≈øtriking point of view, and fall belabouring them with his whip, and kicking them with all his might. I mu≈øt confe≈øs I was much hurt at this extravagant abu≈øe of up≈øtart power, and was two or three times on the point of interfering; but fortunately, recollected that it would neither be in character, nor have any good effect, and that if I pre≈øumed to ≈øpeak, my guide would be obliged in my defence to give me a flogging in order to prevent ≈øu≈øpicion.

This incon≈øiderate tyranny and cruelty, I had afterwards rea≈øon to believe, was by no means a part of his natural di≈øpo≈øition; but vanity, to which ≈øo many among us in Europe fall victims, urged him to exce≈ø≈øes, which I dare ≈øay his heart privately condemned.

It was on the fifth or ≈øixth day (I cannot preci≈øely ≈øay which) after our leaving Aleppo, that we got to the city of Diarbeker, the capital of the province of that name, having pa≈ø≈øed over an extent of country of between three and four hundred miles, mo≈øt of it ble≈ø≈øed with the greate≈øt fertility, producing, in the few cultivated parts, grain, fruits of various kinds, and ≈øilk in great variety and abundance, and abounding with as rich pa≈øtures as
I ever beheld, covered with numerous herds and flocks. The air was charmingly temperate in the day-time, but, to my feeling, extremely cold at night.

Yet notwith≈øtanding the extreme fertility of this country, the bad admini≈øtration of government, con≈øpiring with the indolence of the inhabitants, leaves it unpopulous and uncultivated. Diarbeker, proper, called al≈øo Me≈øopotamia, from its lying between the two famous rivers Tigris and Euphrates, and by Mo≈øes called PADAN ARAM, that is to ≈øay ‚Äî"The fruitful Syria;" abounds with corn, wine, oil, fruits, and all the nece≈ø≈øaries of life. It is ≈øuppo≈øed to be the ≈øeat of the Earthly Paradi≈øe, and all geographers agree that it was there the de≈øcendants of Noah fir≈øt ≈øettled after the flood.

In≈øignificant as tho≈øe circum≈øtances may appear to mere calculators of profit and lo≈øs, it cannot be denied that they have a powerful and plea≈øing effect on the refined imagination. To be treading that ground where Abraham trod; where Nahor the father of Rebecca lived; and where Laban, to whom Jacob fled to avoid his brother E≈øau's re≈øentment, and whom he ≈øerved fourteen years for the love he bore to Rachel, was to me a circum≈øtance productive of delightful ≈øen≈øations. How finely has that giant of the pen, John≈øon, ju≈øtified tho≈øe ≈øen≈øations in his Tour to the Highlands of Scotland and We≈øtern I≈ølands;‚Äîde≈øcribing his emotions on vi≈øiting the famous i≈øland of Iona, or Colombkill, he ≈øays‚Äî"We were now treading that illu≈øtrious i≈øland which was once the luminary of the Caledonian regions, whence ≈øavage clans and roving barbarians derived the benefits of knowledge, and ble≈ø≈øings of religion. To ab≈øtract the mind from all local emotion, would be impo≈ø≈øible if it were endeavoured, and would be fooli≈øh if it were po≈ø≈øible. Whatever withdraws us from the power of our ≈øen≈øes‚Äî whatever makes the pa≈øt, the di≈øtant, or the future,
predominate over the pre≈øent, advances us in the dignity of thinking beings. Far from me, and from my friends, be ≈øuch frigid philo≈øophy, as may conduct us indifferent and unmoved over any ground which has been dignified by wi≈ødom, bravery, or virtue!‚Äîthat man is little to be envied who≈øe patrioti≈øm would not gain force upon the Plain of Marathon, or who≈øe piety would not grow warmer among the ruins of Iona."

The city of D ‚Ä¢ arbeker it≈øelf is ≈øituated in a delightful plain on the banks of the river Tigris, and nearly at its head; it is one of the riche≈øt, mo≈øt trading, ≈øtrong, and populous cities in A≈øiatic Turkey; and is adorned with many pi ‚Ä¢ zzas and market places in the Turki≈øh ≈øtyle, and a large magnificent mo ‚Ä¢ que, formerly a Chri≈øtian church; for Chri≈øtianity flouri≈øhed over this country ≈øo late as the ≈øixth century. Few countries in the world exceed that about this city for natural richne≈øs and beauty:‚Äîthe bread and wine are excellent‚Äîthe fruit beyond conception delicious‚Äîand my friend the Tartar took care, under pretence of ≈øupercilious hauteur, to tear in pieces a couple of fowls, and hand me now a leg, now a wing, till I made the mo≈øt delicious repa≈øt I ever remember to have eat in my life.

the empire:‚Äîthe chief bu≈øine≈øs there, is making that fine leather commonly called Turkey leather.

Figure to your≈øelf, my dear FREDERICK, my Tartar guide, who was an admirable actor, ≈øitting at a caravan≈øera in ≈øtate at his dinner, devouring excellent fowls, choice pillaws, and delicious fruit, in as great pomp as a ba≈øhaw; and in order to keep up the ≈øemblance of authority over me, to favour my di≈øgui≈øe, handing to me, who ≈øat at humble di≈øtance, a part of his provi≈øions. You may form to your≈øelf an idea of the ≈øcene; but all the efforts of imagination mu≈øt fall ≈øhort of the manner, the figure, the words, the looks, and the actions of the Tartar; ≈øometimes affecting contemptuous pity, ≈øometimes ≈øupercilious arrogance; ≈øometimes brutal ≈øterne≈øs, and ≈øometimes the gentle blandi≈øhments of con≈øcious ≈øuperiority; and all in ≈øuch a ma≈øterly ≈øtile of performance, that I doubt whether Garrick him≈øelf, with all his powers of countenance, could outdo him. Critical though my ≈øituation was, and much as I was harra≈ø≈øed with the corro≈øions of mental pain, the extravagant action and lu ‚Ä¢ icrous pomp ‚Ä¢ ≈øity of this man frequently overbo ‚Ä¢ e my prudence, and compelled me to laugh incontinently and loudly;‚Äîon all ≈øuch occa≈øions he would put his hands a-kimbo, draw up his eyebrows to his turban, ≈øcrew down the corners of his mouth in the mo≈øt rueful manner, and give a loud whew! with his eyes fixed in a ≈øtare at me, till entirely overcome with laughter, and ready to ≈øink under it, I clapped my face between my hands, and, as well as I could, bowed in token of ≈øorrow and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion; when, threatning me vehemently, and at the ≈øame time uttering a lamentable expre≈ø≈øion of doubt that he was afraid he had had an idiot impo≈øed on him, he would bu≈øt ‚Ä¢ e about, direct the hor≈øes to be got ready, and order me to get on hor≈øeback, with many denunciations of ≈øevere treatment, and a thou≈øand flouri≈øhes of his whip over my head.

As I have rode along mu≈øing upon the contemptible ≈øtratagems to which I was reduced, in order to get through this country, for no other rea≈øon but becau≈øe I was a Chri≈øtian, I could not help reflecting with ≈øorrow on the melancholy effects of ≈øuper≈øtition, and regretting that that place, which in the times of primitive ≈øimplicity was called the Terre≈øtrial Paradi≈øe; that place where GOD fir≈øt planted man after the flood; where the god-like Abraham and the holy Job breathed the pure air of piety and ≈øimplicity; that place which from all tho≈øe circum≈øtances ought to be con≈øidered above all others as the univer≈øal inheritance of mankind, ≈øhould now be cut off from all but a horde of ≈øen≈øele≈øs bigots, barbarous fanatics, and inflexible tyrants. And I could not help con≈øidering with melancholy concern, the blindne≈øs and infatuation of men, who, le≈øs earne≈øt to accommodate them≈øelves than injure others, ≈øhut out their fellow-creatures from that which they them≈øelves will not u≈øe, and, while they ≈øuffer millions of the riche≈øt acres in the univer≈øe to be untilled, and ≈øpend their ≈øweetne≈øs in the de≈øert air, with wicked jealou≈øy, and envy more than diabolical, begrudge to others the little ≈øpot on which they ≈øtand, and cha≈øe them as they would a ravening tiger from their country.

div.head: LETTER XXXVIII.
div.p:
AS we advanced towards the ≈øouthward and ea≈øtward, in our way from Diarbeker towards Bagdad, I found the air become ≈øen≈øibly warmer, and ob≈øerved that the di≈øpo≈øition of the people grew more and more brutal. My guide's conduct for he knew them well) became proportiontely
artful, and my manners were of cour≈øe to grow ≈øo much the humbler. I ob≈øerved, however, that his authority continued the ≈øame, and that he ≈øeemed to exert it with greater rigour; not in ≈øeverity or cha≈øti≈øement, but in exacting implicit obedience. Yet ≈øtill he evidently acted with great caution and circum≈øpection; for, in ≈øome di≈øtricts, he either avoided the little villages by a circuitous route, or da≈øhed through them at a very quick pace, while the gaping multitude con≈øidered us as on a di≈øpatch of ha≈øte and importance‚Äîin others, he entered the towns without re≈øerve, and left it to ‚Ä¢ ance to decide whether we ≈øhould be di≈øcovered or not. And ≈øometimes we lay at night out in the open air, rather than enter a town; on which occa≈øions I found the weather as piercing cold as it was di≈øtre≈øsfully hot in the day time. Bred, as the man was, a mixture of ≈ølave and, tyrant, I can ≈øuppo≈øe ≈øome parts of this conduct to ari≈øe from caprice; but, as he was naturally kind, as many of tho≈øe aberrations from the u≈øual mode of travelling were atttended with hard≈øhip and inconvenience to him≈øelf, and as my ≈øervant and the other Tartar were clearly of opinion he was right, I am rather di≈øpo≈øed to believe that he, on the whole, acted from principles of ≈øound ≈øen≈øe and policy.
He frequently advi≈øed me again≈øt indulging in laughter; ≈øaid it was unmanly, indecorous, incon≈øi≈øtent with the gravity becoming a wi≈øe man, and withal dangerous.

One evening we came to a caravan≈øera much fatigued, the day being extremely hot, and we having rode very hard‚Äîwhether it was caprice or fatigue, or the ≈øugge≈øtion of policy that moved him,
I cannot ≈øay, but he was certainly more di≈øpo≈øed to play the tyrant than I had ever before ≈øeen him. He flogged the men who took the hor≈øes, kicked every one he met, made the hou≈øe ring with his enormous voice; directed ≈øupper to be got ready, ate growling, and finding fault with every thing; and under pretence of di≈øliking the ingredients of an excellent pillaw, handed it over to me, ≈øaying, "Here, Jimmel (the name he called me), here, take this filth, and cram it down thy coar≈øe throat, it is only fit for a Frank"‚ÄîI took it with be≈øt air of humility I could a≈ø≈øume; and tearing the meat with my fingers, which I al≈øo u≈øed in≈øtead of a ≈øpoon to eat the rice, ≈øwallowed it eagerly; he watching me all the time attentively. When I had fini≈øhed it, I gave him a hint in the Frank language, that I ≈øhould like to wa≈øh it down with ≈øome wine; but he did not, or rather would not under≈øtand me.

Supper done, he ordered a ≈øervant to attend him with ≈øome water, and directed him to wa≈øh his feet; while that operation was performing, he continued menacing every one about him. My ≈øervant, who ≈øat next me and behind him, interpreted every thing he ≈øaid. "Yes, ye ≈ølaves," ≈øaid he, as he lolled back upon his cu≈øhion, "yes, I will make the be≈øt of you wa≈øh my feet; for who ≈øhall refu≈øe to wa≈øh the feet of him, who repre≈øents the Sultan of the World, the Son of Mahomet, the Me≈ø≈øenger of the Lord?" The poor fellow proceeded in his humble office, and only interrupted him by ≈øaying, "Ble≈ø≈øed be my Lord the ≈øultan, and glory be to the Lord our God, and Mahomet his prophet." "Yes, yes," continued my Tartar, "ble≈øs God and the prophet, and pray for his ≈øervant our ≈øultan, and all who repre≈øent him like me, that ≈ølaves of your de≈øcription are permitted to live: nay, thou ≈øhalt wa≈øh this Frank's feet:" then turning to me with an air of magi≈øterial tenderne≈øs, "Jimmel,"
≈øaid he, "hold forth thy feet, and let them be wa≈øhed by this di≈øciple of Ali‚ÄîI ≈øay, hold forth thy feet."

Scarcely able to refrain from laughter at this Bombardinian of the Ea≈øt, and his pompous manner of i≈ø≈øuing his orders, I drew up my trow≈øers and took off my boots‚Äîthe man brought fre≈øh water, and fell to rubbing my feet with great good will and humility; yet evidently felt ≈øo much hurt at the humiliation, that I was ≈øorry for it, and would rather have di≈øpen≈øed with the wa≈øhing, though it was a luxury.

In the mid≈øt of this operation, the Tartar, who was reclining on his cu≈øhion, ≈ømoking, ro≈øe up, and ≈øtalking two or three times acro≈øs the room, with the mo≈øt ludicrous air of ≈øelf conceit and importance, took his tobacco pipe from his mouth, brandi≈øhed it in o≈øtentatious parade, and in the tone and manner rather of one that was ‚Ä¢ aving than of a man in his ≈øober ≈øen≈øes, bur≈øt out with an emphatical expre≈ø≈øion of ≈øatisfaction, and ≈øaid, "This it is to be protected by a great man: Mu≈ø≈øulmen ≈øalam to him and wa≈øh his feet."

The extravagance of this ≈øentiment, the ab≈øurdity of its application, and the con≈øequential ≈øolemnity of his action and countenance while he ≈øpoke, altogether ru≈øhed upon me with ≈øuch impetuous force, that I could not re≈øi≈øt it, and, in ≈øpite of every effort to re≈øtrain my≈øelf, bur≈øt into an immoderate fit of laughter.

Had I the pencil of Hogarth, the pen of Shake≈øpeare, or the powers of a Garrick, I might attempt to give ≈øome idea of his countenance, when, turning, he beheld me convul≈øed with laughter. I might attempt it, I ≈øay, but I could not do it ju≈øtice. Such a combination of ludicrous expre≈ø≈øion I never beheld; it was indeed an epitome of all the lower order of human pa≈ø≈øions. Fury predominated, but it was ri≈øible fury‚Äîit was fury that
rather grinned than frowned; though under it were to be ≈øeen ≈øhame and mortification, ≈øorrow and re≈øentment, pride and degradation, ≈øilly ba≈øhfulne≈øs and decayed importance. For ≈øome time he ≈øtood transfixed to the ≈øpot, his eyes gli≈øtening like tho≈øe of a rat in a trap; his pointed whi≈økers moving with the contortions of his lips, and his mouth every now and then opening like the beak of a wounded hawk. To utter his ≈øen≈øations he was unable; and he continued in this ≈øtate, not only till my laughter was abated, but till I had time to reflect and be ≈øeriou≈øly concerned.

At length, without ≈øaying a ≈øentence, he wheeled about, threw off his ≈ølippers, drew on his boots, vociferated till he brought all the people of the caravan≈øera about him, and ordered hor≈øes to be ready in≈øtantly. I ≈øaw that I mu≈øt either proceed, or come to an open rupture with him; ≈øo recollecting that I was my≈øelf in fault, that a di≈øpute might be fatal, and that at all events it was only the humour of the moment, I drew on my boots too, and was ready to go, though I was much fitter for a twelve hours' nap than for an hour's travelling on hor≈øeback.

We mounted immediately, and it was my good fortune to have the be≈øt hor≈øe. He ≈øet out upon the gallop, the moon ≈øhining as bright almo≈øt as day; I put forward my hor≈øe, and kept rather before him, which vexed him ≈øo, that he beat the poor animal he rode on mo≈øt unmercifully. At length after about eight or ten miles riding, he called a halt‚Äîdi≈ømounted, and ≈øaid he would re≈øt there all night. I ≈øaw it was I re≈øentment: but knowing that it would be in vain to remon≈øtrate, I di≈ømounted too; and, judging that the be≈øt way to mortify him in return, was to comply with affected approbation, turned to my ≈øervant and told him
(knowing that it would go from him to the Tartar) that I was delighted with the beauty of the night; remarking at the ≈øame time, that lying in the ≈øweet ≈øalu ‚Ä¢ ious air was far preferable to being confined in the ≈øultry fi ‚Ä¢ th of a caravan≈øera.

As ≈øoon as this was communicated to the Tartar, he remarked, that the open air was the fitte≈øt place for the bea≈øts of the fore≈øt, and therefore ≈øuitable to a Frank: but for his part, he had much rather repo≈øe on a cu≈øhion, which he ≈øhould have done, had it not been for my accur≈øed ‚Ä¢ ≈øible faculties.

Here the conver≈øation re≈øted, and we fell a≈øleep. In a few hours he awoke us, and we ≈øet forward: after ≈øome pau≈øe, he began in the following manner, when was interpreted to me, as he ≈øpoke, by my ≈øervant:

"Surely God made laughter for the deri≈øion and ≈øhame of mankind, and gave it to the Franks and the monkies; for the one ha, ha, ha's, and the other he, he, he's, and both are malicious, mi≈øchievous, and good for nothing but to f ‚Ä¢ et and tantalize all that come acro≈øs them."

Here he pau≈øed, as waiting for ≈øomething to be ≈øaid: however, I remained ≈øilent. At length, he continued: "Not but that, with all their laughter, they have the wi≈ødom to take ≈øpecial care of them≈øelves; for half a dozen monkies, will he, he, he, and empty a whole orchard of its fruit in the reckoning of a hundred; and a Frank will ha, ha, ha, and eat you up pillaws and poultry like a wolf, and drink up wine with the ≈øame moderation that a camel drinks up water."
I thought I ≈øhould have choaked with ≈ømothered laughter: I would not however interrupt him, and ‚Ä¢ o contrived to keep it to my≈øelf: he proceded to apothegmati≈øe:
