div.head: LETTER XXXIX.
div.p:
THE ≈øolicitude of my guide for my ≈øafety was the earne≈øtne≈øs of a man of bu≈øine≈øs zealous to di≈øcharge with the utmo≈øt punctuality the duty he had undertaken; and I mu≈øt ob≈øerve to you, that
the whole of his conduct evinced a preci≈øion and punctually of dealing rarely found in our intercour≈øe with mankind. Previous to leaving Aloppo, he had undertaken to convey me ≈øafe‚Äîhe was, as you may already perceive, indefatigable and unremitting in his endeavours to do ≈øo; he had promi≈øed to ≈øupply me with food‚Äî≈øo he did, in the mo≈øt ample manner; he promi≈øed to go as I plea≈øed fa≈øt or ≈ølow ‚Äî≈øo he did; he promi≈øed to change hor≈øes with me, as often as I thought proper to de≈øire‚Äîhe did ≈øo. But beyond this, he ≈øeemed to carry his care of me no farther than to any bale of goods he might have in his charge. He was bound to deliver me ≈øafe, in good order and condition, at Bagdad: ≈øo much he was determined to do, and no more did he think of. I had got letters to the ba≈øhaws of ≈øome of the towns through which we were to pa≈øs: but as the delivery of a letter is, according to the cu≈øtom of that country always accompanied with a pre≈øent, I thought it better to decline delivering them, except when nece≈ø≈øity compelled‚Äîthough the ≈øtate of the country was ≈øo un≈øettled, that we often had occa≈øion for a guard.

As ≈øoon as the remembrance of the laughing affair was a little decayed, the Tartar began to relax into good humour, and to talk with his u≈øual vehemence; for he was always, according to the flow of his ≈øpirits, either ≈øullenly ≈øilent or extravagantly l ‚Ä¢ quacious. His tongue might be con≈øidered as a thermometer, by which the warmth or coldne≈øs of his temper might be calculated, and the ex ‚Ä¢ emes‚ñ™ of garrulity and taciturnity were the indices. His conver≈øation, however, was very circum≈øcribed, and con≈øi≈øted chiefly of ≈øtories of him≈øelf and his hor≈øe, the amazing journeys he made, and the fea ‚Ä¢ s of manhood he performed. One circum≈øtance I mu≈øt in ju≈øtice mention, as I think it mark ‚Ä¢ ≈øtrongly the habitual delicacy and mode≈øty of this people. Although he frequently lamented my bani≈øhment from
my family, and although we were for eighteen days continually conver≈øing on a variety of occa≈øions that might lead to the ≈øubject, he never once talked of women; never, in all his pity for my ≈øituation, glanced even remotely at the po≈ø≈øibility of my getting a ≈øub≈øtitute in that way; never hinted that he thought of them him≈øelf. On ≈øeeing women, coming to the wells, they remined me of ≈øome of the ≈øtories in the Old Te≈øtament. I mentioned it, but it went no farther; for whenever the ≈øubject was ≈øtarted, he threw cold water on it.

That he conceived me to be in ≈øome re≈øpects a parcel of property, I have good rea≈øon to believe: for I ob≈øerved that at ≈øome caravan≈øeras the people collected round me, and regarded me with ≈øtrong ≈øymptoms of ≈øurpri≈øe and pity; ≈øome viewed me with commi≈øeration, ≈øome with contempt; but not one creature, however wretched or abject, ≈øeemed to envy my ≈øituation.

I was the more confirmed in this opinion by an incident that happened between Diarbeker and Mo≈øul. One morning I was unu≈øually overcome with the fatigues of the preceding day: the Tartar called me, ≈øummoned me to hor≈øe; and finding that I gave no an≈øwer, nor ≈øhewed any token of awaking, he lifted me in his arms bodily from my couch (≈øuch was his ≈øtrength that he did it without any difficulty), carried me out without the lea≈øt ceremony, and, before I was ≈øo completely awake as to be ≈øen≈øible of my ≈øituation, had me fixed upon a horie ready to depart.

A tran≈øaction ≈øo very ≈øingular, you may well conclude, ≈øurpri≈øed me at the time, and would not readily be forgotten: ≈øuch a crowd of ≈øtrange, confu≈øed, and incongruous thoughts and ≈øen≈øations as occurred to me, I never before experienced: they were painful, they were ≈øurpri≈øing‚Äîbut I was in ≈øuch a ≈øtate that I could not afterwards analy≈øe them. The chief reflection that aro≈øe from it was,
that human ≈øentiment mu≈øt be in a deplorable ≈øtate of degradation indeed, when ≈øuch a circum≈øtance could occur from the notion that a man was as much an a≈ø≈øet or piece of property, could be tran≈øferred by the ≈øame means, and moved in the ≈øame unfeeling manner, as any portion of inert matter that makes up a bale of merchandize. Of the truth of this po≈øition I had ≈øoon after a melancholy proof, in an incident which, though lamentable, was attended with ≈øuch ludicrous circum≈øtances, that even now I never think of it without ≈ømiling ‚Äî≈ømiling, as I did then, with a heart bleeding with pity.

One morning I was awakened before day-break with a bu≈øtle in the caravan≈øera where we lodged. I conjectured that the Tartar was preparing to get forward, and ro≈øe in order to lo≈øe no time. I was ≈øo far right in my conjectures: the hor≈øes were ready, and I came out to mount, and was very much ≈øurpri≈øed to perceive ≈øeveral hor≈øes before me loaded with ≈øomething which ≈øtood erect from their backs, and which I had barely light to di≈øcern were not men. I concluded that they were bales of merchandize packed in a particular form, and a≈øked no que≈øtions till full day-light di≈øclo≈øed to me that they were human creatures tied up in ≈øacks, and fa≈øtened a≈øtride on the hor≈øes' backs. There was a ≈øtrange union of horror and oddity in the conception, that ≈øtruck me at once with a mixed emotion of indignation, pity, and mirth.‚ÄîThe former however got the better, and I a≈øked my ≈øervant with ≈øome warmth what it meant‚ÄîHe ≈øaid that the ≈øacks contained ≈øome young women whom the Tartar had bought.‚ÄîGood GOD! ≈øaid I, is it po≈ø≈øible that he can have bought wretched females to treat them with ≈øo little tenderne≈øs? He has bought them, returned my ≈øervant, in the way of traffic, not for plea≈øure.

"Suppo≈øe he has," ≈øaid I, "≈øuppo≈øe even they were men, not to mention young women, how can he imagine that they will ≈øurvive this? Tied up and ≈øweltered in a ≈øack‚Äîfa≈øtened cro≈øs-legs, on a hor≈øe, and driven at ≈øuch an amazing rate (for by this time we had ≈øet forward, and another Tartar was whipping the hor≈øes up all the time, and driving them on)‚Äîhow is it po≈ø≈øible they can ≈øurvive? They mu≈øt be ≈ømothered‚Äîthey mu≈øt be ≈øhattered to pieces‚Äîthey mu≈øt be ≈øtripped, excoriated, and tortured to death!"
"If I might pre≈øume to advi≈øe," ≈øaid he, "I would ≈øay that you had better make no remarks upon it: it would only get them perhaps wor≈øe treated, and rai≈øe his anger again≈øt you."

To conclude, I took his advice, and kept my mind to my≈øelf. The unfortunate women were in this manner carried fifty miles, at the end of which their tender-hearted purcha≈øer di≈øpo≈øed of them in ≈øome way of keeping till his return; when I ≈øuppo≈øe they were to be carried back in ≈øacks a≈øtride upon hor≈øes, all the way to Aleppo, there to be ≈øold to the highe≈øt bidder.

To us, my FREDERICK, who live in a country where an hour's detention in a hou≈øe again≈øt our will is puni≈øhed as unlawful impri≈øonment, and who feel and value the rich trea≈øure of liberty above all earthly ble≈ø≈øings, the bare idea of ≈ølavery appears horrible; when the mi≈øeries of ≈ølavery are ≈øharpened by cruelty, our indignation burns at the offence: but ≈øuch a complicated piece of enormity as that I have mentioned, almo≈øt tran≈øcends belief, and indignation is lo≈øt in amazement. There are but few men, even in our bracing climate, whom fifty miles riding would not ≈øhake to pieces, and torture almo≈øt to death. No woman would think of it. But when to that is ≈øuperadded, fir≈øt the compul≈øion‚Äîthen the ≈øorry and at be≈øt painful equipage of the hor≈øes‚Äîthe tender per≈øons, unaccu≈øtomed to riding, of the women‚Äîthe ≈ømothering
heat of the ≈øack‚Äîand above all the horrid climate, burning with an almo≈øt vertical heat (vertical at lea≈øt compared with our oblique ≈øun)‚Äîit will be allowed to be a wonder, almo≈øt approaching to a miracle, that they ≈øurvived one half of their journey. The wonder-working hand of Omnipotence alone could bring them through it; and when I a≈øked in the evening whether they were dying or dead, and was told that they were not only alive but in perfect health, I could not help repeating that mo≈øt beautiful expre≈ø≈øion put into the mouth of Maria by the inimitable Sterne, "God tempers the wind to the ≈øide of the ≈øhorn lamb."

This affair tended to prejudice me ≈øtrongly again≈øt my Tartar guide, and I was for ≈øome time that I could not look upon him without horror: but at length my re≈øentment abated; and rea≈øon, re≈øuming her ≈øeat of cool deci≈øion, told me, that though it was a crime and a grievous one, he was not ≈øo re≈øpon≈øible for it as tho≈øe who, knowing better, authori≈øed it by their concurrence, gave it the ≈øanction of law, and made it familiarly practi≈øed; he only did that which he had been even from his mother's brea≈øt in≈øtructed to do, and ≈øhould therefore not be judged by tho≈øe rules which a Briton would lay down for the government of ≈øuch ca≈øes.

A Briton!‚ÄîHold! Have I not now been uttering a mo≈øt ≈øevere ≈øatire upon the Briti≈øh nation? Yes! imputing to men a virtue which they want, is the wor≈øt kind of ≈øatire‚ÄîI meant it not at the time, but will not retract what I have written‚Äî Britons de≈øerve the la≈øh of ≈øatire! They de≈øerve a wor≈øe la≈øh: for the traffic in human bodies ≈øtill ≈øtands a bloody brand of infamy on her great national councils. Their brother's blood! the blood of millions of murdered Africans, like that of Abel, cries to Heaven again≈øt them, and will not, I fear, cry in vain.

Great God!‚ÄîWhat a horrible thought!‚Äîwhat an indelible ≈øtigma! that a legi≈ølator ≈øhall, in the cold blood of commerce, make a calculation of the probable profit upon human lives‚Äîput commercial expediency in the balance again≈øt murder‚Äîand make convenience the excu≈øe for crime!‚ÄîWhy, the robber may do ≈øo!‚ÄîBut ≈øhall Britons, generous Britons, who boa≈øtful claim precedence of the world in freedom, humanity, and ju≈øtice‚Äî≈øhall they look on and ≈øee inferior nations ≈øpurning from them with horror the deba≈øing traffic; and ≈øtimulated by avarice, or mi≈øled by wicked policy, retain the blot that other ≈øtates have wiped away, and live at once the cur≈øe of one part, and the ≈øcorn of the re≈øt of mankind?‚ÄîForbid it mercy! Forbid it Heaven!‚ÄîAnd oh! may that virtuous man, who, di≈ødaining the malignant taunts of the ba≈øe and intere≈øted, boldly ≈øteps forth the advocate of man and of his country, and ≈øe≈ø≈øion after ≈øe≈ø≈øion ≈øprings from the couch of repo≈øe which opulence pre≈øents him, to break the fetters and the ≈øcourges which improbity and avarice have forged for our fellow creatures‚Äîmay he ≈øucceed and bear down all his oppo≈øers! and may the ju≈øtice of his country make his triumph and his glory as certain and complete here, as the ju≈øtice of that Being, under whole direction he acts, will doubtle≈øs make them hereafter!

div.head: LETTER XL.
div.p:
FROM the con≈øiderations I have already pretty fully mentioned, my mind was by no means at ca≈øe. The ince≈ø≈øant travelling for ≈øo many days, at the rate of ≈øeventy-five miles a day, to be continued
I knew not how long, increa≈øed my anxiety: and the apprehen≈øions of accident, interruption, and above all ≈øickne≈øs, intercepting me on my way, haunted my imagination with all its terrors. I was be≈øides approaching fa≈øt to that region where the winds ≈øtrike all living things that draw them in in≈øtantly dead: and conceiving that the more expeditions I was in getting over the journey, the greater chance I had of e≈øcaping tho≈øe mi≈øchiefs; I pu≈øhed heartily forward, and urged the Tartar till he at la≈øt expre≈ø≈øed his a≈øtoni≈øhment and approbation; paid me the compliment to ≈øay, that I was almo≈øt equal to him≈øelf for enduring fatigue; and concluded with a very ≈øagacious ≈øurmi≈øe, that in all probability I had been my≈øelf a carrier of di≈øpatches among the Frank governments.

One day after we had rode about four miles from a caravan≈øera, at which we had changed our cattle, I found that a mo≈øt execrable bad hor≈øe had fallen to my lot: he was ≈øtiff, feeble, and ≈øoundered; in con≈øequence of which he ≈øtumbled very much, and I every minute expected that he would fall and roll over me. I therefore propo≈øed to the guide to exchange with me; a favour he had hitherto never refu≈øed, and for which I was the more anxious, as the bea≈øt he rode was of the very be≈øt kind. To my utter a≈øtoni≈øhment he peremptorily refu≈øed: and as this had been a day of unu≈øual taciturnity on his part, I attributed his refu≈øal to peevi≈øhne≈øs and ill temper, and was re≈øolved not to let the matter re≈øt there. I therefore de≈øired the interpreter to inform him, that as he had at Aleppo agreed to change hor≈øes with me as often as I plea≈øed, I ≈øhould con≈øider our agreement infringed upon if he did not comply, and would write to the Con≈øul at Aleppo to that effect.

As ≈øoon as this was conveyed to him, he ≈øeemed ≈øtrongly agitated by anger; yet endeavoured to conceal his emotions under affected contempt and deri≈øion,
which produced from him one of the mo≈øt ≈øingular grins that ever yet marred the human phy≈øiognomy. At length he broke forth:

"You will write to Aleppo, will you? Fooli≈øh Frank! they will not believe you! By Mahomet, it would be well done to hear the complaint of a wandering Frank again≈øt Ha≈ø≈øan Artaz‚ÄîHa≈ø≈øan the faithful and the ju≈øt, who for ten years and more has been the me≈ø≈øenger of an emperor, and the friend and confidant of cadis, ba≈øhaws, and viceroys, and never yet was called ≈øo much as liar! Who, think you, poor mi≈øguided one! who, think you, would belive that I broke my promi≈øe?"

"Why do you not then," ≈øaid I, interrupting him, "why do you not perform it by changing hor≈øes, when you are convinced in your con≈øcience (if you have any) that it was part of your agreement?"‚Äî"Once for all I tell you," interrupted he, "I will not give up this hor≈øe. There is not," ≈øaid he ga≈øconadingly, "there is not a Mu≈ø≈øulman that ever wore a beard, not to talk of a wretched Frank, that ≈øhould get this hor≈øe from under me; I would not yield him to the commander of the faithful this minute, were he in your place: I would not, I tell you Frank‚Äîand I have my own rea≈øons for it."
"I dare ≈øay you have," returned I; "love of your ea≈øe, and fear of your bones."

At hearing this, he grew quite outrageous‚Äîcalled MAHOMET and ALLA to witne≈øs that he did not know what it was to fear any thing‚Äîdeclared that he was convinced that ≈øome infernal ≈øpirit had that day got po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of me‚Äîand indeed ≈øeemed well di≈øpo≈øed to go to logger-heads. At length ob≈øerving that I looked at him with ≈øneering contemptuous defiance, he rode up along ≈øide of me‚Äî I thought it was to ≈øtrike, and prepared to defend my≈øelf. I was however mi≈øtaken; he ≈ønatched the reins out of my hand, and caught hold of them
collected clo≈øe at the hor≈øe's jaw; then fell flogging my hor≈øe and ≈øpurring his own, till he got them both in full ≈øpeed; nor did he ≈øtop there, but continued to belabour mine with his whip, and to ≈øpur his own, driving headlong over every impediment that came in our way, till I really thought he had run mad, or de≈øigned to kill me. Several times I was on the point of ≈øtriking him with my whip, in order to knock him off his hor≈øe‚Äîbut as often patience providentially came to my a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and whi≈øpered to me to forbear and ≈øee it out. Mean time I con≈øidered my≈øelf as being in ≈øome danger; and yet ≈øuch was the power he had over the cattle, that I found it impo≈ø≈øible to ≈øtop him: ≈øo re≈øigning the event to the direction of Providence, I ≈øuffered him without a further effort to proceed; I calling him every opprobrious name I could think of in lingua Franca, and he grinning, and calling me Dumus, Jiha≈øh, Burhl (i. e. hog, a≈øs, mule), in rapid and impetuous vehemence of tone and utterance.

He continued this for a length of I dare ≈øay ≈øome miles‚ñ™ over an uncultivated tract, here and there inter≈øected with channels formed by rills of water in the periodical rains; thickly ≈øet with low furze, ferns, and other dwarf bu≈øhes, and broken up and down into little hills. His hor≈øe carried him clean over all: and though mine was every minute ≈øtumbling and nearly down, yet with a dexterity inexpre≈ø≈øible, and a vigour altogether amazing, he kept him up by the bridle, and I may ≈øay carried him gallantly over every thing. I was a≈øtoni≈øhed very much at all this, and towards the end as much plea≈øed as a≈øtoni≈øhed; which he perceiving, cried out frequently and triumphantly, "O, la Frangi! Heli! Heli! Frangi!" and at la≈øt drawing in the hor≈øes, ≈øtopping ≈øhort, and looking me full in the face, exclaimed in lingua Franca, "Que dice, Frangi‚ÄîQue dice?"

For ≈øome time I was incapable of making him any an≈øwer, but continued ≈øurveying him from head to foot as the mo≈øt extraordinary ≈øavage I had ever beheld; while he ≈øtroked his whi≈økers with great ≈øelf-complacency and compo≈øure, and nodded his head every now and then, as much as to ≈øay, Ay, ay, it is ≈øo! look at me! am not I a very capital fellow?‚Äî"A capital fellow indeed you are," ≈øaid I, "but I wi≈øh I was well out of your confounded clutches."

We alighted on the brow of a ≈ømall hill, whence was to be ≈øeen a full and uninterrupted pro≈øpect of the country all round. The interpreter coming up, he called to him and de≈øired him to explain to me carefully the meaning of what he was about to ≈øay; which I will give you as nearly as I can in his own words, as they were tran≈ølated by the lingui≈øt:

"You ≈øee tho≈øe mountains yonder," ≈øaid he, pointing to the ea≈øt; "tho≈øe are in the province of Kurde≈øtan, inhabited by a vile race of robbers called Je≈øides, who pay homage to a God of their own called Je≈øid (Je≈øus), and wor≈øhip the Devil from fear. They live by plunder, and often de≈øcend from tho≈øe mountains, cro≈øs the Tigris which runs between them and us, and plunder and ravage this country in bands of great number and formidable ≈øtrength, carrying away into ≈ølavery all they can catch, and killing all who re≈øi≈øt them. This country therefore, for ≈øome di≈øtance round us, is very dangerous to travellers, who≈øe only ≈øafety lies in flight. Now it was our misfortune this morning to get a very bad hor≈øe, for which, plea≈øe ALLA (≈øtroking his whi≈økers), ≈øome one ≈øhall receive the ba≈øtinado. Should we meet with a band of tho≈øe Curds, what could we do but fly? And if you, Frangi, rode this hor≈øe, and I that, we could never e≈øcape; for I doubt you could not keep him up from falling under me, as I did under you: I ≈øhould
therefore come down and be taken‚Äîyou would lo≈øe your guide, and mi≈øs your way, and all of us be undone. Be≈øides," continued he, "there are many villages here where people live, who, if they only ≈øu≈øpected you were a Frank, would follow and ≈øacrifice you if they could to MAHOMET, and where of cour≈øe you mu≈øt run for it."
As ≈øoon as the interpreter had explained this to me, "Well," continued the Tartar, "what does he ≈øay now to it?" Then turning to me, and to≈ø≈øing up his head‚Äî"Que dice, Frangi?"
"Why, I ≈øay," returned I, "that you have ≈øpoken good ≈øen≈øe and found rea≈øon; and I am obliged to you."

This, when interpreted fully, operated mo≈øt plea≈øingly upon him; his features relaxed into a broad look of ≈øatisfaction, and he ≈øaid:‚Äî"I will do every thing I can to make you ea≈øy and contented: and when I am ob≈øtinate, don't re≈øi≈øt‚Äîfor be a≈ø≈øured I have rea≈øon for it; and above all things avoid laughing in my pre≈øence. But we ≈øhall reach Mo≈øul by and bye, and probably then we may have no more rides." For I expected to get down the river Tigris from Mo≈øul to Bagdad, and had told him ≈øo, and he encouraged me with the expectation.

That night we came to a caravan≈øera which lay at ≈øome di≈øtance from a village. Here the Tartar, plea≈øed with him≈øelf for the conduct of the day, and plea≈øed with me for my approbation of it, ordered a mo≈øt admirable ≈øupper; and not only, as was very common with him, rejected the be≈øt di≈øh in order to pre≈øent it to me, but al≈øo ≈øelected for me the choice≈øt bits of tho≈øe upon the table. He then ordered wine, ob≈øerving that the fatigue of a government me≈ø≈øenger demanded indulgence; and u≈øing a ≈øalvo of my ≈øugge≈øtion on a former occa≈øion, viz. that the Prophet would not be offended with travellers more than with the ≈øick for taking it as it were medicinally.

We accordingly had wine, and admirable it was, though by no means equal to that we drank at the city of Diarbeker. I took little however, and the Tartar was much ≈øurpri≈øed at my ab≈øtemiou≈øne≈øs; remarking, that he never ≈øaw a Frank before that was not a downright hog when he got the cup to his lips. My taking it in ≈ømall portions, while he drank it as we do table beer, particularly a≈øtoni≈øhed him. Before he lay down on his couch, he gave orders for hor≈øes, threatening the people with ≈øevere ca≈øtigition if they gave bad ones; holding up as an example the per≈øon that gave us the ≈øtumbling hor≈øe that day, who he declared ≈øhould be ba≈øtinadoed as ≈øoon as he returned, if there was a cadi within ten leagues of him; and I dare to ≈øay that he kept his word mo≈øt religiou≈øly.

The next morning we had excellent cattle; fear produced wonders among them, and we ≈øet forward ju≈øt as the ≈øun ro≈øe. As we entered the fir≈øt village, I was ≈øomewhat alarmed by perceiving my guide draw up his hor≈øe‚Äîdeliberate‚Äîmutter to him≈øelf‚Äîand ≈øeem rather unea≈øy while he viewed a crowd that was up the ≈øtreet before us; ≈øome of whom I perceived to be agitated with ≈øome extraordinary motions of the body, while one man ≈øtood in the middle, rolling his body into a variety of ≈øtrange contortions.‚ÄîThe Tartar, for a minute or two, ≈øeemed to be debating within him≈øelf whether he ≈øhould proceed or turn about: at length putting me on his left hand, he ≈øet forward at full ≈øpeed, leaving the crowd on his right, who, ≈øeeing the rapidity of our pace, flew on one ≈øide, and let us pa≈øs. We ≈øoon however heard ≈øhouting behind us, and could hear plainly the words, "Ghiaour! Frangi Cucu!" and looking back, perceived ≈øeveral ragged men like ≈øavages pur≈øuing us, lifting ≈øtones occa≈øionally, and ca≈øting them after us with all their might. The ≈øpeed of our hor≈øes at la≈øt got us out of both ≈øight and hearing; and I plainly perceived,
and was for the fir≈øt time convinced, that my guide's conduct was directed by ≈øound ≈øen≈øe, ≈øpirit, good faith, and integrity.

div.head: LETTER XLI.
div.p: THE extraordinary occurrence which I mentioned in my la≈øt letter required explanation, and my Tartar friend was not backward in giving it; for he loved exceedingly to hear him≈øelf talk, and, on any ≈øubject within the compa≈øs of his knowledge, was ≈øhrewd, per≈øpicuous, and even naturally eloquent: he had moreover on that occa≈øion acted the part of a ≈økilful general; and as I applauded his prudence and addre≈øs, he was extremely kind and communicative, and gave me a full account of that affair, his motives, his deliberations, and the urgency of the ca≈øe; and, in ≈økort, every thing that could elucidate the circum≈øtance, or aggrandize his own importance. It would be a pity to take it out of his own words: I ≈øhall therefore relate them to you, as I had them through the medium of our lingui≈øt, for they made an impre≈ø≈øion on my memory not ea≈øily te be era≈øed.

"You mu≈øt know," ≈øaid he, "that there are ≈øpread over the face of this great and glorious empire a number of dervi≈øes of different kinds‚Äîholy men, who renounce the enjoyments and plea≈øures of the world to conver≈øe with Mahomet and wor≈øhip Alla. Some of tho≈øe are very good men, indeed ≈øaints, and never do any thing bad; preaching and praying, without hurting any thing, even a rat or a ≈ønake; nay, they would not hurt a Chri≈øtian. There are others again, of whom I have heard our ba≈øhaws and effendis, and even the Maazeen, declare
that they are forbid by the Koran; and yet the common people (the lower ≈øort you know have no ≈øen≈øe) reverence and wor≈øhip them‚Äîthey are called Santons; live by them≈øelves, ≈øometimes under ground like rabbits, end ≈øometimes in the thickets and woods. They go where they plea≈øe, take the be≈øt ≈øeat in any man's hou≈øe, cram them≈øelves with meat and drink, and yet none re≈øi≈øt them; for ≈øome will not, and others dare not. Nay, they often pollute women in the open ≈øtreets‚Äîand they never ≈øet their eyes on a Chri≈øtian or a Frank, that they will not kill, if po≈ø≈øible. For my part, I think that they ought to be hanged, every one of them that had a head to be hanged by‚Äîor rather ≈øtaked ‚Äîfor no puni≈øhment is too great for them; but I dare not ≈øay ≈øo in that town‚Äîif I did, I ≈øhould be ≈øtoned to death by the rabble.

"As ≈øoon as I perceived the crowd, and the ra≈øcals dancing, I knew that they were ≈øantons, and was ≈øure that they would ≈øtop us in order to extract money from us; in which ca≈øe they would mo≈øt probably have di≈øcovered you‚Äîfor they have the eyes of the devil. Nothing then could ≈øave your life; the crowd would join them, and your brains would have been beat out with ≈øtones. I had a mind to turn back and go round the town, but that might have cau≈øed ≈øu≈øpicion, and got us perhaps intercepted; ≈øo I determined to pu≈øh by them boldly, which I did, you can te≈øtify, like a brave man. You ≈øaw enough your≈øelf, to convince you of the danger you have e≈øcaped, and of my wi≈ødom and valour; let me therefore entreat you to be entirely guided by me, and above all things avoid that accur≈øed propen≈øity to laughter."

Since I fir≈øt formed the re≈øolution of writing this account of my journey, I have been at ≈øome pains to dip into the be≈øt hi≈øtories of that country, and I find that in every in≈øtance my Tartar guide's information was correct. Tho≈øe ≈øantons, as well as
other cla≈ø≈øes of dervi≈øes and ≈øheihs, travel about the country, and levy contributions on the inhabitants: ≈øome are really what they pretend to be, and are as pure and as pious as the monks of the primitive Chri≈øtian church; but the ≈øantons are mon≈øters, who exi≈øt only by the barbarous credulity and more than ≈øavage ignorance of the lower order of the people‚Äîthough reprobated, and indeed, execrated, by the better ≈øort of Turks. They affect to be dementated (which with the Mahomedans is the greate≈øt mark of ≈øanctity), and under cover of that madne≈øs commit every exce≈øs and enormity, not merely with impunity, but with applau≈øe. Such is the melancholy ≈øtate of degradation, to which the weight of ≈øuper≈øtition's chains bends the mind of man! It is not long ≈øince I had a very plea≈øing di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of this extraordinary ≈øubject, with a gentleman of my acquain ‚Ä¢ ance, for who≈øe veracity I have great re≈øpect. Super≈øtit ‚Ä¢ on and credulity very naturally led to a con≈øideration of the Turki≈øh religion, and I expre≈ø≈øed my ≈øatisfaction, that the wor≈øt excre≈øcences of the Chri≈øtian ≈øchi≈øms could not be compared with the Turki≈øh faith in their dervi≈øes. He ≈øaid, that he agreed it did not go quite the length of the ≈øantons; but he related to me a conver≈øation between him and a Roman catholic, not more than twenty-four miles from the enlightened city of Dublin, which ≈øurpri≈øed me much.

"I was," ≈øaid he, "when a youth, very free in cen≈øuring all religions, and chiefly Popery; for, being bred among Roman catholics, I had the greater opportunity of ≈øeeing their ab≈øurdities, which I trea≈øured up as ≈øo much gain, without ever taking into account their many virtues, of which they have their ≈øhare. One day I was on a party of plea≈øure, at a place called ‚Äî, and in pre≈øence of a poor country fellow ridiculed the prie≈øthood, attributing to them many vices, and particularly
fornication and adultery. The man re≈øi≈øted me, and declared it was impo≈ø≈øible, Then I ≈øuppo≈øe, ≈øaid I, if a prie≈øt and a woman were locked up in a room together for a year, and the woman in a week after coming forth was brought to bed of a child, you would not believe it to be the prie≈øt's. No, ≈øaid he, I would not. Then how comes the child? I don't know, replied he‚Äîany way but by him. In ≈øhort, he would believe in ≈øelf-impregnation, or preternatural vi≈øitation, rather than allow a prie≈øt to be capable of fornication."

"But," ≈øaid I, "you ≈øuppo≈øed a ca≈øe‚Äîif the fellow was ≈øhrewd enough to ≈øay, no ≈øuch ca≈øe could at all happen, he would have put you down; that was what he meant, though he knew not how to go about expre≈ø≈øing it.

The difficulties and hazards of the journey, which ≈øeemed to thicken upon us as we advanced, made me pant for a ≈øpeedy conclu≈øion to it; and the adventure of the la≈øt day opened more clearly to my view the dangers we had to encounter, which were ≈øtill likely to increa≈øe as we got to the ea≈øtward and ≈øouthward, where the fury of bigotry raged without remor≈øe; where the greater di≈øtance from the ≈øeat of government made the populace more lawle≈øs, and the magi≈øtrate more corrupt and tyrannical; where the total ≈øeclu≈øion from all well ordered ≈øociety rendered the manners barbarous; where ≈øtrangers were ≈øeldom ≈øeen, and when ≈øeen fleeced and per≈øecuted; and where particularly I had rea≈øon to believe, ≈øcarcely any Engli≈øhman had ever ≈øet his foot; and above all, where the very winds that blew were charged with de≈øtruction, and carried in≈øtant death upon their wings. I therefore earne≈øtly longed to reach Mo≈øul, where the probability was, I ≈øhould get at lea≈øt the more comfortable and commodious conveyance of water carriage, and where I might refre≈øh my≈øelf completely, after the fatigues of ≈øo many days journey; and, if there
was occa≈øion, claim a guard and protection, having along with me a letter to the ba≈øhaw, which I might withhold or deliver, ju≈øt as be≈øt ≈øuited my inclination or convenience.

I could not help viewing with a ≈øad and melancholy eye my pre≈øent ≈øtate; wandering, I may ≈øay alone, unaccommodated and wretched, through an inho≈øpitable region, and more inho≈øpitable people; where danger be≈øet me in a thou≈øand forms, and every ≈øtep I took, I took in hazard of my life; and comparing it with tho≈øe ≈øcenes of opulence and comfort which I had once experienced, where every lawful wi≈øh met with its accompli≈øhment; where every nece≈ø≈øity was ≈øupplied, and every difficulty obviated; where tender love and attachment anticipated every de≈øire; and ≈øoothed every care: where the mutual endearments and reciprocal accommodations of tender relatives, wife, children, faithful friends, and kindly intimates gave a ze≈øt to life, made me feel that my exi≈øtence was of intere≈øt to others as well as to my≈øelf, and communicated a con≈øcious importance which the i≈øolated, ≈øolitary, ≈øelfi≈øh man can never feel: I could not help looking back with grief and mortification, to think that I once po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed tho≈øe ble≈ø≈øings, and ≈øhould perhaps po≈ø≈øe≈øs them no more; but, on the contrary, might peri≈øh unknown, unheeded, and unlamented, in an unknown corner of the wilds of an unknown ho≈øtile country, without one friend to ≈øolace or to cheer me, or tell to tho≈øe who loved or took ≈øhare in my concerns, the place where I lay, or the particulars of my fate.

Nor in this di≈ømal train of reflections was Aleppo forgotten. It made the great connecting link between my former happine≈øs and pre≈øent mi≈øery; it was, as it were, the door through which I pa≈ø≈øed when I took my la≈øt farewell of comfort: when it clo≈øed and ≈øhut me out, the pro≈øpect was indeed gloomy; nor did I after feel one happy ≈øen≈øation,
unle≈øs the convul≈øive tran≈øports of a laugh, and the boi≈øterous fleeting mirth ari≈øing from the ≈øingularities of my guide, which, as the ≈øurge rai≈øed by the tempe≈øt above its proper height lifts up the ≈øhattered bark only to ca≈øt it on the beach and leave it ≈øhip-wrecked, elevated my ≈øpirits for the moment beyond their proper pitch, to retire quickly, and leave them in the horrors of ten times deeper melancholy.

Perceiving how much ca≈øt down I was, my friendly Tartar began to rally me: "Jimmel," ≈øaid he, "the ≈øantons have frightened you:‚Äîbut don't be afraid‚ÄîHASSAN ARTAZ is no boy: he can bring you through greater difficulties than tho≈øe, ≈øhould they befall us."
"But how comes it," ≈øaid I, "Ha≈ø≈øan, that you, who have ≈øo much power at the caravan≈øeras, have not power to re≈øi≈øt tho≈øe ra≈øcally ≈øantons, or the mobs of a village?"

"Why, as to the mob," ≈øaid he, "if I was by my≈øelf, or had only a true Believer with me, I would make them fly before me like the du≈øt before the wind. As to the ≈øantons, no one can re≈øi≈øt them: the Great, who hate them, are obliged to ≈øhow them re≈øpect: and the ba≈øhaw of Aleppo, nay the Commander of the Faithful him≈øelf, could not ≈øave you, if one of them called on the mob to ≈øtone you, or tear you to pieces. However, be of good cheer; for, plea≈øe ALLA, I will deliver you ≈øafe and ≈øound to the Coja at Bagdad: be≈øides, we ≈øhall very ≈øoon be at Mo≈øul from whence we will go down by water, which will be very plea≈øant: and the chief danger then will be in fair fighting, which is better than being cut off by ≈øantons.‚Äî Should there be occa≈øion," ≈øaid he, looking mo≈øt ferociou≈øly and brandi≈øhing his whip‚Äî"≈øhould we be attacked by Curds or Robbers, you ≈øhall ≈øee‚Äî you ≈øhall ≈øee, Jimme!‚ÄîOh! holy Prophet, how I'll fight!"

div.head: LETTER XLII.
div.p: IT was early in the evening when the pointed turrets of the city of Mo≈øul opened on our view, and communicated no very unplea≈øant ≈øen≈øations to my heart. I found my≈øelf on Scripture ground; and could not help feeling ≈øome portion of the pride of the traveller, when I reflected that I was now within ≈øight of Nineveh, renowned in Holy Writ.‚ÄîThe city is ≈øeated in a very barren ≈øandy plain, on the banks of the river Tigris, embelli≈øhed with the united gifts of Pomona, Ceres, and Flora. The external view of the town is much in its favour, being encompa≈ø≈øed with ≈øtately walls of ≈øolid ≈øtone, over which the ≈øteeples or minarets of other lofty buildings are ≈øeen with increa≈øed effect. Here I fir≈øt ≈øaw a large caravan encamped, halting on its march from the Gulph of Per≈øia to Armenia; and it certainly made a mo≈øt noble appearance, filling the eye with a multitude of grand objects, all uniting to form one magnificent whole.

But though the out≈øide be ≈øo beautiful, the in≈øide is mo≈øt dete≈øtable: the heat is ≈øo inten≈øe, that in the middle of the day there is no ≈øtirring out; and even at night the walls of the hou≈øes are ≈øo heated by the day's ≈øun, as to produce a di≈øagreeable heat to the body at a foot or even a yard di≈øtance from them. However, I entered it with ≈øpirits, becau≈øe I con≈øidered it as the la≈øt ≈øtage of the wor≈øt part of my pilgrimage. But al ‚Ä¢ s! I was di≈øappointed in my expectation; for the Tigris was dried up by the inten≈øity of the heat, and an unu≈øually long ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ought; and I was obliged to take the matter with a patient
≈øhrug, and accommodate my mind to a journey on hor≈øeback, which, though not ≈øo long as that I had already made, was likely to be equally dangerous, and which therefore demanded a full exertion of fortitude and re≈øolution.‚ÄîThere are a thou≈øand latent energies in every man, which only want the powerful voice of nece≈ø≈øity to call them out: and now drawn to the top of my bent, I prepared my mind to ≈øet out in the morning, with as much cheerfulne≈øs as if the hopes of water carriage to Bagdad had never once occured to my mind.

It was ≈øtill the hot ≈øea≈øon of the year, and we were to travel through that country, over which the horrid wind I have before mentioned ≈øweeps its con≈øuming bla≈øts: it is called by the Turks ≈øamiel, is mentioned by holy Job under the name of the Ea≈øt Wind, and extends its ravages all the way from the extreme end of the Gulph of Cambaya up to Mo≈øul; it carries along with it fleaks of fire, like threads of ≈øilk; in≈øtantly ≈øtrikes dead tho≈øe that breathe it, and con≈øumes them inwardly to a≈øhes; the fle≈øh ≈øoon becoming black as a coal, and dropping off from the bones. Philo≈øophers con≈øider it as a kind of electric fire, proceeding from the ≈øulphureous or nitrous exhalations which are kindled by the agitation of the winds. The only po≈ø≈øible means of e≈øcape from its fatal effects, is to fall flat on the ground, and thereby prevent the drawing it in‚ñ™ to do this, however, it is nece≈ø≈øary fir≈øt to ≈øee it, which is not always practicable.

But be≈øides this, the ordinary heat of the climate is extremely dangerous to the blood and lungs, and even to the ≈økin, which it bli≈øters and peels away from the fle≈øh, affecting the eyes ≈øo much that travellers are obliged to wear a tran≈øparent covering over them to keep the heat off.

That night, Ha≈ø≈øan ≈øaid, that as we mu≈øt proceed to Bagdad on hor≈øeback, he would ≈øtay the next at Mo≈øul to refre≈øh us; which I objected to: he then
≈øpoke of the ≈øucceeding part of the journey as a thing of nothing: we had already come near nine hundred miles, and had not above five to go: be≈øides, as the weather was warmer, we would travel more in the night, and lie-by in the day-time, in places with which he was well acquainted.

In ≈øhort, the poor fellow ≈øeemed to take an intere≈øt in my ≈øafety, and to wi≈øh to alleviate the pains of my mind; and he always concluded with a remon≈øtrance again≈øt laughing, which from frequently hearing I now under≈øtood even in his own language.‚Äî"Don't laugh‚ñ™ Jimmel, don't laugh," he would ≈øay with great ≈øolemnity.‚ÄîBy the bye, I ob≈øerved, that when he was well di≈øpo≈øed to me he always called me Jimmel (a name which I pre≈øume he con≈øtructed, with my ≈øervant's a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, from the re≈øemblance of ≈øound between Campbel and Camel, Jimmel being the Turki≈øh for that animal); and when angry, he called me Frangi, with all its gradations of Turki≈øh abu≈øe, Damus, Cucu, &c.

That evening, as we ≈øat in the caravan≈øera‚ñ™ a man entered and ≈øpoke to Ha≈ø≈øan, who ≈øeemed to pay great attention to what he was ≈øaying.‚ÄîHe was a well made man‚Äîbelow the middle ≈øize‚Äîand had that kind of countenance which be≈øpeaks ≈øhrewdne≈øs, ingenuity, and mirth. At length he retired; and ≈øoon after Ha≈ø≈øan bade us ri≈øe and follow him: he went into a ≈øort of public room, where a number of people were collected, ≈øitting as is the cu≈øtom in coffee-hou≈øes on low ≈øtools. H ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øan pointed to me to ≈øit down, which I did: then placing the Interpreter near us, he ≈øat him≈øelf: and ≈øtraight I perceived the little man, who had ju≈øt been ≈øpeaking to him, ≈øtep forth from the crowd and begin to pronounce a ≈øort of prologue, which I neither under≈øtood nor wi≈øhed to under≈øtand: it appeared from his cadences to be metrical, and ≈øeemed, by the little impre≈ø≈øion it made on his auditors, to have nothing particular to recommend
it. At length, however, he pau≈øed, and, hemming ≈øeveral times to clear his pipes, began again to hold forth. "He is going to tell a ≈øtory," ≈øaid the Interpreter. The attention of all was fixed upon him, and he proceeded with a modulation of tones, a variety of action, and an energy of expre≈ø≈øion, that I think I have never heard or ≈øeen excelled: his action indeed was ≈øingularly admirable; and I could perceive that he was occa≈øionally ≈øpeaking in the tones of a man and a woman: in which latter character he gave a picture of whining ludicrous di≈øtre≈øs, that moved the ri≈øible mu≈øcles of all the company. I looked at Ha≈ø≈øan, and he was grinning as merrily as could any monkey or Frank in A≈øia. The Lingui≈øt occa≈øionally interpreted what the ≈øtory-teller was ≈øaying; and I ≈øoon began to ≈øu≈øpect that it was a ≈øtory I had more than once read in the Arabian Nights, though altered, and in ≈øome mea≈øure dramatized by the ≈øpeaker. I looked ≈øeveral times archly at Ha≈ø≈øan, and he returned my glance, as much as to ≈øay, You ≈øee I don't laugh at all this. At length, however, the orator came to a part where he was to mimic a poor little hunch back (for I now di≈øcovered it to be the ≈øtory of little Hunch-back) choking with a bone: he threw up his back; ≈øqueezed till all the blood in his body ≈øeemed collected in his face, his eyes rolled in their ≈øockets, his knees knocked, he twi≈øted and folded his body, putting his fore finger, and thumb into his throat, and pulling with all his might, as if to pull ≈øomething out: at length he grew weaker, ≈øtretched his arms down, and his fingers back, like tho≈øe of a per≈øon ≈øtranggling‚Äîkicked, fell, quivered, and died. It is impo≈ø≈øible for any de≈øcription to do ju≈øtice to the perfection of his acting; and what rendered it the more extraordinary was, that though it was a ≈øcene of death, and well acted death he continued to render it ≈øo ludicrous in circum≈øtances,
as to ≈øu≈øpend the audience between a laugh and cry. They did not remain long ≈øo; for he ≈øuddenly bounced up, and began the mo≈øt doleful lamentation of a woman, and exhibited ≈øuch a ≈øcene of burle≈øque di≈øtre≈øs as I never witne≈ø≈øed. All bur≈øt out in torrents of laughter, Ha≈ø≈øan as well as the re≈øt‚ÄîI alone remained purpo≈øely ≈øerious; and the orator, according to cu≈øtom, broke off in the middle of an intere≈øting ≈øcene.

When we returned to the caravan≈øera, I rallied the Tartar on the ≈øcore of his laughter: he growled, and ≈øaid, "who could avoid it? Why did not you laugh as you were wont?"‚ÄîBecau≈øe, ≈øaid I, he did not act as cornically as you.‚Äî"No," returned he, "but becau≈øe Franks and monkies only laugh for mi≈øchief, and where they ought not. No, Jimmel, you will never ≈øee me laugh at mi≈øchief."‚Äî"What," ≈øaid I, "not a a poor man's being choked to death!"‚Äî"Nay," ≈øaid he, "I ≈øeldom laugh, Yet I could not avoid it then." That very hour, however, a puppet-≈øhow was exhibited in the ≈øame room, and my grave guide laughed till the tears ran down his cheeks, and his voice ≈øunk into a warning treble. Kara ghu≈øe was certainly extravagantly comical, though filthy; and frightened a cad ‚Ä¢ with a whole troop of Jani≈ø≈øaries, by letting fly at them a ≈øhot or two‚Äîa parte po≈øt‚Äî

The next day we ≈øet out well mounted, and pu≈øhed on with renovated ≈øpirits towards Bagdad.‚Äî Ha≈ø≈øan could no more have the a≈ø≈øurance to cen≈øure laughing and, as I was little di≈øpo≈øed to do it in time of danger, we were likely to agree well. In ≈øhort, we began to like one another's company; and if I brought him to be a greater laugher than he u≈øed to be, he gave him≈øelf the credit of having made me much more ≈øerious than I had been before‚ÄîI profiled by his in≈øtructions.

It would be an effort as idle and fruitle≈øs on my „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚Ä¢ ntertaining and unintere≈øting on yours,
to attempt to give you a regular detail of our progre≈øs from Mo≈øul to Bagdad; the ≈øame general cautions were ob≈øerved, with the ≈øame occa≈øional relaxations. Ha≈ø≈øan ≈øtill continued to treat me with a repetition of him≈øelf and his hor≈øe, his own feats and his hor≈øe's feats; to be ≈øilent when ill-tempered, and loquacious when gay; to flog the attendants at the caravan≈øeras; order the be≈øt hor≈øes, and eat the be≈øt victuals, and to give me the be≈øt of both; and finally we had our fallings out and fallings in again: but I had not the mortification of ≈øeeing any more women tied in ≈øacks on hor≈øe's backs, and excoriated with a ride of fifty miles a day.

As we rode along we overtook ≈øeveral times ≈øtraggling callenders, a kind of Mahomedan monks, who profe≈øs poverty and great ≈øanctity; they were dre≈ø≈øed all in rags, covered with filth, ca ‚Ä¢ ried a gourd, by way of bottle, for water‚ÄîI pre≈øume ≈øometimes for wine too‚Äîand bore in their hands a long pole decorated with rags, and pieces of cloth of various colours. They are ≈øuppo≈øed by the vulgar to have ≈øupernatural powers: but Ha≈ø≈øan, who ≈øeemed to have caught all his ideas from his betters, expre≈ø≈øed no ≈øort of opinion of them; he ≈øalam'd to them and gave them money, however. It was extraordinary enough, that they were all in one ≈øtory‚Äîall were going on a pilgrimage to Mecca‚Äîor, as they call it, Hadje.

As ≈øoon as ever we got out of their ≈øight and hearing, Ha≈ø≈øan ≈øhook his head, and repeated "Hadje, Hadje!" ≈øeveral times doubtingly, and grinned, as he was accu≈øtomed to do when he was di≈øplea≈øed, without being able to manife≈øt anger. "Hadje!" he would cry, "Hadje, Hadje!" I a≈øked him what he mean ‚Ä¢ ; and he ≈øaid, that the≈øe fellows were no more going to Mecca than I was. I have a thou≈øand and a thou≈øand times," ≈øaid he, met callenders on the road, and always found them facing towards Mecca. If I am going ≈øouthward,
I always overtake them; if northward, I meet them; and all the time they are going whereever their bu≈øine≈øs carries them. I overtook, continued he, "one of them one day, and I gave him alms and pa≈ø≈øed him by; he was coming he ≈øaid, after me, towards Mecca: but I halted on purpo≈øe for a day, and he never pa≈ø≈øed; and a merchant arriving at the ≈øame caravan≈øera informed me, he had met the very ≈øame fellow four leagues farther northward; who had an≈øwered him with the ≈øame ≈øtory, and ≈øtill had his face turned towards the ≈øouth."

Fifty years ago, no man in Turkey would have dared to hold his language; but every day's experience evinces that the light of rea≈øon ≈øpreads its rays fa≈øt through the world‚Äîeven through Turkey; and furni≈øhes a well founded hope, that in another half century every monki≈øh impo≈øtor (I mean real impo≈øtors,) whether they be Mahomedan monks, or Chri≈øtian monks, will be cha≈øed from ≈øociety, and forced to apply to hone≈øt means for ≈øub≈øi≈øtence.

div.head: A JOURNEY TO INDIA, &c. PART III.
LETTER XLIII.
div.p: AFTER pa≈ø≈øing through an immen≈øe tract of country, di≈øtingui≈øhed by nothing that could ≈øerve even as a circum≈øtance to mark and remember our daily journeys, but which I ob≈øerved to grow manife≈øtly wor≈øe, both in ≈øoil and climate, as we proceeded Southward, we came in fight of the famous city of Bagdad, on the ≈øeventh day from that on which we left Mo≈øul, and on the eighteenth from that of my departure from Aleppo; in which eighteen days we had rode fourteen hundred miles, pa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ly through a route which no European, I have rea≈øon to believe, ever took before.

On entering the city, I de≈øired my guide to conduct me to the hou≈øe of a Merchant, to whom I had got letters of credit and introduction. He took me accordingly through the windings of ≈øeveral ≈øtreets, and at la≈øt ≈øtopped at the do ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of an Armenian Merchant, or Coja, where he made me alight, and come in. I was received with great politene≈øs; and, on producing my „Äà‚óä„Äâ , ≈øound that he was not the per≈øon to whom it was directed: I accordingly
made a ≈øuitable apology, and was for retiring to find the hou≈øe of the proper per≈øon, for which purpo≈øe the Armenian offered me a ≈øervant, when, to my great a≈øtoni≈øhment, my Tartar interfered; ≈øaid that it was to this Merchant he brought all his goods, and that I mu≈øt remain where I was; at the ≈øame time ordering the Armenian, in a peremptory tone, to take charge of me, and u≈øe me well. It was in vain that the Armenian endeavoured to explain to him the nature of the bu≈øine≈øs, and that I in≈øi≈øted I mu≈øt go to the other Merchant‚ÄîHASSAN was peremptory, and declared that I ≈øhould not. It was ≈øo extremely outre and ridiculous, that I could not be angry; and the good Armenian uniting his voice with that of the Tartar, and entreating me to favour him with my company, I acquie≈øced, and indeed remained in his hou≈øe all the time I was at Bagdad. This was proof po≈øitive, if any other than I already had was wanting, that he con≈øidered me merely as a piece of merchandi≈øe, which he was bound (according to the language of Merchants) to deliver in good order and condition.

I had undertaken, before leaving Aleppo, to give the guide, if he acted conformably to my wi≈øhes, and behaved well, twenty pounds over and above the hundred provided by the agreement: I therefore ≈øent for him, to ≈øettle finally, and part. He had heard that I was a per≈øon different from what he had ≈øuppo≈øed me to be: but it did not alter his conduct, as might be expected, or make him ≈øtoop to cringing; he ≈øtill ≈øpoke with the ≈øame hone≈øt, bold familiarity; and when I gave him the promi≈øed twenty pounds, he never hinted, cringed for, or even looked as if he expected more: but when we came to part, the feelings he di≈øclo≈øed, and tho≈øe I my≈øelf felt, convinced me, that Man is not naturally that brute which prejudice has made him; and, when left to his own operations,
the human heart would be uniformly kindly, affectionate, and ≈øympathetic: the poor, rough, unpoli≈øhed Turk, betrayed the ≈øtronge≈øt marks of ≈øen≈øibility, and I my≈øelf once more felt the unea≈øine≈øs of parting.

I think this is the proper place to give you my opinion of the Turks, while the recollection of hone≈øt HASSAN is fre≈øh in my mind; and I cannot do it better than by quoting the words of an excellent French Writer‚Äî

"The Turks (≈øays M. du LOIR) are naturally a good people, which is not to be a≈øcribed to the climate; for the Greeks born in the ≈øame climate have very different di≈øpo≈øitions, and retain only the bad qualities of their ance≈øtors, v ‚Ä¢ z. roguery, treachery, and vanity. The Turks, on the contrary, priding them≈øelves on their integrity and mode≈øty, are di≈øtingui≈øhed in general by an open, ingenuous ≈øimplicity of manners; courtiers only excepted, who, in Turkey, as every where el≈øe, are the ≈ølaves of ambition and avarice."

The name of Bagdad has been ≈øo renowned in Ea≈øtern ≈øtory, and is the ≈øcene of ≈øo many of tho≈øe bewitching tales which we find tran≈ølated, or pretended to be tran≈ølated, from the Arabic and Per≈øian, that I felt great plea≈øure in ≈øeeing it, and conceived my≈øelf to be at the very fountain-head of marvellous adventure and romance. Fraught with this idea, I was impatient to go forth into the town; and notwith≈øtanding the weather was beyond conception hot, I paraded a number of ≈øtreets: but never did I, in the cour≈øe of my life, ≈øee a place ≈øo calculated to belie the opinion one would form of it from the ea≈øtern tales. It appeared to me to be among the mo≈øt di≈øagreeable cities of the world, and has no one circum≈øtance that I could di≈øcover to recommend it: the heat is ≈øo great, that in the Summer-time the inhabitants are forced to keep their markets in the night, and to lie
all night in the open air, on the terraces of their hou≈øes.

The Armenian with whom I re≈øided, did every thing in his power to render the place agreeable to me; and I ≈øhall always retain a lively ≈øen≈øe of his goodne≈øs and ho≈øpitality: he was not only generous and polite, but well informed, and plea≈øing in conver≈øation. I took occa≈øion to expre≈øs to him the di≈øappointment I felt at finding Bagdad ≈øo very different from what I expected; and told him that I had, when a youth, learned to think highly of it, or rather romantically, from reading Ea≈øtern tales. This led to a conver≈øation on the Arabian Nights Entertainments, a copy of which he had in the Arabic, and produced it: he then ≈øhewed me, with great triumph, a French tran≈ølation of them, printed at Paris, which he had read, and declared that the tran≈ølation was nothing it all in compari≈øon with the original. I believe he was well qualified to judge, for he was a perfect ma≈øter of the French language.

We talked of the Ea≈øtern tale of the Gla≈øs Man, who, in a reverie, increa≈øes his ≈øtock till he gets ≈øo rich as, in imagination, to marry the Cadi's daughter, &c. &c. and in kicking his wife, kicks all his gla≈ø≈øes about, and de≈øtroys the whole of his vi≈øionary fortune. I prai≈øed the humour of it much ‚Äî"Sir," ≈øaid he, "there is nothing in it that may not be experienced frequently in actual life: tho≈øe waking dreams are the u≈øual concomitants of opium: a man who has accu≈øtomed him≈øelf to the pernicicious practice of eating opium, is con≈øtantly ≈øubject to them. I have, in the cour≈øe of my time, found a thou≈øand of tho≈øe dreamers holding forth in the plenitude of imaginary power. I have ≈øeen a common porter become Cadi, and order the ba≈øtinado. I have ≈øeen a wretched tailor rai≈øed by the effects of opium to the office of Aga of the Jani≈ø≈øaries, depo≈øing the Sultan, and ordering the bow≈øtring
to all about him. I have ≈øeen ≈øome indulging in the blandi≈øhments of love with Prince≈ø≈øes, and others wallowing in the wealth of Golconda. But the mo≈øt extr ‚Ä¢ ordinary vi≈øionary of this kind I ever met with, was one who imagined him≈øelf tran≈ølated to Paradi≈øe, co-equal to Mahomet, and ≈øitting by the ≈øide of that prophet, arguing with him in defence of the u≈øe of wine and opium: he argued mo≈øt ingeniou≈øly, li≈øtened in ≈øilence to the ≈øuppo≈øed arguments of his adver≈øary, an≈øwered them, replied, rejoined, and ≈øtill argued on‚Äîtill, growing at la≈øt angry, he ≈øwore that he was as good a prophet as him, did not care a fig for him, and called him fool and fal≈øe prophet. A Turk who was pre≈øent, in the fulne≈øs of his zeal, laid a ≈øtick very heavily acro≈øs his ≈øhoulders, and put an end to the vi≈øion: and never did I ≈øee a wretch ≈øo abject, ≈øo forlorn, or ≈øo mi≈øerably de≈øponding; he put his forehead to the ground, which he wet with his tears, crying, Mercy, Mahomet! mercy, holy Prophet! mercy, Alla!‚Äînor could he find relief (≈øuch is the ruin of opium) till he got a fre≈øh ≈øupply of it in his mouth, which ≈øoon gave him a temporary re≈øpite from the horrors of his ≈øituation."

Unque≈øtionably, Bagdad was once a great city, of flouri≈øhing commerce; but the Sultan AMURATH the Fourth, when he made him≈øelf ma≈øter of it, put the riche≈øt Merchants ≈øettled there to death; and it has ever ≈øince gradually declined. About two days journey from it, lie the ruins of the once famous city of Babylon. I was much di≈øpo≈øed to go to ≈øee it, and thence drop down the Euphrates to Ba≈ø≈øora: but my Armenian ho≈øt told me there was nothing in it to recompen≈øe a per≈øon for half the trouble; for, of that magnificent city, which was ≈øixty m ‚Ä¢ les in circumference, which was encompa≈ø≈øed with walls eighty-≈øeven feet in thickne≈øs, and three hundred and fifty in height, nothing was to be ≈øeen but the bare foundations of
≈øome great edifices. The Tower of Belus, and the Palace of Nebuchadnezzar, lie with the re≈øt in undi≈øtingui≈øhed ruin. The greate≈øt curio≈øities, then, were, in the fir≈øt place, the ruins of a building ≈øaid to be the famed Tower of Babel, which appeared to have been half a league in compa≈øs; and the remains of a va≈øt bridge over the Euphrates, where it is half a league broad.

I was not more anxious to arrive at the city of Bagdad than I was to leave it; and having written letters, and put them in a way of being forwarded to Europe, I took leave of my friendly ho≈øpitable Armenian, and, with a thou≈øand acknowledgments for his kindne≈øs, ≈øet out on hor≈øeback to a place on the Tigris, where I embarked in a boat, in order to proceed to Ba≈ø≈øora. This river, known ≈øince the fir≈øt records of human exi≈øtence by Geographers, is remarkable for its rapidity, whence, PLINY ≈øays, it has the name of Tigris, (in the Median language, a dart); and for its extraordinary cour≈øe, which is in many places under ground, ri≈øes in Armenia, ≈øinks into the earth near mount Taurus, and runs under a mountain‚Äîthen ri≈øing at the other ≈øide, follows its cour≈øe through the lake The≈øpites‚Äîagain ≈øinks frequently under ground, and continues hid at one time for a ≈øpace of twenty-five miles; where, once more emerging, it glides along wiih a very rapid ≈øtream, meets the Euphrates at a place called Korna, pa≈ø≈øes through Ba≈ø≈øora, and falls into the Per≈øian Gulph.

As the boat in which I took my pa≈ø≈øage had no convenience for excluding the violence of the ≈øun, except an awning, I ≈øuffered extremely from the heat. The River it≈øelf was grand; but the banks, and contiguous country, contained nothing to attract notice‚Äîno object to diver≈øify the dreary, de≈øer ‚Ä¢ ed a≈øpect of the ≈øcene‚Äînothing to afford room for reflection, or give birth to a new idea. I do not remember to have ever pa≈ø≈øed through ≈øuch a
va≈øt extent of country, ≈øo uniformly dull and unintere≈øting. The only thing that ≈øerved to keep the mind alive, was the apprehen≈øion of robbers, who, in great numbers, hover over this river, and plunder pa≈ø≈øengers. We had taken care, on leaving Bagdad, to be well provided with fire-arms; and they did us yeomen's ≈øervice‚Äîfor we were frequently attacked by robbers with a view to plunder, but found that a ≈øhot or two di≈øper≈øed and ≈øent them off in con≈øternation. One night, however, in pa≈ø≈øing a creek, we perceived ≈øeveral boats i≈ø≈øuing from it, in great order, and in a manner that evinced method and premeditation: we ≈øilently prepared for their reception, and were completely ready to meet them warmly, while they thought us quite unprepared, and uncon≈øcious of their approach: they fir≈øt endeavoured to board us by ≈øurpri≈øe: wi≈øhing rather to frighten than to kill them, we began by firing over their heads; on which they ≈øet up the mo≈øt horrible ≈øhouts, and ru≈øhed on with a tumultuous rapidity, making the mo≈øt terrible noi≈øe in order to intimidate us: they were by this time quite near us; we therefore took aim at them, and let fly, and immediately perceived them in great confu≈øion, ≈øome of the boats lo≈øing their helm, and falling with the ≈øtream on the others: at la≈øt we ≈øaw them ≈øheer off, and they gave us no farther trouble.

div.head: LETTER XLIV.
div.p:
AFTER eight or ten as di≈øagreeable days as I remember to have ≈øpent in my life, weakened with ince≈ø≈øant watching, hara≈ø≈øed with bodily fatigue, and melted with the exce≈ø≈øive heat of the
≈øun, I arrived at the city of Ba≈ø≈øora, where I was received with the utmo≈øt ho≈øpitality by Mr. LATOUCHE, the Company's Re≈øident from Bombay, who did every thing po≈ø≈øible for my accomodation, and procured me every in≈øtruction re≈øpecting my further progre≈øs.

This city, as well as Bagdad, is famous in marvellous ≈øtory. The country about it is con≈øidered by the natives as the be≈øt ≈øpot in A≈øia, though the burning winds annoy and frequently de≈øtroy travellers, overwhelming them with mountains of hot ≈øand, driven like waves of the ≈øea, before the tempe≈øt out of the neighbouring de≈øerts. It carries on a great trade, and is inhabited by va≈øt numbers of Chri≈øtians and Jews. The Engli≈øh and Dutch have factories here, as well for the purpo≈øe of commerce, as the tran≈øit of di≈øpatches, by way of Dama≈øcus and Aleppo, to Europe. The Riche≈øt merchandi≈øe of India and Europe are brought here in caravans; and its opulence is greatly increa≈øed by the caravans of Pilgrims, who pa≈øs through it on their way to Mecca, and pay great duties, bartering for many rich commodities. The hor≈øes of this place are celebrated for their ≈øuperior excellence: it is ≈øaid that they will run thirty hours without meat or drink‚ÄîI doubt the fact, and ≈øhould be ≈øorry to ≈øee ≈øo inhuman an experiment tried.

One comfortable circum≈øtance attending Ba≈ø≈øora is, that at night the ≈øtreets may be walked with perfect ≈øafety at all hours. It is ≈øubject to an Arab Prince, who is tributary to the Turk, and who≈øe revenue is very great, as well from the above-mentioned cau≈øes, as becau≈øe he gives full liberty to all Nations to come and trade to his capital.

From Ba≈ø≈øora I took my pa≈ø≈øage in a date-boat going to Mu≈økat, expecting to get from thence a ≈øpeedy pa≈ø≈øage to Bombay: but the boat ≈øprung a leak at ≈øea, and we were obliged to run into Bu≈øheer, where I was very ho≈øpitably received and
entertained by Mr. GALLEY, the Company's Re≈øident.

There really ≈øeemed to be an unu≈øual fatality attending me throughout the whole of my journey. You will recollect, in the fir≈øt in≈øtance, I was prevented, by the war with France, from going by the direct route which I ≈øhould otherwi≈øe have taken, and obliged to pa≈øs through the Low Countries and Germany‚ÄîIn the next place, at Venice I was di≈øappointed in obtaining a pa≈ø≈øage to Latachaea; and, immediately on the heels of that, lo≈øt my ≈øervant at Trie≈øte, by ≈øending him for letters to Venice‚ÄîAfterwards, when I had gone to Alexandria with expectation of travelling through Egypt, and viewing that intere≈øting part of the world, I found my≈øelf prevented by the unhappy circum≈øtances of the country‚Äîthe plague raging in Alexandria, and all the roads being blocked up by an incur≈øion of the Arabs. Thus mortified and di≈øappointed, I turned about, in order to make my way in another direction; and arriving at Cyprus, found, to my infinite ≈øurpri≈øe and regret, that an epidemic di≈øea≈øe, little ≈øhort of the plague, prevailed there, and ≈øwept off the inhabitants in great numbers: when, after ≈øurmounting all tho≈øe ob≈øtacles, I arrived at Aleppo, the fir≈øt information I got was, that the caravan was gone, and that it would be a long time before another would be ready; and my departure from Aleppo was attended with circum≈øtances no le≈øs inau≈øpicious than my entrance‚ÄîAt Mo≈øul I experienced another di≈øappointment, by the river's being dried up, and rendered impracticable by boats‚ÄîMy pa≈ø≈øage from Ba≈ø≈øora to Mu≈økat was impeded by the ve≈ø≈øel ≈øpringing a leak‚ÄîAnd now, when at la≈øt I hoped to get from Bu≈øheer to Bombay, I was ≈øtopped by the intelligence that the Gulph was blocked up by French privateers, in≈øomuch as no ve≈ø≈øel could hope to e≈øcape, I was therefore obliged to remain at
Bu≈øheer, till a Company's frigate, commanded by Captain HARDY, and ≈øoon expected ≈øhould afford me an opportunity of proceeding to Bombay. Time, however, brought that period about; and I took my pa≈ø≈øage, and arrived ≈øafe at Bombay, where I ≈øoon after embarked on board a Portugue≈øe ve≈ø≈øel, being the only conveyance that offered for me to proceed to Madras: ≈øhe was fir≈øt bound to Goa, and we arrived ≈øafely at that i≈øland, where I was received with great politene≈øs, and treated with the mo≈øt friendly attention, by Mr. HENSHAW, the Engli≈øh Re≈øident.

Goa belongs to the Portugue≈øe: the Viceroy of the Nation lives there in great pomp. It was once the ≈øcene of the mo≈øt abominable cruelties, exerci≈øed by that flagitious people on the natives, under pretended ze ‚Ä¢ l for Chri≈øtianity‚ÄîI had read the Abb√® RAYNAL'S glowing de≈øcription of it; and as I trod the ground, my frame trembled at the thoughts of the ma≈ø≈øacres perpetrated there.

I was impatient to get from Goa, and yet I looked forward to my departure with a ≈øecret unea≈øine≈øs, for which I was entirely unable to account‚Äî I wi≈øhed to proceed, and yet ≈øome ≈øecret foreboding whi≈øpered to my heart that I was on the verge of calamity: ≈øo powerful was it, and ≈øo ob≈øtinate, that I could neither rea≈øon away its admonitions, nor re≈øi≈øt its impre≈ø≈øions; and ≈øomething ince≈øtantly told me, in as plain language as if a human being ≈øpoke, that I ≈øhould ≈øuffer a dreadful misfortune. As I had all my life been an enemy to ≈øuper≈øtition, I felt my ≈øpirit in≈øulted, and my under≈øtanding degraded, by the involuntary victory which I allowed to this impre≈ø≈øion‚ÄîI combated it with rea≈øon, with ridicule, with ≈øelf-contempt ‚Äîall in vain: in ≈øpite of me, I became the very ≈ølave of gloomy pre≈øentiment; and in order to get the ≈øuccedaneous aid of a friend's rea≈øon, as well as to be prepared, I communicated the ≈øtate of my
feelings to Mr. HENSHAW. In vain he endeavoured to cheer me: all he could do was to give me his coun≈øel; in con≈øequence of which I actually ≈øettled all my affairs up to that day, made my will, left it with Mr. HENSHAW, and, full of dreadful forebodings of ≈øhipwreck, went on board a Portugue≈øe ≈ønow bound to Madras.

It was now the eighteenth day of May when we ≈øailed from Goa. The hemi≈øphere had been for ≈øome days overca≈øt with clouds: ≈øome light ≈øhowers of rain had fallen; and you may conclude that it did not tend to rai≈øe my ≈øpirits, or free me from ominous apprehen≈øions, to hear that tho≈øe circum≈øtances indicated an approaching gale of wind. I ob≈øerved, moreover, that the ve≈ø≈øel was much too deep in the water, being greatly overloaded‚Äîthat ≈øhe was in many re≈øpects defective, and, as the ≈øeamen ≈øay, ill-found, and in ≈øhort very unfit to encounter a gale of wind of any violence. I ≈øcorned, however, to yield to tho≈øe united impre≈ø≈øions, and determined to proceed.

On the nineteenth, the ≈øky was ob≈øcured by immen≈øe fleeces of clouds, ≈øurcharged with inflammable matter; and in the evening, the rain fell in torrents, the firmament darkened apace, ≈øudden night came on, and the horrors of extreme darkne≈øs were rendered ≈øtill more horrible by the peals of thunder which rent the air, and the frequent fla≈øhes of lightning, which ≈øerved only to ≈øhew us the horror of our ≈øituation, and leave us in increa≈øed darkne≈øs: mean-time the wind became more violent, blowing on the ≈øhore; and a heavy ≈øea, rai≈øed by its force, united with it to make our ≈øtate more formidable.

By day-light on the morning of the twentieth, the gale had encrea≈øed to a furious tempe≈øt; and the ≈øea, keeping pace with it, ran mountain-high; and as it kept invariably to the ≈øame point, the Captain and Officers became ≈øeriou≈øly alarmed, and almo≈øt
per≈øuaded that the South-We≈øt Mon≈øoon had ≈øet in, which, if it were ≈øo, would render it ab≈øolutely impo≈ø≈øible for us to weather the coa≈øt. All that day, however, we kept as clo≈øe as the violence of the weather would allow us to the wind; but the ≈øea canted her head ≈øo to leeward, that ≈øhe made more lee than head-way; and the rigging was ≈øo ≈øtrained with the work that we had little hope of keeping off the ≈øhore, unle≈øs the wind changed, of which there was not now the ≈ømalle≈øt probability. During the night there was no intermi≈ø≈øion of the ≈øtorm: many of the ≈øails flew into ribbons; ≈øome of the ‚Ä¢ igging was carried away; and ≈øuch exertions were made, that, before morning, every ≈øtick that could po≈ø≈øibly be ≈øtruck was down upon the deck.

About ≈øeven o'clock on the morning of the twenty-fir≈øt, I was alarmed by an un≈øual noi≈øe upon the deck, and running up, perceived that every remaining ≈øail in the ve≈ø≈øel, the fore-≈øail alone excepted, was totally carried away. The ≈øight was horrible; and the whole ve≈ø≈øel pre≈øented a ≈øpectacle as dreadful to the feelings as mortifying to human pride. Fear had produced, not only all the helple≈ø≈øne≈øs of de≈øpondency, but all the mi≈øchievous freaks of in≈øanity. In one place ≈øtood the Captain, raving, ≈øtamping, and tearing his hair in handfuls from his head‚Äîhere ≈øome of the crew were ca≈øt upon their knees, clapping their hands, and praying, with all the extravagance of horror painted in their faces ‚Äî there, others were flogging their images with all their might, calling upon them to allay the ≈øtorm. One of our pa≈ø≈øengers, who was Pur≈øer of an Engli≈øh Ea≈øt-Indiaman, had got hold of a ca≈øe-bottle of rum, and, with an air of di≈øtraction and deep de≈øpair imprinted in his face, was ≈øtalking about in his ≈øhirt. I perceived him to be on the point of ≈øerving it about, in large tumblers, to the few undi≈ømayed people; and well convinced, that, ≈øo far from alleviating, it would ≈øharpen the horrors of
their mind, I went forward, and with much difficulty prevented him.

Having accompli≈øhed this point, I applied my≈øelf to the Captain, and endeavoured to bring h ‚Ä¢ m back (if po≈ø≈øible) to his recollection, and to a ≈øen≈øe of what he owed to his duty as a commander, and to his dignity as a man: I exhorted him to encourage the ≈øailors by his example; and ≈øtrove to rai≈øe his ≈øpirits, by ≈øaying that the ≈øtorm did not appear to me by any means ≈øo terrible as ≈øome I had before experienced.

While I was thus employed, we ≈øhipped a ≈øea on the ≈øtarboard ≈øide, which I really thought would have ≈øent us down. The ve≈ø≈øel ≈øeemed to ≈øink beneath its weight, ≈øhivered, and remained motionle≈øs‚Äîit was a moment of critical ≈øu≈øpen≈øe: fancy made me think I felt her gradually de≈øcending‚ÄîI gave my≈øelf up as gone, and ≈øummoned all my fortitude to bear approaching death with becoming manhood.

Ju≈øt at this cri≈øis, the water, which ru≈øhed with incredible force through all parts of the ve≈ø≈øel, brought out floating, and nearly ≈øuffocated, another Engli≈øh pa≈ø≈øenger, who was endeavouring to take a little repo≈øe in a ≈ømall cabin boarded off from the deck: he was a very ≈øtout young man, and full of true ≈øpirit. Finding that the ve≈ø≈øel was not, as I had thought, going immediately down, he joined me in exhorting the captain to his duty: we per≈øuaded him to throw the guns overboard, as well as a number of trunks and packages with which the ve≈ø≈øel was much encumbered; and with ≈øome little exertion, we got the pumps ≈øet agoing.

Here I will ≈øtop, knowing the warm ≈øen≈øibility of my FREDERICK'S mind; and, convinced that his ≈øympathetic heart will go hand-in-hand with his Father's ≈øuffering's, I will not overcharge it with grief by an immediate continuation of the bu≈øine≈øs, but defer it to another Letter.

div.head: LETTER XLV.
div.p: THE name of the Engli≈øh pa≈ø≈øenger, whom I mentioned to you in my la≈øt Letter as a≈ø≈øi≈øting me in getting the Captain and Mariners to do their duty, was HALL. He was a young man of a mo≈øt amiable di≈øpo≈øition, and with it po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed all that manly ≈øpirit that gives pre≈øence of mind in exigences of danger. He and I having, with great difficulty, got ≈øome hands to ≈øtick to the pumps, ≈øtood at the wheel, at once to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the men, and prevent them from quitting it; and, although hopele≈øs, determined that no effort practicable on our parts ≈øhould be wanting to the pre≈øervation of the ve≈ø≈øel. The water, however, gained upon the pumps, notwith≈øtanding every effort; and it evidently appeared that we could not keep her long above water.

At ten o'clock the wind ≈øeemed to increa≈øe, and amounted to a downright hurricane: the ≈øky was ≈øo entirely ob≈øcured with black clouds, and the rain fell ≈øo thick, that objects were not di≈øcernable from the wheel to the ≈øhip's head. Soon the pumps were choaked, and could no longer be worked: then di≈ømay ≈øeized on all‚Äînothing but unutterable de≈øpair, ≈øilent angui≈øh, and horror, wrought up to frenzy, was to be ≈øeen; not a ≈øingle ≈øoul was capable of an effort to be u≈øeful‚Äîall ≈øeemed more de≈øirous to extingui≈øh their calamities by embracing death, than willing, by a painful exertion, to avoid it.

At about eleven o'clock we could plainly di≈øtingui≈øh a dreadful roaring noi≈øe, re≈øembling that of waves rolling again≈øt rocks; but the darkne≈øs of
the day, and the accompanying rains, prevented us from ≈øeeing any di≈øtance; and if they were rocks, we might be actually da≈øhed to pieces on them before we could perceive them. At twelve o'clock, however, the weather cleared up a little, and both the wind and the ≈øea ≈øeemed to have abated: the very expan≈øion of the pro≈øpect round the ≈øhip was exhilerating; and as the weather grew better, and the ≈øea le≈øs furious, the ≈øen≈øes of the people returned, and the general ≈øtupefaction began to decrea≈øe.

The weather continuing to clear up, we in ≈øome time di≈øcovered breakers and large rocks without ≈øide of us; ≈øo that it appeared we mu≈øt have pa≈ø≈øed quite clo≈øe to them, and were now fairly hemmed in between them and the land.

In this very critical juncture, the Captain, entirely contrary to my opinion, adopted the dangerous re≈øolution of letting go an anchor, to bring her up with her head to the ≈øea: But, though no ≈øeaman, my common ≈øen≈øe told me that ≈øhe could never ride it out, but mu≈øt directly go down. The event nearly ju≈øtified my judgment; for ≈øhe had ≈øcarcely been at anchor before an enormous ≈øe ‚Ä¢ rolling over her, overwhelmed and filled her with water, and every one on board concluded that ≈øhe was certainly ≈øinking‚ÄîOn the in≈øtant, a La≈øcar, with a pre≈øence of mind worthy an old Engli≈øh mariner, took an axe, ran forward, and cut the cable.

On finding her≈øelf free, the ve≈ø≈øel again floated, and made an effort to right her≈øelf; but ≈øhe was almo≈øt completely water-logged, and heeled to larboard ≈øo much that the gunnel lay under water. We then endeavoured to ≈øteer as fa≈øt as we could for the land, which we knew could not be at any great di≈øtance, though we were unable to di≈øcover it through the hazy weather: the fore≈øail was loo≈øened; by great efforts in balling, ≈øhe righted a little,
her gunnel was got above water, and we ≈øcudded as well as we could before the wind, which ≈øtill blew hard on ≈øhore; and at about two o'clock the land appeared at a ≈ømall di≈øtance a head.

The love of life countervails all other con≈øiderations in the mind of man. The uncertainty we were under with regard to the ≈øhore before us, which we had rea≈øon to believe was part of HYDER ALLI'S dominions, where we ≈øhould meet with the mo≈øt rigorous treatment, if not ultimate death, was forgotten in the joyful hope of ≈øaving life; and we ≈øcudded towards the ≈øhore in all the exulting tran≈øports of people ju≈øt ≈ønatched from the jaws of death.

This gleam of happine≈øs continued not long: a tremendous ≈øea rolling after us, broke over our ≈øtern, tore every thing before it, ≈øtove in the ≈øteerage, carried away the rudder, ≈øhivered the wheel to pieces, and tore up the very ring-bolts of the deck‚Äîconveyed the men who ≈øtood at the wheel forward, and ≈øwept them overboard. I was ≈øtanding, at the time, near the wheel, and fortunately had hold of the taffarel, which enabled me to re≈øi≈øt in part the weight of the wave. I was, however, ≈øwept off my feet, and da≈øhed again≈øt the main-ma≈øt. The jerk from the taffarel, which I hold very tenaciou≈øly, ≈øeemed as if it would have di≈ølocated my arms: however, it broke the impetus of my motion, and in all probability ≈øaved me from being da≈øhed to pieces again≈øt the ma≈øt.

I floundered about in the water at the foot of the ma≈øt, till at length I got on my feet, and ≈øeized a rope, which I held in a ≈øtate of great embarra≈ø≈øment, dubious what I ≈øhould do to extricate my≈øelf. At this in≈øtant I perceived that Mr. HALL had got upon the cap≈øtern, and was waving his hand to me to follow his example: this I wi≈øhed to do, though it was an enterpri≈øe of ≈øome ri≈øk and difficulty; for, if I lo≈øt the hold I had, a ≈øingle
motion of the ve≈ø≈øel, or a full wave, would certainly carry me overboard. I made a bold pu≈øh, however, and fortunately accompli≈øhed it. Having attained this ≈øtation, I could the better ≈øurvey the wreck, and ≈øaw that the water was nearly brea≈øt-high on the quarter-deck, (for the ve≈ø≈øel was deep-wai≈øted); and I perceived the unfortunate Engli≈øh Pur≈øer ≈øtanding where the water was mo≈øt ≈øhallow, as if watching with patient expectation its ri≈øing, and awating death: I called to him to come to us, but he ≈øhook his head in de≈øpair, and ≈øaid, in a lamentable tone, "It is all over with us! GOD have mercy upon us!"‚Äîthen ≈øeated him≈øelf with ≈øeeming compo≈øure on a chair which happened to be rolling about in the wreck of the deck, and in a few minutes afterwards was wa≈øhed into the ≈øea along with it, where he was ≈øpeedily relea≈øed from a ≈øtate ten thou≈øand times wor≈øe than death.

During this univer≈øal wreck of things, the horror I was in could not prevent me from ob≈øerving a very curious circum≈øtance, which at any other time would have excited laughter, though now it produced no other emotion than ≈øurpri≈øe‚ÄîWe happened to be in part laden with mangoes, of which the i≈øland of Goa is known to produce the fine≈øt in the world; ≈øome of them lay in ba≈økets on the poop; a little black boy, in the moment of greate≈øt danger, had got ≈øeated by them, devouring them voraciou≈øly, and crying all the time mo≈øt bitterly at the horrors of his ≈øituation!

As the larboard ≈øide of the ve≈ø≈øel was gradually going down, the deck, and of cour≈øe the cap≈øtern, became too nearly perpendicular for us to continue on it: we therefore fore≈øaw the nece≈ø≈øity of quitting it, and got upon the ≈øtarboard ≈øide, holding fa≈øt by the gunnel, and allowing our bodies and legs to yield to the ≈øea as it broke over us. Thus we continued for ≈øome time: at length the ≈øeverity of the labour ≈øo entirely exhau≈øted our ≈øtrength and ≈øpirits, that our be≈øt hope ≈øeemed to be a ≈øpeedy conclu≈øion to our painful death; and we began to have ≈øerious intentions of letting go our hold, and yielding our≈øelves up at once to the fury of the waves.

The ve≈ø≈øel, which all this time drifted with the ≈øea and wind, gradually approximated the ≈øhore, and at length ≈øtruck the ground, which for an in≈øtant revived our almo≈øt departed hopes; but we ≈øoon found that it did not in the ≈ømalle≈øt degree better our ≈øituation‚ÄîAgain I began to yield to utter de≈øpair‚Äîagain I thought of letting go my hold, and ≈øinking at once: It is impo≈ø≈øible thought I ever to e≈øcape‚Äîwhy, then, prolong, for a few minutes, a painful exi≈øtence that mu≈øt at la≈øt be given up? Yet, yet, the all-≈øubduing love of life ≈øugge≈øted, that many things apparently impo≈ø≈øible had come to pa≈øs; and I ≈øaid to my≈øelf, If life is to be lo≈øt, why not lo≈øe it in a glorious ≈øtruggle? Should I ≈øurvive it by accident, life will be rendered doubly ≈øweet to me, and I ≈øtill more worthy of it by per≈øevering fortitude.

While I was employed in this train of reflection, I perceived ≈øome of the people collecting together, talking, and holding a con≈øultation‚ÄîIt immediately occurred to me, that they were devi≈øing ≈øome plan for e≈øcaping from the wreck, and getting on ≈øhore: and, ≈øo natural is it for man to cling to his fellow-creature for ≈øupport in difficult or dangerous exigences, I propo≈øed to Mr. HALL to
