div.head: LETTER XLVI.
div.p: AS prodigality of life is, in ≈øome ca≈øes, the exce≈øs of virtue and courage‚Äî≈øo there are others in which it is vice, meanne≈øs and cowardice. True courage is, according to the circum≈øtances under which it is to operate, as rigidly tenacious and vigilant of life in one ca≈øe, as it is indifferent and regardle≈øs in another; and I think it is a very ≈øtrange contradiction in the human heart (although it often happens), that a man who has the mo≈øt unbounded courage, in ≈øeeking death even in the cannon's mouth, ≈øhall yet want the nece≈ø≈øary re≈øolution to make exertions to ≈øave his life in ca≈øes of ordinary danger. The unfortunate Engli≈øh Pur≈øer could not collect courage ≈øufficient to make an effort to ≈øave him≈øelf; and yet I think it probable that he would have faced a battery of artillery, or expo≈øed him≈øelf to a pi≈øtol-≈øhot, if occa≈øion required, as ≈øoon as any other man. Thus it appears at fir≈øt view: but may not this ≈øeeming incongruity be explained by ≈øaying, that per≈øonal courage and fortitude are different qualities of the mind and body, and depend upon the exerci≈øe of entirely different functions?

Be that as it may, I argued with my≈øelf, in the height of my calamitous ≈øituation, upon the ≈øubject of fortitude and dejection, courage and cowardice; and, nothwith≈øtanding the ≈øerious a≈øpect of
affairs, found my≈øelf li≈øtening to the ≈øugge≈øtions of pride: What a paltry thing to yield, while ≈øtrength is left to ≈øtruggle! There were, I confe≈øs, tran≈øitory images in my mind, which, co-operating with the natural attachment to ≈øelf-pre≈øervation, made me per≈øevere, and re≈øolve to do ≈øo, while one ve≈øtige of hope was left for the mind to dwell on.

Ob≈øerving, as I told you before, the people con≈øulting together, and re≈øolving to join them, I made an effort to get to the lee ≈øhrouds, where they were ≈øtanding, or rather clinging; but before I could accompli≈øh it, I lo≈øt my hold, fell down the hatchway (the gratings having been carried away with the long-boat), and was for ≈øome minutes entangled there among≈øt a heap of packages, which the violent fluctuations of the water had collected on the lee ≈øide. As the ve≈ø≈øel moved with the ≈øea, and the water flowed in, the packages and I were rolled together‚Äî≈øometimes one, ≈øometimes another, uppermo≈øt; ≈øo that I began to be apprehen≈øive I ≈øhould not be able to extricate my≈øelf: by the mere≈øt accident, however, I gra≈øped ≈øomething that lay in my way, made a vigorous ≈øpring, and gained the lee ≈øhrouds. Mr. HALL, who followed me, in ≈øeizing the ≈øhrouds, came thump again≈øt me with ≈øuch violence that I could ≈øcarcely retain my hold of the rigging. Compelled by the perilous ≈øituation in which I ≈øtood, I called out to him for GOD'S ≈øake to keep off, for that I was rendered quite breathle≈øs and worn out: he generou≈øly endeavoured to make way for me, and, in doing ≈øo, unfortunately lo≈øt his hold, and went down under the ≈øhip's ≈øide. Never, never ≈øhall I forget my ≈øen≈øations at this melancholy incident‚ÄîI would have given millions of worlds that I could have recalled the words which made him move; my
mind was wound up to the la≈øt pitch of angui≈øh: I may truly ≈øay, that this was the mo≈øt bitter of all the bitter moments of my life, compared with which the other circum≈øtances of the ≈øhipwreck ≈øeemed le≈ø≈øened‚Äîfor I had in≈øen≈øibly acquired an unu≈øual e≈øteem and warm attachment for him, and was doubtful whether, after being even the innocent occa≈øion of his falling, I ought to take further pains to pre≈øerve my own life. All tho≈øe ≈øen≈øations were pa≈ø≈øing with the rapidity of lightning through my thoughts, when, as much to my a≈øtoni≈øhment as to my joy, I ≈øaw him borne by a returning wave, and thrown among the very packages from which I had but ju≈øt before, with ≈øuch labour and difficulty, extricated my≈øelf‚ÄîIn the end he proved equally fortunate, but after a much longer and harder ≈øtruggle, and after ≈øu≈øtaining much more injury.

I once more changed my ≈øtation, and made my way to the poop, where I found my≈øelf rather more ≈øheltered‚ÄîI earne≈øtly wi≈øhed Mr. HALL to be with me, whatever might be my ultimate fate ‚Äîand beckoned to him to come to me; but he only an≈øwered by ≈øhaking his head, in a feeble, de≈øponding manner‚Äî≈øtaring at the ≈øame time wildly about him: even his ≈øpirit was ≈øubdued; and de≈øpair, I perceived, had begun to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his mind.

Being a little more at ea≈øe in my new ≈øtation than I had been before, I had more time to deliberate, and more power to judge. I recollected, that, according to the cour≈øe of time, the day was far gone, and the night quickly approaching: I reflected, that for any enterprize what≈øoever, day was much preferable to night; and above all I con≈øidered, that the ve≈ø≈øel could not hold long together‚ÄîI therefore thought, that the be≈øt mode I could adopt would be, to take to the water with the fir≈øt boyant thing I could ≈øee; and, as the wind and water
both ≈øeemed to run to the ≈øhore, to take my chance in that way of reaching it. In pur≈øuance of this re≈øolution, I tore off my ≈øhirt, having before that thrown off the other parts of my dre≈øs‚ÄîI looked at my ≈øleeve buttons, in which was ≈øet the hair of my departed children‚Äîand, by an involuntary act of the imagination, a≈øked my≈øelf the que≈øtion, "Shall I be happy enough to meet them where I am now about to go?‚Äî≈øhall tho≈øe dear la≈øt remains, too, become a prey to the devouring deep?"‚ÄîIn that in≈øtant, rea≈øon, ≈øu≈øpended by the horrors of the ≈øcene, gave way to in≈øtinct; and I rolled my ≈øhirt up, and very carefully thru≈øt it into a hole between decks, with the wild hopes that the ≈øleeve buttons might yet e≈øcape untouched. Watching my opportunity, I ≈øaw a log of wood floating near the ve≈ø≈øel, and, waving my hand to Mr. HALL as a la≈øt adieu, jumped after it. Here, again, I was doomed to aggravated hard≈øhips‚ÄîI had ≈øcarcely touched the log when a great ≈øea ≈ønatched it from my hold: ≈øtill as it came near me, I gra≈øped at it ineffectually, till at la≈øt it was completely carried away, but not before it had cut and battered and brui≈øed me in ≈øeveral places, and in a manner that at any other time I ≈øhould have thought dreadful.

Death ≈øeemed inevitable: and all that occured to me now to do, was to acclerate it, and get out of its pangs as ≈øpeedily as po≈ø≈øible; for, though I knew how to ≈øwim, the tremendous ≈øurf rendered ≈øwimming u≈øele≈øs, and all hope from it would have been rediculous. I therefore began to ≈øwallow as much water as po≈ø≈øible; yet, ≈øtill ri≈øing by the the boyant principle of the waves to the ≈øurface, my former thoughts began to recur; and whether it was that, or natural in≈øtinct, which ≈øurvived the temporary impre≈ø≈øions of de≈øpair, I know not‚Äîbut I endeavoured to ≈øwim, which I had not done long, when I again di≈øcovered the log of wood I had lo≈øt floating near me, and with ≈øome difficulty caught it:
hardly had it been an in≈øtant in my hands, when, by the ≈øame unlucky means, I lo≈øt it again. I had often heard it ≈øaid in Scotland, that if a man will throw him≈øelf flat on his back in the water, lie quite ≈øtraight and ≈øtiff, and ≈øuffer him≈øelf to ≈øink till the water g ‚Ä¢ ts into his ears, he will continue to float ≈øo for ever; this occured to me now, and I determined to try the experiment; ≈øo I threw my≈øelf on my back in the manner I have de≈øcribed and left my≈øelf to the di≈øpo≈øal of providence: nor was it long till I found the truth of the ≈øaying‚Äîfor I floated with hardly an effort, and began for the fir≈øt time to conceive ≈øomething like hopes of pre≈øervation.

After lying in this manner, committed to the di≈øcretion of the tides, I ≈øoon ≈øaw the ve≈ø≈øel‚Äî≈øaw that it was at a con≈øiderable di≈øtance behind me. Livelie≈øt hope began to play about my heart, and joy fluttered with a thou≈øand gay fancies in my mind: I began to form the favourable conclu≈øion, that the tide was carrying me rapidly to land from the ve≈ø≈øel, and that I ≈øhould ≈øoon once more touch terra f ‚Ä¢ rma.

This expectation was a cordial that revived my exhau≈øted ≈øpirits: I took courage, and left my≈øelf ≈øtill to the ≈øame all directing Power that had hitherto pre≈øerved me, ≈øcarcely doubting that I ≈øhould ≈øoon reach the land. Nor was I mi≈øtaken; for, in a ≈øhort time more, without effort or exertion, and without once turning from off my back, I found my≈øelf ≈øtrike again≈øt the ≈øandy beach. Overjoyed, as you may well ≈øuppo≈øe, to the highe≈øt pitch of tran≈øport at my providential deliverance. I made a convul≈øive ≈øpring, and ran up a little di≈øtance on the ≈øhore; but was ≈øo weak and worn down by fatigue, and ≈øo unable to clear my ≈øtomach of the ≈øalt water with which it was loaded, that I ≈øuddenly grew deadly ≈øick, and apprehended that I had only exchanged one death for another; and in a minute or two fainted away.

div.head: LETTER XLVII.
div.p: THAT admirable man and ≈øagacious penetrating philo≈øopher, Dr. FRANKLIN, has left us, among innumerable in≈øtructions for the conduct of human life, and for remedying many of the grievances of it, directions for going a voyage at ≈øea, and has particularly enforced the folly of quitting ≈øhips ha≈øtily, and yielding one's ≈øelf up to de≈øpair. I am convinced, that nine tenths of the people who peri≈øh by ≈øhipwreck, peri≈øh from the want of pre≈øence of mind, and ≈øufficient fortitude to bear them out. The unhappy pur≈øer, who ≈øat deliberately in a chair, and ≈øuffered him≈øelf, without a ≈øtruggle, to be carried overboard, is an in≈øtance in point. The feeble conduct of the captain and crew is another. Had he, in≈øtead of tearing of his hair, raving, and acting the part of a bedlamite, encouraged his men, and taken vigorous mea≈øures in time; and had they, in≈øtead of whimpering prayers on their knees, and whipping their images, made all clear, and prepared for the wor≈øt; in ≈øhort, had they, according to the moral of the old fable, put their ≈øhoulder to the wheel, in≈øtead of calling on Hercules, it is not impo≈ø≈øible but the ve≈ø≈øel might have been ≈øaved.

As for my part, the joy of e≈øcaping immediate death made me blind to the other mi≈øeries of my ≈øituation. Naked, moneyle≈øs and friendle≈øs, upon an unknown, and probably inho≈øpitable coa≈øt, what rea≈øonable cau≈øe had I to rejoice? Perhaps the rever≈øe. But that remains to be ≈øeen.

How long I continued in the ≈øwoon into which I had fallen, it is impo≈ø≈øible for me to tell; but, when I recovered, I found my≈øelf ≈øurrounded by
a guard of armed ≈øoldiers, ≈øepoys, and pikemen. I knew them immediately to be the troops of HYDER ALLI, and almo≈øt wi≈øhed my≈øelf back into the waves again. Looking round, I ≈øaw that the people and effects that had been ≈øaved from the wreck were collected all together along with me.

In this ≈øtate we remained till it was dark. A La≈øcarNatives of India, employed ≈øometimes as ≈øailors, ≈øometimes for inferior offices in the army, ≈øuch as pitching tents, drawing guns, &c. belonging to the ve≈ø≈øel, perceiving that my nakedne≈øs gave me great concern, tore into two a piece of cloth which he had tied round his wai≈øt, and gave me one part of it, which afforded a ≈øhort apron. This ≈øimple act of a poor, uninformed black man, whom chri≈øtian charity would call an idolator, methought had more of the true and e≈ø≈øential ≈øpirit of charity in it, than half the o≈øtentatious, parading new≈øpaper public charities of London‚Äîthe ≈ølough of pur≈øe-proud vanity, and unwieldy bloathed wealth. Of all the acts of beneficence that I ever met with, it ≈øtruck me the mo≈øt forcibly: it had kindne≈øs, di≈ø-intere≈øtedne≈øs and delicacy for its ba≈øis; and I have never ≈øince thought of it without wi≈øhing that I could meet the man, to reward him for his beneficence with a ≈øub≈øi≈øtence for life. The lower order of people of a certain country, I know, would think a man in ≈øuch circum≈øtances as I was then in, a fitter object of plea≈øantry than pity.

The va≈øt quantity of ≈øalt water I had ≈øwallowed, ≈øtill made me deadly ≈øick in the ≈øtomach: however, after ≈øome time, I threw it up, and got great relief. I had hardly felt the comfortable effects of this, before I was ordered to march: nine of us, all La≈øcars except my≈øelf, were conveyed to a village at a few miles di≈øtance on the ≈øea-≈øide, where we were for the night put into a ≈øquare place, walled round, open to the inclemency of the weather
above and below, and filled with large logs of wood; it blew mo≈øt violently, and the rain fell in torrents‚Äîwhile not one ≈ømooth plank could be found on which to ≈øtretch our fatigued and wa≈øted bodies. Thus, naked, ≈øick, exhau≈øted with fatigue and fa≈øting, drenched with wet, and unable to lie down, our mi≈øery might be ≈øuppo≈øed to be incapable of increa≈øe. But, alas! where are the bounds which we can ≈øet to human woe?‚ÄîThir≈øt, that mo≈øt dreadful of pains, occa≈øioned by the drenching with ≈øalt water, ≈øeized us: we begged, we entreated, we clamoured for water; but the inhuman wretches, deaf to the groans and ≈øcreeches of their fellow-creatures, (for ≈øome grew delirious with the agony of thir≈øt), refu≈øed them even the cheap and mi≈øerable indulgence of a drop of water!

The influence of the mind upon the body has been much in≈øi≈øted on by philo≈øophers and phy≈øicians, and I believe will be admitted by all wi≈øe men. I was my≈øelf in this in≈øtance, a ≈øtriking proof of it; for, though I had ≈øwallowed and thrown up ≈øo much ≈øalt water, though my thir≈øt had exceeded any thing I had ever before felt‚Äîyet, finding that water was not to be had or expected, I compo≈øed my mind to do without it, diverted my thoughts from it by the contemplation of the many other evils which be≈øet me, and pa≈ø≈øed the night without that horrible agony experienced by the others.

Indeed, a night of more exqui≈øite horror cannot be imagined. The thoughts of being a pri≈øoner to HYDER ALLI, was, of it≈øelf, ≈øufficient to render me completely unhappy: but my utter want of clothes almo≈øt put me be≈øide my≈øelf; and lying expo≈øed to the open air, where I was glad to ≈øit clo≈øe to the La≈øcars to receive a little heat from their bodies, and to hold open my mouth in order to catch a drop of the de≈øcending rain, was a ≈øtate
that might be con≈øidered as the highe≈øt refinement upon mi≈øery.

About four o'clock in the morning, a little cold rice was brought us to eat, and water was dug out of a hole near the ≈øpot for us; but as all things in this life are good or bad merely relatively, this wretched fare was ≈øome refre≈øhment to us. I was then removed to the ruins of a toddy-hut,A ≈ømall temporary hut, where toddy (a liquor extracted from the cocoa-nut tree) is ≈øold. ≈øeparated from the re≈øt, and a guard ≈øet over me. Here I had full room for reflection, and could "meditate e'en to madne≈øs." The whole of my ≈øituation appeared before me with all its aggravating circum≈øtances of horror; and to any one who con≈øiders it, I believe it will appear that it was hardly po≈ø≈øible to fill the bitter cup of calamity fuller. Oh! what were my thoughts! My family bereft of him on who≈øe efforts they were in a great mea≈øure to depend for ≈øupport and protection‚Äîyou, then a little innocent cherub, appeared to my di≈øtracted imagination twining round your mother's neck, and, in infant clamour, calling your father‚Äîwhile he, in a dreadful captivity, compared with which even a cruel death were mercy, lay wa≈øting, naked and forlorn, peri≈øhing with the inclemency of the weather, wanting even food fit for his ≈øupport, and expo≈øed to the ≈øcourge of every petty tyrant that barbarous power might employ to guard him!‚Äî Such were my reflections: they were in rea≈øon well founded; for there was no probability of my being ever relea≈øed, as my captivity was unlikely to be known to my country, or by my friends.

In this ≈øtate I was, when, to my utter a≈øtoni≈øhment, and to my no le≈øs joy, the amiable companion of my ≈øhipwreck, Mr. HALL, appeared before me. I ≈øcarcely knew how to think his appearance reality, as I under≈øtood that the La≈øcars then along with
me were all that were ≈øaved from the wreck; and he was, at the time I parted from him, ≈øo exhau≈øted both in body and mind, that I thought he would be the la≈øt who could e≈øcape. He, however, ≈øhook me by the hand; and, fitting down, told me that he had given me up for lo≈øt, and remained with the ve≈ø≈øel until the tide, having ebbed, left her almo≈øt dry‚Äîthat, immediately on getting a≈øhore, and being taken pri≈øoner, he made inquiries about me, and heard that I had been ≈øaved‚Äîthat, finding this, his joy was ≈øuch as to make him almo≈øt forget his own misfortunes‚Äîand, exerting all his entreaties not to be ≈øeparated from me, they had been ≈øo far indulgent to him, and had brought him to me, that we might be companions in bondage. He ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ded, that out of eleven Europeans and fifty-≈øix La≈øcars who were on board, only he and I of the former, and fourteen of the latter, were ≈øaved from the wreck, the re≈øt having been drowned in the attempt, excepting ≈øome who, overcome with terror, angui≈øh and anxiety, and exhau≈øted with fatigue, had bid a formal adieu to their companions, let go their hold, and calmly and voluntarily given them≈øelves up to the deep.

I here took occa≈øion to remark to him, what I have already ≈øaid to you, that thou≈øands lo≈øe their lives for want of per≈øeverance, fortitude, and courage to pre≈øerve them‚ÄîHad the Engli≈øh Pur≈øer collected courage enough to hold fa≈øt till the tide ebbed, he might have been ≈øafe on ≈øhore as we were, as he was ≈øuperior to either of us in bodily ≈øtrength.
"Ah! my friend!" ≈øaid he, ≈øhaking his head de≈øpondingly‚Äî"is he wor≈øe where he is? I doubt whether death is not far preferable to our pre≈øent pro≈øpects."

"Come, come," ≈øaid I, perceiving he was melancholy, though I my≈øelf laboured under all the horrors he expre≈ø≈øed‚Äî"come, let us not think; all
will yet be well: I fore≈øee it will; and you mu≈øt known I have ≈øomething of the prophet in my nature‚Äîperhaps the ≈øecond ≈øight." I then told him my pre≈øentiments on leaving Goa, which much a≈øtoni≈øhed him‚Äî≈øtill more when I acquainted him with the formal acts I had done in con≈øequence thereof, by Mr. HENSHAW'S advice, and with his privity.
In fact, our joy at meeting was reciprocally great, and in ≈øome re≈øpect cheered us for the time under all our mi≈øeries in hand, and the dreary pro≈øpect of tho≈øe yet to come.

Perceiving that he ≈øtood as much in need of relief as I did when the La≈øcar relieved me by dividing his cloth, I took mine off, tore it in two, and gave him half of it: you may well conceive our mi≈øery from this, if other circum≈øtances were wanting, that ≈øuch a thing as a rag of linen, not worth ≈øix pence, was a very material accommodation to us both.

div.head: LETTER XLVIII.
div.p:
YOUR letter, occa≈øioned by the account of my ≈øhipwreck and ≈øub≈øequent di≈øa≈øter, gave me, my amiable boy! as great plea≈øure as tho≈øe di≈øa≈øters gave me pain. Your account, too, of JOHN'S bur≈øting into tears on the reading of it to him, had almo≈øt a ≈øimilar effect upon my≈øelf: and I tru≈øt in the Almighty di≈øpo≈øer of events, that that excellent turn of mind will be ≈øo fa≈øhioned by the education I give you, as to make it the ≈øource of boundle≈øs gratification and true greatne≈øs (by which I mean goodne≈øs) here, and of never-fading felicity hereafter. You ≈øay you cannot account for it,
but you found more happine≈øs at my e≈øcape, than mi≈øery at my misfortunes. I hail that circum≈øtance as the ≈øtronge≈øt mark of perfect excellence of di≈øpo≈øition. A great moral philo≈øopher has laid it down as a maxim, that it is the ≈øurer mark of a good heart to ≈øympathi≈øe with joy than with ≈øorrow; and this in≈øtance only comes in aid of that opinion of you which my fond hopes have always nouri≈øhed.

At the ≈øame time I mu≈øt declare to you, that my plea≈øure at e≈øcaping ≈øhipwreck was by no means as great as the agony my mind underwent as the pro≈øpect now before me was poignant. I have already ≈øaid, and indeed with truth, that I ≈øhould have with much greater plea≈øure embraced death: I, who had been already ≈øome years in India, and had opportunities of hearing, as well from my father as from other officers in the ≈øervice, what the di≈øpo≈øition of the tyrant in who≈øe power I had now fallen was, knew too well the horrors of my ≈øituation to feel any thing like hope. The unmerciful di≈øpo≈øition of HYDER, and all tho≈øe in authority under him, and the cruel policy of the Ea≈øtern chiefs, making the life of any one, particularly a Briti≈øh pri≈øoner, at the be≈øt a precarious tenure, I did not know the moment when death might be infl ‚Ä¢ cted upon me with perhaps a thou≈øand aggravating circum≈øtances: and at all events, the affairs which demanded my pre≈øence in India ≈øo very importunately as to urge me to all the fatigues and hard≈øhips of a pa≈ø≈øage over land, were, of them≈øelves, ≈øufficient to make my mind unea≈øy; but the abject ≈øtate of want and nakedne≈øs in which it ≈øeemed I was likely to remain, ≈øtruck a deep and damp horror to my heart, and almo≈øt unman'd me.

Mr. HALL and I, however, endeavoured with all our might to ≈øtem the headlong torrent of our fate‚ÄîMelancholy preyed deeply and openly upon him, while I concealed mine, and endeavoured to
cheer the ≈øinking ≈øpirits of that noble youth, who, I perceived was the prey rather of extreme ≈øen≈øibility than feeblene≈øs of mind. All the horrors of ≈øhivering nakedne≈øs, though, to a mind delicate like his, and a per≈øon reared in the lap of luxury, ≈øufficiently goading, appeared as nothing when compared with one lo≈øs he had ≈øu≈øtained in the depredations with which ≈øhipwreck is con≈øtantly followed up. In the cruel ≈øu≈øpen≈øe between life and death, which I have already de≈øcribed, previous to my getting on ≈øhore, this amiable young man had ≈øecured and trea≈øured next his heart, as the in≈øeperable companion of his fate, a miniature portrait of a young lady; it hung round his neck, and was, by the unfeeling villains who ≈øeized him on his landing, taken away. This cruel deprivation was an ince≈ø≈øant corro≈øive to his mind‚Äîthe copious ≈øource of angui≈øh to his heart‚Äîthe hourly theme of the mo≈øt pathetic, affl ‚Ä¢ cting exclamations. "Had I," he would cry, "oh! had I had but the good fortune to have gone to the bottom while yet it hung about my neck, I ≈øhould have been happy: but now, ≈øeparated from the heavenly original, and bereft of the precious image, what is life? what would be life were I yet ≈øure of it? What plea≈øure, what common content, has the world left for me? None‚Äîoh! none, none! Never ≈øhall this heart again know comfort!

I did every thing I could to con≈øole him, and, as far as I could, prevent him from dwelling on tho≈øe gloomy ≈øubjects. Our conver≈øations were intere≈øting and pathetic; but, alas! the picture, at every pau≈øe, cha≈øed away the flight impre≈ø≈øions of the preceding conver≈øe: no ≈øufferings of the body could countervail that lo≈øs‚Äîno con≈øolation mitigate it; and amid≈øt the horrid reflections which unparalleled calamity impo≈øed upon his mind, the lo≈øs of that one dear relic ro≈øe paramount to all‚Äîand as every thought began, ≈øo it ended, with the picture.

For ≈øome days we lay in this place, expo≈øed to the weather, without even the ≈ølender comfort of a little ≈øtraw to cover the ground beneath us‚Äîour food, boiled rice, ≈øerved very ≈øparingly twice a-day by an old woman, who ju≈øt threw a handful or more of it to each upon a very dirty board, which we devoured with tho≈øe ≈øpoons nature gave us.

At the end of that time, we, and, along with us, the La≈øcars, were ordered to proceed into the country, and drove on foot to a con≈øiderable di≈øtance, in order to render up an account of our≈øelves to per≈øons belonging to government, authori≈øed to take it. It was advanced in the morning when we moved, without receiving any ≈øort of ≈øu≈øtenance; and were marched in that wa≈øting climate eight hours, without breaking our fa≈øt; during which time we were expo≈øed alternately to the ≈øcorching heat of the ≈øun and heavy torrents of rain, which rai≈øed painful bli≈øters on our ≈økin: we had often to ≈øtand expo≈øed to the weather, or to lie down, under the pre≈ø≈øure of fatigue and weakne≈øs, on the bare ground; then wait an hour, or more, at the door of ≈øome in≈øolent, unfeeling mon≈øter, until he fini≈øhed his dinner, or took his afternoon's nap; and when this was over, drove forward with wanton barbarity by the people who attended us.

You, my FREDERICK! who only know the mild and merciful di≈øpo≈øition of the people of Great Britain, where government, religion, and long habit, have reduced charity and benevolence ≈øo completely to a ≈øy≈øtem that they ≈øeem to be innate principles of the mind, can have no conception of a people who will not only look upon the wor≈øt human afflictions with indifference, but take a ≈øavage delight in the mi≈øeries of their fellow-creatures, even where no po≈ø≈øible advantage can be reaped from their inhumanity, and where the only reward they can propo≈øe to them≈øelves for their cruelty is the plea≈øure of contemplating human ≈øufferings.

Such, ≈øorry am I to ≈øay it, is the di≈øpo≈øition of ≈øome parts of the Ea≈øt Indies that I have been in; and although tho≈øe parts under the dominion of Great Britain owe their emancipation from the mo≈øt galling yokes to the Engli≈øh‚Äîand though, under their au≈øpices, they live in a ≈øtate of greater happine≈øs than ever they did, and greater freedom even than Britons them≈øelves‚Äîyet ≈øuch is the wicked ingratitude of many of them, ≈øuch the inflexible animo≈øity ari≈øing from a contradictory religion, that the death or ≈øuffering of an Engli≈øhman, or any misfortune that may befal him, often ≈øerves only as matter of ≈øport or amu≈øement to them. It would be well if it re≈øted there‚Äî but unfortunately they are wor≈øe again; for in general they have the like coldne≈øs and indifference, or indeed, to ≈øpeak more properly, the like aver≈øion, to each others good; and the ≈øame diabolical principles of ≈øelfi≈øhne≈øs and treachery pervade the greater number in tho≈øe va≈øt regions, almo≈øt boundle≈øs in extent, and almo≈øt matchle≈øs in fertility.

Two days after this, we were moved again, and marched up the country by a long and circuitious route, in which we underwent every hard≈øhip that cruelty could inflict, or human fortitude endure‚Äî now bli≈øtered with the heat, now drenched with the rain, and now chilled with the night damps ‚Äîde≈øtitute of any place but the bare earth to re≈øt or lay our heads on, with only a ≈øcanty pittance of boiled rice for our ≈øupport‚Äîoften without water to quench our thir≈øt, and con≈øtantly goaded by the guards, who pricked us with their bayonets every now and then, at once to evince their power, entertain the ≈øpectators, and mortify us. We arrived at Hydernagur, the metropolis of the province of Biddanore‚Äîa fort of con≈øidereble ≈øtrength, mounting upwards of ≈øeventy guns, containing a large garri≈øon of men, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of immen≈øe wealth.

It was about two o'clock in the morning when we arrived at Biddanore: the day was extremely hot, and we were kept out under the full heat of that broiling ≈øun till ≈øix o'clock in the evening, before we were admitted to an audience of the Jemadar, or governor of the place, without having a mouthful of victuals offered to us after the fatiguing march of the morning.

While we ≈øtood in this forlorn ≈øtate, a va≈øt concour≈øe of people collected about, and viewed us with curio≈øity. Looking round through tho≈øe who ≈øtood neare≈øt, I ob≈øerved ≈øome men gazing at me with ≈øtrong marks of emotion, and a mixture of wonder and concern pourtrayed in their countenances. Surpri≈øed to ≈øee ≈øuch ≈øymptoms of humanity in a My≈øorian Indian, I looked at them with more ≈øcrutiinicing attention, and thought that their faces were familiar to me. Catching my eye, they looked at me ≈øignificantly, as though they would expre≈øs their regard and re≈øpect for me, if they dared; and I then began to recollect that they were formerly privates in my regiment of cavalry, and were then pri≈øoners at large with HYDER.

I was not le≈øs ≈øurpri≈øed that tho≈øe poor fellows ≈øhould recogni≈øe me in my pre≈øent mi≈øerable fallen ≈øtate, than affected at the ≈øympathetic feeling they di≈øclo≈øed. I returned their look with a private nod of recognition; but, ≈øeeing that they were afraid to ≈øpeak to me, and fearing I might injure them by di≈øclo≈øing our acquaintance, I forbore any thing more. The guilty ≈øouls of de≈øpotic governments are perpetually alive to ≈øu≈øpicion: every look alarms them; and alarm or ≈øu≈øpicion never fails to be followed up with pro≈øcription or death.

Men, when in the fullne≈øs of power and pride of office, very ≈øeldom give them≈øelves time to reflect upon the in≈øtability of human greatne≈øs, and the uncertainty of earthly contingencies. When, inve≈øted with alll the trappings of authority, I commanded
the regiment to which tho≈øe poor fellows belonged, I would have thought that he ≈øpoke wildly indeed who would have alledged that it was po≈ø≈øible I could ever become an object of their pity ‚Äîthat I ≈øhould ≈øtand naked and degraded before them, and they be afraid to acknowledge me; but, though I ≈øhould have thought ≈øo then, it was yet ≈øome comfort to me, when that unfortunate event did come to pa≈øs, to reflect, that, when in power, I made ≈øuch u≈øe of it as to excite emotions in their bo≈øoms of affection and re≈øpect. Did the tyrant and overbearing in≈øolent chiefs con≈øider this, and govern them≈øelves by its in≈øtructions, they would go into the field with the con≈øoling reflection, that no gun would be levelled at their head except that of the common enemy‚Äîa thing that does not always happen.

div.head: LETTER XLIX.
div.p:
HAD we been made pri≈øoners of war in battle again≈øt an enemy, there is no law of nature or nations, no rule of rea≈øon or principle of equity, that could palliate ≈øuch treatment as that which we now received: but, ca≈øt by misfortune and ≈øhip-wreck on their ≈øhore, we were entitled to ≈øolace and protection. The word wretches who hang out fal≈øe beacons on the we≈øtern coa≈øts of England, to allure ≈øhips to their de≈øtruction, would not be cruel without temptation; and, if they did not expect to gain ≈øome profit by it, would rather decline knocking their fellow-creatures in the head‚ñ™ but tho≈øe barbarians, without any profit but what a malignant heart derives from the mi≈øeries of others, or any plea≈øure but what proceeds from their
pain, exerci≈øed upon us the mo≈øt wanton cruelty. Compared with ≈øuch treatmen, in≈øtant death would have been an act of mercy to us; and we ≈øhould have had rea≈øon to ble≈øs the hand that inflicted it.

Mortifications of one ≈øort or other‚Äîthe ince≈ø≈øant torturing of the mind on the rack of ≈øu≈øpen≈øe‚Äîthe injuries to the animal ≈øy≈øtem, occa≈øioned by con≈øtant expo≈øure to the weather, and the want of food ‚Äîall con≈øpired to reduce me to the dimen≈øions and feeblene≈øs of a ≈økeleton. I had grown daily weaker and weaker, and was now nearly exhau≈øted, and quite faint; while, on the other hand, my amiable companion in affliction was reduced by a dy≈øentery, which attacked him ≈øoon after our ≈øhipwreck, and which the torments of his mind, the want of medicine and comfortable food, and, above all, the alternate violent changes from profu≈øe per≈øpiration in walking to chilling cold at night, had increa≈øed to ≈øuch an alarming degree, that he was obliged to be carried the two la≈øt days journey:‚ÄîIn this ≈øtate, we appeared to each other as two ≈øpectres hanging over the brink of the grave: and in truth, perceiving the rapid progre≈øs he was making to his di≈ø≈øolution, I was affected to a degree, that, while it really exa≈øperated my own worn-down ≈øtate, deprived me of all attention to the rapid decline I was falling into, and almo≈øt entirely engro≈ø≈øed my care. In my progre≈øs through life, I have had occa≈øion to try ≈øeveral men, and have found among them many who were every thing that a good heart could wi≈øh to find: but this young gentleman had at once ≈øo much ≈øuavity and ≈øpirit‚Äî≈øuch gentlene≈øs and fortititude‚Äîhis ≈øufferings (tho≈øe of his mind, as well as tho≈øe of his body) were ≈øo exqui≈øite, and he bore them with ≈øuch meekne≈øs, tempered by ≈øuch uninterrupted good humour, and concealed and managed with ≈øo much delicacy, that I do not tran≈øgre≈øs the bounds of truth when I ≈øay I never met one who ≈øo entirely intere≈øted my feelings, and attached my
friend≈øhip ≈øo unalterably, upon principles of in≈øtinctive impul≈øe, as well as rea≈øon. Impelled by the irre≈øi≈øtible claims he had upon my approbation and e≈øteem, I entered with all the warmth of a brother into his ≈øufferings, and can a≈ø≈øert with truth that they con≈øtituted the ≈øevere≈øt trials I underwent during my whole impri≈øonment.

While we ≈øtood in the court, waiting to be brought before the Jemadar, we pre≈øented a ≈øpectacle that would have wrung pity, one would think, from the heart of a tiger, if a tiger was endued with reflection. At length we were ≈øummoned to appear before him, and brought into his pre≈øence. I had made up my mind for the occa≈øion‚Äîdetermined to deport my≈øelf in a manly, candid manner‚Äîand to let no con≈øideration what≈øoever lead me to any thing di≈øgraceful to my real character, or unworthy my ≈øituation in life; and, finally, had prepared my≈øelf to meet, without ≈øhrinking, whatever misfortunes might yet be in ≈øtore for me, or whatever cruelties the barbarous di≈øpo≈øition or wicked policy of the Tyrant might think proper to inflict.

On entering, we found the Jemadar in full Durbar.Court. He was then occupied with the reading of di≈øpatches, and in tran≈øacting other public bu≈øine≈øs. We were placed directly oppo≈øite to him, where we ≈øtood for near an hour, during which time he never ca≈øt his eyes towards us: but when at la≈øt he had concluded the bu≈øine≈øs, in which he was engaged, and deigned to look at us, we were ordered to pro≈øtrate our≈øelves before him: the La≈øcars immediately obeyed the order, and threw them≈øelves on the ground; but I contented my≈øelf with making a ≈øalam, in which poor Mr. HALL, who knew not the Ea≈øtern manner as I did, followed my example.

As ≈øoon as this ceremony was over, the Jemadar (who was no other man than the famous HYAT SAHIB that has made ≈øome noi≈øe in the hi≈øtory of that war) began to que≈øtion me. He de≈øired to know, who I was?‚Äîwhat my profe≈ø≈øion was?‚Äî what was the cau≈øe and manner of my approaching the country of HYDER ALLI?‚ÄîTo all tho≈øe que≈øtions I gave an≈øwers that ≈øeemed to ≈øatisfy him. He then a≈øked me, what news I had brought with me from Europe?‚Äîinquired into the ≈øtate of the army, and number of recruits di≈øpatched in the ≈øhips of that ≈øea≈øon‚Äîwas minute and circum≈øtantial in his que≈øtions re≈øpecting the nature and ≈øucce≈øs of the war in Europe‚Äîand examined me clo≈øely, touching the re≈øources of the Ea≈øt India Company. I ≈øaw his drift, and was cautious and circum≈øpect in my an≈øwers, and at the ≈øame time contrived to ≈øpeak with an air of candour that in ≈øome ≈øort ≈øatisfied him.

Having exhau≈øted his whole ≈øtring of que≈øtions, he turned the di≈øcour≈øe to another ≈øubject‚Äîno le≈øs than his great and pui≈ø≈øant Lord and Ma≈øter, HYDER, of whom he had endeavoured to impre≈øs me with a great, if not terrible idea‚Äîamplifying his power, his wealth, and the extent and opulence of his dominions‚Äîand de≈øcribing to me, in the mo≈øt exaggerated terms, the number of his „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚Ä¢ his military talents‚Äîhis va≈øt, and, accor ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to his account, unrivalled genius‚Äîhis amazing abilities in conquering and governing Nations‚Äîand, above all, his many amiable qualities, and ≈øplendid endowments of heart, no le≈øs than under≈øtanding.

Having thus, with equal zeal and fidelity, endeavoured to impre≈øs me with veneration for his Lord and Ma≈øter, and for that purpo≈øe attributed to him every perfection that may be ≈øuppo≈øed to be divided among all the Kings and Generals that have lived ≈øince the birth of CHRIST, and given each their due, he turned to the Engli≈øh Government,
and endeavoured to demon≈øtrate to me the folly and inutility of our attempting to re≈øi≈øt his progre≈øs, which he compared to that of the ≈øea, to a tempe≈øt, to a torrent, to a lion's pace and fury‚Äîto every thing that an Ea≈øtern imagination could ≈øugge≈øt as a figure proper to exemplify grandeur and irre≈øi≈øtible power. He then vaunted of his Sovereign's ≈øucce≈ø≈øes over the Engli≈øh, ≈øome of which I had not heard of before, and did not believe; and concluded by a≈ø≈øuring me, that it was HYDER'S determination to drive all Europeans from Indo≈øtan, which he averred he could not fail to do, con≈øidering the weakne≈øs of the one, and boundle≈øs power of the other. This part of HYAT SAHIB'S di≈øcour≈øe is well worth your remembering, as it will ≈øerve to make a very diverting contra≈øt with his ≈øub≈øequent conduct.

After having expended near half an hour in this manner, he called upon me to come over near him, and cau≈øed me to ≈øeat my≈øelf upon a mat with a pillow to lean upon‚Äîencouraged me, by every means he could, by the mo≈øt gentle accents, and the mo≈øt ≈øoothing, mollifying language, to ≈øpeak to him without the lea≈øt re≈øerve‚Äîexhorted me to tell him the truth in every thing we ≈øpoke of‚Äîand hinted to me, that my falling into his hands might turn out the mo≈øt fortunate event of my life.

I was at a lo≈øs to what motive to attribute all tho≈øe ≈øingular marks of indulgence; but found that he had learned who≈øe ≈øon I was, and knew my father by reputation from the pri≈øoners, our Sepoys, who were now pri≈øoners at large here: and as rank and office are the chief recommendation in the Ea≈øt, as well as el≈øewhere, or rather much more than any where el≈øe, the ≈øagacious HYAT SAHIB found many claims to e≈øteem and humanity in me as the ≈øon of a Colonel CAMPBELL, which he never would have found in me had I been the ≈øon of a plain humble farmer or trade≈øman in England.

After a full hour's audience, in which HYAT SAHIB treated me with di≈øtingui≈øhed marks of his favour, con≈øidering my ≈øituation, he di≈ømi≈ø≈øed me with the ceremony of beetle-nut,An aromatic nut which the Ea≈øt Indians chew; it is warm and a≈øtringent, and con≈øidered by them a great re≈øtorative. ro≈øe-water, and other compliments, which are in that country held as the ≈øtronge≈øt marks of politene≈øs, re≈øpect, and good-will.

Leaving the Durbar, I was led to the inner fort or citadel: and the officious zeal of tho≈øe about me, unwilling to let me remain ignorant of that which they conceived to be a mo≈øt fortunate turn in my affairs, gave the coup de grace to my mi≈øeries as I went along, by congratulating me on the favourable opinion which the Jemadar had formed of me, and intimating at the ≈øame time that I would ≈øoon be honoured with a re≈øpectible command in HYDER'S ≈øervice.

If I was mi≈øerable before, this intimation entirely de≈øtroyed the la≈øt remnant of peace or hope. I was determined to die a thou≈øand deaths ≈øooner than ≈øerve any State ho≈øtile to Great Britain‚Äîbut ≈øtill more a Tyrant, who≈øe country, nature and principles I de ‚Ä¢ e≈øted, and could never think of without the greate≈øt horror; and I judged, that if ≈øuch an offer ≈øhould be made, and I refu≈øed it; my life would fall a ≈øacrifice to their rage and di≈øappointment, or at lea≈øt I ≈øhould live a life of impri≈øonment, and never more behold country, family, friends, connections, or any thing that I valued in l ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e.

That night the Jemadar ≈øent me an excellent ≈øupper, of not le≈øs than ≈øix di≈øhes, from his own table; and although I had been ≈øo long fami≈øhing with the want of whole≈øome food, the idea of being „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ in the ≈øervice of HYDER ≈øtruck me „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , that I lo≈øt all appetite, and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to eat a mouthful. Mr. HALL and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ,
were ≈øeperated from the La≈øcars, Who were relea≈øed and forced to work.

Notwith≈øtanding the favourable intentions manife≈øted towards me by the Jemader, as I have already mentioned, no mark of it what≈øoever appeared in our lodging. This con≈øi≈øted of a ≈ømall place, exactly the ≈øize of our length and breadth, in the zig-zag of one of the gates of the citadel: it was open in front, but covered with a kind of a ≈øhed on the top; and a number of other pri≈øoners were about us: each of us was allowed a mat and pillow, and this formed the whole of our local accommodations. Upon my remarking it, we were told, that in conformity to the cu≈øtom of the Circar,Country or Province. we mu≈øt be treated ≈øo for ≈øome time, but that our accommodations would afterwards be extended, and made more agreeable to our wi≈øhes: even this was better than our ≈øituation ≈øince we landed.

In addition to this luxury, we were allowed to the value of four pence halfpenny a day for our maintenance; and a guard of Sepoys was put over us and a few more pri≈øoners, one of whom was directed to go and purcha≈øe our victuals, and do ≈øuch offices for us.
This guard was changed every week‚Äîa ≈øtrong mark of the ≈øu≈øpicious and wary tempers of tho≈øe people, who could fear intrigues and cabals between wretched pri≈øoners like us and their ≈øoldiers.

In two or three days after this, HYAT SAHIB ≈øent for me, treated me with great kindne≈øs, gave me ≈øome tea, and furni≈øhed me with two or three ≈øhirts, an old coat, and two pairs of breeches, which were ≈øtripped from the dead bodies that were thrown a≈øhore from the wreck‚Äîevery thing that was ≈øaved from it being ≈øent to Biddanore. At this interview ‚Ä¢ he treated me with great re≈øpect‚Äî gave me, be≈øides the articles already mentioned,
thirty rupees‚Äîand, upon my going away, told me that in a few days a very flattering propo≈øal would be made to me, and that my ≈øituation would be rendered not only comfortable, but enviable.

It is impo≈ø≈øible for me to expre≈øs to you, my dear FREDERICK! the horror I felt at the idea of this intended propo≈øal‚Äîfor I knew but too well what it meant. It was the ≈øource of bitter mi≈øery to my mind: neverthele≈øs, I determined to re≈øi≈øt every effort that ≈øhould be made, whether blandi≈øhment, intreaty, or menace‚Äîto lay down my life it≈øelf, though in ob≈øcurity, with honour‚Äîand to carry along with me, go where I would, the con≈øciou≈øne≈øs of having done my duty.

div.p: MR. HALL having, as I told you in my la≈øt, obligingly agreed to favour me with a relation of his ≈øtory, I now give it to you as nearly in his own words as I can remember them. He proceeded thus:

"Although you are now, my dear friend! a witne≈øs to my being the mo≈øt perfectly wretched of all created beings, yet the time is not long pa≈øt when fortune ≈ømiled upon and gave me promi≈øe of as much happine≈øs as Man in this wretched vale of tears is allowed by his circum≈øcribed nature to hope for. Your friend≈øhip and pity may indeed induce you to excu≈øe this interruption; but, to ≈øympathi≈øe truly, and feel as I feel, you mu≈øt have known the charming girl her≈øelf.

"My father, though he did not move in the very fir≈øt walk of life, held the rank of a Gentleman by birth and education, and was re≈øpectable, not only as a man of con≈øiderable property, but as a per≈øon who knew how to turn the gifts of fortune to their be≈øt account: he was generous without prodigality, and charitable without o≈øtentation: he was allowed by all who knew him to be the mo≈øt tender of hu≈øbands‚Äîthe mo≈øt zealous and ≈øincere of friends; and I can bear witne≈øs to his being the be≈øt of parents. "As ≈øoon as I thought my father's mind fit for ≈øuch a conver≈øation, I opened to him a plan I had formed of coming to India, to advance my fortune. His under≈øtanding approved of it, but his heart di≈ø≈øented; and he ≈øaid, that to part with me would give the fini≈øhing ≈øtroke to his misfortunes; but, as my intere≈øt was tolerably good, I repre≈øented to him the great likelihood I had of ≈øucce≈øs; and at la≈øt, with ≈øome difficulty, he con≈øented.

"My next ≈øtep was to acquaint Mi≈øs ‚Äî with my re≈øolution. I purpo≈øely pa≈øs over a meeting which no power of language can de≈øcribe! ‚Äî then how can I?‚ÄîOh! CAMPBELL, the remembrance of it gnaws me like a vulture here," (and he put his hand upon his heart, while the tears rolled down his cheeks), "and will ≈øoon, ≈øoon bring me to my end.

"Not to detain you with vain efforts to de≈øcribe all our feelings, I will confine my≈øelf to telling you that after having made every nece≈ø≈øary preparation, and divided with my much honoured parents the little property I po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, I ≈øet ≈øail for India, in a ≈øtate of mind compared with which the horrors of
annihilation would have been enviable: the choas in my thoughts made me in≈øen≈øible to every object but one; and I brooded with a ≈øort of ≈øtupid, gloomy indulgence, over the portrait of Mi≈øs ‚Äî, which hung round my neck, and was my in≈øeperable companion, till the people who ≈øeized me as I came a≈øhore plundered me of it, and thereby deprived me of the la≈øt refuge for comfort I had left. Oh! mon≈øters! barbarians! had you glutted your ≈øavage fury by di≈ø≈øevering my limbs, one after another, from my body, it would have been mercy, compared with depriving me of that little image of her I love! But it is all over, and I ≈øhall ≈øoon ≈øink into the grave, and never more be ble≈ø≈øed with the view of tho≈øe heavenly features, till we meet in that region where all tears are wiped away, and where, I tru≈øt, we ≈øhall be joined together for endle≈øs ages, in eternal, never-fading bli≈øs!"

div.head: LETTER LII.
div.p:
ON the day ≈øucceeding that on which the agent of HYAT SAHIB had held the di≈øcour≈øe with me, mentioned in my la≈øt letter but one, I was again ≈øent for, and brought to the ≈øame per≈øon, who a≈øked me, whether I had duly con≈øidered of the important offer made me by HYAT SAHIB, and of the con≈øequences likely to re≈øult from a refu≈øal? and he appri≈øed me at the ≈øame time, that the command of five thou≈øand men was an honour which the fir≈øt Rajahs in the My≈øorean dominions would gra≈øp at with tran≈øport. I told him I was well convinced of the honour ≈øuch a command would confer on any man but an Engli≈øhman, who≈øe country being the object of HYDER'S ince≈ø≈øant
ho≈øtility, would make the acceptance of it infamy‚Äîthat although I knew there were but too many Engli≈øhmen apo≈øtates to their country, I hoped there were but few to be found in India willing to accept of any emoluments, however great, or any temptations, however ≈øpecious, to fly from the ≈øtandard of their country, and rally round that of its bittere≈øt enemy‚Äîthat, for my own part, being of a name ever foremo≈øt in the ranks of loyalty and patrioti≈øm, and of a family that had hitherto detracted nothing from the honours of that name, ≈øuch an act of apo≈øtacy would be peculiarly infamous in me, and I could view it in no better light than traitorous and parricidal‚Äî that, independent of all tho≈øe claims, which were of them≈øelves ≈øufficient to deter me, I felt within my≈øelf a principle, perhaps innate, perhaps in≈øpired by military habit, that forbade my acceding‚Äî and, finally, appealed to the good ≈øen≈øe of HYAT SAHIB, whether a man who in ≈øuch circum≈øtances had betrayed his country, and ≈øacrificed her intere≈øts to his own convenience, was ≈øuch a per≈øon as confidence could properly be put in.

Notwith≈øtanding the≈øe, and a thou≈øand other remon≈øtrances, which I cannot immediately recollect, but which the hazards of my ≈øituation ≈øugge≈øted, he ≈øtill continued to pre≈øs me, and u≈øed every argument, every per≈øua≈øion, that ingenuity could dictate, or hints of puni≈øhment enforce, to ≈øhake my purpo≈øe‚Äîbut in vain: attachment to country and family ro≈øe paramount to all other con≈øiderations; and I gave a peremptory, deci≈øive refu≈øal.

Circum≈øtanced as I was, it was impo≈ø≈øible for me to keep an accurate journal of the various incidents that p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed, or vici≈ø≈øitudes of thought that occurred, ‚Ä¢ uring the period of my impri≈øonment. Indeed, I was ≈øcarcely con≈øcious of the length of my captivity, and could not, till I was relea≈øed, determine exactly how long it had continued. You
mu≈øt therefore content your≈øelf to be told in general terms, that I was repeatedly urged on the ≈øubject by fair per≈øua≈øives: they then had recour≈øe to menace; then they withheld the daily pittance allowed for my ≈øupport; and at length proceeded to coercion, tying a rope round my neck, and hoi≈øting me up to a tree. All this, however, I bore firmly: if it had any effect, it was to confirm me in my re≈øolution, and call in policy to the aid of honour's dictates. Every man of feeling or rea≈øon mu≈øt allow, that it was better to die, than live a life of ≈øubjection to tyranny ≈øo truly diabolical.

Mr. HALL and I, thus drove to the brink of extinction, yet con≈øoled our≈øelves with the reflection, that tho≈øe whom mo≈øt we loved were not ≈øharing our unhappy fate, and were fortunately ignorant of our ≈øufferings; and as I enjoyed perfect good health, hope yet lived within me.

There is a ≈øpring, an ela≈øticity, in every man's mind, of which the owner is rarely, very rarely con≈øcious, becau≈øe fortunately the occa≈øions ≈øeldom occur in which it can be brought to the proof, for, as la≈ø≈øitude is the nece≈ø≈øary forerunner of refre≈øhment, ≈øo is extreme dejection to the mo≈øt vigorous exerei≈øe of our fortitude. So I found it: as the horrors of my ≈øituation thickened round me, I felt my ≈øpirits increa≈øe; my re≈øolution became more firm, my hopes more ≈øanguine‚ÄîI even began to look forward, and form projects for the future: whole hours amu≈øement, every day and every night, aro≈øe from the contemplation of my beloved boy; I in imagination traced his growth, directed his ri≈øing ≈øentiments, formed plans for his future ≈øucce≈øs and pro≈øperity, and indulged by anticipation in all the enjoyment which I now tru≈øt I ≈øhall yet have in his ripened manhood.

Thus we continued for many months, during which no alteration what≈øoever took place in our
treatment or ≈øituation. We heard a thou≈øand contradictory reports of victories gained over the Engli≈øh, and again of ≈øome ≈øucce≈ø≈øes on their part: they, however, de≈øi≈øted to pre≈øs me into then ≈øervice. The only relief from our ≈øufferings lay in the re≈øources of our own minds, and in our mutual endevours to plea≈øe and con≈øole one another: the circum≈øtances of aggravation were the nece≈ø≈øity of daily bearing witne≈øs to the mo≈øt barbarous puni≈øhments he inflicted upon wretched individuals under the ≈øemblance of ju≈øtice, and the occa≈øional deprivation of our food, either by the fraud of the ≈øepoys who attended us, or the caprice or cruelty of their ≈øuperiors. It is but ju≈øtice, however, to ≈øay, that they were not all alike: ≈øome overflowed with mercy, charity, and the milk of human kindne≈øs; while others, again, were almo≈øt as bad men as the ≈øovereigns they ≈øerved. We were not allowed the u≈øe of pen, ink, or paper; and very ≈øeldom could afford our≈øelves the luxury of ≈øhaving, or clean linen: nor were we at all ≈øheltered from the inclemency of the weather, till at length a little room was built for us of mud, which being ≈ømall and damp, rendered our ≈øituation wor≈øe than it was before.

The pri≈øoner whom I have already mentioned, as having, in the time of the former ≈øovereign, held the fir≈øt office in Bidanore, ≈øtill continued oppo≈øite to me; and he and I at length began to under≈øtand each other, and found means, by looks, ≈øigns and ge≈øtures, to exchange thoughts, and hold an intercour≈øe of ≈øentiments together. From the circum≈øtance of his being a native, and better ≈økilled in the language than me, he had much better intelligence than I could po≈ø≈øibly have, and he was always eager to convey to me any circum≈øtance or news that he thought might be agreeable: ≈øome me≈ø≈øages al≈øo pa≈ø≈øed between us, by means of the ≈øepoys who had alternately been his guard and mine ‚Äîfor our guards were changed every week.

Projects and hopes of a new kind now began to intrude them≈øelves on my thoughts; and I conceived a de≈øign, which I flattered my≈øelf was not entirely impracticable to effect an e≈øcape, and even a revolt in the place. A variety of circum≈øtances concurred to per≈øuade me, that the tyranny of HYDER, and his ≈øervant HYAT SAHIB, was abhorred, though none dared to give vent to their ≈øentiments. I thought I could ob≈øerve, that the native pri≈øoner oppo≈øite to me was privately beloved, and might, from the recollection of his former dignities, have con≈øiderable influence in the place. Several Arcot ≈øepoys and their officers (≈øome of them belonging to my own regiment) were al≈øo pri≈øoners at large; and withal I recollected, that difficulties apparently more ≈øtupendous had been overcome by Engli≈øhmen‚Äîhaving often heard it a≈ø≈øerted, that there was not a pri≈øon in the known world out of which a Briti≈øh ≈øubject had not made his e≈øcape.

Fraught with tho≈øe conceptions, I attempted to ≈øound the officers of the Arcot Sepoys, whether it were not po≈ø≈øible for us to effect our e≈øcape? So ardent is the flame of liberty in all men's brea≈øts, ≈øo great is the dete≈øtation of human nature to ≈ølavery, that I perceived a manife≈øt willingne≈øs in the people about us to join me in an attempt to procure our liberty, or bring about a revolt in the garri≈øon. My heart beat high with the hope; and I began to flatter my≈øelf, that, the day was not far removed when we ≈øhould not only bid defiance to our tyrants, but even make them repent the day on which we were ca≈øt a≈øhore on their coa≈øt.

Having thus di≈øtantly ≈øounded all who I thought were likely to concur, upon the practicability of the attempt, and found them, as I conceived, di≈øpo≈øed to take ≈øhare in it, it yet remained to con≈øider of the quomodo‚Äîand, after having formed the general outlines of a plan, to lick it into ≈øhape. The fir≈øt of the≈øe was a critical con≈øideration: the
≈øecond required addre≈øs and management, and was likely to be impeded by the vigilance of the people about, who would not fail to remark, and take the alarm, from any unu≈øual intercour≈øe or di≈øcour≈øe between us; and without a mutual communication of thoughts, and full deliberation by all parties concerned, as well as knowledge of the fort and its different gates, nothing could, with any pro≈øpect of ≈øucce≈øs, be determined‚Äînothing, without the mo≈øt imminent hazard, be attempted. I therefore held various councils with my own mind, and with Mr. HALL, on the ≈øubject‚Äîmo≈øt of which were abortive, without at all di≈øcouraging us.

At la≈øt I began to think of ≈øounding the Bidanore pri≈øoner, ci-devant governor of the place; and determined, if po≈ø≈øible, to bring him into our con≈øultations, as I had before hoped to make him a party in the execution of the project: but while I was ≈øettling all this much to my own ≈øatisfaction, an event occured which extingui≈øhed all my hopes in that way‚Äîof which you ≈øhall have an account in my next letter.

div.head: LETTER LIII.
div.p:
WHETHER the plan which I mentioned in my la≈øt was di≈øcovered or not, or from what other motive it aro≈øe, I have not to this day been able to decide; but ≈øo it was, that while my ≈øanguine mind was overflowing with the hope of carrying my project for an e≈øcape into effect, Mr. HALL and I were one day unexpectedly loaded with irons, and fa≈øtened together, leg by leg, by one bolt. This, as nearly as I can compute, was four or five mouths before my relea≈øe. Of all the
circum≈øtances of my life, it has made the ≈øtronge≈øt impre≈ø≈øion upon my mind: it unexpectedly and ≈øuddenly broke down the mo≈øt plea≈øing fabric my imagination had ever built. The ≈øurpri≈øe occa≈øioned by the appearance of the irons, and the precautionary manner in which it was undertaken, was indeed great: ≈øtill more was I ≈øurpri≈øed to ob≈øerve, that the per≈øon who was employed to ≈øee this put in execution, manife≈øted unu≈øual emotions, ≈øeemed much affected, and even ≈øhed tears as he looked on: and while the ≈øuddenne≈øs and cautionary mode of doing it convinced me that ≈øome re≈øi≈øtance on our part was apprehended, the ≈øorrow which the officer who ≈øuperintended it di≈øclo≈øed, portended in my mind a fatal, or at lea≈øt a very ≈øerious i≈ø≈øue.

Unfortunately, poor Mr. HALL had for ≈øome time been afflicted with a return of his dreadful di≈øorder, the dy≈øentery; and our being ≈øhackled together increa≈øed an unconquerable mortification of feelings which we had before undergone, from a delicacy of nature that would have done honour to the mo≈øt mode≈øt virgin, be her ≈øen≈øibility ever ≈øo exqui≈øite, or her delicacy ever ≈øo extreme‚ÄîAnd here, my dear FREDERICK! I cannot let ≈ølip this opportunity of remarking to you, that the man, as well as the woman, who would render him≈øelf truly amiable in the eyes of his fellow-creatures, ≈øhould cultivate delicacy and mode≈øty, as the mo≈øt captivating of all the moral virtues: from them, heroi≈øm derives additional lu≈øtre‚Äîwit, ten-fold force‚Äîreligion and morality, the charms of per≈øua≈øion‚Äîand every per≈øonal action of the man, irre≈øi≈øtible dignity and winning grace. From this unlucky event, I received a temporary depre≈ø≈øion; and the rapidly increa≈øing illne≈øs of poor HALL rendered my ≈øituation more than ever calamitous; when, again, my ≈øpirits, eagerly prone to gra≈øp at every thing that gave a momentary hope of ≈øupport, were a little recruited by confu≈øed rumours of the
Engli≈øh army having made a de≈øcent on the Malabar coa≈øt: and ≈øo powerful is the influence of mind on the animal ≈øy≈øtem, that Mr. HALL enjoyed from the report a momentary alleviation of his malady; but, having no medical a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, nor even ≈øufficient ≈øu≈øtenance to further the favourable operations of nature, he relap≈øed again; the di≈øea≈øe fell upon him with redoubled fury: a very ≈øcanty portion of boiled rice, with a more ≈øcanty mor≈øel of ≈øtinking ≈øalt fi≈øh or putrid fle≈øh, was a very inadequate ≈øupport for me, who, though emaciated, was in health ‚Äîand very improper medicine for a per≈øon labouring under a malady ≈øuch as Mr. HALL'S, which required comfort, good medical ≈økill, and delicate nutritious food. The tea which HYAT SAHIB had given me was expended; and we were not allowed to be ≈øhaved from the hour we were put in irons, an indulgence of that kind being forbidden by the barbarous rules of the pri≈øon: and, to refine upon our tortures ≈øleep, "the balm of hurt minds," was not allowed us uninterrupted; for, in conformity to another regulation, we were di≈øturbed every half hour by a noi≈øe ≈øomething re≈øembling a watchman's rattle, and a fellow who, ≈øtriking every part of our irons with a kind of hammer, and examining them le≈øt they ≈øhould be cut, broke in upon that kind re≈øtorative, and awoke our ≈øouls to fre≈øh horrors.

As it mu≈øt be much more naturally matter of a≈øtoni≈øhment that any bodily ≈øtrength could ≈øupport it≈øelf under ≈øuch complicated calamities, than that infirmity ≈øhould ≈øink beneath them, you will be rather grieved than ≈øurpri≈øed to hear that poor Mr. HALL was now app ‚Ä¢ oaching to his end with ho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ly accelerated ≈øteps. Every application that I made in his favour was refu≈øed, or rather treated with cruel neglect and contemptuous ≈øilence; and I fore≈øaw, with inexpre≈ø≈øible angui≈øh and indignation, that the barbarians would not abate him in his
la≈øt minutes one jot of mi≈øery, and that my mo≈øt amiable friend was fated to expire under every attendant horror that mere ≈øublunary circum≈øtances could create. But that pity which the mighty, the powerful and enlightened denied, natural benevolence operating upon an uninformed mind, and ≈øcanty means, afforded us. HYAT SAHIB, the powerful, the wealthy, the governor of a great opulent province, refu≈øed to an expiring fellow-creature a little cheap relief‚Äîwhile a poor ≈øepoy taxed his little means to ≈øupply it: one who guarded us, of his own accord, at hazard of imminent puni≈øhment, purched us a lamp and a little oil, which we burned for the la≈øt few nights.

Philo≈øophers and divines have declaimed upon the advantages of a well-≈øpent life, as felt in articulo mortis; and their efforts have had, I hope, ≈øome effect upon the lives of many. To witne≈øs one example ≈øuch as Mr. HALL held forth, would be worth volumes of precepts on this ≈øubject. The unfeigned re≈øignation with which he met his di≈ø≈øolution, and the maje≈øtic fortitude with which he looked in the face the various circum≈øtances of horror that ≈øurrounded him, rendered him the mo≈øt dignified object I ever beheld or conceived, and the mo≈øt glorious in≈øtance of con≈øcious virtue triumphing over the terrors of death, and the cunning barbarity of mankind. Were the progre≈øs of virtue attended with pain, and the practice of vice with plea≈øure, the adoption of the former would be amply repaid by its ≈øoothings in the dreadful moment, even if it were to accompany us no further. About a quarter of an hour before he died, Mr. HALL broached a mo≈øt tender ≈øubject of conver≈øation, which he followed up with a ≈øeries of ob≈øervations, ≈øo truly refined, ≈øo exqui≈øitely turned, ≈øo delicate and ≈øo pathetic, that it ≈øeemed almo≈øt the language of in≈øpiration, as if, in proportion to the decay of the body, intellect increa≈øed, and the
dying man had become all mind. Such a conver≈øation I never remembered to have heard, or heard of. Its effects upon me were wonderful; for, though the combination of melancholy circum≈øtances attending my now critical ≈øituation had almo≈øt rai≈øed my mind to frenzy, the ≈øalutary influence of his words and example controuled the exce≈ø≈øes of my ≈øen≈øations; and I met the afflicting moment of his departure with a degree of tranquility, which, though not to be compared to his, has on reflection appeared to me a≈øtoni≈øhing. This conver≈øation continued to the very in≈øtant of his death; during which time he held my hand cla≈øped in his, frequently enforcing his kind expre≈ø≈øions to me with a ≈øqueeze‚Äîwhile my ≈øorrow, taking its mo≈øt ea≈øy channel, bedewed my face with tears. As he proceeded, my voice was choaked with my feelings; and I attempted once or twice in vain to ≈øpe ‚Ä¢ k. H ‚Ä¢ s hand grew cold: he ≈øaid his lower „Äà‚óä„Äâ were all lifele≈øs, and that he felt death coming ov ‚Ä¢ r him with ≈ølow creeping ≈øteps‚ÄîHe again moralized, thanking GOD with pathetic fervour for his great mercy in leavi ‚Ä¢ g him his intellects unclouded, and the organ of communication (the tongue) unenfeebled, that, to the la≈øt, he might ≈øolace his friend and fellow-≈øufferer‚Äî"Ah! CAMPBELL!" continued he, "to what a ≈øeries of mi≈øeries am I now leaving you! death in ≈øuch circum≈øtances is a ble≈ø≈øing‚ÄîI view mine as ≈øuch; and ≈øhould think it more ≈øo, if it contributed, by awakening tho≈øe people to a ≈øen≈øe of their cruelty, to ≈øoften their rigour to you: but cruelty like their's is ≈øy≈øtematic, and ≈øtoops not to the controul of the feelings. Could I hope that you would yet e≈øcape from their clutches, and that you would once more pre≈øs your family to your bo≈øom, the thought would brighten ≈øtill the moment of our ≈øeparation: and, oh! my friend! could I ≈øtill further hope that you would one day ≈øee my mo≈øt beloved and honoured
parents, and tell them of my death without wringing their hearts with its horrid circum≈øtances, offer them my la≈øt duties, and tell how I revered them‚Äî If, too, you could ≈øee my ‚Äî, and tell her how far, far more dear than‚Äî!" Here he turned his eyes toward the lamp, then faintly on me‚Äîmade a convul≈øive effort to ≈øqueeze my hand ‚Äîcried out, "CAMPBELL! oh, CAMPBELL! the lamp is going out!" and expired without a groan.

The recital of this afflicting event has called up to my fancy ≈øo lively a picture of the ≈øcene as it pa≈ø≈øed with all its horrors‚Äîhorrors which out≈øtrip all efforts of de≈øcription, and baffle all power of language‚Äîthat my feelings are in part renewed, and I find my≈øelf incapable of proceeding further at pre≈øent.

div.head: LETTER LIV.
div.p:
FOR ≈øome time I was lo≈øt in grief for the death of Mr. HALL. Though I had long expected it, and might con≈øequently be ≈øuppo≈øed to have wa≈øted great part of my ≈øorrow in anticipation; yet, having only con≈øidered and felt the point before his death merely as it re≈øpected him and his misfortunes, a great portion of the calamity yet remained unconceived: and, now that he was dead, I began for the fir≈øt time to con≈øider and feel the ≈øubject as it concerned my≈øelf. Reflection told me, that he was happily relieved from woe, and in a ≈øtate of bli≈øs‚Äî
"After life's fitful fever, he ≈øleeps well:
"‚Äî Nor ≈øteel nor poi≈øon,
"Malice dome≈øtic, foreign levy‚Äînothing
"Can touch him further!"

But I ≈øtill remained a prey to perhaps new barbarities, without hope of relief from the old. No partner to ≈øhare, no ≈øocial conver≈øe to alleviate, no friend to con≈øole me under my afflictions, I looked at the body of my friend with envy, and lamented that death had not afforded me, too, a ≈øhelter from the cruelties which fate ≈øeemed determined to heap upon me.

It is impo≈ø≈øible for me to expre≈øs to you the agonies of mind I underwent during the re≈øt of the night. In the morning a report was made to the commandant, of the death of Mr. HALL; and in about an hour after, he pa≈ø≈øed me by, but kept his face purpo≈øely turned away from me to the other ≈øide. I patiently waited for the removal of the dead body till the evening, when I de≈øired the Sepoys who guarded me to apply for its being removed. They returned, and told me that they could get no an≈øwer re≈øpecting it. Night came on, but there was no appearance of an intention to unfetter me from the corp≈øe. The commandant was ≈øitting in his court, admini≈øtering, in the manner I have before de≈øcribed, ju≈øtice! I called out to him my≈øelf with all my might, but could get no an≈øwer from him. Nothing could equal my rage and con≈øternation; for, exclu≈øive of the painful idea of being ≈øhackled to the dead body of a friend I loved, another circum≈øtance contributed to make it a ≈øerious ≈øubject of horror. In tho≈øe ciimates the weather is ≈øo inten≈øely hot, that putrefaction almo≈øt in≈øtantly ≈øucceeds death, and meat that is killed in the morning, and kept in the ≈øhade, will be unfit for dre≈ø≈øing at night. In a ≈øubject, then, on which putrefaction had made advances even before death, and which remained expo≈øed to the open air, the proce≈øs mu≈øt have been much more rapid. So far, however, from compa≈ø≈øionating my ≈øituation, or indulging me by a removal of the body, their barbarity ≈øugge≈øted to them to make it an in≈øtrument of
puni≈øhment; and they pertinaciou≈øly adhered to the mo≈øt mortifying ≈øilence and di≈øregard of my complaints. For ≈øeveral days and nights it remained attached to me by the irons. I grew almo≈øt di≈øtracted‚Äîwi≈øhed for the means of putting an end to my mi≈øeries by death, and could not move without witne≈ø≈øing ≈øome new ≈øtage of putre≈øcence it attained, or breathe without inhaling the putrid effluvia that aro≈øe from it‚Äîwhile myriads of flies and loath≈øome in≈øects re≈øted on it, the former of which every now and then vi≈øited me, crawling over my face and hands, and lighting in hundreds on my victuals. I never look back at this cri≈øis without confu≈øion, horror, and even a≈øtoni≈øhment; and, were it not connected with a chain of events preceding and ≈øub≈øequent to it, too well known by re≈øpectable people to be doubted, and too much interwoven with a part of the hi≈øtory of the la≈øt war in India to admit of a doubt, I ≈øhould not only be afraid to tell, but ab≈øolutely doubt my≈øelf whether the whole was not the illu≈øion of a dream, rather than credit the po≈ø≈øibility of my enduring ≈øuch unheard of hard≈øhips without lo≈øs of life or deprivation of ≈øen≈øes.

At la≈øt, when the body had reached that ≈øhocking loath≈øome ≈øtate of putrefaction which threatened that further delay would render removal abominable, if not impo≈ø≈øible, the mon≈øters agreed to take it away from me‚Äîand I was ≈øo far relieved: but the mortification and injury I underwent from it, joined to the agitation of the preceding week, made a vi≈øible inroad on my health. I totally lo≈øt my ≈øpirits; my appetite entirely for≈øook me: my long-nouri≈øhed hopes fled; and I looked forward to death as the only de≈øirable event that was within the verge of likelihood or po≈ø≈øibility.

One day, my oppo≈øite friend (the native pri≈øoner) gave me a look of the mo≈øt intere≈øting and encouraging kind; and I perceived a more than u≈øual bu≈øtle in the citadel, while the ≈øepoys informed
me that they were ordered on immediate ≈øervice, and that ≈øome events of great importance had taken place. From this feeble gleam, my mind, naturally active, though depre≈ø≈øed by circum≈øtances of unu≈øual weight, again took fire, and hope brightened with a kind of gloomy light the pro≈øpect before me: I revolved a thou≈øand things, and drew from them a thou≈øand ≈øurmi≈øes; but all as yet was only conjecture with me. In a day or two, the bu≈øtle increa≈øed to a high pitch, accompanied with marks of con≈øternation: the whole of the troops in the citadel were ordered to march; and the commandant, and a man with a hammar and in≈øtruments, came to take off my irons.

This the Jemadar him≈øelf afterwards acknowledged to me‚Äîand, what was ≈øtill more abominable if po≈ø≈øible, undertook to ju≈øtify the proceeding upon the principles of rea≈øon, ≈øound ≈øen≈øe, and precedent of A≈øiatic policy.

In order to elucidate the whole of this bu≈øine≈øs, it is nece≈ø≈øary for me to recur to events which happened antecedent to this time, but of which, by rea≈øon of my ≈øituation, I was then entirely ignorant; and as they involve, not only the grounds of my ≈øub≈øequent e≈øcape and proceedings, but a con≈øiderable portion of hi≈øtorical fact, and ≈øome of the material intere≈øts of the Ea≈øt India Company,
