div.head: LETTER LV.
div.p: HYDER ALLI KHAWN, late Nabob of My≈øore, and father to the pre≈øent TIPPO SAHIB SULTAIN, was as extraordinary a man, and perhaps po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed as great natural talents, as any recorded in the page of hi≈øtory. Born and bred up in the lowe≈øt ranks of an unenlightened and ignorant people, and to the la≈øt day of his life perfectly illiterate, he not only emerged from his native ob≈øcurity by the vigor of his mind and body, but became an object of terror and admiration to ≈øurrounding potentates. Early initiated in the habits and inured to the toils of a military life, he ro≈øe, by the gradual ≈øteps of promotion, to a rank which afforded an opportunity of di≈øplaying his capacity and prowe≈øs: he ≈øoon obtained the command of that army in which he had once ≈øerved as a common ≈øoldier, and immediately demon≈øtrated that the ≈øublimity of his mind was formed to keep pace with his extraordinary elevation.

The Marhattas, the mo≈øt formidable people in Hither India, bordered on the My≈øorean dominions, and kept their neighbours, by frequent ho≈øtilities, in a continual ≈øtate of awe‚Äîmaking incur≈øions on their territories, and taking po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, by force of arms, of large portions of their country: but no ≈øooner had HYDER got the command of the armies of his country, than he drove back the Marhattas
from the My≈øorean dominions, which he extended by con≈øiderable acqui≈øitions from the Marhatta frontiers; and followed up his conque≈øts with ≈øuch ≈øucce≈øsful ardour, that he compelled that warlike nation to re≈øpect his countrymen as their equals, if not ≈øuperiors, in military achievement. Thus, while he ingratiated him≈øelf with his ≈øovereign and fellow-citizens by his wi≈ødom, he acquired the admiration of the ≈øoldiery by his per≈øonal addre≈øs and valour; and at the ≈øame time, by the ≈øeverity of his decipline, and the occa≈øional au≈øterity of his deportmet, maintained an awe over them, which ≈øtrengthened his authority with dimini≈øhing their affection.

HYDER was therefore now arrived at that point of elevation, beyond which no exertion of mental capacity, if governed by virtue or integrity, could rai≈øe him‚ÄîSo far he owed all to guenius: but his towering ambition looked higher; and, unre≈øtrained by any principle of religion or morality, he determined to accompli≈øh, at any rate, that which he knew nothing but crime could accompli≈øh. With wicked deliberation he looked forward into the womb of time, and with unparalleled policy arranged the whole ≈øy≈øtem upon which he was to act, when that order of things his penetrating and intuitive genius enabled him to ≈øee would naturally ari≈øe from each other, ≈øhould afford him a proper opportunity. Although he was utterly ignorant of books, and of cour≈øe could derive little benefit from the examples of the great and ambitious men recorded in hi≈øtory, yet, drawing upon the infinite re≈øources of his own mind for information, he adopted the very ≈øame means of furthering his views; and fore≈øeeing, that, with an immen≈øe army devoted to his intere≈øts, few things would be unattainable, he applied him≈øelf diligently to model and form that of the KING of MYSORE to the greate≈øt perfection in di≈øcipline, and to render it
attached to his per≈øon, and ≈øub≈øervient to his views, by a ≈økilful mixture of ≈øeverity and relaxation, toil and reward, danger and applau≈øe, which none but a ma≈øter-hand like his was capable of exactly compounding.

The death of his ≈øovereign the KING of MYSORE at length afforded him the opportunity to which he had ≈øo long, and with ≈øo prophetic an eye, looked forward‚Äîand gave him ample room for ≈øelf gratulation on the ≈øcore of his ≈øagacity and prudence.

The heir in ≈øucce≈ø≈øion to the throne being then an infant, the politic HYDER, ≈øetting a≈øide all claims of the kindred of the young prince, took upon him≈øelf the guardian≈øhip‚Äîunder the title of Regent a≈ø≈øumed the ≈øupreme authority‚Äîand, though too well aware of the inviolable attachment of the people to their lawful monarch to put him directly to death, u≈øurped the throne, and con≈øigned him to impri≈øonment in Seringapatam, the capital of the My≈øorean dominions.

Having thus, by his talents, acquired the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the throne, he gave a large range to the ≈øublimity of his views, and ≈øoon di≈øplayed the exhau≈øtle≈øs re≈øources of his mind in the new office of Governor and Legi≈ølator‚Äîforming ≈øuch va≈øt well-ordered military e≈øtabli≈øhments, and ≈øuch judicious and ≈øalutary civil in≈øtitutions, as made him blaze forth at once the terror of his neighbours, and rendered him, in the ≈øequel, the mo≈øt powerful and formidable potentate in the Hither Penin≈øula. In carrying on tho≈øe, his deficiency in letters was ≈øupplied by his vigilance and ≈øagacity, ≈øharpened by ≈øu≈øpicion: three ≈øecretaries executed all his orders in ≈øeparate apartments: and if, on compari≈øon, they were found to differ, he who committed the error received ≈øentence of death. His natural cruelty made him take the execution of their ≈øentence upon him≈øelf not unfrequently: to ≈ølice off a
head with his own hand, or ≈øee it done by others, was a luxurious recreation to the ≈øanguinary HYDER.

The natural ≈øagacity of this great man ≈øugge≈øted, that in order to accompli≈øh the exten≈øive objects which his active and ambitious temper held up to his imagination, the introduction of the mo≈øt perfect military di≈øcipline was above all other things nece≈ø≈øary; and his judgment informed him that the European was the be≈øt. He therefore held out the mo≈øt tempting allurements to military adventures, and particularly to tho≈øe, whether black or white, who had been trained in the ≈øervice of the Engli≈øh Ea≈øt India company: he ≈øent emi≈ø≈øaries, for the purpo≈øe, to all parts of India, with in≈øtructions to offer great rewards; and carried this de≈øign ≈øo far, that whenever accident or war threw per≈øons of that de≈øcription into his hands, he never failed to detain them, and, if they refu≈øed to enter into his ≈øervice, treat them with the mo≈øt unpardonable rigour and barbarity; and by the≈øe means brought his army to a ≈øtate of perfection till then unknown to a black power. He did not ≈øtop there, but determined to e≈øtabli≈øh a navy‚Äîby large offers allured many ≈øhip-carpenters and artizans from Bombay‚Äîmade no incon≈øiderable progre≈øs in con≈øtructing dock-yards, and had actually equiped ≈øome ≈øhips „Äà‚óä„Äâ the line, be≈øides frigates, fitted to encounter European ≈øeas. Indeed, he ≈øeemed to have carried his views of conque≈øt even to the Polar regions; for it is a fact, that he directed his people, in con≈øtructing tho≈øe ve≈ø≈øels, to fit them for encountering ≈øeas of ice, or, as he called it, the thick water.

To a man of ≈øuch ardent ambition and deep penetration, the va≈øt power which the Engli≈øh Ea≈øt India company had acquired, and were daily acquiring, in the Ea≈øt, could not fail to be an object of jealou≈øy. He conceived a deadly and implacable animo≈øity to the Briti≈øh Nation, which influenced
his whole ≈øucceeding life, ended only with his death, and was then tran≈ømitted to his ≈øon TIPPOO SAHIB, with the exaction of a ≈øolemn oath, ever to retain tho≈øe ≈øentiments.

A coincidence of circum≈øtances, which has ≈øeldom occured in the fortunes of men, tended, at a lucky cri≈øis, to further the bold projects of HYDER; and neither fortune, though extremely propitious to him, nor his own unbounded talents and energetic ≈øpirit, favoured the execution of them, more than the bungling politics, the ludicrous ambition, and the con≈øequent unju≈øt fiable proceedings, of one of our Pro ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ encies in India‚ÄîI mean Bombay. Fortunately, the wi≈ødom and moderation of our Ea≈øt India councils at this day, vindicate the wounded character of the Briti≈øh nation, and ju≈øtify me in the remarks I make.

An ambitious and profligate chief of the Marhatta Tribes‚Äîhis name RAGANAUT ROW‚Äîhad been depo≈øed by the wi≈øe men of his country, for having murdered his nephew, in order to u≈øurp the throne of Setterah. He fled to Bombay, and, by ≈øpecious promi≈øes and other means, prevailed on that Pre≈øidency to afford him an a≈øylum, and finally to take up arms in his defence again≈øt the united Marhatta States, who at the very time were able to rai≈øe an army of three hundred thou≈øand fighting men. Ho≈øtilities were fir≈øt commenced by the Engli≈øh; and by them peace was fir≈øt propo≈øed. The treaty of Poonah was made, by which it was provided that RAGANAUT ROW would quit Bombay; and by the Engli≈øh the provi≈øions of that treaty were broken‚Äîfor, in direct violation of it RAGANAUT was kept at Bombay. This breach of the treaty led to another; for this crafty and unprincipled chief made u≈øe of it with ≈øuch addre≈øs as to per≈øuade that Pre≈øidency to attack the Marhattas again: ‚Äîby magnifying the power of his party among his countrymen, he prevailed upon them once more
to a≈ø≈øert his rights; and the Pre≈øidency of Calcutta, I am afraid, were induced to join that of Bombay in the plan.

It happened unfortunately, that at this time the Pre≈øidency of Bombay was compo≈øed of per≈øons the mo≈øt unqualified, probably, that could be found in any community for offices of ≈øuch importance. One, particularly, was allowed, by the almo≈øt unanimous con≈øent of tho≈øe who knew his private or public character, to be ignorant, not only of the fir≈øt principles of government, but of the ordinary knowledge requi≈øite for a gentleman; and for ≈øituations of moment he was peculiarly di≈øqualified by a fondne≈øs for minutiae, to which he paid more attention than to matters of greater con≈øequence. A temper and intellect of this kind were rendered ≈øtill more incapable of the enlarged views any Repre≈øentative of a great Nation in a di≈øtant colony ≈øhould po≈ø≈øe≈øs, by a mercantile education and habits, which narrowed even his circum≈øcribed mind, and left him not a ≈øentiment, not an idea, that was not merely commercial. The admini≈øtration of ≈øuch men was exactly what might have been expected; and, in≈øtead of a≈ø≈øerting the dignity of Great Britain, or promoting the advantage of their employers‚Äînarrow policy, ≈øelfi≈øh views, and efforts ari≈øing from mi≈øtaken notions of conque≈øt, made the whole ti≈ø≈øue of their conduct in India.

Blinded by the plau≈øible in≈øinuations of RAGANAUT, and ≈øtimulated, as I have already ob≈øerved, by a lu≈øt for conque≈øt, which would have been unju≈øtifiable even in an hereditary de≈øpot, but which were peculiarly vicious and ridiculous in a body of merchants who were them≈øelves ≈øubjects, the Ea≈øt India company's ≈øervants again determined to ≈øupport, by force of arms, that mo≈øt atrocious murderer: and with the contemptibly inadequate force of four ‚Ä¢ hou≈øand men, encumbered with an unwieldy train of baggage and ≈øervants for the accommodation
of finikin voluptuous officers, and led by two doughty compting-hou≈øe champions (CARNAC and MOSTYN), with colonel EGERTON as military a≈ø≈øi≈øtant rather than commander, they ≈øet out, to encounter the whole torrent of the Marhatta force, and conduct RAGANAUT to Poonah.

Had RAGANAUT advanced at the head of his own partizans only, the chiefs of the Marhatta Nation might po≈ø≈øibly have taken different ≈øides of the que≈øtion, and left between them a breach for his arms or intrigues to make an entrance fatal to the general cau≈øe of the country: but the a≈ø≈øaults of a foreign army‚Äîan army of intere≈øted peculating ≈øtrangers, as the company's troops then were‚Äî an army of avowed natural enemies, profe≈ø≈øing a different religion, entertaining different political principles, and formed by nature of a different complexion‚Äîrou≈øed and united them in one common cau≈øe, and compre≈ø≈øed di≈øcordant intere≈øts, which had been for time immemorial at irreconcilable variance, into one compact body of re≈øi≈øtance, which, as it became more firm from the ≈øtrokes of ho≈øtility, could not, in the nature of things, be ≈øubdued; in the ≈øame manner as the unju≈øtifiable confederacy of kings again≈øt France lately united all the conflicting parties of that country‚Äîconverted twenty-≈øeven millions of people, male and female, into one compact armed force‚Äîrendered them not only invincible at home, but terrible abroad‚Äîand finally, has enabled them to be≈øtride, Colo≈ø≈øus like, the univer≈øe.

div.head: LETTER LVI.
div.p: THE approach of the Briti≈øh troops with RAGANAUT cau≈øed great alarm at Poonah; and the mini≈øters there ≈øent to offer terms, which were contemptuou≈øly rejected. They then determined to ≈øave, by prowe≈øs, tho≈øe rights which they could not pre≈øerve by ju≈øtice or negociation‚Äîand took the field with ≈øuch great force, that their menacing enemies found it expedient to con≈øider of a retreat. The faithful RAGANAUT, finding his plans baffled, ≈øent privately to SCINDIAH, the Marhatta chief, propo≈øing to him to attack the Engli≈øh, and promi≈øing in that ca≈øe to join him with his part of the army: his perfidy, however, being di≈øcovered, the Engl ‚Ä¢ ≈øh commanders began to retreat, carrying him along with them. They were, however, ≈øurrounded, and reduced to make the mo≈øt abject conce≈ø≈øions‚Äîoffering a carte-blanche to SCINDIAH as the price of a retreat: but that augu≈øt chief nobly di≈ødained to take advantage of their ≈øituation, and contented him≈øelf with terms which ju≈øtice ≈øhould have ex ‚Ä¢ cted from them, even if nece≈ø≈øity had not compelled their acceptance. The re≈øtoration of Sal≈øette, and of the other conque≈øts made by the company's troops during the preceding ho≈øtilities, and the delivery of RAGANAUT'S per≈øon into the hands of the Marhattas, were among the prov ‚Ä¢ ≈øions. RAGANAUT was delivered up: two he ‚Ä¢ itag ‚Ä¢ s were taken for the remaining part of the treaty, and the harra≈ø≈øed remains of the Engli≈øh army were permitted to return to Bombay.

RAGANAUT having found means to e≈øcape, reached S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ ; and the company's chiefs refu≈øed to comply
with the provi≈øions of the treaty: notwith≈øtanding which, the noble Marhatta di≈ømi≈ø≈øed the ho≈øtages, and prepared for a more manly revenge than that which could be wreaked on two defencele≈øs individuals. General GODDART, who had been ≈øent with an army from Bengal, was commi≈ø≈øioned to negociate for a pacification: but SCINDIAH making the delivery of RAGANAUT into his hands an indi≈øpen≈øable preliminary, the negociation was broken off, and both parties determined to refer the controver≈øy to the deci≈øion of the ≈øword.

Every thing ≈øeemed to con≈øpire to cha≈øti≈øe the ra≈øhne≈øs and folly of our Indian councils. The difficulties in which our American conte≈øt had involved the nation, were reported with exaggeration in India, and gave additional firmne≈øs to our enemies in that quarter. The re≈øtle≈øs and intriguing ≈øpirit of the court of Ver≈øailles found its way with Mon≈øieur ST. LUBIN to the ≈øhores of Indo≈øtan, and ≈øo powerfully worked upon the mind of HYDER, that he entered into a treaty with France again≈øt England, and brought the ≈øtrength of both into the mo≈øt formidable combination that ever was made in that country, to root out the power of Great Britain from the Ea≈øt.

Thus, by the depraved politics of the councils of a petty ≈øettlement, were the important intere≈øts of Great Britain in India, and the lives and properties of all its ≈øervants in that quarter, at once expo≈øed to the fury of three formidable ho≈øtile powers‚Äîthe Marhattas, HYDER and the French.

I will not entangle my narrative with a detail of the various military operations which aro≈øe from this confederacy: they were in general di≈øa≈øtrous to the Engli≈øh, who≈øe power there was pre≈øerved from utter annihilation by the energetic councils of Mr. HASTINGS, the unexampled courage of our troops, and the unparalleled abilities and gallantry of the veteran Sir EYRE COOTE. That
part which applies to my pre≈øent narrative, is the only part I think it nece≈ø≈øary to detail; but I wi≈øh you to inform your≈øelf of all of them fully, by an attentive peru≈øal of the different hi≈øtories of that war.

In order to relieve the Carnatic, which was ≈øuffering under the ravages of a formidable victorious army, who had not only cut off a great part of our forces on that coa≈øt, but affronted our army even at the walls of Fort St. George, de≈øcents upon the coa≈øts of Malabar were planned, in order to make a diver≈øion: and General MATHEWS, in January 1783, landed with a ≈ømall army under his command, at a place called Rajamondroog‚Äîtook Onore, and ≈øeveral forts: and being joined by other troops, which, under the command of Colonel HUMBERTSON, had done con≈øiderable ≈øervice to the ≈øouthward, and were now commanded by Colonel MACLEOD, marched from Cundapore, with an army con≈øi≈øting of twelve hundred Europeans and eight battalions of Sepoys, towards Huff ‚Ä¢ ingurry Ghaut, a pa≈øs that leads over the≈øe immen≈øe mountains which divide the penin≈øula, running north and ≈øouth from Per≈øia to Cape Comorin. After ≈øurmounting ob≈øtacles that would have di≈øcouraged a le≈øs enterpri≈øing commander, and for which I refer you to his own letter, inclo≈øed herewith,See Appendix he mounted the Ghaut, carrying every thing before him with the fixed bayonet; and reached within a ≈øhort march of Hydernagur, the place where I was confined. Tho≈øe operations were undoubtedly much facilitated by the death of HYDER ALLI, which happened while I was in pri≈øon, and which drew the at ‚Ä¢ ention of TIPPOO SAHIB to affairs of more immediate importance than the defence of the Malabar forts.

I have thus digre≈ø≈øed from the ≈øtraight path of my narrative, in order to explain to you the occa≈øion
of the extraordinary revolution that ≈øo ≈øuddenly took place in the fort, which I ≈øtated to you in my la≈øt letter but one‚ÄîYou will therefore look back to the conclu≈øion of that letter, from whence I again take up my narrative.

I was utterly at a lo≈øs to conjecture what this ≈øo ≈øudden re≈øolution to relea≈øe me and my oppo≈øite fellow-pri≈øoner meant. I endeavoured to get ≈øome explanation of it from the per≈øons about me; but all I could at the time collect was, that the Jemadar had directed me to be taken out of irons, and ordered me to appear before him. I walked out of the citadel with two or three men who had got charge of me: it was a delightful afternoon; and my ≈øen≈øations on once more vi≈øiting the open air‚Äî at again viewing the va≈øt expan≈øe of the firmament above, and the profu≈øion of beauties with which nature embelli≈øhed the earth beneath‚Äîwere too bli≈øsful, too ≈øublime for de≈øcription. My heart beat with involuntary tran≈øports of gratitude to that Being from which all ≈øprung; and I felt that man is, in his nature, even without the intervention of his rea≈øon, a being of devotion. For an hour of ≈øuch delight as I then experienced, a year of impri≈øonment was, I thought, hardly too dear a price. Tho≈øe exqui≈øite ≈øen≈øations in≈øen≈øibly led my heart to the mo≈øt flattering pre≈øages; the animal ≈øpirit appeared to have, in corre≈øpondence with the body, ≈øhaken off a load of chains; and as I walked along, I ≈øeemed to tread on air.

As we proceeded forward, we found, at ≈øome di≈øtance from the fort, an open dooly, into which the guards forcibly crammed me; and I was carried off, ≈øtill attended by the ≈øame men. As we went along, they gave me to under≈øtand that HYAT SAHIB, the Jemadar, was at a place ten or a dozen miles di≈øtant from Bidanore. I thought it within my≈øelf a mo≈øt extraordinary circum≈øtance, and was at a lo≈øs to conjecture for what purpo≈øe he required
my pre≈øence there. Perhaps, thought I, it is to deliver me per≈øonally into the hands of TIPPOO‚Äî perhaps to ≈øend me to Seringapatam. Su≈øpence whetted my curio≈øity; and impatience to know my fate, ≈øet my mind afloat upon a wide ≈øea of conjecture. Still, however, my ≈øen≈øes acknowledged a degree of plea≈øure inde≈øcribable‚ÄîI inhaled the fre≈øh air with greedine≈øs, and, as I ≈ønuffed it in, ≈øaid to my≈øelf, "Well, well‚Äîat the wor≈øt, this will enliven my ≈øpirits, and lay up a new ≈øtock of health and vigour, to enable me to endure with manhood whatever other ≈øufferings the barbarians, into who≈øe hands I have fallen, may have in ≈øtore for me."

When we had got about a mile from the fort, we met a per≈øon attended by three others, all on hor≈øeback. He was a man of con≈øiderable rank in that country, and I recollected to have ≈øeen him at the Jemadar's Durbar, where he had manife≈øted a favourable di≈øpo≈øition towards me, looking always graciou≈øly, and nodding to me, which, con≈øidering my circum≈øtances and his, was not a little extraordinary. The moment he recognized me, he leaped from his hor≈øe, apparently in great agitation: then turning to the guards, ordered them to leave me immediately‚Äî≈øaying at the ≈øame time that he would be an≈øwerable for the con≈øequences. They ≈øeemed at fir≈øt to he≈øitate whether they would obey him or not; but on his ≈øhaking at them his ≈øword, which was all along drawn in his hand, and ≈ømeared with blood, and repeating his orders a ≈øecond time in a firm and deci≈øive tone of voice and manner, they all ran off.

As ≈øoon as we were alone, he revealed to me, that he had all along known who I was‚Äîhad mo≈øt heartily pitied my ≈øufferings, and privately entertained the mo≈øt anxious wi≈øhes to ≈øerve me, but could not venture to interfere‚Äîthe lea≈øt jealou≈øy, when once awakened, being there always followed
up by ≈øummary vengeance. He then mentioned his name, informing me that he was the ≈øon of a Nabob near Vellore, who≈øe dominions had been wre≈øted from him by force, and united to the Carnatic; that his family had received great favours from my father, in return for which he felt him≈øelf bound to do me every ≈øervice in his power; but that, having been, after the misfortunes which befel his family, taken into the ≈øervice of HYDER, and holding then a place of con≈øequence under him, he was di≈øqualified from demon≈øtrating his gratitude and e≈øteem in the way he wi≈øhed; he added, he had ju≈øt come from the ≈øummit of the Ghauts, where he left the Engli≈øh army po≈øted, after their having beat the Circar troops, and carried all the ≈øtrong works which had been erected for the defence of the pa≈ø≈øes, and were deemed from their ≈øituation impregnable; that the Jemadar, HYAT SAHIB, had gone there to encourage the troops, and animate them to one grand effort of re≈øi≈øtance, and would remain there till the ≈øucceeding day‚ÄîHere he ≈øtopped, and ≈øeemed much agitated; but recovering him≈øelf ≈øoon, ≈øaid, in a ‚Ä¢ olemn and alarming manner, "This day I heard HYAT SAHIB give orders to bring you before him, in order that he might ≈øatiate his revenge by your dea ‚Ä¢ h! div.head: LETTER LVII.
div.p:
SUCH unprecedented genero≈øity affected me ≈øen≈øibly. To run ≈øuch a hazard as he mu≈øt
have incurred, merely from a principle of gratitude for ≈øervices ≈øo remote in both time and per≈øon, was more than we could hope to find even among Engli≈øhmen, who boa≈øt of their ≈øuperior ju≈øtice and genero≈øity‚Äîbut in a native of Indo≈øtan, where the tide of human feeling runs rather low, was a≈øtoni≈øhing. As well as my limitted knowledge of the language of the country enabled me, I endeavoured to make him a ≈øuitable acknowledgement: in ≈øuch a cau≈øe, dullne≈øs mu≈øt have become eloquent: and I lamented that my deficiency in the language prevented my giving vent to the extreme fullne≈øs of my heart. He ≈øeemed, however, to be ≈øati≈øfied with my meaning; and I was ju≈øt on the point of returning with him to Hydernagur, when we were ≈øuddenly ≈øtartled by the Jemadar's mu≈øic, which was ≈øoon afterwards ≈øucceeded by the appearance of his guards advancing towards us at ≈øome di≈øtance. He ≈øeemed confounded and alarmed‚Äîlamented, in warm terms, his incapacity to ≈øerve me ‚Äîand, pointed to a path which wound through a wood that lay on either ≈øide of the road, directed me to ≈øtrike into it immediately, ≈øaying, that by following that route, I ≈øhould certainly fall in with the Briti≈øh army. He then rode away, and I followed his advice, and proceeded for ≈øome time through the wood without interruption; for, though I did not implicitly believe the a≈ø≈øertion that HYAT SAHIB meant to have cut me off, I deemed it prudent to avail my≈øelf of the opportunity which offered to effect my e≈øcape, apprehending a wor≈øe fate than death, namely, being ≈øent pri≈øoner to Seringapatam.

Finding my≈øelf fairly extricated, I began to examine my ≈øituation, and to reflect on the different conver≈øations which had pa≈ø≈øed between HYAT SAHIB and me, and on his conduct previous to my being put in irons. I recollected the information I had from time to time received, touching the
Jemadar's di≈øpo≈øition, HYDER'S death, TIPPOO SAHIB'S character and avowed hatred of HYAT, and the nature of the inhabitants. I moreover took into con≈øideration, that my ≈øtrength was impaired, and my con≈øtitution undermined; and that my pro≈øpects in India, in point of ≈øame or emolument, could only be promoted by ≈øome extraordinary exertion, or ≈øome hazardous enterpri≈øe. The re≈øult of the whole was a determination on my part to return back to the fort, and venture an attempt to per≈øuade the Jemadar to offer propo≈øals for an accomodation to General MATHEWS, and to make me the in≈øtrument of his negociation.

In pur≈øuance of this determination, I returned; and about ≈øix o'clock in the evening re-entered the fort, and proceeded to the palace of the Jemadar, where, de≈øi ‚Ä¢ ing an audience, I was admitted. At the very fir≈øt ≈øight of him, I could perceive in his appearance all the mortification of falling power. He received me with a gloomy countenance, in which there was more of thoughtful ≈øadne≈øs than of vindictive fury. After a minute's ≈øilence, however, he ≈øaid to me, "Well, Sir! you have heard, I ≈øuppo≈øe, that the Engli≈øh army are in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Ghauts, and doubtle≈øs know that the cu≈øtoms of this country authori≈øe my proceeding again≈øt you with the utmo≈øt rigor." Here he pau≈øed for a few moments‚Äîthen proceeded thus: "Neverthele≈øs, in con≈øideration of your family‚Äîin con≈øideration of the regard I have for a long time conceived for you, from ob≈øerving your conduct, and ≈øtrict adherence to truth in an≈øwering all my que≈øtions, and ≈øtill more on account of the ≈øuffering which you have ≈øu≈øtained with fortitude, I will allow you to e≈øcape: ha≈øte you, then, away‚Äîfly from this fort directly‚ÄîBegone!" Then waving his hand as a ≈øignal for me to depart, averted his face from me, and looked another way.

I thought that this was a very favourable opportunity for my intended purpo≈øe, and entreated him to hear me while I ≈øaid a few words of perhaps more moment to him than to my≈øelf. He again turned towards me; and, nodding a≈ø≈øent, while his eye be≈øpoke impatient curio≈øity, I proceeded‚Äî And, fir≈øt, I expre≈ø≈øed in the ≈øtronge≈øt terms I was able, the high ≈øen≈øe I entertained of the favourable reception I met with when I fir≈øt came to the fort; a≈ø≈øuring him, that I ≈øhould never forget the kindne≈øs he ≈øhewed me on that occa≈øion‚ñ™ and that in my con≈øcience I imputed all the ≈øufferings I had undergone wholly to orders which he had been obliged to execute, and not to any want of humanity in him≈øelf. Here I perceived the clouds wh ‚Ä¢ ch had over≈øpread his countenance begin gradually to di≈øper≈øe, and with the greater confidence proceeded to ≈øay, that if he would conde≈øcend to give me a patient hearing, and not take my boldne≈øs ami≈øs, I would venture to intrude upon him with my advice. At this he ≈øtared at me with a look of ≈øurpri≈øe‚Äîpau ‚Ä¢ ed‚Äîthen ≈øaid, that he authori≈øed me to ≈øpeak whatever I plea≈øed‚Äîcontinuing, in a tone of gentle melancholy, "But of what u≈øe can your advice be to me now?"

Having thus obtained his permi≈ø≈øion, I began by complimenting him on his great talents and temper in governing‚Äîon his fidelity, zeal and attachment to HYDER‚Äîand on the mild and beneficient u≈øe which he was acknowledged to have made of the unbounded power ve≈øted in him by tha ‚Ä¢ g ‚Ä¢ eat Prince, which was the more extraordinary, con≈øidering how many examples he had to ju≈øtify him in a contrary practice. I reminded him, however, that circum≈øtances were at pre≈øent widely different from what they were‚Äîthat he had now got a very different ≈øovereign to ≈øerve‚Äîthat he had no longer the tender father (for to HYDER might have been con≈øidered to him), but TIPPOO SULTAN, now the
ma≈øter, once the rival, who≈øe mea≈øures he had always oppo≈øed, again≈øt whom he had once laid a mo≈øt ≈øerious charge, and who, con≈øidering the firmne≈øs of his nature, could not be rea≈øonably ≈øuppo≈øed to have forgiven him; and I hinted, that whatever external appearance of regard TIPPOO might from the political nece≈ø≈øity of the moment a≈ø≈øume, his temper, and the ≈øpirit of A≈øiatic policy, were too well known to have a doubt remaining, that ≈øo far from continuing him (HYAT) in the ≈øame power and authority which he enjoyed during the life of his father HYDER, he would, on the contrary, proceed again≈øt him with rigor and cruelty.

Here I perceived the Jemadar involuntary nodding his head in a manner which, though not intended for my ob≈øervation, denoted internal a≈ø≈øent; and was convinced that I had exactly fallen in with the current of his own thoughts. No wonder, indeed, they ≈øhould be his ≈øentiments; for they had long been the ≈øentiments of all per≈øons who had known the circum≈øtances of the Nabob's family.

Having, therefore, gone as far on that point as I conceived to be nece≈ø≈øary to awaken the mind of HYAT to the precariou≈øne≈øs, of rather danger of his ≈øituation with TIPPOO, I painted to him, in the ≈øtronge≈øt colours I was ma≈øter of, the humanity, the fidelity, the bravery and genero≈øity of the Engli≈øh, which, I ≈øaid, were ≈øo univer≈øally acknowledged, that even their wor≈øt enemies bore te≈øtimony to them: and I a≈ø≈øured him, that if, in≈øtead of making an unavailing oppo≈øition to them, he would throw him≈øelf with confidence upon their protection, and become their friend, he would not only be continued in his ≈øtation, power and authority, and ≈øupported as heretofore, but be made a much greater man, with ≈øtill greater ≈øecurity, than ever he had been before.

This was the general ≈øcope of my argument with him; but there were many more which ≈øugge≈øted them≈øelves at the time, though I cannot now remember them. I enforced them with all the power I had: they were ≈øupported by the acknowledged character for genero≈øity of the Engli≈øh, and ≈øtill more by HYAT'S apprehen≈øions of TIPPOO; and they had their effect. That very night he authori≈øed me to go to the Briti≈øh General; and, though he would not commit him≈øelf by ≈øending propo≈øals in writing, he con≈øented to receive them from the General, and promi≈øed to wait for my return till day-light the next morning‚Äîadding, that if I did not appear by that time, he would go off with his family and trea≈øure to ≈øome other place, and ≈øet the town, powder-magazine and ≈øtore-hou≈øes on fire, leaving a per≈øon of di≈øtingui≈øhed character to defend the citadel or inner fort, which was ≈øtrong, with a deep ditch, and mounted with many pieces of cannon, and ≈øend immediate intelligence to an army of ≈øix thou≈øand hor≈øe and ten thou≈øand infantry, who were at that time on their road from Seringapatam, to ha≈øten their progre≈øs, and make them advance with all po≈ø≈øible rapidity; and he further ob≈øerved, that as TIPPOO him≈øelf would come to the immediate protection of his country, and, if once come while the Engli≈øh army remained in the open field, would give them cau≈øe to repent their temerity, there was no time to be lo≈øt.

Accompanied by a per≈øon who had officiated as interpreter between the Jemadar and me, and who≈øe good offices and influence with HYAT, which was very great, I had been previou≈øly lucky enough to ≈øecure, I ≈øet off at ten o'clock at night, on hor≈øeback to the Briti≈øh army. My companion was in high ≈øpirits when we fir≈øt ≈øet out from the fort; but as we proceeded, he expre≈ø≈øed great apprehen≈øion of being ≈øhot in approaching the camp,
and earne≈øtly entreated me to ≈øleep at a choreltry, which lay in our way, till morning. His terror mu≈øt have been great indeed, to induce him to make ≈øuch a propo≈øal, as he knew very well that we had pledged our≈øelves to be back before dawn next day. I rallied him upon his fears, and endeavoured to per≈øuade him there was not the ≈ømalle≈øt danger, as I knew how to an≈øwer the outpo≈øts, when they ≈øhould challenge us, in ≈øuch a manner as to prevent their firing. As we advanced to the camp, however, his trepidation increa≈øed; and when we approached the ≈øentries, I was obliged to drag him along by force. Then his fears had very nearly produced the danger he dreaded, (the almo≈øt invariable effect of cowardice); for the ≈øentry next to us, hearing the ru≈øtling noi≈øe, let off his piece, and was retreating when I had the good fortune to make him hear me. My companion, alarmed at the noi≈øe of the mu≈øquet, fell down in a paroxy≈øm of terror, from which it was ≈øome time before he was completely recovered. The ≈øentry who had fired, coming up, conducted us to a place where other ≈øentries were po≈øted, one of whom accompanied us to a guard, from whence we were brought to the grand guard, and by them conducted to the General.

div.head: LETTER LVIII.
div.p:
I WAS no le≈øs plea≈øed than ≈øurpri≈øed to find, that the commander of this gallant and ≈øucce≈øsful little army was General MATHEWS‚Äîan old friend of my father's, and a per≈øon with whom I had ≈øerved in the cavalry ≈øoon after I entered the ≈øervice. When I arrived he was fa≈øt a≈øleep upon
the bare ground in a choreltry. His duba≈øh, who≈øe name was SNAKE, recollected me immediately, and was almo≈øt as much frightened at my appearance at fir≈øt, as my interpreter companion was at the ≈øhot of the ≈øentry; for it was full five months ≈øince my hair and beard were both ≈øhaved at the ≈øame time, during which period a comb had never touched my head: I had no hat‚Äîno ≈øtockings‚Äîwas clad in a pair of very ragged breeches, a ≈øhirt which was ≈øo full of holes that it re≈øembled rather a net than a web of cloth, and a wai≈øtcoat which had been made for a man twice my ≈øize‚Äîwhile my feet were defended from the ≈øtones only by a pair of Indian ≈ølippers. SNAKE, as ≈øoon as he was able to conquer his terror, and ≈øtop the loquacious effu≈øions of a≈øtoni≈øhment, brought me to the General, whom I found fa≈øt a≈øleep. We awoke him with great difficulty, and, on his di≈øcovering me, expre≈ø≈øed great plea≈øure and ≈øurpri≈øe at ≈øo unexpected a meeting; for, though he had heard of my impri≈øonment at Bidanore, he did not expect to have had the plea≈øure of my company ≈øo ≈øoon.

Having ≈øtated to the General the nature and object of my mi≈ø≈øion, and related to him what had happened in the fort, he in≈øtantly ≈øaw the great advantages that mu≈øt accrue from ≈øuch an arrangement‚Äîentered into a full but ≈øhort di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of the bu≈øine≈øs‚Äî≈øettled with me the plan to be pur≈øued in either ca≈øe of HYAT SAHIB'S acceding to or di≈ø≈øenting from the terms he propo≈øed to offer; and in le≈øs than an hour after my arrival, I was di≈øpatched back to the fort in the General's palanquin, with a cowl from him, ≈øignifying that the Jemadar HYAT SAHIB'S power and influence ≈øhould not be le≈ø≈øened, if he ≈øhould quietly ≈øurrender up the fort. Before my departure, the General expre≈ø≈øed, in the warme≈øt terms, his approbation of my conduct; and added that con≈øidering the importance of the fort, the exten≈øive influence
of HYAT SAHIB, and the advantages that might be derived from his experience and abilities, coupled with the enfeebled ≈øtate of his army, the benefits of ≈øuch a negociation ≈øcarcely admitted of calculation.

Notwith≈øtanding the very flattering circum≈øtances with which my pre≈øent pur≈øuit was attended, I could not help, as I returned to Hydernagur, finding ≈øome unea≈øy ≈øen≈øations, ari≈øing from the immediate nature of the bu≈øine≈øs, and from my knowledge of the faithle≈øs di≈øpo≈øition of A≈øiatics, and the little difficulty they find in violating any moral principle, if it happens to cla≈øh with their intere≈øt, or if a breach of it promi≈øes any advantage. I con≈øidered that it was by no means impo≈ø≈øible, that ≈øome re≈øolution adver≈øe to my project might have been adopted in my ab≈øence, and that the Jemadar's policy might lead him to make my de≈øtruction a ≈øort of propitiation for his former offences, and to ≈øend me and the cowl together to TIPPOO, to be ≈øacrificed to his re≈øentment. The≈øe thoughts, I own, made a very deep impre≈ø≈øion on my mind‚Äî but were again effaced by the reflection, that a laudable mea≈øure, once begun, ought to be per≈øevered in, and that the accompli≈øhing a plan of ≈øuch importance and incalculable public utility, might operate ≈øtill further by example, and produce con≈øequences of which it was impo≈ø≈øible at pre≈øent to form a conception. Tho ‚Ä¢ e, and a variety of ≈øuch ≈øugge≈øtions, entirely overcame the ≈øcruples and fears of the danger; and I once more entered the fort of Hydernagur. At this time the Briti≈øh troops were, by detaching a part with Colonel MACLEOD, to get round the fort, and attack it in the rear, and, by death and ≈øickne≈øs, reduced to le≈øs than four hundred Europeans and ≈øeven hundred Sepoys, without ordnance.

When I delivered the cowl to the Jemadar, he read it, and ≈øeemed plea≈øed, but talked of four or
five days to con≈øider of an an≈øwer, and ≈øeemed to be wavering in his mind, and labouring under the alternate impul≈øes of oppo≈øite motives and contradictory pa≈ø≈øions. I ≈øaw that it was a cri≈øis of more importance than any other of my life‚Äîa cri≈øis in which delay, irre≈øolution, or yielding to the protractive expedients of HYAT, might be fatal. To prevent, therefore, the effects of either treachery or repentance, I took advantage of the general confu≈øion and trepidation which prevailed in the fort‚Äîcollected the Arcot Sepoys, who, to the number of four hundred, were pri≈øoners at large‚Äî po≈øted them at the gates, powder-magazines, and other critical ≈øituations; and, having taken the≈øe and other precautions, went out to the General, who, according to the plan concerted between us, had pu≈øhed on with the advanced guard; and, conducting him into the fort with hardly an attendant, brought him ≈øtraight to the Jemadar's pre≈øence while he yet remained in a ≈øtate of indeci≈øion and terror. General MATHEWS, in his fir≈øt interview with the Jemadar, did every thing to re-a≈ø≈øure him, and confirmed with the mo≈øt ≈øolemn a≈ø≈øeverations the terms of the cowl; in con≈øequence of which the latter acceded to the propo≈øitions contained in it, and the Briti≈øh colours for the fir≈øt time waved upon the walls of the chief fort of the country of Bidanore.

Having thus contributed to put this important garri≈øon, with all its trea≈øures, which certainly were immen≈øe, into the hands of the Company, without the lo≈øs of a ≈øingle man, or even the ≈øtriking of a ≈øingle blow, my exultation was inconceivable; and, much though I wanted money, I can with truth aver, that avarice had not even for an in≈øtant the lea≈øt ≈øhare in my ≈øen≈øations. 'Tis true, the con≈øciou≈øne≈øs of my ≈øervices a≈ø≈øured me of a reward; but how that reward was to accrue to me, never once was the ≈øubject of my contemplation
‚Äîmuch le≈øs did I think of availing my≈øelf of the in≈øtant occa≈øion to obtain it. How far my delicacy on the occa≈øion may be cen≈øured or approved, I cannot tell; but if I got nothing by it, I have at lea≈øt the con≈øolation to reflect that I e≈øcaped calumny, which was with a mo≈øt unju≈øtifiable and un≈øparing hand lavi≈øhed on others. The General, it is true, promi≈øed that I ≈øhould remain with him till he made ≈øome arrangements; and HYAT SAHIB offered, on his part, to make me, through the General, a hand≈øome pre≈øent. The General, however, ≈øuddenly became di≈ø≈øatisfied with me; and I neither got HYAT SAHIB'S pre≈øent, nor ever received even a rupee of the va≈øt ≈øpoil found there.

Here I think it a duty incumbent on me to ≈øay ≈øomething of General MATHEWS, and, while I deplore the unfortunate turn in his temper, which injured me, and tarni≈øhed in ≈øome mea≈øure his good qualities, to re≈øcue him from that unremitted obloquy which the ignorant, the intere≈øted and the envious have thrown upon his fame. Light lie the a≈øhes of the dead, and hallowed be the turf that pillows the head of a ≈øoldier! General MATHEWS was indeed a ≈øoldier‚Äîwas calumniated too; and although he did not u≈øe me as I had rea≈øon to hope he would, I will, as far as I can, re≈øcue his fame from gro≈øs mi≈ørepre≈øentation.

An extravagant love of fame was the ruling pa≈ø≈øion of General MATHEWS: it was the great end of all his pur≈øuits; and while, in his military profe≈ø≈øion, he walked with a firm pace towards it, he lo≈øt his time, di≈øtorted his progre≈øs, and pal≈øied his own efforts, by a jealous vigilance and envious oppo≈øition of tho≈øe whom he found taking the ≈øame road, whether they walked be≈øide him, or panted in feeble effort behind. This was his fault; it was doubtle≈øs a great alloy to his good qualities: but it has been puni≈øhed with rigour di≈øproportionate
to the offence. Tho≈øe who per≈øonally felt his jealou≈øy, took advantage of his melancholy end to traduce him, and magnify every mole-hill of error into a mountain of crime. It is unmanly in any one‚Äîindeed it is‚Äîto traduce the ≈øoldier who has fallen in the ≈øervice of his country; but it is here≈øy in a ≈øoldier to do ≈øo. No ≈øooner did the buzz of calumny get abroad, than thou≈øands of hornets, who had neither intere≈øt nor concern in the affair, joined in it. The malignant, who wi≈øhed to ≈øting merely to get rid of ≈øo much of their venom‚Äîand the vain, who wi≈øhed to acquire a reputation for knowledge of A≈øiatic affairs at the expence of truth ‚Äîunited together, and rai≈øed a hum which reached Europe, where the hornets (I mean authors), under the le≈øs unju≈øtifiable impul≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity, took it up, and buzzed through the medium of quartos and octavos ≈øo loud, that public opinion was poi≈øoned; and the gallant ≈øoldier who, for the advantage of England, ≈øtood the harde≈øt tugs of war, and at la≈øt drank the poi≈øoned cup from the tyrant hands of her enemy, was generally under≈øtood to be a peculator, and to have clande≈øtinely and di≈øhone≈øtly obtained three hundred thou≈øand pounds.

On this attention I put my direct negative. It may be ≈øaid, however, that this is only a≈ø≈øertion again≈øt a≈ø≈øertion‚ÄîTrue! Sorry ≈øhould I be to re≈øt it there: my a≈ø≈øertions are grounded on ≈øuch proofs as are no ‚Ä¢ to be ≈øhaken‚Äîproofs on record in the office of the Pre≈øidency of Bombay.

As ≈øoon as Hydernagur was taken po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of, HYAT SAHIB immediately i≈ø≈øued orders to the ≈øorts of Mangatore, Deokull, Ananpore, and ≈øome others in that country, to ≈øurrender to the Briti≈øh arms. Some obeyed the mandate; but tho≈øe three re≈øi≈øted, and were reduced by General MATHEWS. Rendered incautious by ≈øucce≈øs, our army became le≈øs vigilant, and TIPPOO retook Hydernagur; and, in direct breach of the capitulation, made the garri≈øon
pri≈øoners, treated them with a degree of inhumanity which chills the blood even to think of, and forced General MATHEWS to take poi≈øon in pri≈øon!

Mean-time HYAT SAHIB, with whom the General had got into di≈øputes, arrived at Bombay, and laid a charge again≈øt him, which he, being in the hands of TIPPOO, could not controvert, or even know. And what was the charge? The whole extent of it was his (MATHEWS'S) having got two lacks of rupees, and a pearl necklace, as a pre≈øent ‚Äîa ≈øum, con≈øidering the country and circum≈øtan≈øtances, not at all extraordinary, but which is completely vindicated by the General's letter to the Court of Directors, dated at Mangalore, the 15th of March, 1783; in which he ≈øtates the pre≈øent, and reque≈øts permi≈ø≈øion to accept it. This, as I ≈øaid before, is on record, and was tran≈ølated by Mr. SYBBALD, who was then Per≈øian interpreter at Bombay. The letter I allude to, you will ≈øee in the APPENDIX. In ≈øhort, General MATHEWS had his faults, but an unju≈øt avarice was not among≈øt them.

div.head: LETTER LIX.
div.p:
HAVING, in my la≈øt letter, ≈øaid as much as I thought ju≈øtice demanded in defence of General MATHEWS, again≈øt the charge of peculation, I am now to ≈øpeak of him as his conduct touched me. He was, as I have already mentioned, an old friend of my father's, and an intimate of my own: I had rea≈øon, therefore, to expect from him, according to the u≈øual di≈øpo≈øitions and manners of men, if not partiality, at lea≈øt friend≈øhip; and in ≈øuch a ca≈øe as
I have related, where my ≈øervices gave me a claim to notice, it was not unrea≈øonable to ≈øuppo≈øe that he would have been forward to promote my intere≈øt, by ≈øtating my ≈øervices in ≈øuch a manner as to call attention to them. He had, however, ≈øome di≈øagreeable di≈øcu≈ø≈øions with his officers; and ≈øeeing I was on a footing with Colonel HUMBERTSON, and ≈øtill more with Major CAMPBELL (he who ≈øo ably and gallantly defended Mangalore again≈øt TIPPOO'S whole army and ≈øix hundred French), and finding me extremely zealous and importunate to have his arrangement with HYAT SAHIB adhered to, he became di≈øplea≈øed, and, though he him≈øelf had determined that I ≈øhould remain with him, changed his mind, and ordered me away at an hour's notice‚Äî many days ≈øooner than he had originally intended to ≈øend off any di≈øpatches. He moreover occa≈øioned my lo≈øing a ≈øum of money, and on the whole paid le≈øs attention to my intere≈øt than the circum≈øtances of the ca≈øe demanded.

In the evening of the day on which he determined on my departure, I ≈øet off with his di≈øpatches to the governments of Madra≈øs and Bengal, and reached the mo≈øt di≈øtant of our po≈øts that night. From thence I had thirty miles to Cundapore, a ≈øeaport town upon the Malabar coa≈øt, taken by us from the enemy. During this journey, which was through the country of TIPPOO SAHIB, I had only ≈øix Sepoys to conduct me: yet, ≈øuch was the univer≈øal panic that had ≈øeized all cla≈ø≈øes and di≈øtinctions of people at the progre≈øs of the Briti≈øh arms in that quarter, I met only a few ≈øcattered Sepoys, who were ≈øo badly wounded I pre≈øume they were unable to travel‚Äîthe villages throughout being completely abandoned by all their inhabitants.

The ≈øudden change of diet, which phy≈øicians tell us, and I experienced, is dangerous, from bad to good, as well as the rever≈øe, con≈øpiring with the
mortification I felt at ≈øeeing things going on ≈øo very contrary to what I wi≈øhed, and what I had rea≈øon to expect, had a mo≈øt ≈øudden and alarming effect upon my con≈øtitution; and I was ≈øeized on the road with the mo≈øt excrutiating, internal pains, which were ≈øucceeded by a violent vomiting of blood. At length, with great difficulty, I reached Cundapore, where the commanding officer, and all about him did every thing in their power to afford me a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and comfort under my mi≈øeries, which increa≈øed every hour rapidly. I felt as if my in≈øide was utterly decayed, and all its functions lo≈øt in debility: at the ≈øame time my head ≈øeemed deranged ‚ÄîI could ≈øcarcely comprehend the meaning of what was ≈øaid; lifting up my head was attended with agonizing pain; and if I had any power of thought, it was to con≈øider my≈øelf as approaching fa≈øt to di≈ø≈øolution. I had the ≈øen≈øe, however, to ≈øend to General MATHEWS, to acquaint him with my indi≈øpo≈øition, and utter inability to proceed with his di≈øpatches. To this I received the following letter:

body.p: I am ≈øorry to hear that you have been unwell. Should your indi≈øpo≈øition increa≈øe, or continue, ≈øo as to tender you unable to pur≈øue your journey with the nece≈ø≈øary expedition, I beg that you will forward the letters to Anjengo by a boat, with directions to Mr. HUTCHINSON to ≈øend them per tappyPo≈øt, or expre≈øs. to Palamcotah, and ≈øo on to Madras.
I ≈øhall hope to hear of your recovery, and that you'll have gone to ≈øea.

div.p: The receipt of this letter induced me, bad as I was, to make one other exertion; and I re≈øolved, though I ≈øhould die on the way, not to leave any thing which, even by malicious con≈øtruction, could be made a ≈øet-off again≈øt my claims: I therefore hired an open boat to carry me along the coa≈øt to Anjengo, and ≈øet out with every pro≈øpect of having the virulence of my di≈øorder increa≈øed, by being expo≈øed in an uncovered ve≈ø≈øel to the damp of the night air, and the raging heat of the ≈øun in the day, and of being arre≈øted by the hand of death in my way. By the time I had got down the coa≈øt as far as Mangalore, my complaints increa≈øed to an alarming height; and I became ≈øpeechle≈øs, and unable to ≈øtand. Fortunately there happened to be a Company's ve≈ø≈øel then lying at anchor off that place, the captain of which had the goodne≈øs to invite me to remain on board with him, ≈øtrenuou≈øly advi≈øing that I ≈øhould give up the thoughts of proceeding immediately on my voyage to Anjengo, which I could not po≈ø≈øibly ≈øurvive, and to forward my di≈øpatches by another hand. The ≈øurgeon of the ≈øhip joining the captain in opinion that I could not ≈øurvive if I attempted it, and my own judgment coinciding with their's, I at length con≈øented, and remained there.

Tranquility, kind treatment, and good medical a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, produced, in the ≈øpace of two or three weeks, ≈øo material a change in my health, I was in a condition to avail my≈øelf, at the expiration of that time, of a ≈øhip bound to Anjengo, and which offering the additional inducement of touching at Tellicherry, determined me to take my pa≈ø≈øage in her. When I arrived at Tellicherry, and during my ≈øtay there, the great attention ≈øhewn me by Mr. FREEMAN, the chief of that place, and the comforts of his hou≈øe, re≈øtored me to a great ≈øhare of health and ≈øpirits‚ÄîAnd here a very ≈øingular circum≈øtance occurred.

One day a ve≈ø≈øel arrived; and perceiving a boat coming on ≈øhore from her, Mr. FREEMAN and I walked down to the beach, to make the u≈øual inquiries‚Äî≈øuch as, where ≈øhe came from? what news ≈øhe brought? &c. &c. As ≈øoon as the boat touched the ≈øhore, a gentleman leaped out of it, who≈øe per≈øon ≈øeemed familiar to me: upon his nearer approach, I di≈øcovered that it was Mr. BRODEY, a gentleman who had been kind enough to take upon him the office of my attorney, upon my leaving India ≈øome years before‚Äînot my attorney in the ordinary acceptation of that word, but a liberal and di≈øintere≈øted friend, who obligingly undertook the management of my affairs in my ab≈øence, without the ≈ømalle≈øt hope of advantage, or rather under circum≈øtances which ≈øerved as preludes to further obligations. I was certainly plea≈øed and ≈øurpri≈øed to ≈øee him; but his a≈øtoni≈øhment to ≈øee me amounted almo≈øt to a di≈øtru≈øt of his eye≈øight: he had received ≈øuch indubitable proofs of my death, that my ≈øudden appearance on his landing, at the fir≈øt ru≈øh of thought, impre≈ø≈øed him with the notion of a deceptio vi≈øus. My identity, however, was too po≈øitive for re≈øi≈øtance; and his wonder melted down into cordial ≈øatisfaction, and congratulations on my ≈øafety. He then took out a pocket account-book, in which, for ≈øecurity again≈øt accidents, he kept accounts-current, written in a brief manner‚Äîand ≈øhewed me mine, ≈øettled almo≈øt to the very day, upon which was tran≈øcribed a copy of a letter he had received, and which he thought was a te≈øtimony of my death. So, cutting out the account, and pre≈øenting it to me, he expre≈ø≈øed, in the mo≈øt cordial and hand≈øome manner, his joy that it was into my own hands he had at la≈øt had an opportunity to deliver it. This gentleman is now in this Kingdom, and too well known for me to de≈øcribe him. Suffice it to ≈øay, that in England, as well as in India, he has always enjoyed
the e≈øteem and re≈øpect of all his acquaintances, to as great an extent as any other per≈øon I know.

I again embarked to proceed on my voyage, and had hardly got on board when a ≈øhip dropped anchor along ≈øide of us, in which captain CAMPBELL of Comby, a very near connection of mine, was pa≈ø≈øenger. On hailing one another, he heard that I was on board, and immeditely was with me. Tho≈øe who ≈øincerely love each other, and who≈øe hearts confe≈øs the fond ties of con≈øanguinity, can alone conceive what our mutual plea≈øure was at meeting ≈øo unexpectedly in ≈øo remote a corner of the world. He was then on his way to join the army. This amiable young man, now repo≈øes in the bed of honour at Mangalore! He fell, after having di≈øtingui≈øhed him≈øelf in the very gallant defence made by that place again≈øt the whole force of TIPPOO. With regret we parted: and in due time I arrived at Anjengo without any accident befalling me, which was rather extraordinary.

Leaving Anjengo, I ≈øet out for Madras, de≈øigning to go all the way by land‚Äîa journey of near eight hundred miles. I accordingly ≈øtruck through the Kingdom of Travancore, who≈øe ≈øovereign is in alliance with the Engli≈øh; and had not long entered the territories of the Nabob of Arcot, before Major MACNEAL, an old friend of mine, and commandant of a fort in that di≈øtrict, met me preceded by a troop of dancing girls, who encircled my palanquin, dancing around me until I entered the Major's hou≈øe.

It would be difficult to give you an adequate notion of tho≈øe dancing girls. Trained up from their infancy to the practice of the mo≈øt graceful motions, the mo≈øt artful di≈øplay of per≈øonal ≈øymmetry, and the mo≈øt wanton allurements, they dance in ≈øuch a ≈øtyle, and twine their limbs and bodies into ≈øuch po≈øtures, as bewitch the ≈øen≈øes, and extort applau≈øe and admiration where in ≈øtrictne≈øs
di≈øapprobation is due: nor is their agility inferior to the grace of their movements‚Äîthough they do not exert it in the ≈øame ≈økipping way that our ≈øtage dancers do, but make it ≈øub≈øervient to the elegance, and, I may ≈øay, grandeur, of their air. They are generally found in troops of ≈øix or eight, attended by mu≈øicians, who≈øe a≈øpect and dre≈øs are as uncouth and ≈øqualid, as the ≈øounds they produce under the name of mu≈øic, are inelegant, har≈øh and di≈ø≈øonant. To this mu≈øic, from which mea≈øure as much as harmony is excluded, they dance, mo≈øt wonderfully adapting their ≈øtep to the perpetual change of the time, accompanying it with amorous ≈øongs, while the corre≈øpondent action of their body and limbs, the wanton palpitation and heaving of their exqui≈øitely formed bo≈øoms, and the amorous, or rather la≈øcivious expre≈ø≈øion of their countenance, excite in the ≈øpectators emotions not very favourable to cha≈øtity. Thus they continue to act, till, by the warmth of exerci≈øe and imagination, they become ≈øeemingly frantic with ec≈øtacy, and, ≈øinking down motionle≈øs with fatigue, throw them≈øelves into the mo≈øt alluring attitudes that ingenious vice and voluptuou≈øne≈øs can po≈ø≈øibly devi≈øe.

That ≈øuch incitements to vice ≈øhould make a part of the ≈øy≈øtem of any ≈øociety, is to be lamented: yet, at all ceremonies and great occa≈øions, whether of religious wor≈øhip or dome≈øtic enjoyment, they make a part of the entertainment; and the altar of their gods, and the purity of the marriage rites, are alike polluted by the introduction of the dancing girls. The impurity of this cu≈øtom, however, vani≈øhes in India, when compared with the hideous practice of introducing dancing boys.

The Major, after having entertained me in the mo≈øt ho≈øpitable manner, accompanied me to Palamcotah, to the hou≈øe of Doctor DOTT, who lived in a generous and ho≈øpitable ≈øtyle. I had once had
an opportunity of evincing my good di≈øpo≈øition to this gentleman, when he was mo≈øt critically ≈øituated; and the reception he gave me demon≈øtrated, that he than retained a lively ≈øen≈øe of my conduct to him.

Leaving Palamcotah, I continued my route thro' Madura. This country is rendered remarkable by the revolt of the famous ISIF CAWN, who made a bold and well-conducted attempt to erect him≈øelf into the ≈øovereignty of that province, independent of the Nabob of the Carnatic, in who≈øe ≈øervice he was: and as the affair occurs to my thoughts, I will, for your information, notwith≈øtanding its being unconnected with my ≈øtory, digre≈øs into an account of it. As ≈øoon as the revolt of ISIF CAWN was known, General MONSON, an officer of great military ≈økill and per≈øonal merit, went again≈øt him at the head of the King's and company's troops, and inve≈øted the ≈øort of Madura, in which that rebellious chief was po≈øted. The general made a practicable breach, and, in ≈øtorming, was beat back with great ≈ølaughter by ISIF; and the ≈øetting in of the mon≈øoons immediately after, retarded the further operations of our army again≈øt the place; and in the interim, peace having been concluded between the courts of St. James's and Ver≈øailles, the King's troops were withdrawn.

On the recall of the King's troops, an army of company's troops was formed, to proceed again≈øt Madura, in order to reduce this gallant turbulent rebel to ≈øubjection; and the renowned general LAWRENCE being rendered incapable of actual ≈øervice, and obliged to remain at the pre≈øidency by extreme age and infirmity, the chief command devolved upon my father by ≈øeniority: he headed the expedition; and, after overcoming innumerable difficulties thrown in his way by the inventive genius and enterpri≈øing ≈øpirit of ISIF CAWN, again
made a breach, which was deemed practicable by the chief engineer, now Sir JOHN CALL. An a≈ø≈øault was made with no better ≈øucce≈øs than the former; for our army was again repul≈øed with incredible ≈ølaughter: more than two thirds, I believe, of our European officers, were among the killed or wounded; and the death o ‚Ä¢ Major PRESTON, ≈øecond in command, a man endeared to the a my by the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of every advantage of per≈øon, heart and talents‚Äîan active, intrepid and able officer‚Äîaggravated the calami ‚Ä¢ ies of the day.

If, impelled by my feelings, or tempted by remembrance of the pa≈øt. I ≈øometimes digre≈øs from the direct path of my narrative, my FREDERICK will accompany me, not only wi ‚Ä¢ h patience, bu ‚Ä¢ I dare ≈øay with plea≈øure: I cannot refrain, therefore, from mentioning a memorable occurence during that fiege, not only as it is ≈øomewhat extraordinary in it≈øelf, but as it relates to a very near and dear connection. Colonel DONALD CAMPBELL, who then commanded the cavalry, received no le≈øs than fourteen ≈øword-wounds and a mu≈øquer-ball in his body‚Äîyet continued doing his duty with ≈øuch cool in ‚Ä¢ repidity, that brave ≈øoldiers who were witne≈ø≈øes to it, expre≈ø≈øed the utmo≈øt a≈øtoni≈øhment: upon being reque≈øted to quit the field, he replied, that as his family were provided for, he had nothing to fear; and as it was very unlikely his life could be ≈øave ‚Ä¢ , he would not deprive his country of any advantage that might be derived from his exertions for the ≈øhort re≈øidue of it, but continue to the la≈øt moment at his duty. With all this firmne≈øs and magnanimity, he was gentle, good-humoured, mode≈øt and una≈ø≈øuming; and was admired for his great per≈øonal beauty, as well as military talents, particularly by the Duke of CUMBERLAND, under whom he ≈øerved in the war in Germany as a ≈øubaltern officer, in ≈øo much that his Royal Highne≈øs had his picture drawn. It was to him the company were
fir≈øt indebted for the introduction of perfect military di≈øcipline into their army in India. In the various relations in which he ≈øtood, whether dome≈øtic ‚Ä¢ r public, as the ≈øubject, the citizen, the father, or the friend, he was ≈øo uniformly excellent, that the ≈øhafts of malevolence, which the be≈øt and wi≈øe≈øt of men have but too often felt, ≈øeldom reached him; and he may ju≈øtly be reckoned among≈øt that very ≈ømall number of created beings, of whom ≈øcarcely any one had the audacity to ≈øpeak ill. Upon my fir≈øt arrival in India, I was put under his command, and lived in his family‚Äîwhen, in≈øtead of deporting him≈øelf towards me with that re≈øerve and au≈øterity which rank and reputation like his, coupled with the circum≈øtance of his being my uncle, might in ≈øome ≈øort have ju≈øtified, he took me into his confidence, treated me with the greate≈øt affection, and acted rather as the brother and the equal, than as the parent and ≈øuperior; and thus his gentle admonitions had more effect in re≈øtraining the ≈øallies of youth, and impetuo≈øity of my temper, than the four, unpalatable documents of a ≈øupercilious preceptor could po≈ø≈øibly have had.

The wonderful effects of this happy temper in ≈øwaying the ≈øtubborn di≈øpo≈øition of head≈øtrong youth, was exemplified in another in≈øtance‚Äîof which, ≈øince I am on the ≈øubject, I will inform you. Mr. DUPRES, then governor of Madras, wrote to him about a young gentleman, in the following words:

body.p:
In the li≈øt of officers appointed to your garri≈øon, you will ≈øee the name of ‚Äî. This young man (nephew to Mrs. DUPRES), with abilities that might render him con≈øpicuous, I am ≈øorry to ≈øay, ≈øtands in need of a ≈øtrict hand. All the favour I have to reque≈øt of you is to
≈øhew him no favour: keep him rigidly to his duty; and, if he requires it, rule him with a rod of iron. Should his future conduct meet your approbation, it is unnece≈ø≈øary for me to a≈øk it, as you are always ready to ≈øhew kindne≈øs to tho≈øe who merit it.

div.p: The peculiar ≈øtyle of this letter made ≈øuch an impre≈ø≈øion on my memory, that I am able to give the exact words. Colonel CAMPBELL, however, took his own unalterable method, mildne≈øs‚Äîtreated the young gentleman in ≈øuch a manner as to rai≈øe in him a con≈øciou≈øne≈øs of his dignity as a man, the fir≈øt and be≈øt guard again≈øt mi≈øconduct‚Äîand appointed him to the grenadier company. The re≈øult was an≈øwerable to his expectations; for the young man's conduct, both as an officer and a gentleman, was ≈øuch in the ≈øequel as to reflect credit on him≈øelf and his family; and his very honourable and hopeful career was at la≈øt terminated by a cannon-ball at the ≈øiege of Tanjore.

If the veneration in which I ≈øhall ever hold this mo≈øt dear and re≈øpected relative admitted of increa≈øe, it would certainly receive it from the contra≈øt I am every day obliged to draw between him and the wretched butterflies who ≈øometimes flutter round us under the name of men: for, how can I help contra≈øting his inflexible courage, united to angelic mildne≈øs, with the in≈øolence of lilly-livered Hectors, who, con≈øcious of the mo≈øt abject cowardice, dare to give an in≈øult, and ba≈øely ≈økulk from hone≈øt re≈øentment beneath the arm of the law!‚Äî fellows who, like Bobadil in the play, can kill a whole army with the tongue, but dare not face a pigmy in the field!‚Äîand, while they want the prudence to re≈øtrain the torrent of effeminate invective, have patience enough to bear a kicking, or a box in the ear!‚Äîwho blu≈øter and vapour to hide the trembling limb and poltroon a≈øpect, as
children whi≈øtle in the dark to brave the gho≈øts they dread! Beware of all ≈øuch wre ‚Ä¢ ches as you would ≈øhun plague or pe≈øtilence. I hope you do not imagine that I have ≈øo little common ≈øen≈øe or philanthropy as to cen≈øure tho≈øe who, from phy≈øical cau≈øes or con≈øtitutional delicacy, are aver≈øe to conte≈øt: No, no‚ÄîI do a≈ø≈øure you, on the contrary, that my ob≈øervation leads me to think ≈øuch men, though ≈ølow to quarrel, and inoffen≈øive in conduct, are very gallant when honour or duty demand from them a conque≈øt over their we kne≈øs. I have, in my time, ≈øeen ≈øuch men a ‚Ä¢ fir≈øt the ≈øport, and at la≈øt the terror of your blu≈øtering bu≈øhes; and I have always thought, that in ≈øuch a triumph over their feelings, they had more true merit than men con≈øtitutionally courageous: the latter has his valour in common with the mere animal; the other po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes the valo ‚Ä¢ of ≈øentiment. I mean that mo≈øt ignominious of all beings, who, prodigal in offence, yet rel ‚Ä¢ ctant in ≈øeparation‚Äîwho, hoping to find ≈øome per≈øon pa≈ø≈øive as them≈øelves over whom to triumph, hazard the giving of an in≈øult, with the malignant view to ga≈øconade over him if he ≈øubmits‚Äîand, if he re≈øents, to wreak the whole vengeance of law upon him. In ≈øociety with ≈øuch men, there is no ≈øafety; for they leave you only the ca≈øual alternative to choo≈øe between ≈øhame and ruin. Him who ≈øubmits, they call poltroon; and him who re≈øents, they fleece in form of law. There are others who, to bring their fellow-creatures down to their own level, brave the execrations of mankind, and the vengeance of Heaven: ≈øuch ha ‚Ä¢ p ‚Ä¢ es do exi≈øt, who, though bold enough to in≈øult, are tame enough to receive cha≈øti≈øement without re≈øi≈øtance; and, though tame enough to ≈øubmit to cha≈øti≈øement, are ≈øo furiou≈øly vindictive as to proclaim their ≈øhame, their cowardice, perhaps in the face of an open court, in order to glut their revenge by the pillage of their adver≈øary's pur≈øe.
Let ≈øuch men enjoy the fruits of their machinations, if they can‚ÄîTo their own feelings I con≈øign them; for I can wi≈øh a villain no greater cur≈øe than the company of his own con≈øcience, nor a poltroon a more poignant ≈øting than that which the contempt of mankind inflicts upon him.

div.head: LETTER LX.
div.p:
PASSING through Madura, I arrived at Trichinopoly, where I met Mr. SULLIVAN, the re≈øident of Tanjore, who very politely furni≈øhed me with a letter to Mr. HIPPESLEY, his deputy at Tanjore, from whom I received many marks of civility. At that place I had the plea≈øure of meeting a gentleman with whom I had been at college, and for whom I had always entertained a great e≈øteem: this was Colonel FULLARTON. It is an old maxim, that we ≈øhould ≈øay nothing but good of the dead‚Äî"De mortuis nil ni≈øi bonum." It is not a new maxim, I believe, to avoid prai≈øing the living: I am aware of the indelicacy of it; and therefore purpo≈øely avoid in this, as I ≈øhall in other in≈øtances, ≈øpeaking the full opinion I entertain‚ñ™ To the general e≈øteem in which he was held by all ranks of people in India, I refer you to Colonel FULLARTON'S character: it is of ≈øuch a ≈øort, that I wi≈øh to hold it up for your imitation. At a time of life when others have arrived to ≈øome perfection in their profe≈ø≈øion, he made choice of his, and entered for the fir≈øt time into the arduous military department, with a command for which the training of many years is no more than ≈øufficient to prepare other men. The Mini≈øter of that day gave him this important charge, underwent the clamours of
Oppo≈øition for it, and was ju≈øtified in the event. When the Colonel came to act, ≈øo far from being deficient, his whole conduct was di≈øtingui≈øhed, not le≈øs for military talent than courage‚Äîwhile the mo≈øt fortunate command and temper and captivating addre≈øs ≈øubdued the ≈øpirit of prejudice, reconciled the mo≈øt di≈øcordant, and gained him, though a King's Officer, the e≈øteem as much of the Company's as King's troops. Be a≈ø≈øured, my dear boys, (for now I ≈øpeak to JOHN as well as FREDERICK), that one act of triumph over the temper is worth a million of triumphs over our fellow-creatures, and that the perfect dominion of our mind is more advantageous and laudable than the dominion over Provinces or Nations. I had al≈øo the good luck to meet, at Tanjore, Mr. BUCHANAN, a very near connection of mine, for whom I had long entertained a ≈øincere and warm regard. It has been my misfortune to have been obliged frequently to cen≈øure ≈øome of my relatives for ill-nature and ingratitude: I never did

div.head: De≈øcription of the Ceremony of the Gentoo Women burning them≈øelves with the bodies of their Hu≈øbands.
div.p: "This day, ‚Äî, I went to ≈øee a Gentoo woman re≈øign her≈øelf to be burned along with the corp≈øe of her decea≈øed hu≈øband.
"The place fixed upon for this tragic ≈øcene, was a ≈ømall i≈ølet on the bank of one of the branches of the river Cavery, about a mile to the Northward of the fort of Tanjore.

"When I came to the ≈øpot, I found the victim, who appeared to be not above ≈øixteen, ≈øitting on the ground, dre≈ø≈øed in the Gentoo manner, with a white cloth wrapped round her, ≈øome white flowers like je≈ø≈øamins hanging round her neck, and ≈øome of them hanging from her hair. There were about twenty women ≈øitting on their hams round her, holding a white handkerchief, extended horizontally over her head, to ≈øhade her from the ≈øun, which was exce≈ø≈øively hot, it being then about noon.

"At about twenty yards from where ≈øhe was ≈øitting, and facing her, there were ≈øeveral Bramins bu≈øy in con≈øtructing a pile with billets of firewood: the pile was about eight feet long, and four broad. They fir≈øt began by driving ≈øome upright ≈øtakes into the ground, and then built up the middle to about the height of three feet and a half with billets of wood.

"The dead hu≈øband, who, from his appearance, ≈øeemed to be about ≈øixty years of age, was lying clo≈øe by, ≈øtretched out on a bie ‚Ä¢ , made of Bamboo canes. Four Bramins walked in proce≈ø≈øion three times round the dead body, fir≈øt in a direction contrary to the ≈øun, and afterwards other three times in a direction with the ≈øun, all the while muttering incantations; and at each round or circuit they made, they untwi≈øted, and immediately again twi≈øted up the ≈ømall long lock of hair which is left un≈øhaven at the back of their heads.

"Some other Bramins were in the mean time employed in ≈øprinkling water out of a green leaf, rolled up like a cup, upon a ≈ømall heap of cakes of dry cow-dung, with which the pile was afterwards to be ≈øet on fire.
"An old Bramin ≈øat at the North-ea≈øt corner of the pile upon his hams, with a pair of ≈øpectacles on, reading, I ≈øuppo≈øe, the Sha≈øter, or their Scriptures, from a book compo≈øed of Cajan leaves.

"Having been pre≈øent now nearly an hour, I inquired when they meant to ≈øet the pile on fire: they an≈øwered, in about two hours. As this ≈øpectacle was mo≈øt melancholy, and naturally ≈øtruck me with horror, and as I had only gone there to a≈ø≈øure my≈øelf of the truth of ≈øuch ≈øacrifices being made, I went away towards the fort. After I was gone about five hundred yards, they ≈øent ≈øome one to tell me they would burn immediately; on which I returned, and found the woman had been moved from where ≈øhe was ≈øitting to the river, where the
Bramins were bathing her. On taking her out of the water, they put ≈øome money in her hand, which ≈øhe dipped in the river, and divided among the Bramins: ≈øhe had then a yellow cloth ‚Ä¢ olled partially round her. They put ≈øome red colour, about the ≈øize of a ≈øixpence, on the centre of her forehead, and rubbed ≈øomething that appeared to me to be clay. She was then led to the pile, round which ≈øhe walked three times as the ≈øun goes: ≈øhe then mo ‚Ä¢ nted it at the North-ea≈øt corner, without any a≈ø≈øi≈øtance; and ≈øat her≈øelf down on the right ≈øide of her hu≈øband, who had been previou≈øly laid upon the pile. She then un≈øcrewed the pins which fa≈øtened the jewels or ≈øilver rings on her arms: after ≈øhe had taken them off, ≈øhe ≈øhut them, and ≈øcrewed in the pins again, and gave one to each of two women who were ≈øtanding: ≈øhe un≈øcrewed the car-rings, and other toys, with great compo≈øure, and divided them among the women who were with her. There ≈øeemed to be ≈øome little ≈øquabble about the di≈øtribution of her jewels, which ≈øhe ≈øettled with great preci≈øion; and then, falling gently backwards, polled a fold of the yellow cloth over her face, turned her brea≈øt towards her hu≈øbands ≈øide, and laid her right arm over his brea≈øt; and in this po≈øture ≈øhe remained without moving.

"Ju≈øt before ≈øhe lay down, the Bramins put ≈øome rice in her lap, and al≈øo ≈øome in the mouth and on the long grey beard of her hu≈øband: they then ≈øprinkled ≈øome water on the head, brea≈øt and feet of both, and tied them gently together round the middle with a ≈ølender bit of rope: they then rai≈øed, as it were, a little wall of wood lengthways on two ≈øides of the pile, ≈øo as to rai≈øe it above the level of the bodies; and then put cro≈øs pieces, ≈øo as to prevent the billets of wood from pre≈ø≈øing on them: they then poured on the pile, above where the woman lay, a po ‚Ä¢ ful of ≈øomething that appeared to me to be oil; after this they heaped on more
wood, to the height of about four feet above where the bodies were built in; ≈øo that all I now ≈øaw was a ≈øtack of fire-wood.

"One of the Bramins, I ob≈øerved, ≈øtood at the end of the pile next the woman's head‚Äîwas calling to her through the inter≈øtices of the wood, and laughed ≈øeveral times during the conver≈øation. La≈øtly, they over≈øpread the pile with wet ≈øtraw, and tied it on with ropes.

"A Bramin then took a handful of ≈øtraw, which he ≈øet on fire at the little heap of burning cakes of cow-dung; and, ≈øtanding to windward of the pile, he let the wind drive the flame from the ≈øtraw till it catched the pile. I li≈øtened a few ≈øeconds, but could not di≈øtingui≈øh any ≈øhricks, which might perhaps be owing to my being then to windward. In a very few minutes, the pile became a heap of a≈øhes.

"During the whole time of this proce≈øs, which la≈øted from fir≈øt to la≈øt above two hours before we lo≈øt ≈øight of the woman by her being built up in the middle of the pile, I kept my eyes almo≈øt con≈øtantly upon her; and I declare to GOD that I could not perceive, either in her countenance or limbs, the lea≈øt trace of either horror, fear, or even he≈øitation: her countenance was perfectly compo≈øed and placed; and ≈øhe was not, I am po≈øitive, either intoxicated or ≈øtupified. From ≈øeveral circum≈øtances, I thought the Bramins exulted in this helli≈øh ≈øacrifice, and did not ≈øeem at all di≈øplea≈øed that Europeans ≈øhould be witne≈ø≈øes of it."
From Tanjore I proceeded to N ‚Ä¢ gapa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ am, which had been taken from the Dutch by the Company's troops, and where Mr. COCHRAN, and old friend of mine, was Chief.
