div.head: LETTER LXI.
div.p: HITHERTO every ≈øtep of my journey has been marked by occurrences ≈øo unexpected, and accidents ≈øo extraordinary, that I ≈øhould feel ≈øome repugnance to relate them, le≈øt my veracity ≈øhould be called in que≈øtion, were they not atte≈øted by ≈øo many living per≈øons of re≈øpectability, and by written documents of authority on record. Were one to con≈øider them merely as the offspring of fiction, they would perhaps have intere≈øt enough to catch the attention; but, viewing them as facts, they borrow, from their number and rapid ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, as well as from their ≈øingularity, ≈øo much of the complexion of imaginary adventure, that the combination cannot, I think, fail to intere≈øt your mind as well as your feelings.

Arrived at Negapatnam, within a ≈øhort run of Madras, it is natural for you to ≈øuppo≈øe that adventure was at an end, and that fortune, fatigued by the ince≈ø≈øant exertion of her caprice, might have left me to proceed the ≈øhort re≈øidue of my way without further mole≈øtation. It fell out otherwi≈øe: ≈øhe had marked me as her game, and re≈øolved to worry me to the la≈øt moment; for, as we approached Madras, we were cha≈øed by a French frigate, and taken near Fort St. George.

This appeared to me the greate≈øt misfortune I had yet met with, and likely to be the mo≈øt fatal
in its con≈øequences. In order to explain this, I mu≈øt recur to certain circum≈øtances, which though I was informed of them ≈øince my relea≈øe from Hydernagur, I did not relate to you, becau≈øe they were no way connected with my narrative till now.

Mon≈øieur SUFFREIN, the French Admiral, having a number of Briti≈øh pri≈øoners in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, whom he found it extremely inconvenient to ≈øupport, made a propo≈øal for an exchange‚Äîwhich, from ≈øome failure in the conveyance, or ambiguity in the terms of the corre≈øpondence, was neglected.

The motives or accidents which gave ri≈øe to this neglect have never been completely developed; and perhaps the Admiral him≈øelf, Sir EDWARD HUGHES, and Lord MACARTNEY, were the only per≈øons who knew the bottom of that tran≈øaction. In ≈øuch ca≈øes, however, the ignorance of fact is generally ≈øupplied by conjecture; and men have pre≈øumed to cen≈øure unequivocally on the mere hypothetical ≈øugge≈øtions of their own imaginations. Candour, however, in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, where it could not ≈øpeak with certainty, would ≈øpeak with caution. An Hi≈øtorian, particularly, ≈øhould ≈øteer clear of party rancour, and not ≈øuffer the prejudice or malignity which mi≈øled him≈øelf, to go down to and mi≈ølead po≈øterity. Where po≈øitive proof is wanting, if we are obliged to decide, we mu≈øt judge by analogy and inference; and in the ca≈øe now before us, we have little but the characters of the per≈øons concerned to guide us in our deci≈øion.

Of the horrid cata≈øtrophe which ≈øucceeded the neglect of exchanging pri≈øoners, it is hardly po≈ø≈øible that any one but Mon≈øieur SUFFREIN him≈øelf could have had a conception. To ≈øuppo≈øe, that, under ≈øuch an impre≈ø≈øion, our leading men would have he≈øitated to prevent it, would be to ≈øuppo≈øe their intellects weak, and their hearts corrupt and inhuman. I fancy it will be difficult to fa≈øten on
Lord MACARTNEY either the one or the other; for he was wi≈øe and humane: tho≈øe whom the di≈øappointment of unrea≈øonable expectations, or the malevolence of party, have induced to ≈øu≈øpect his Lord≈øhip's heart, have been forced by his conduct to revere his talents; and the breath of calumny has never touched the humanity of Sir EDWARD HUGHES. Whatever their motives, therefore, may have been‚Äîrea≈øon, con≈øcience, and candour, mu≈øt acquit them of the con≈øequences. It ≈øhould be recollected, too, that Mon≈øi ‚Ä¢ ur SUFFREIN'S character was a very probable ≈øecurity, in the mind of men of ≈øen≈øe and honour, again≈øt any act of horrid inhumanity: his conduct as an officer had made a new aera in the Naval Hi≈øtory of France: his talents and courage might be compared, without di≈øadvantage, to tho≈øe of the be≈øt of our Briti≈øh Admirals; and he had exhibited marks of uncommon genero≈øity to tho≈øe whom the chance of war had thrown into his hands. It would therefore have been ≈øomething more than pre≈øcience to have pre≈øuppo≈øed what actually happened; and I declare mo≈øt ≈øolemnly, that the inference I draw from the whole information I have had on the ≈øubject is, that, calamitous though the event was, it attaches no po≈øitive guilt on any of the parties concerned. The fact is plainly this: The French Admiral having no place on the coa≈øt where he could ≈øecure his pri≈øoners, and grieving, as he him≈øelf ≈øub≈øequently wrote to Mr. HASTINGS, to ≈øee the unhappy men, who had been ≈øix or ≈øeven months at ≈øea, dying of the ≈øcurvy, delivered over the pri≈øoners, to the number of above three hundred, to HYDER. Their fa ‚Ä¢ e afterwards was ≈øuch as it would har ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ up your ≈øoul to hear related.

Take the whole of the circum≈øtances into one glance, and ≈øee what my feelings mu≈øt have been on finding my≈øelf once more a pri≈øoner. HYDER ALLI, who was, when compared with the wor≈øt de≈øpots
of the European world, a mon≈øter, mu≈øt yet be con≈øidered, when put in compari≈øon, with his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor TIPPOO, mild and merciful. HYDER, from policy and hypocri≈øy, ≈øhewed ≈øome lenity to the pri≈øoners who fell into his hands. In≈øtances are known where Briti≈øh captives have broke through the crowd that ≈øurrounded him into his pre≈øence for protection‚Äîwhen he has hypocritically feigned anger, threatened the per≈øons who had treated them ill, reprobated ≈øeverity, and ≈øent them off ≈øatisfied for the pre≈øent. TIPPOO, on the contrary, was ≈øo perfectly ≈øavage, that cruelty ≈øeemed to be, not only the internal habit of his ≈øoul, but the guide of all his actions, the moving principle of his policy, the rule of his public conduct, and the ≈øource of his private gratification. Like the tyger which, BUFFON tells us, kills the whole flock before he begins to feed, every appetite of his yielded to the more urgent calls of barbarity; and while one drop blood of remained un≈øpilled, one agony uninflicted, one tear un≈øhed, the natural appetites of TIPPOO ≈øtood ≈øu≈øpended, and the luxuries of life courted his enjoyment in vain. Like the hyena which THOMPSON calls the felle≈øt of the fell, the fury of his nature was neither to be controuled by re≈øi≈øtance, nor a≈ø≈øuaged by blandi≈øhments. Aloof from the general order of the workings of Providence, he ≈øtands a ≈øingle in≈øtance, in which the Omnipotent has pre≈øented a glowing living picture, ALL SHADE: not one ray breaks in, to relieve the glomy a≈øpect of the piece; but, di≈øtinct from the whole human race, of him alone it may be ≈øaid, that he never yet di≈øolo≈øed, even for a moment, one ≈øpark of virtue.

From barbarity ≈øo inflexible to tho≈øe taken in the ordinary chance of war, what could I expect if I fell again into his hands‚ÄîI who had been the in≈øtrument of one of his chief Governor's defection ‚Äîwho had, by my negociations, contributed to
deprive him of a Province, and, what perhaps might have had greater weight with him, robbed him of the gratification of a long harboured revenge, by putting his enemy HYAT SAHIB under the protection of the Company? Diabolical vengeance never perhaps met with a ≈øubject of ≈øuch ≈øublime enjoyment, as the torturing of me would have been to this mon≈øter. Couple this then, my FREDERICK, with the fears of SUFFREIN'S doing by me as he had already done by the other Engli≈øh pri≈øoners‚Äî and gue≈øs what my terror and con≈øternation mu≈øt have been at falling into the hands of the French!

Having ≈øtruck our colours to the French frigate, the Captain ordered us to follow her, and ≈øteered to the northward. We obeyed him for ≈øome time: at length night fell; and, a fre≈øh and favourable breeze fortunately aiding the attempt, we put about, ran for Madras, and luckily dropt anchor ≈øafely in the roads. In the e≈øcapes I had hitherto had, there was always ≈øome di≈øagreeable circum≈øtance to alloy the plea≈øure ari≈øing from them‚ÄîIn this in≈øtance, my joy was pure and unqualified; and I looked forward with a rea≈øonable hope that the wor≈øt was all over.

Here I found Lord MACARTNEY governor, ≈øtruggling to ≈øupport the credit of the Company, and directing their affairs through ≈øuch embarra≈ø≈øments and difficulties as made the mo≈øt wi≈øe and temperate de≈øpair of ≈øucce≈øs. So arduous an undertaking as the government of Madras then was, has ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ ely occurred: and a more ≈øucce≈øsful final accompli≈øhment is not to be in≈øtanced. In the ince≈ø≈øant conflicts to which he was expo≈øed, he maintained his po≈øt with inflexible firmne≈øs and unabated energy of mind‚Äîand, in the mo≈øt trying circum≈øtances, di≈øcharged his important duty with zeal, integrity and wi≈ødom. The ≈øtrict di≈øcharge of the duty he owed to his country, rai≈øed clamours again≈øt him among an intere≈øted few in India; but the
united applau≈øes of all parties, on his return to England, ≈øtamped currency on his fame, and has broken the ≈øhafts of detraction.

div.head: LETTER LXII.
div.p: AFTER ≈øo many hazards and hard≈øhips as I had undergone, it was a mo≈øt plea≈øing reflection to find my≈øelf in a ≈øociety compo≈øed of my olde≈øt profe≈ø≈øional connections, and warme≈øt and ≈øincere≈øt friends: but this was a happine≈øs I could not long enjoy: for, being charged with a mi≈ø≈øion from HYAT SAHIB to the Governor-General and Supreme Council, I was con≈øtrained to proceed to Bengal, and accordingly ≈øet ≈øail, for Calcu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a, which I ‚Ä¢ eached in little more than a week, without encountering any accident, or meeting a ≈øingle occurence, worth the relation. Upon my arrival there, Sir JOHN MACPHERSON, who was in the Supreme Council, gave me a kind invitation to live at his hou≈øe, and pre≈øented me to Mr. HASTINGS, with whom I entered into a negociation on behalf of HYAT SAHIB, which will appear by the following letters:

body.head: LETTER TO WARREN HASTINGS, ESQ.
body.p: Indi≈øpo≈øition has put it out of my power, ≈øince the fir≈øt day after my arrival here, to have the honour of paying you my re≈øpects, and of laying before you, for the information of the board, the objects of my mi≈ø≈øion to your ≈øuperintending government.

As the≈øe objects are of public importance, and as ill health may prevent me, for ≈øome time longer from having the honour of waiting upon you, I take the liberty to beg your attention to this addre≈øs.

The great revolution in favour of the India Company upon the we≈øt ≈øide of India, and to which I had the happine≈øs of being in ≈øome little degree in≈øtrumental, has been certainly brought about by the zeal and ≈øpirit of General MATTHEWS; but that officer a≈øcribes to the orders and ≈øupplies of your government the principal merit of the undertaking: he looks to the ≈øame government for ≈øupport in the arrangement which he has made, and may make, for the ≈øecurity of the conquered province.

The hurry in which I left him, and his anxi ‚Ä¢
ty for my ≈øpeedy communication of his ≈øucce≈ø≈øes, gave no time for a formal communication to the Governor-General and cooncil. of the particulars of his ≈øucce≈ø≈øes, and of the arrangements which he wi≈øhed to be adopted. He wrote a ≈øhort account of the fir≈øt to the Pre≈øidency of Fort St. George; and gave me a public letter to the Commander in Chief of the Military E≈øtabli≈øhment of that Pre≈øidency to which I particularly belong, in atte≈øtation of the ≈øervices I rendered in the negociation between him and the Governor of Bidanore, for the ≈øurrender of that capital and province. A copy of that letter I have the plea≈øure to lay before you.

As I was charged with a particular commi≈ø≈øion from HYAT SAHIB, the manager of the Bidanore province, to the Governor-General and council, as appears by his letter, which I had the honour of pre≈øenting to you, General MATHEWS gave me, in verbal in≈øtructions, and memorandums written in his own hand, the particulars of what he wi≈øhed me to repre≈øent to your Government:
he gave me, be≈øides, ≈øhort notes of introduction to two of the members of Government, whom he knew per≈øonally‚Äîreferring them to me for an account of his ≈øituation, and allowing me, I believe, more credit than I de≈øerve, for the ≈øhare I had in contributing to his final acqui≈øition of Bidanore without drawing a ≈øword.

It would be tedious, and more fit for the detail of conver≈øation than of a public addre≈øs, to inform you of the various ≈øteps that led to the ≈øurrender of the capital and province of Bidanore. I had had ≈øeveral conferences with HYAT SAHIB before HYDER'S death, and endeavoured to ≈øugge≈øt to him the advantage which would ari≈øe to him from a revolt in favour of the Company. My efforts in the≈øe conver≈øations ended ultimately in the mo≈øt rigorous di≈øtre≈øs to my≈øelf: I was put in irons, and remained ≈øo for four months, in a ≈øituation only of exi≈øtence without any hopes of ever e≈øcaping. When General MATHEWS had ≈øtormed the Ghauts, HYAT SAHIB ≈øent for me, and, after various ≈øtruggles, and much indeci≈øion, agreed to my proceeding to the Engli≈øh camp; and I conducted General MATHEWS, almo≈øt unattended, into Bidanore. HYAT SAHIB at length agreed to ≈øubmit: but as, in his various conver≈øations with me before and after that event, he made a very particular di≈øtinction between the government of Bombay and the chief government of the Engli≈øh in Indo≈øtan, ≈øo he propo≈øed that I ≈øhould immediately depart, after he had given up the place and all the forts of the Province, with a letter to you, to obtain your ≈øanction to me to his arrangements with the Engli≈øh General.

The≈øe arrangements were not even clearly defined before my departure; and ≈øo anxious was he for my ≈øpeedy arrival at Calcutta, that he only
gave me the general propo≈øitions that are contained in his letter.

Permit me here to ob≈øerve, that it is by the treatment which HYAT SAHIB meets with, that the other chiefs of HYDER'S country will e≈øtimate the advantage of abandoning the intere≈øts of TIPPOO SAHIB, or will confirm their dependence upon him. TIPPOO was prevented by his father from all intercour≈øe with the Governors of his provinces, or any interference in country affairs; ≈øo that tho≈øe left in charge at his father's death are ≈øtranger's to him, and are men to whom he has little attachment. He is, be≈øides, con≈øidered to be of a cruel di≈øpo≈øition. His father was cruel upon a political principle: he is thought to be ≈øo from nature.

The unfortunate differences about money which aro≈øe in General MATHEWS'S camp, and of which you will probably hear from the Pre≈øidency of Bombay, took up much of the General's time, and may have retarded his operations: however, his ≈øucce≈øs in the reduction of Mangalo ‚Ä¢ e gives a ≈øecurity to his conque≈øts. The revenues of the Bidanore Province are about twenty lacks of pagodas per annum.

The particular ≈øituation of the capital merits attention. It is placed in a valley of con≈øiderable extent in circumference: according to the be≈øt ob≈øervation I could make, there is an a≈øcent to it, from all ≈øides, of near ≈øeven miles: it can only be approached by four roads, which are cut among the hills, and which were judiciou≈øly fortified with great pains by HYDER: woods, to the depth of many miles, are a frontier round its ≈økirts; and where the≈øe admitted a pa≈ø≈øage, HYDER took the precaution to plant bamboos and thorns‚Äî≈øo that I have little fear but that General MATHEWS will be able to defend the≈øe pa≈ø≈øes; and as for provi≈øions, and military ≈øtores
of all kinds, that were found in Bidanore, of the latter particularly, what, according to General MATHEWS'S own declaration, would equip nine ≈øuch armies as his.

Cundapore is the next ≈øea-port to Bidanore, and is di≈øtant about fifty miles: Mangalore is di≈øtant about a hundred miles. The road leading from Mangalore joins with that from Cundapore, where the a≈øcent of the hills commence: another road from Bidanore leads to Seringapatam, and a fourth into the Marhatta country.

It was from the lower country, along the ≈øeacoa≈øt, between Onore and Mangalore, which is watered by many rivers, and is the be≈øt cultivated country I ever ≈øaw, that HYDER got the greate≈øt part of his provi≈øions for his army in the Carnatic; and, independent of the advantages which the Company have gained by the acqui≈øition of the≈øe countries, the con≈øequent lo≈ø≈øes of the My≈øoreans are immen≈øe, and ≈øuch as will di≈øable them from a≈ø≈øi≈øting the French in the Carnatic.

It becomes not an officer of my rank to make any ob≈øervations that relate to the conduct of the different governments of my employers; but I am obliged to ob≈øerve, in ju≈øtice to HYAT SAHIB'S declaration to me, that he will not rely upon any arrangement made in his favour by the Governor and council of Bombay, unle≈øs he has a ≈øpeedy an≈øwer to his letter from this government. He has reque≈øted me to return with that an≈øwer, and with the ≈øanction of the Governor-General to the cowl given to him by General MATHEWS. Though I am worn down by my ≈øufferings in pri≈øon, and my health can ≈øcarcely enable me to be carried by land, I am ready to undertake this ≈øervice; for I know it is the greate≈øt I may ever have it in my power to re ‚Ä¢
der to the company and to my country.

My return to the other coa≈øt with a favourable an≈øwer to HYAT SAHIB, will be the ≈øignal to
other Chiefs to throw off the yoke of TIPPOO; and if Colonel LONG has made any progre≈øs in the Coimbatore country, or that General MATHEWS has not been too ≈øeverely pre≈ø≈øed by TIPPOO, I may arrive upon the other coa≈øt in time to be of real u≈øe to the company.

I know, Honourable Sir, the liberal and great ≈øy≈øtem of your admini≈øtration: I will not, therefore, point out any little circum≈øtances about the footing upon which I ≈øhould return to HYAT SAHIB, or remain upon the other coa≈øt. I wi≈øh only to be rewarded by my employers as I am ≈øucce≈øsful; and I ≈øhall leave it to your goodne≈øs, and to your di≈øtingui≈øhed zeal for the public propriety, to give me any in≈øtructions for my conduct, or to charge me with any advices to General MATHEWS, as you may think proper.
I hope you will pardon this long and irregular addre≈øs, and honour me by communicating any part of it that you may think worthy of communication to the gentlemen of the council.

closer.signed: I have the honour to be, &c. &c. DONALD CAMPBELL.

postscript.p: P. S. When you are at lei≈øure, and I am able to have the honour of attending you, I would wi≈øh to communicate to you a more particular detail of my conver≈øation with HYAT SAHIB‚Äî what General MATHEWS'S hopes of ≈øupport from this government were, and the future plans he then meditated‚Äîand my ideas of the mea≈øures that ≈øhould be pur≈øued by the Pre≈øidency of Fort St. George, to ≈øupport General MATHEWS, and improve the advantages he has gained.

body.head: LETTER FROM HYAT SAHIB, ALLUDED TO IN THE FOREGOING.
body.p: I have directed the affairs of the Soobeh of Hydernagur for ≈øome years pa≈øt, on the part of the NAVVAUB HYDER. When lately attacked by the victorious forces of the Engli≈øh under the command of General MATHEWS, I oppo≈øed him, and fulfilled my duty in every re≈øpect: but ≈øeeing the ≈øuperior fortune and force of the Engli≈øh, and receiving propo≈øals for peace from General MATHEWS, by the≈øe circum≈øtances, but more e≈øpecially by the per≈øua≈øions of Captain CAMPBELL, the ≈øon of Colonel CAMPBELL, who was formerly at Chinaputtan, I was induced to come to terms, and delivered up to General MATHEWS the trea≈øury, property, ≈øtores and keys of the ≈øorts of this country. If I had been di≈øpo≈øed, I had it in my power to have appropriated this collected wealth to other purpo≈øes; but, from a regard to the high fortune of the KING of ENGLAND, and the uprightne≈øs and integrity of the Engli≈øh people, I have included my≈øelf in the number of your ≈øervants, and have determined, with the utmo≈øt ≈øincerity and purity of heart, to ≈øerve you well and faithfully. By the ble≈ø≈øing of GOD, under your au≈øpices, my endeavours towards the well and full performance of my duty ≈øhall be ten-fold greater than heretofore; and as General MATHEWS intends to proceed to Seringputtam, your loyal ≈øervant will a≈ø≈øi≈øt, to the utmo≈øt of his ability and power. You will be fully informed on this ≈øubject by Captain CAMPBELL. Honour, and favour, and reward, mu≈øt flow from you.

From the time of your fir≈øt e≈øtabli≈øhment in this country to the pre≈øent period, the engagements of
the Engli≈øh have been ≈øacredly performed and adhered to; nor have they been wanting in their protection of the honor and dignity of the Surdars of Bengal, and other places. I hope, from your favour and benevolence, that you will i≈ø≈øue your commands to General MATHEWS, to favour me with all due kindne≈øs and attention. I have taken ≈øhelter under the ≈øhadow of your benevolence. Captain CAMPBELL has ≈øhewn me great kindne≈øs in this re≈øpect, and, by encouraging me to hope for your favour, has led me to become your ≈øervant. You will be fully informed of the ≈øtate of affairs in this quarter by Captain CAMPBELL'S letters.

body.head: LETTER TO WARREN HASTINGS, ESQ
body.p: Some time ago, I did my≈øelf the honour of writing to you, on the ≈øubject of my mi≈ø≈øion from HYAT SAHIB to his government.

It is with plea≈øure I now under≈øtand that you have come to the re≈øolution of ≈øending an an≈øwer to his letter. I cannot help delivering it as my opinion, that a decided and avowed protection granted to him from this government, will be productive of great public utility: but ≈øhould you, and the other gentlemen of the council, think proper to decline this, from motives be≈øt known to your≈øelves, and of which I ≈øhall not pretend to judge, I beg leave humbly to repre≈øent, that the ≈øooner HYAT SAHIB'S letter is acknowledged, the more ≈øatisfactory it will be to
him, and the more efficacious in its probable good con≈øequences.

I am ready and anxious to proceed immediately to the other coa≈øt with the an≈øwer to HYAT SAHIB, and ≈øhall take the liberty of hoping that you will give me in≈øtructions to remain ≈øome time with him, that he may have an opportunity of tran≈ømitting, through me, any communication that he may wi≈øh to e≈øtabli≈øh with this government. I have the honour to be, with the greate≈øt re≈øpect,

div.p: After ≈øome delay, I received in≈øtructions, together with a letter from Mr. HASTINGS for HYAT, with which I ≈øet off in order to deliver it into his own hands, as follows:

body.head: LETTER TO CAPTAIN DONALD CAMPBELL.
body.p:
I have it in command from the Honourable the Governor-General and council, to tran≈ømit
you the inclo≈øed an≈øwer from the Gevernor-General to the letter which you brought from HYAT SAHIB, the Fou≈ødar of Bidanore, to this government, upon the occa≈øion of his ≈øurrendering that country to the company. As you propo≈øe to return to Bidanore, the Board reque≈øt that you will deliver this an≈øwer in per≈øon to HYAT SAHIB, with the a≈ø≈øurances from them of every protection and ≈øupport which the eminent ≈øervices rendered by him to the company give him ≈øo good a right to expect, and which they have it in their power to grant; and you will acquaint him, that they have further agreed to recommend him in ≈øuch terms to the Honourable the Court of Directors, as may encourage him to hope for every attention from their ju≈øtice.

Con≈øidering the great importance of the acqui≈øition of Bidanore to the company, its proportionable di≈øadvantage to the enemy, and the magnitude of the object to be obtained by holding out every po≈ø≈øible incitement and encouragement to the Managers of the My≈øore country, to throw off a new and un≈øettled dependence on the enemy's government, in order to obtain a more ≈øecure and beneficial tenure from the company's po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, the Board are the more read ‚Ä¢

It will be at your option, either to return immediately with HYAT SAHIB'S an≈øwer to the Governor-General's letter, if you ≈øhall deem it of ≈øufficient con≈øequence to require it, or to remain with him, if you conceive that your re≈øidence there for any time will be more conducive to the public intere≈øts; but, in either ca≈øe, you are de≈øired to report the particulars of your reception

div.p: It would be unpardonable in me to let this occa≈øion pa≈øs, without expre≈ø≈øing the high ≈øen≈øe I entertain of Mr. HASTINGS'S politene≈øs, and Sir JOHN MACPHERSON'S kindne≈øs and ho≈øpitality, during my ≈øtay at, Calcutta. As to Mr. HASTINGS, in his public capacity, it would be pre≈øumptuous and injudicious to ≈øay much, as he now ≈øtands for the judgment of the highe≈øt tribunal in this country. My own ob≈øervation leads me to con≈øider him as a man of ≈øound, acute and brilliant talents, and of a va≈øt and comprehen≈øive mind‚Äîof manners ≈øociable, amiable, meek and unaffected‚Äîand of a di≈øpo≈øition truly benevolent. His ≈øuperior knowledge of the political intere≈øts of Indo≈øtan, and particularly of the affairs of the Ea≈øt India company, has never been que≈øtioned; and, if the ≈øuffrage of the people of India may be allowed to decide, his conduct as Governor-General, though, like every thing human, intermixed with error, was, on the whole, great and laudable‚Äîfor I declare I ≈øcarcely ever heard a man in India, Native or European, cen≈øure him, although he was often the ≈øubject of conver≈øation with all per≈øons and in all companies in the Ea≈øt.

The ≈øocial virtues of Sir JOHN MACPHERSON are ≈øo well known, that it would be ≈øuperfluous to notice them. The ≈øame friend≈øhip and ho≈øpitality I experienced in his hou≈øe, has been ≈øhared by many, who are not backward in doing him ample ju≈øtice on that head. But his conduct during his
≈øhort admini≈øtration can be known only by tho≈øe who make the political concerns of India a ≈øubject of ≈øtudious attention: To enter into a detail of his various wi≈øe regulations for the re≈øtoration of the company's affairs, would be de≈øtructive of the end I propo≈øe, which is, by a conci≈øe and ≈øimple ≈øummary of the whole, to render a fair picture of his admini≈øtration ≈øo clear as to be under≈øtood by any per≈øon, however ignorant he may be of the politics of that country, and ≈øo brief as not to di≈øcourage the reading of it.

Sir JOHN MACPHERSON took the reins of government into his hands on the fir≈øt of February, 1785. He found the company's revenues dimini≈øhed, and their expenditure increa≈øed, by the continual claims of Proprietors, Directors, and Mini≈øters, to a ≈øhare in the patronage of Mr. HASTINGS‚Äîand a public debt accumulating to an enormous amount. He therefore ≈øaw the nece≈ø≈øity of putting in practice every expedient po≈ø≈øible, and trying every experiment that the ≈øtate of the country ≈øugge≈øted, as likely to promote an increa≈øe of the revenue, a diminution of the public expenditure, and a liquidation of the debt. He, therefore, on the fourteenth day of his admini≈øtration, commenced a reform, which he continued with indefatigable zeal and indu≈øtry to introduce through the various departments of government‚Äîand, beginning with him≈øelf, di≈øcharged his body-guards. While he was thus employed in India, the Company and Parliament in England were unremittingly engaged con≈øidering and molding into ≈øhape a ≈øy≈øtem of reform al≈øo; and, extraordinary as it may appear, the fact is, that the ≈øagacity of Mr. MACPHERSON had adopted by anticipation, and actually reduced to practice, the identical ≈øpeculative reforms which the Parliament and Company were proceeding upon in England; and the general plan of reform which pa≈ø≈øed the court of
directors on the eleventh of April, 1785, had been actually carried into execution by Sir JOHN MACPHERSON in Bengal, in the months of February, March and April, 1785. He made arrangements for the diffu≈øion of knowledge‚Äîe≈øtabli≈øhed the ≈øettlement of Pulo Penang, or Prince of Wales's I≈øland‚Äî≈øettled the bank of Calcutta on a firm ba≈øis ‚Äîregulated the markets‚Äîand, by a plan of his own conception, ≈øecured the Company from the accu≈øtomed fraudulent compo≈øitions with Zemindars, by bonding their balances, and making the bonds cancelable only by the Court of Directors. In fine, he introduced and carried into effect a ≈øy≈øtem of reform which had a mo≈øt ≈øudden and ≈øalutary effect on the Briti≈øh affairs in India; and in an admini≈øtration of only eighteen months, he had the felicity to perceive the fruits of his wi≈ødom and indu≈øtry maturing‚Äîto receive that be≈øt of earthly rewards, the e≈øteem and applau≈øe of his fellow-citizens‚Äîand to be honoured by the be≈øt of Sovereigns with the dignity of a Baronet.

While I was at Sir JOHN MACPHERSON'S hou≈øe, I happened, in conver≈øation one day with Mr. MACAULY, Sir JOHN'S Secretary, to be talking over ≈øome part of my adventures; and found to my a≈øtoni≈øhment, that he had, in his route to India, accidentally hired the very ≈øervant whom I had lo≈øt at Trie≈øte by ≈øending him for letters to Venice; and Mr. MACAULY a≈ø≈øured me, that he found him po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of all the good qualities I had expected to meet in him: but the poor fellow had died before my arrival at Calcutta, to my great mortification and di≈øappointment.

As the ≈øea≈øon in which I was to leave Calcutta was very unfavourable for a voyage by ≈øea, and the coa≈øt thereabouts is one of the mo≈øt inho≈øpitable in the world, I ≈øet off by land for Madras, and in my way had an opportunity of ≈øurveying that curious and grote≈øque monument of ≈øuper≈øtitious folly, called
the Jagranaut Pagoda. It is an immen≈øe, barbarous ≈øtructure, of a kind of pyramidal form, embelli≈øhed with devices cut in ≈øtone-work, not more ≈øingular than di≈øgu≈øting. Chri≈øtian idolators, in forming types and figures of divine beings, always endeavour to repre≈øent them with per≈øonal beauty, as proportionate to their divine nature as human ≈økill can make it. Tho≈øe Pagans, on the contrary, in forming their idols, ca≈øt out every ve≈øtige of beauty‚Äîevery thing that, by the con≈øent of mankind, is ≈øuppo≈øed to convey plea≈øing ≈øen≈øations; and, in their place, ≈øub≈øtitute the mo≈øt extravagant, unnatural deformity, the mo≈øt loath≈øome na≈øtine≈øs, the mo≈øt di≈øgu≈øting ob≈øcenity. It is not in language to convey an adequate idea of their temples and idols; and if it was, no purpo≈øe could be an≈øwered by it, only the excitement of painful and abominable ≈øen≈øations. To keep pace with the figures of their idols, a chief Bramin, by ≈øome accur≈øed artificial means, (by herbs, I believe), has brought to a mo≈øt unnatural form, and enormous dimen≈øions, that which decency forbids me to mention; and the pure and ≈øpotle≈øs women, who from infancy have been ≈øhut up from the ≈øight of men, even of their brothers, are brought to ki≈øs this di≈øgu≈øting and mis≈øhapen mon≈øter, under the prepo≈øterous belief that it promotes fecundity.

In this Pagoda ≈øtands the figure of Jagranaut, (their god under Brama); and a ≈øightly figure it is truly!‚Äînothing more than a black ≈øtone, in an irregular pyramidal form, having two rich diamonds in the top by way of eyes, and a no≈øe and mouth painted red. For this god, five hundred prie≈øts are daily employed in boiling food, which, as he ≈øeldom eats it, they doubtle≈øs convert to their own u≈øe in the evening.

I ≈øtopped at Vizagapatnam for a few days with Mr. RUSSEL, who was chief of that place. His ≈øtyle of living was ≈øo exactly ≈øimilar to that of an
elegant family re≈øiding at their country-hou≈øe in England, that I felt my≈øelf more happy and comfortable than I had been ≈øince my arrival in India; and that happine≈øs was much increa≈øed by meeting Mr. MAXTON, who was married to Mr. RUSSEL'S daughter. This gentleman and I had, when mere boys, been ≈øhipmates on our fir≈øt going out to India: a warm friend≈øhip took place between us, which has met with no interruption, but rather increa≈øed from lap≈øe of time, and greater habits of intimacy. To ≈øee a man whom I ≈øo entirely e≈øteemed, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the mo≈øt perfect dome≈øtic felicity, and ≈øurrounded by a number of amiable connections and friends, was to me a ≈øubject of the mo≈øt plea≈øing contemplation.

div.head: LETTER LXIII.
div.p: LEAVING Vizagapatam, I took my route along the coa≈øt, and arrived at Ma≈øulipatam, where I heard rumours of the unfortunate fate of General MATHEWS. This threw ≈øuch a damp upon my ≈øpirits, that all the ho≈øpitality and kindne≈øs of Mr. DANIEL, the chief, could ≈øcarcely rai≈øe me from de≈øpondence; and on my arrival at Madras, I found the whole amply confirmed.

As HYAT SAHIB'S affair yet remaining un≈øettled, and I con≈øidered my≈øelf in a degree pledged to obtain him ≈øome ≈øatisfaction for his ≈øervices in ≈øurrendering the province of Bidanore, and to fulfil my engagements with him and the Supreme Council, I determined to proceed to Bombay, notwith≈øtanding the di≈øa≈øter of General MATHEWS, which had entirely cru≈øhed all my private pro≈øpects in that quarter, and to co-operate with HYAT SAHIB
in ≈øuch mea≈øures as might yet remain to us for promoting the public good. I left Madras, therefore, and pro≈øecuted my journey without any material interruption until I reached Palamcotah, where the chagrin ari≈øing from my various di≈øappointments, co-operating with fatigue and climate, threw me into a fit of ≈øickne≈øs, which confined me to my bed for five or ≈øix weeks. Upon recovering a little, I crawled on to Anjengo, where, at the hou≈øe of Mr. HUTCHINSON, the Re≈øident, (who treated me with cordial kindne≈øs), I waited for an opportunity of getting to Bombay, and during that time laid in a ≈øtock of ≈øtrength and ≈øpirits: at length a Europe ≈øhip touched at Anjengo on her way to Bombay, I obtained a pa≈ø≈øage and proceeded.

At Bombay I found HYAT SAHIB, it having been deemed expedient to ≈øend him away from Bidanore on the approach of TIPPOO with his army, where I received from him a confirmation of what I have ≈øtated re≈øpecting General MATHEWS receiving only two lacks of rupees and a necklace. And now, as peace was negociating between us and TIPPOO, and my remaining on the Malabar coa≈øt could be of little u≈øe, I determined to return to the Carnatic. And here I have an incident to add to the many di≈øagreeable occurrences of my life, in which, with intentions the mo≈øt innocent, I was made the ≈øubject of obloquy and unmerited ≈øcandal.

Ju≈øt at the time I was leaving Bombay, a young lady, the daughter of a per≈øon formerly of high rank in India, and now a member of Parliament, but who≈øe name it would be u≈øele≈øs to mention, wi≈øhed to return to the Carnatic; and I, at the reque≈øt of her≈øelf, and another lady with whom ≈øhe lived, unguardedly took charge of her during the journey. Before our departure, I reflected upon the difficulties and impropriety of this ≈øtep,
and communicated my ideas to the ladies, who, in≈øtead of li≈øtening to the objections I ≈øtarted, pre≈ø≈øed me to fulfil my promi≈øe: I con≈øented, purely from principles of politene≈øs and good-nature. During the cour≈øe of our journey, ≈øhe unfolded to me, of her own accord, certain acts of cruelty and inju≈øtice ≈øhe had ≈øuffered from her father, at the in≈øtigation of her mother-in-law, with a ≈øtory of her innocence having fallen, and her reputation having been de≈øtroyed, by a connection of the lady under who≈øe charge ≈øhe was, and who for that rea≈øon had pre≈ø≈øed her departure with me; and added, ≈øhe was ≈øo di≈øgu≈øted with India, that ≈øhe determined to quit it; and entreated me to a≈ø≈øi≈øt her in the accompli≈øhment of her wi≈øhes. I di≈øapproved, in the mo≈øt unqualified terms, of her project‚Äîgave her the be≈øt and mo≈øt di≈øintere≈øted advice‚Äîand, through the whole di≈øagreeable bu≈øine≈øs which was impo≈øed upon me, acted merely with a view to her honour and happine≈øs; and ≈øeveral of the mo≈øt re≈øpectable people in Palamcotah, where ≈øhe pa≈ø≈øed ≈øome time, and at Madras, where ≈øhe afterwards re≈øided, could atte≈øt the delicacy of my conduct towards her, as well as the concern and intere≈øt I took in every thing that was likely to be of advantage to her.

This is a fair ≈øtatement of the matter; and yet, on account of it, I was mo≈øt infamou≈øly ≈øcandalized; and the ≈øcandal reached even the ears of my father, whom, however, I ≈øoon ≈øatisfied on that head. But that which ≈øtung me to the quick was the conduct of ≈øome of my own relations, (who, if they even could not ju≈øtify or approve, ought at lea≈øt to have been ≈øilent), in becoming the mo≈øt virulent of my detractors‚Äîthough, when the character of tho≈øe very relations had on former occa≈øions been reflected upon, I ≈øtood up and defended them at the imminent hazard of my life. Such conduct appeared to me mo≈øt atrocious; for, whether
from affection, ≈øelfi≈øhne≈øs, or pride, I always ≈øtrenuou≈øly ≈øupported my relations, if I heard them traduced in their ab≈øence‚Äîand, when I was not able to ju≈øtify their proceedings, at lea≈øt ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed the conver≈øation. To a man who had uniformly acted ≈øo. were there even no reciprocation of family affection, mutual ju≈øtice demanded different treatment from that I experienced, which could have ≈øprung only from depravity of heart, poverty of intellect, and the mo≈øt abject meanne≈øs of ≈øpirit. And what is remarkable on this, as well as on other occa≈øions, tho≈øe who had been under the greate≈øt obligation to my father and my≈øelf, were the mo≈øt inveterate.

On the death of my father, looking over his papers in the pre≈øence of the Deputy Sheriff of Argyll, and three other gentlemen, we met with a letter on the ≈øubject from the young lady's father to mine, reflecting in a gro≈øs manner on my character. I directly wrote to that gentleman, explaining the whole affair, and demanding ju≈øtice to be done to my reputation. Upon an ecclaireci≈ø≈øement of the matter, he wrote to me a complete apology, acknowledging that he had acted on that occa≈øion through mi≈ørepre≈øentation, and had too ea≈øily given credit to ill-founded reports; and ≈øaying, that as the letter in que≈øtion had, by the peru≈øal of the Deputy Sheriff and other gentlemen, in ≈øome mea≈øure become a matter of public notoriety, he thought it incumbent on him to make that apology, and to expre≈øs his ≈øincere regret for any detriment I might have ≈øu≈øtained, by his yielding unguardedly to a ≈øudden impul≈øe of pa≈ø≈øion, cau≈øed, as he was then perfectly convinced, by mi≈øinformation.
Thus was my character at once cleared of a calumny which the indu≈øtrious villany of a few had contrived to propagate through every ≈øpot of the earth where I was known.

This ≈øtory may ≈øerve as an in≈øtructive le≈ø≈øon to you, my FREDERICK, to avoid, in the very fir≈øt in≈øtance, any connection with women that in the probable cour≈øe of things can lead to private acts of confidence: they are at be≈øt indi≈øcreet‚Äîtend, as in this ca≈øe, to make a man a dupe‚Äîand never fail to lead to ≈øcandal and reproach. You will al≈øo, from the letter of the lady's father, found eight or ten years after it was written among my father's papers, ≈øee the impropriety and hazard of committing your thoughts incautiou≈øly to paper. I have known it frequently, as in this in≈øtance, end in mortification and regret.

Before quitting entirely the Malabar coa≈øt, I took a trip to Surat, which amply repaid me for my trouble. It ≈øurpa≈ø≈øes any part of India for extent and variety of commerce, for populous ≈øtreets and ≈øuburbs, and for a continually moving ≈øcene of opulence. For a more minute account of it, I refer you to the Abb√© RAYNAL, who, though not generally accurate, is ≈øo elegant, that you will be able, from his de≈øcription, to form a lively conception of the place, and its ≈øingular cu≈øtoms.

Here I was received in a very friendly manner by Mr. SETON. And indeed I may now once for all declare, that at every place where I ≈øtopped, and every po≈øt I pa≈ø≈øed, from my leaving England till my return, I experienced the mo≈øt kind and liberal reception, and the mo≈øt a≈ø≈øiduous attention: my wants of every kind, whether of ve≈ø≈øels, boats, guards of Sepoys, letters of introduction, &c. being ≈øupplied by anticipation, I had ≈øcarcely occa≈øion to make a reque≈øt, or expre≈øs a wi≈øh; nor was the attention ≈øhewn to the public ≈øervice le≈øs than that which was manife≈øted for my private convenience. To kindne≈øs ≈øo truly con≈øolatory as it then was to me, I never look back without ≈øentiments of u ‚Ä¢
bounded gratitude and unfeigned acknowledg „Äà‚óä„Äâ .

My journeys by land in India after my ≈øhipwreck, independent of long voyages by ≈øea, amounted to more than three thou≈øand miles. After getting back to Madras, my health being materially injured, I re≈øolved to return to England‚ñ™ but, having ≈øeen almo≈øt all the Company's po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, I felt a curio≈øity to ≈øee China, and determined to make that my way. To render this route more agreeable to me, Lord MACARTNEY, in addition to his other favours, gave me the following hand≈øome letter of introduction to Mr. PIGOU, the Company's chief ≈øupercargo at Canton:

body.p: This letter will be delivered to you by Captain DONA ‚Ä¢ D CAMPBELL, of this E≈øtabli≈øhment‚Äîa gentleman who has ≈øignalized him≈øelf on many occa≈øions, but more particularly by his ability and addre≈øs in accompli≈øhing the ≈øurrender of the fort of Bidanore, at which place he had been long a pri≈øoner. His ill ≈øtate of health contracted there, renders a voyage to China, perhaps to Europe, ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary. Should he remain any time at your Settlement, I ≈øhall be much obliged to you for any attention and civility ≈øhewn to him; and I ≈øhall be happy, on any occa≈øion you may afford me, of returning your polite attention to an officer of ≈øo much merit as Captain CAMPBELL, and of proving how much I am,

div.p:
I had al≈øo a letter to Mr. FREEMAN, another Supercargo there; by whom, as well as by Mr.
PIGOU, I was treated with great politene≈øs; and Mr. FREEMAN being obliged to leave Canton, and go to Macao, for the recovery of his health, invited me to accompany him there. I availed my≈øelf of the opportunity: and, as we went all along through the rivers, had an opportunity of ≈øeeing more of the country than many of the Europeans who vi≈øit that country. With the ob≈øervations which I made in the cour≈øe of this excur≈øion and my re≈øidence at Canton, I would furni≈øh you, but that Lord MACARTNEY'S emba≈ø≈øy is ju≈øt returned from that country; and there is every rea≈øon to hope that he, or ≈øome of the gentlemen who attended him, and who po≈ø≈øe≈øs ≈øuperior abilities and more ample materials, will favour the public with a much more perfect account than mine could po≈ø≈øibly be.

While I remained at Canton, a very di≈øagreeable rupture took place between the Factory and the Chine≈øe. An Engli≈øh ≈øhip lying at Wampoa, in ≈øaluting, ≈øhattered a Chine≈øe boat; by which accident, two men in it were much hurt with the ≈øplinters, and one of them died of his wounds ≈øoon after. The matter was clearly explained to the Mandarins; and they ≈øeemed to be ≈øatisfied that it was merely an accident. A few days after, the Supercorgo of the ≈øhip was forcibly ≈øeized, and carried into the city: the Council met, and determined to ≈øend for the ≈øailors from the ≈øhips; and in the evening after dark, fifteen or ≈øixteen, boats, with four or five hundred men attempted, in an irregular manner, to come up to Canton‚Äîwere fired upon by the Chine≈øe boats and forts in pa≈ø≈øing, and, with a few men wounded, were compelled to retreat. Nothing could ≈øurpa≈øs the con≈øternation and indeci≈øion of the Council; and after the mo≈øt humiliating language, they were obliged to appea≈øe the Chine≈øe, and ≈øettle the affair by giving up the gunner of the ≈øhip to their re≈øentment.

On the 29th December, 1784, I embarked in the Pon≈øborne Ea≈øt-Indiaman, Captain HAMMET, in which I had come from Madras to China; and, after a tolerable voyage of five months and two days, got on board a fi≈øhing boat off Falmouth, and was put on ≈øhore there, having been exactly four years and five days from England.

Such was my impatience to ≈øee you, that I wrote from Falmouth for you to meet me at Bath. We arrived there the ≈øame day: and never in my life did I experience ≈øuch tran≈øports as in fir≈øt pre≈ø≈øing you to my bo≈øom; I found you all that my heart could wi≈øh; and I mu≈øt, in ju≈øtice to my opinion, aver, that not one action of your life has tended ≈øince to give me a moment's pain: on the contrary, I have every rea≈øon to be ≈øatisfied that my ≈øanguine hopes of you will be realized. The turn of your thoughts and actions have been vigilantly watched and clo≈øely examined by me; and from your affection to my≈øelf and your mother, your gentle deportment to my dome≈øtics, your frankne≈øs and candour with your brother and ≈øchool-fellows‚Äîeven from your fondne≈øs for your favourite dog Pompey, and frequent ≈øilent contemplations of the etchings of his countenance, I have drawn the mo≈øt plea≈øing pre≈øages of purity and innocence of heart, ≈øweetne≈øs of temper, and refined honour and genero≈øity. If it plea≈øes GOD to ≈øpare your life, and ≈øtrengthen your con≈øtitution, I ≈øhall ≈øtill be the happie≈øt of men, notwith≈øtanding the inroad made upon my feelings by the hard≈øhips and afflictions I had undergone, of which many aro≈øe from unavoidable accident, and ≈øome from malignant and unnatural per≈øecution, ari≈øing from ba≈øe envy, dictated by cowardly revenge. I do not wi≈øh you to know who the wretches are: I only wi≈øh you to know that ≈øuch dete≈øtable pa≈ø≈øions do exi≈øt in human nature‚Äî that, warned by their wickedne≈øs to me, you
may, in your progre≈øs through life, be cautious, temperate and guarded.

Another thing I am anxious to impre≈øs upon the mind, particularly, of your brother JOHN, is the danger of a warm, impetuous temper. Many of the hazards and difficulties of my life aro≈øe from the predominance of a fiery ≈øpirit, and an ungovernable, mi≈øtaken ambition. A ≈øingle in≈øtance will ≈øerve to ≈øhew it. When I was under the command of Captain, afterwards General MATHEWS, in his regiment of cavalry, being cantoned at a place called Tuckolam, in the neighbourhood of exten≈øive woods, information was brought us that wild bulls infe≈øted the neighbouring villages, and had killed ≈øome people: we prepared to enter the wood, and de≈øtroy, if po≈ø≈øible, the≈øe ferocious animals, which had become the terror and de≈øtruction of the contiguous country. The origin of tho≈øe wild herds was this‚ÄîFrom time immemorial, a religious cu≈øtom had prevailed among the Pagan inhabitants, of offering a calf to the wood upon the accompli≈øhment of any favourite purpo≈øe, ≈øuch as the ≈øafe delivery of his wife, or the obtaining an employment, &c. In proce≈øs of time, tho≈øe calves bred, and became numerous and incredibly fierce. Independent of protecting the defencele≈øs natives, it was in it≈øelf a mo≈øt intere≈øting kind of hunting. The mode of doing it was this‚ÄîA large party, well mounted, galloping in a body up to a great flock, and marking out the fierce≈øt champion of the whole, attacked him with ≈øwords and pi≈øtols. One day, a bull which was wounded, and thereby rendered more fierce, though not le≈øs vigorous, got po≈øted in ≈øome thick bu≈øhes, in ≈øuch a manner as to be approached only in front: a whim of the mo≈øt extravagant kind came into my head, ≈øugge≈øted by vain-glory and youthful fire‚ÄîI thought it ungenerous for ≈øo many to attack him at once; and, wi≈øhing to have the credit of ≈øubduing him, I di≈ømounted
from my hor≈øe, and attacked him with a pike: I ≈øoon, however, had cau≈øe to repent this ra≈øh and unwarrantable ≈øtep; it had nearly been fatal to me‚Äîfor the bull ≈øoon threw the pike into the air, and, had it not been for the very gallant exertions of my brother officers, who rode in upon him, and re≈øcued me at the moment that the brute's horns had touched my coat, I mu≈øt have been killed. An Indian officer, who was in my troop, particularly di≈øtingui≈øhed him≈øelf, at the imminent hazard of his life, the bull having to≈ø≈øed his hor≈øe and him≈øelf to a di≈øtance from his horns. At this time I was but eighteen years of age, and had not the judgment to reflect, that if I had been killed, my fate would be attended with only pity or ≈øcorn for my folly; whereas, had I ≈øucceeded, the whole reward of my danger would have been the u≈øele≈øs applau≈øe of ≈øome young≈øters, idle and incen≈øiderate as my≈øelf‚Äîwhile my ra≈øhne≈øs would have been reprobated by every man who≈øe good opinion was worth enjoying. One or two people who were pre≈øent at the time, are now living in great repute in England. We ≈øucceeded, however, in driving tho≈øe wild cattle into the interior rece≈ø≈øes of the wood, dividing the fle≈øh of tho≈øe we killed among ≈øuch of the poor S ‚Ä¢ poys as would eat it, and thereby rendered e≈ø≈øential ≈øervice to the contiguous villages.

Often when I have heard, in coffee-hou≈øes and play-hou≈øes, ≈øome of our ≈øporting ≈øparks boa≈øting of their prowe≈øs over a timid hare or a feeble fox, I could not help recollecting with re≈øpect the hunters of India, who cha≈øe the de≈øtructive mon≈øters of the fore≈øt‚Äîthe boar, the tyger, the hyena, the bull, or the buffalo; and, while they ≈øteel the nerves, animate the courage, and, by habitual deeds of pith, fit them≈øelves for war, ‚Ä¢ ender e≈ø≈øential ≈øervice to their fellow creatures, and ≈øave the lives and property of thou≈øands. Such greatne≈øs of ≈øpirit,
under the controul of good ≈øen≈øe, and the direction of prudence, mu≈øt render a man re≈øpectable ‚Äîbut, if not managed with di≈øcretion, leaves a man no other prai≈øe than that of a magnanimous madman. Take every opportunity, my dear FREDERICK, of inculcating the≈øe precepts in the mind of your brother: the natural warmth of his temper often makes me fearful of the mi≈øchievous con≈øequences which I have my≈øelf too often experienced ‚Äîthough, I thank GOD, it never ≈øtimulated me to revenge, or to a premeditated intention of injur ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ g any one.

I have already ≈øaid more than once, that I have a mo≈øt perfect conviction your amiable di≈øpo≈øition will en≈øure to you the love of mankind; but it will at the ≈øame time ≈øubject you to many impo≈øitions‚Äî to gaurd again≈øt which, a great ≈øhare of ≈øternne≈øs is ≈øometimes nece≈ø≈øary: there is, be≈øides, a certain degree of fortitude ab≈øolutely requi≈øite to give lu≈øtre to a gentle di≈øpo≈øition; without it, meekne≈øs is thought timidity‚Äîmode≈øty, weakne≈øs ‚Äîand the charming mildne≈øs of the forgiving heart, abu≈øed as the pitiful re≈øource of abject apprehen≈øio ‚Ä¢ and a mean ≈øpirit. There are times, therefore, when the wickedne≈øs of men, and the cu≈øtoms of the world, make it nece≈ø≈øary to lay a≈øide the lamb, and a≈ø≈øume the lion. EUROPE at this moment pre≈øents an awful and alarming cri≈øis. In a neighbouring country, the conduct of the higher cla≈ø≈øes of ≈øociety has produced a dreadful convul≈øion:≈øocial order has been ≈øubverted, and the ≈øtability of property annihilated: all rea≈øoning from the hi≈øtory of former times is found inapplicable to the pre≈øent: the ≈øy≈øtem of warfare it≈øelf has undergone a revolution; and no man is able to ≈øay from po≈øitive inference, "Thus will it be to morrow." Our in≈øular ≈øituation, thank GOD! protects us: and the precarious footing upon which civil order and property ≈øtand in mo≈øt countries on the continent,
make our ≈øtate in England enviable. The time is neverthele≈øs pregnant with extraordinary event; and you are now approaching that age at which men ≈øhould be ready to act at the call of their country. It is therefore fitting for you to make ≈øuch things the ≈øubject of frequent contemplation‚Äîto habituate your mind to the meeting of danger, ≈øo as to be ready, at a moment's warning, to lay down your life, if nece≈ø≈øary, for the good of your country; for, after all, my FREDERICK, what avails it whether we die in this way or in that?‚Äîto die with honour and a good con≈øcience, is all. Let prejudice be laid a≈øide‚Äîand who, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of common ≈øen≈øe, could he≈øitate a moment to prefer death in the field, to death with the loath≈øome aggravation of ≈øickne≈øs, the crocodile tears of pretended friends, and the painful emotions and lamentations of tho≈øe who really love us?

Finally, I mu≈øt ob≈øerve, that at the time I left India, the affairs of the Briti≈øh Nation wore ≈øo very lowering an a≈øpect, all per≈øons acquainted with our concerns there, allowed nothing but a long ≈øeries of wi≈øe mea≈øures, with the be≈øt efficient ≈øervants to execute them, could re ‚Ä¢ cue the company from ruin. I am happy in being able now to ≈øtate, without the po≈ø≈øibility of contradiction, that the clouds which menaced us in that quarter have ≈øince been gradually di≈ø≈øipating beneath the mea≈øures of the BOARD of CONTROUL, under the direction of Mr. DUNDAS; and are at la≈øt entirely di≈øper≈øed by the glorious admini≈øtration of Lord CORNWALLIS, who≈øe wi≈ødom in the cabinet tended no le≈øs to the ≈øecurity, than his military talents, ju≈øtice and moderation, to the honour, of GREAT BRITAIN in the Ea≈øt. The choice of ≈øuch a per≈øon for the government of India, reflects credit on HIS MAJESTY'S Councils, and evinces that the paternal care and ≈øolicitude of our amiable SOVEREIGN extend to the mo≈øt remote part of the Empire.

div.head: APPENDIX. LETTER FROM GENERAL MATHEWS, TO THE COURT OF DIRECTORS OF THE EAST INDIA COMPANY. (REFERRED TO IN THE FOREGOING LETTERS.)
div.p:
I HAVE the honour of informing you of the ≈øucce≈øs of your arms on the Malabar coa≈øt. You will have received advices of the out≈øet of the expedition from Bombay, and the general purport of it. On the 12th of December, I ≈øailed with a ≈ømall party; and thought proper, of my own accord, to land at Rajamundroog, in preference to any other place‚Äîbecau≈øe, on this part of the coa≈øt. I had the double advantage of being able to ≈øecure my≈øelf until reinforced, and to procure provi≈øions, which I could not have done at Cundapore, or any place to the ≈øouthward, by rea≈øon of the numerous garri≈øons, and the vicinity of them to the capital. The mea≈øures and di≈øpo≈øitions of the gentlemen at Bombay were ≈øuch, that I could not place any dependence upon being timely reinforced from thence, or of having any ≈øupply of provi≈øions. Rajamundroog is on the top of a
high hill, and commands the entrance of the be≈øt river on the coa≈øt. We took it by ≈øtorm. The moment we landed, a ≈øhort time was taken up in preparing to move towards Onore; for we had not a cooly, carriage, or bullock, to convey any ≈øtores. The battering cannon, ammunition, provi≈øions, &c. were ≈øent by ≈øea; and the great additions that HYDER had made to the fortifications of Onore and fortified I≈øland, prevented my entering the river with the ≈ømall craft, and obliged me to land every thing through a heavy ≈øurf on the beach, and then to cro≈øs the river to the northward of the fort. The≈øe impediments were got over; and a practicable breach being effected, the a≈ø≈øault was made‚Äî and the garri≈øon, con≈øi≈øting of two thou≈øand five hundred men, were either killed, drowned, or made pri≈øoners.‚ÄîShortly after this event, the troops from the ≈øouthward, under Lieutenant Colonel MACLEOD, were landed at Rajamundroog. To wait for a junction, would take up much time: ≈øo, that not a moment ≈øhould be lo≈øt, I embarked, and landed near Cundapore, under the fire of the Bombay Grab and the Intrepid, and immediately ≈øeized a ≈ømall fort that ≈øerved to ≈øecure our ≈øtores. The enemy were in ≈øight, and ≈øeemed numerous: ≈øome pri≈øoners that we took, reckoned them at twelve hundred hor≈øe, one thou≈øand Sepoys, and five hundred Peons.
